title: Alcatraz, San Francisco
address: Bay Street and Embarcadero, Pier 33 Alcatraz Landing, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
Well worth a visit and take the audio tour option. The audio tour takes you round the prison part of the island and provides lots of information...excellent value

Alcatraz is an historical place and visiting it is an experience I would recommend to anybody. The tour starts on a ferry boat, then you are free to wander through the island gardens and the cellar buildings. There is an audio guide in all languages

Impressive to be there, after having seen movies and documentaries. Boat trip offers many photo opportunities and the guides are friendly and professional. Even with a toddler, The Rock is a nice visit. We took the first one in the morning.

This is an event that should be on your list. Filled with history, it is worth the cost of entry. I hear that an evening tour is very eery! It's a "must see" for San Francisco!

The ferry ride was superb. San Francisco Bay is gorgeous. The tour of Alcatraz was the most overrated tourist trap I have been to in a long time. Once you get off the ferry you are covered in flies. The tour of the prison is just that...it is an old prison. I did not enjoy it and I would not...


More  



It's amazing pass trough all the places that I knew from movies. The view it's great and the crew it's very nice!!

This was the one place my husband wanted to see while in San Francisco. The tour includes headsets that tell you the stories of the inmates and the history. They have it set up so you can truly imagine what it was like. Would do this again.

While we were in a hurry we thought we would take a tour of Alcatraz since we was in the area.
It is definitely worth seeing if you have any interest at all.

The super organised approach made me feel a bit like a regimented prisoner as our time to board approached. But better too much organisation than not enough. The boat trip across allowed many scenic shots of San Fran and the experience at Alcatraz was better than I expected. It really is an awesome prison with many stories to tell. I...


More  



It was a cold windy day but we enjoyed ourselves nonetheless. There was plenty of information around and we were lucky enough to have an ex-guest of Alcatraz visiting that day signing books. A fascinating insight to America's past.

title: Golden Gate Bridge, San Francisco
address: Lincoln Boulevard, near Doyle Drive and Fort Point, San Francisco, CA 94129
review_list:
Make sure to visit the Golden Gate Bridge on a SUNNY DAY! The pictures you will take will be so much more beautiful and not to mention the weather will be nicer and warmer. Definitely worth seeing and taking some photos.

Golden Gate Bridge is something that anyone visiting San Francisco should see. It is pretty spectacular in its simplicity.

When I am in San Francisco I love to take a walk across the Golden Gate bridge. See the city from the bay. The boats as they sail underneath the bridge. It is a great way to kill a little time and marvel at this amazing structure.
There are always people on the bridge. Walking or riding bicycles back and...


More  



Of old Army fortifications , with the city in the background for Amazing Photo Views, make sure to walk across, when u look at GGB look to the left on Marin side and you will see road with a few cars and army forts for hiking, I used to find rivets from under the bridge on SF side if u...


More  



We always make the trip to the bridge. If you are heading north there is a park right at the end of the bridge. There is plenty of parking, bathrooms and incredible views of the bay, Alcatraz and the bridge.
Be advise there is a toll to pay on your way back to SF. You will get a bill in...


More  



Beautiful, historical, amazing, architectural mankind achievement, with stunning views of the bay, city of SF and beyond

Truly great experience riding over the Golden Gate bridge. Hired a bike from the wharf area and cycled over to Sausilito where you can have a beautiful lunch by the waterfront before cycling back. Highly recommend this way to see the bridge and take in the views.

What an amazing feat of engineering, style, and art. Catch it from the Berkeley side for a broadside view. Or view from the southern shore on a sunny day

What a thrill, it's a great bridge and the view of the Pacific is awesome, so you should totally go.

Took a boat/bus tour. It was very enjoyable.I would recommend this tour as we saw a lot of interesting places on the tour.

title: AT&T Park, San Francisco
address: 24 Willie Mays Plaza, San Francisco, CA 94103
review_list:
It's great, just 6 blocks from my house but it's hard to find people who are interested in going. I like it but not in the bleachers

Best ballpark this is the home of my team SF Giants not a bad seat in the house great views lots of delicious foods to try easy to get to by public transportation. Get there early for the giveaways

Went here for a concert. I was on the field. I love whatever surface they put down as it didn't make my ankles or feet hurt. The sound was amazing. I walked around the field and got good sound everywhere. I had a bummer of a time finding the bathrooms. They were a walk from the field to either the...


More  



If you like to visit ballparks , you will enjoy this park. We went on a Sunday morning and parked across the street and it was free. This is something you will want to see

Went to AT&T park for the first time to see Metallica the night before the super bowl 2016.
Had a blast!!!!!

First, for ball games, try to get View Level seats behind home plate or close. Great view of the field! If the game is a boring one, you can watch the boats and ships in the Bay and take in the wondrous view! For real baseball fans, go to McCovey Cove to see the wall with every SF Giants team...


More  



This was a wonderful experience, my first time to the new ball park. I really enjoyed the way it was built. It actually close to my house and we took the T train which stops right in front of AT&T park. I highly recommend visiting the park and enjoying a great baseball game.

Amazing place. View Reserved sections 304-307 have my favorite view in the entire city. Plus the Giants are awesome and so is the organization. I actually biked around the part today for exercise.

Nice facility! Really enjoyed our visit for the Metallica concert. Nice and clean before the concert anyway. Good times!

So we were here for the night before the super bowl concert and while Metallica was great someone wasn't prepared for a full stadium even though they knew it was sold out. Took too long to get through security and the people working the concession stands had no hustle, they did not care if you got served. Great concert but...


More

title: San Francisco Bay, San Francisco
review_list:
The bay is absolutely gorgeous. Take a ferry ride around the bay for beautiful views of the skyline of the city, the bay bridge, and Golden Gate bridge.

Frisco, the city on the bay. One of the highlights of our stay was crossing the Golden Gate bridge on foot, walking into Sausalito for lunch and then taking the ferry back to the Embarcadero. You get wonderful views as well as a sense of scale. Highly recommended on a sunny day and bring your camera.

What else can you say about this bridge ? its pretty awesome, try to take pictures from every possible spot :)

I have the whole California in my top top USA destinations by far. U have everything around it, and the San Francisco Bay is not the exception.
Lots of tourist attractions, great and amazing local and non local food. Lots of places to catch for every person taste.
Take at least a week to explore it, plan ur with time....


More  



I have been to San Francisco twice and what can i say that probably hasn't already been said a thousand times! The Bay is breathtakingly beautiful as are the views of the bridge and Alcatraz Island. There's something laid back about the city, almost as if the air gets to you or something i can't explain the feeling. As the...


More  



You have to see San Francisco, its a beautiful city. Being there several time and going back this year in May. In addition to SF you need to visit Napa Valley, drive a portion of the Pacific Highway to Big Sur and if possible visit Yosemite National Park .

Imagine seeing 4 iconic landmarks in one visual sweep: the Golden Gate Bridge, the Bay Bridge with its new strand of 25,000 LED lights, Alcatraz, and the San Francisco Bay. Breath-taking - you've arrived!

We booked a private tour of Monterey & Carmel through Viator. We made a mistake on the time and date of the tour, but called Viator and they changed the date and time of pick-up without any hassle at all. Viator has great 24/7 service and people. Our driver/guide Kenneth was waiting at the curb when at the appointed time...


More  



Saw most of the sights on a big red bus tour. It's the best way to travel round San Francisco due to the volume of traffic. Worth seeing though

I visited many years ago while on the back of a motorcycle. It was fun to say I was there and cross the bridge. There is a nearby park to stop and take some photographs with the bridge behind you, but that's about it. If you are into architectural photography you will enjoy it, otherwise, it's just a bridge :)...

title: Golden Gate Park, San Francisco
review_list:
We had a short ride in the park with no stops. It was so beautiful with many trees and plants and a wonderful forest scent. There are golf tracks and plenty of space

With all the hustle and bustle of the city. This is a breath of fresh air. It's so green and picturesque here. There are many activities to do from museums to gardens and bike rentals to restaurants. Def a must see.

We had a very nice walk trough the park, in the morning. Sunny and bright and we got to see the natural history museum. The park is huge so get ready for quite a walk...

This park is really big. I always find it difficult to find parking unless you arrive early. This place is popular with local and tourist alike. You can visit museums, conservatory of flowers, Japanese tea garden and many other attractions. You can just walk around or play freebie, take a prt for a walk or visit the arboretum. All attractions...


More  



Golden Gate Park is huge. It came as a relaxing stop after the hustle and bustle of going through trendy places of this beautiful city. We walked under the trees, by the lakes, watched some people swimming and boating. It was a surprise to see bison in the park!

An enormous park, where the landscape changes so much from an end to another.
We cycle it all and suggest anyone doing the same (bring your good legs, or an electric bike)

The park is very relaxing. Also, a place to see nature. You can swim there is a beach there, people were enjoying them self of all ages. However, I didn't not swim. Enjoyable.

It was nice to feel like we were getting out of the city. We didn't go in the conservatory, and we came close to (but didn't try) getting in a boat on the lake, but the walk through the trees, around the water, and then to the cafe was a lovely break en route to the golden gate bridge (we...


More  



Great place for anyone! If you have a family with young children, there are several playgrounds for them. For groups there is a Frisbee throwing activity area. Beautiful botanical garden, with spectacular types of flowers and plants from all over the planet. Yes there are more types of flower than roses and tulips :P There is the separate Japanese Tea...


More  



Ran thru GGP during the SF Marathon .. nice day nice view. I saw the video of marathon and the tour by running did not disappoint.

title: Lands End, San Francisco
address: Point Lobos Avenue and El Camino del Mar, San Francisco, CA 94121
review_list:
I generally bring out of town guest to other end of San Francisco to see the beach, specifically, the Pacific Ocean. Lunch at the Cliff House, then walk a short path to see views of the Golden Gate Bridge. Excellent National Park mini museum of the the history of the former Cliff House. Nice little cafe for coffee and snacks.

Iconic vistas. Sea life. Trees bent by wind. The pounding Pacific Ocean.
It's all here, and a walk will show you some of the natural beauty tucked away on the edge of San Francisco. Photo op heaven!
Enjoy!

Always have a good time when I go there. Great to get back to nature, well at lest in the city. Plenty of things to see and the hiking trail is as long as you want it to be. I hiked for a few hours till I realized that I went 4.8 miles. Then i thought, oh shet, I have...


More  



If you are outdoorsy at all (or just enjoy killer views) you need to visit this place. Such a gorgeous hike, with well-maintained trails and many opportunities for great photographs. If you pop out of the trails on the East side, you'll find yourself in a lovely residential neighborhood.

I love this place for hiking in San Fransisco..and near by with Cliff House Restaurant.
One best view to see Golden Gate Bridge from hike ....nice trail with a lot steps...I visited on Winter time (Christmas holiday) very cold...but worth for hike.
I recommend good hiking place ..come early so easy parking.
Next to Lands End..landmark Cliff House Restaurant..good place...


More  



This is a must do! The best views of San Francisco and the Golden Gate Bridge! A perfect 2 mile nature hike along the cliffs of the Bay.

Not the expected San Francisco here...a rugged natural park overlooking the Golden Gate Bay with beautiful trees taking you along a route turns and twists, is well maintained and well worth the visit. Good vistas of the Bridge, good vibe.

Despite it being a rainy day, we still enjoyed some time visiting the Lands End area. Lots of parkland, trails, and wonderful views of Seal Rocks, Sutra Baths, the Pacific Ocean and Golden Gate Bridge (if you wander along some of the trails). The Visitor Information Center was well equipped with maps to guide you along trails and also to...


More  



Took the bus from Hotel Vertigo - about 35 minutes. The spent a few hours walking the trails. Beautiful forest and magnificent views. .

The views are amazing here. Park at the Sutro Baths or across the street from the Land's End lookout. There are bathrooms there, they close at 5:30pm though. The sunset is gorgeous there too!

title: Twin Peaks, San Francisco
address: 501 Twin Peaks Blvd, San Francisco, CA 94114
review_list:
In my opinion this is the best overall view of San Francisco! Definitely stop by here if you are visiting. I would recommend going on a clear day to get the most of the sights, it is still great if it is a little gloomy out though.

We went to Twin Peaks at Night. It had great views of the city and it was fun to see it at night with all the city lights. Worth the drive.

From this place you can see the whole city of San Francisco looking down into the bowl....To actually see what San Fran looks like this is a must see

I went by car (yout could walk or bike, but it's a bit long if you are not a sportman). Nice views of the city.
Don't go if climate are cloudy, it's a waste of time. But on a clean day, you can see the city from top, the brige, all the bay, the ocean.
Plan to go on sunset.

Did this on our first night. Bit of a nightmare getting there bus hopping. Once youre there you get amazing panoramic views. We could just about see the Golden Gate but it was quite cloudy at the time. Definitely worth doing and if you want an adventure try walking back down...just dont get lost

Driven up here for views with dates and locals but best time is when its covered in folks positioning for a solar eclipse! Good long walk up the hill.

Went here on basis of a good rating for attractions and it was a great little excursion to do. Is a whole new perspective seeing San Fransisco from above and we enjoyed the drive up. Worth a visit if you have a car but if you have to choose between this and the view from the fort on the other...


More  



We wanted a view over the city, so decided to stop here on our way out of the city. Even with directions from our hotel, it was a bit tricky to find, as it is quite poorly signposted. Some good views from the top, but these are probably better of a night.

You can have a great view of the city from the top, and that´s about it. There´s not much to do there.

The entire city (and then some) laid out for you to contemplate.
Get up there early to beat the caravan of tour buses and get a parking space. If you're hearty, you can make your way up on foot, too. It's usually very windy at the top, and sometimes the view is completely obscured by fog. Timing is key. If...


More

title: The Exploratorium, San Francisco
address: Pier 15, on the Embarcadero, San Francisco, CA 94111
review_list:
This place proves how science can be so much fun. This place is absolutely for everyone. It's for curious kinds and of course explorers. There are too many interactive things that eventually you end up being short of time so make sure you reach when it opens because it's not gonna be easy to cover it all.

My dad and I like to have "boys days out". One day we went here. It was very interesting to drink out of a toilet drinking fountain, test your skills against technology, and try out cool experiments. Dont expect to be alone though. If you do go be sure to be there during school hours on a week day. Otherwise...


More  



Give yourself enough time. It is a fun hands on place for inquisitive kids. Many things to do and lots to learn.

Had a great time wandering around the Exploratorium.
it's basically filled with hundreds of sciency things to play with, to tinker with, to learn with. Everything from electricity, magnetism, light, water, insects, fish, sound etc...
Everything is very well maintained and explained and it reminded me of some great days as a child learning about all these kinds of things....


More  



Very good option for kids. Also for teens and adults, but you will enjoy more the nerdest your are ;)
We use about 4hs, and still want more. Full of hands-on activities, science experiments, and cools thinks to obaserver an d to do.

Being in the STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) line of work, I can't help but be amazed at the level of detail and science that was put behind the highly interactive exhibits... Mainly geared for kids, but it was still fun for (the always learning) adults! Great to see physical/mathematical concepts "watered-down" to make it easy and enjoyable for...


More  



This place is amazing! SO much cooler than I expected. I'm from Southern California, where we have a place called Discovery Cube, which is what I was expecting this to be. However, this place is SO much better. Discovery Cube is really geared towards children enjoying science, and while this place does wind up filling with children in the afternoon...


More  



Be it rain or shine, it's a must do ! Whether you have kids or you are young at heart, the new Exploratorium is worth the money.
It is so easy to get to by Muni or just walking along the waterfront. Great restaurants along the way.

We weren't traveling with our kids, but we decided to check out the Exploratorium based on other Trip Advisor reviews. Science, science, and more science and all hands on. We probably spent a good 2 hours there and didn't make it through all the exhibits. The exhibits are very well maintained and very interesting for all ages. I am so...


More  



Depending on your age or your child's age, it can be a fun place and/or a learning place. It has many, many stations illustrating the various principles of science. I wish I had this when I was learning physical and biological sciences. To describe the various display stations and programs will take pages. The best thing is to be there...


More

title: Palace of Fine Arts, San Francisco
review_list:
Adorable place of tranquility, class and photo ops. Not too many people come here (which allows place to stay with a taste of local atmosphere).

Originally built for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition as an art exhibition, the Palace of Fine Arts, located in the Marina District of San Francisco, is one of a only few surviving structures from the Exposition. The park that consists of the structure itself and a small artificial lagoon (around which the structure was built) is a serene place to go...


More  



this place is nice however there wasn't much to do once there. The area is nice and it is also very close to the Golden Gate bridge.

This is the most impressive building in San Francisco, the architecture particularly of the dome with statues outside is wonderful.

I love this place and it's always a top stop on my trip to SF, The architecture is beautiful and the park peaceful as long as it's not too busy. great spot for a romantic picnic or just hang out.

The palace is nestled in a very low key residential area so it's very easy to miss. It is however one of those pieces of architecture you never forget. It's especially nice at night, and if the weather is good it's a great little city breaks

When we got married, Hubby and I and our Videographer/Photographer crew went here for a photoshoot.. It was adorable, quiet, very magical ambience.. Seems like you're in Rome Italy..

Great scale and inviting architecture welcome visitors to this lovely spot...can get up close and personal with ducks and swans, understand a bit of the city's history and enjoy walking around a lovely setting.

Bring your camera. This is an awesome photo spot with beautiful architecture. It's a little far from Pier 39 or Union Square so take a tour to the area.

We saw this on a bus tour and then ended up seeing a live show on the stage there - great place. Don't miss it!

title: Cable Cars, San Francisco
review_list:
started operating in the 19th century to move people up and down many of San Francisco's steepest hills, Modernists tried to kill them, but the people won out, and the little cable cars still climb halfway to the stars.

At a $7.00 a ticket one way this is not a cheap way to see the city. So why go, well it is fun ,it is a great way to see the city. It is a blast to hear the bell. It IS sanfransico and this is why your there.

No visit to San Francisco is complete without taking the cable car to get across the hill to Fisherman's Wharf. The only downside is the waiting time. And the cars don't go that often.

Loved sharing the cable car rides with friends while San Fran was busy hosting the 2016 Super Bowl. Drivers were very nice & knew what they were doing, as well as info when we asked directions.

Took my kids for a trip along Californian to a park had a great trip they were very obliging letting the kids hold the brake and teaching them some engineering and history on the ride. Just awesome!! 5🌟

Kids under 5 are free so that is a plus, nice way to travel, but more for tourists than local i would think because of the price.

I was in town for a few days so I purchased a 3-day pass, which not only was financially advantageous but made it easier to use the cable cars without looking for more tickets.
The cars don't let you hop on at any point like they used to, you must find a stop. I did not try hopping off between...


More  



We bought a day pass and went to Chinatown, Union Square, and just riding them up and down the hills was great.

Oh my, I have never had a concession person yell at my out of town guests before. They spoiled the evening and put a bad impression on San Francisco. Why doesn't Muni train their cable car operators?? The whole ride was like a holding cell where everyone on board had to be ordered here and there and refrain from speaking...


More  



Whilst we know that this is effectively public transport, no-one but tourists were using this. We just felt that for something this iconic, we might had had a bit of commentary or some kind of information about it whilst we were onboard. Yes there is a museum, but whilst you're on the cable cars I wanted to know more about...


More

title: Walt Disney Family Museum, San Francisco
address: 104 Montgomery St, The Presidio, San Francisco, CA 94129
review_list:
Kinda temple for Walt Disney fans. I wasn't expecting it to be this thorough and emotional journey. I was literally seeing WD in the first person when I was walking through the corridors of this museum and I could feel every bit of his ups and downs. Must visit for every entrepreneur, dreamer and animation fans.

It's really for the adults. I don't understand how such a museum in the presidio meant for education can charge so much and not have any free days for those families in the city who might not be able to afford the ticket price of $20. Presidio's quickly becoming an attraction mainly for the deep pocketed with only the lawn...


More  



This seems like the contents of your great aunt's attic spread around a museum. Bits and pieces of memorabilia, none of which tell a particularly compelling or interesting story. Disney fanatics will be interested...anyone else will wonder why they are there.

Well thought out, detailed, and informative Museum in a beautiful location. Must see for any Disney enthusiast. Clean restrooms and snack bar a plus

As a non Californian, I find some of these attractions a bit spendy. $20 for adults, $15 for seniors. However, if you have proof of any military service with you, the soldier and spouse are free. There is a lobby with all the awards, including the famous Snow White Oscar. A walking tour over 2 floors shows Mortimer Mouse and...


More  



very detailed, lots of info more then I could absorb, but very interesting.Very beautiful grounds,neat old buildings.

I find it weird that this museum is housed in San Francisco, and its location within San Francisco to be even weirder (albeit beautiful)... But, once you find the place, it is truly a spectacular world class museum. The Disney Family spared no expense highlighting the legendary man that was Walt Disney. Surprisingly it wasn't just the positive points in...


More  



My husband and I were impressed with the museum and found it very interesting. My 12 & 15 yr old Disney fans weren't as interested as I had thought they would be.

The museum is sort of like completing the triple crown in the states, WDFM, DL and WDW...lol The have a little snack and souvenir shop. Saddest part of the whole tour is at the end when you see all the art work of when Walt passed away, Again, if you're a try Disney fan, you'll have a lump in your...


More  



The entrance visit fee was fine, but I was expecting more from the money we spent.. I hope that Norcal will have our very own version of Disneyland here and not just a museum that sells over-priced goodies..

title: California Academy of Sciences, San Francisco
address: 55 Music Concourse Drive, Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, CA 94118
review_list:
Do not think it will be just a 30min visit... The place is super cool with a lot of nice exhibitions so be ready to spend there some time. Some quality time!

This is a large room with a few things to look at. Too expensive compared to other nice museums, always busy. Try the conservatory of flowers and Japanese garden instead. Try twi for the price of one instead.

This is a big place with a lot of terrain to take in as a visitor. Accessible, but very crowded and not a lot going on for the grown ups. Great stuff for the wee ones though. We were already exhausted from walking to the CAS, so we did appreciate the seating with its good viewing, but it was lots...


More  



The best science museum in the country with some truly cool exhibits and an awesome planetarium. Perfect for when the weather is a little less than great, as it takes place almost entirely indoors.

Having visited the old Cal Academy as a child, it was wonderful to visit it's modern reincarnation. The quality of exhibits, the access to everything as part of the admission, the incredible aquariums... just fantastic.

Did this as part of the CityPass. I really loved the CAoS, I would say more than even going to Alcatraz. We spent 3-4hrs here and don't think we saw everything. There was so many beautiful exhibits and interactive displays. I was worried that it would be crowed after reading the reviews but we felt it was quite quiet. The...


More  



I visited this with my three boys aged 9, 7 and 5. There was plenty to do and we all enjoyed ourselves immensely for about three hours.
The aquarium and planetarium exhibits are definitely highlights. The albino alligator is actually worth the trip just to see. We didn't do the tour but we have been told it is very much...


More  



My fiance and I visited the academy of science while we were in SF last June and it was awesome! I have a degree in Biology, so science is one of my favorite topics. We saw many cool displays and interactive exhibits as well as animals from all over the world. The only negative for me was that some of...


More  



Fun time do much to see. Sadly when we went the rainforest was closed but the rest was really cool a full day trip.

California Academy of Sciences is the largest natural history Museum in the world. It is a home to more than 26 million specimens. Situated in the Golden Gate Park, the place is well known for its aquarium and rainforest exhibit. The Museum is a wonderful place for both tourists and those interested in knowing about the various species exhibited there.

title: Legion of Honor, San Francisco
address: 34th Avenue & Clement Street, Lincoln Park, San Francisco, CA 94121
review_list:
So I am from the area, and have lived here for about 2 years, and usually went to the Deyoung. I had heard of the "Legion of Honor; but dismissed it. Then I was looking for somewhere to go with my 3 year old on a day off from work. Children's museum was too far away. So I came here....


More  



Away from the "touristy" parts of San Francisco, the Legion of Honor sits on the top of a hill in parkland with views back into the city and the Golden Gate Bridge. The galley spaces contain a high quality collection of European art up to the impressionist period. This is really a different side to SF that I strongly encourage...


More  



The Legion of Honor has the most amazing restrooms. I recommend room 19. The art us exquisite. The periodic benches are greatly appreciated.

The Legion of Honor and surrounding area is one of my favorite places to go in San Francisco. I was up at the Legion the other weekend and was reminded of how much I love this place. The facility itself is relatively small, and as a semi-local, I usually only pop in to see the special exhibits which amounts to...


More  



Grande experience of opera singing in the marble rotunda of the Rodin room. The glorious sounds and wonderful works of art made for a truly memorable afternoon!

Many folks are not aware of this museum but its one of the best kept secrets of the SF. Its located on a pretty spot where the views are great. The museum does not get as crowded as De Young and you can see a lot in a relaxed way. We never found parking to be a problem. The same...


More  



It's a wonderful art exhibit and worth your time in the park to stop and see this. The Rodin's out side and the view of the city alone is worth the drive so take the time to see this wonderful place. I hope you have time along with all the other sights in the park with so much entertainment to...


More  



Despite what the name suggests, Legion of Honor is not a military museum. Instead, this is the museum of European arts as a part of the San Francisco fine arts museum system. As impressive as the Greco-Roman temple architecture, Legion of Honor's art collection is definitely worth checking out!
The museum architecture is a masterpiece of its own: a fine...


More  



This is my favorite San Francisco art museum. The rooms are beautiful and intimate and there is a good variety in the displays.

We visited at a time when Raphael's "Young Woman with a Unicorn" was being displayed. The information about the history of the painting (at one point the painting was overpainted!) was very informative and made the painting more interesting to me. The works of a few other Italian artists (Titian, Tintoretto, et al) were also present, and I enjoyed viewing...


More

title: Cable Car Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
Really interesting to see how the Cable Car system works.
A great free attraction that's worth stopping off at.

See how the famous cable cars work and see the actual machinery that keeps them going. Good souvenir shop .

We loved this museum. It was free to get into, and we learned so much about the cable cars and their history. You can take a cable car all the way there! I would highly recommend this to anyone interested in history or engineering.

We popped in as it was a very rainy day. The museum is free to visit, and tells the story of the cable cars in San Francisco. There is quite a lot to read, and you just guide yourself around the museum.

We have gone by this museum so many times and this was the first time we got off the cable car and checked it out. Very informative and interesting. Glad we stopped.

We were treated great by Levi one of the Machinists, and the place was technically closed!!! So above and beyond the call of duty. We love the cable cars and the history and where better? The nations only moving historical monument, and the museum which is free, is the best way to learn about it's amazing history.

The cable car museum is located near the cable car lines and is free to enter. There you can see the cables at work -- very cool!

Great free museum to check out the history of San Francisco as well as the cable car system.
This is not just a museum but also the working hub of the cable car system.
Take time to read the informative posters and exhibits

It is amazing to see the workings of the cable car system. Great information on the history and workings of the cable cars. This is a don't miss for anyone interested in engineering or mechanics. Highly recommend a visit.

We decided to head here on a Sunday morning and were pleasantly surprised to find it open earlier than their schedule indicated affording us a little more time to explore. As indicated by others, this is free and there is nobody around to greet you, but lots of displays to check out along with the actual working mechanisms of the...


More

The cable car museum is located near the cable car lines and is free to enter. There you can see the cables at work -- very cool!

Great free museum to check out the history of San Francisco as well as the cable car system.
This is not just a museum but also the working hub of the cable car system.
Take time to read the informative posters and exhibits

It is amazing to see the workings of the cable car system. Great information on the history and workings of the cable cars. This is a don't miss for anyone interested in engineering or mechanics. Highly recommend a visit.

We decided to head here on a Sunday morning and were pleasantly surprised to find it open earlier than their schedule indicated affording us a little more time to explore. As indicated by others, this is free and there is nobody around to greet you, but lots of displays to check out along with the actual working mechanisms of the...


More

title: Lombard Street, San Francisco
review_list:
An absolute "must do" when visiting San Francisco is to visit Lombard St "the crookedest street in the world". Definitely recommend walking down (not up!) this street just for the views alone.

Nothing fancy except the unique nature, and best of all, especially in SF, it's free. Take the cable car, hop off at the top and walk down. Beautiful flowers, great view looking east, and you can say you've been there. For a real experience, Stop at the Buena Vista, have an Irish coffee, then walk up the hill on Hyde...


More  



Just a pleasant windy street with history and flowers all woven into one very accessible location on Nob Hill. I recommend going up the street and then walking down Hyde st for the view. It will take you to the Hyde street harbor where there are lots of wharf shops and the chocolate factory nearby. Don't forget to check out...


More  



Fun to do at least once. My son surprised me on the way home from dinner out on our last night in SF and drove down Lombard. The traffic wasn't too bad at 10 PM on a weeknight.

Everybody needs to visit this. Photos just an't convey how really steep and twisty this street is. So interesting.

Even do is another of the "must" places to go in san francisco. When u get there is full of tourists and getting pictures is not that easy.
Also, is way better looking on other season than winter. U must like some flowers on your pictures.

Somehow we end up here with friends that insist we drive down and I have to admit I look forward to it. Buses and crowd the top and the bottom and you have to be careful of not hitting people with selfie sticks on the winding road down. Lol.

nothing to write home about, it was pretty homes on the street and we walked down it and then had to walk back up hill,

To drive the car down Lombard St was to tick off one of my bucket list Items. I know I should have more exciting things on my list, but I'm now down to 493 things left to do.Go to San Francisco - hire a car - drive down Lombard St. Tick!

Saw most of the sights on a big red bus tour. It's the best way to travel round San Francisco due to the volume of traffic. Worth seeing though

title: Musee Mecanique, San Francisco
address: Pier 45, Fishermen's Wharf, foot of Taylor Street, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
A great place to revisit childhood memories and to discover new things that I hadn't seen in my youth.
The guy who created this place clearly enjoys sharing his passion free of charge with others.
Well worth a visit.

Great place for kids to see and try some of the video games their parents and grandparents grew up with. The kids really enjoyed seeing and playing the old games.

Who knew this was here in Fisherman's Wharf. What a fun way to spend an afternoon. Playing with antique arcade games. Definitely worth spending a few minutes here and checking out these fun (and old) arcade games.

Take yourself back to a bygone age of laughs and funfairs. Get to see and participate in the machines. This museum is free but I urge you to make a donation to keep it going

This was a surprise to be sure - a warehouse packed to the gunnels with old game machines - some which were turn of the 20th century. Most of the machines were on and in working order which in itself was a pleasant surprise. Most could be played for 25 cents. You have to keep your eyes peeled as it...


More  



What am amazing array of old-fashioned amusement machines. f you are older than 30 you will recognise at least half of these machines. Definitely worth a visit.

I had seen a smaller version of this collection years ago at the cliff house, and it was ok, it has since moved down to the Pier area, which I'm not that crazy about, very touristy, but if you do find yourself down there, this museum is incredible. Mechanized attractions that must be 100 years old or more, and they...


More  



In all fairness, I had not read any reviews on this place before coming, so I was going off of my husband's description only, which was "an old school penny arcade!". Now while there are many many of these "old school penny arcade" type games, I was also surprised to find many of the 70's/80's type arcade games as well...


More  



Just happen to see this place and walked in and WOW!!!!! What a fun historical place this is. Games from ever era. The old penny arcade games were a real treat. It transported you back in time when these games were the Xbox of their time. IF your down in Fisherman's Wharf, please stop in for an hour and drop...


More  



We went here on our last night in San Francisco on our way to dinner. It is great fun looking at the old machines and we quite a bit of time playing the old pin ball machines and looking at all the different amusements. My daughter (15) enjoyed it immensely - much to her own surprise.

title: Pier 39, San Francisco
address: Beach Street & The Embarcadero, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
Boardwalk with shops and restaurants. Many tourists are visiting this place and it is worthwile to take a look here. Don't miss the sea lions at the end.

been here a few times and not as many seals as previously but it was a real delight to see a group of about 50. making lots of noise and putting on as real show for the tourists. Pier 39 is a great place ot spend time enjoying the food & atmosphere looking out over bay towards Alcatraz.

Great view of the bay from the end of Pier 39 and the Sea lions from the Western end.
The shops in the middle are a strange collection of bars and jewellery shops.

Pier 39 and The Embarcadero was a great place to walk around and have a good time. The NFL Experience was open with free admission and concerts. Family friendly atmosphere. Great restaurants and shops. The streets were closed in certain areas because of Super Bowl but nothing that was unbearable. Everyone was friendly and helpful toward us. Police presence was...


More  



Your choice of where too eat is over whelming so go down and walk around and find a place. Me I love eggs , toast and bacon. Simple nice and every one has a little twist that makes it different. Lots of shops with a real feel of the tourist, do not forget this is a great tourist city so...


More  



Busy while volunteering during 2016 Super Bowl, but a fun place to shop, eat and sight seeing while visiting San Francisco

Fun - look for the seals! Lots of shopping and restaurants to choose from; and you may even take in some street entertainment nearby.

Haven't been here for a long time and brought family visiting from Costa Rica and loved it. Has something for everyone...shopping, gifts, loads of restaurants (recommend Fog Harbor highly), sea lions, views of Alcatraz and Golden Gate Bridge ...the list goes on. Fantastic start to the day

Another MUST visit Place in San Francisco. U have to Walk by all the Pier. There are plenty of shops and restaurants. Try not to get in the Crab House, its just an expensive Tourist Trap, u can get the same but extremely better in fisherman's wharf street shops..

Visited on a very busy Saturday night before the Super Bowl and it was crowded with locals, young families, out of towners and cruise ship passengers. Lots of eateries, bars, gift shops, souvenir shops and game arcades. Bright and noisy. Not really our cup of tea. Enjoyed it but I think once is enough for us.

title: Crissy Field, San Francisco
review_list:
Mesmerizing views of the Golden Gate Bridge from below,
Great views of Alatraz Sausalito, Tiberon and Belvadere

We went here to celebrate a very big occasion and we decided to have a picnic gathering..naturally it was an open for public place, we were fine with that as we love crowd.. Few hours gone by it was smooth and quiet, until a pitbull of an asian owner attacked our dog for no reason at all. Our dog was...


More  



Took a few minutes to walk along the area, nice views, access to the beach and off course another angle of the golden gate bridge and Alcatraz

We returned to Crissy Field for another wonderful end of January walk. The sun was out. The views of San Francisco and of the Golden Gate Bridge stunning. There are picnic tables. Its a delightful area to return to and visit.

Lots of parking (paid) and tons of trails to walk, hike or bike. People watching, photo taking. Easy access to the Golden Gate and shoreline. Perfect place to see Alcatraz and other famous landmarks from a different perspective

I went to Crissy Field and the view of the bridge from there was beautiful. Would definitely recommend going to Crissy Field. Free parking, amazing views, and just a beautiful place to walk around in.

This is a fun park and beach area. The views are great, lots of parking. Lots of people walking dogs off leash. Wasn't a big deal to me as I love dogs and most will stay to themselves, some will come to you randomly or if you call them over. Just make sure that you watch out for the dog...


More  



It's always crowded. However, it's just a beautiful place to take a long walk or run (if that's your thing) with the rest of San Francisco. Need coffee or food? Stop by the Warming Hut.

Crissy field has something for everyone. Lots of walking area, beach for kids, lawn for kites, etc, Long bike trails for every level of skill.

We walked from our hotel on Fisherman's wharf to the golden gate bridge through Crissy Field and were blown away with the beautiful views. The walk is so great along comfy walkways and stunning beaches, ideal for taking our 7 month old son in his buggy. We didn't feel like we were in the city!

title: de Young Museum, San Francisco
address: 50 Hagiwara Tea Garden Dr, Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, CA 94118
review_list:
I can't say this museum's building is anything close to the previous building they had here. Returning after years away, I can't believe someone envisioned this as an improvement. There was more art on display before in a Florentine building with vistas of gardens and hallways leading to cloisters filled with different kinds of art. Today, it's a 1/4 of...


More  



I admit I am not the most attached to art in the world, but you will find some interesting pieces here.

The de young is one of the City's treasures. There is way too much to absorb, so we directed ourselves to the Willard Worden photo exhibition and surrounding exhibits for a couple of hours. We also liked very much the gift shop which has very unique items. A small lunch in the cafe and then a brief walk through the...


More  



This is a very interesting museum, with many items from around the world. Don't expect the standard American and European art exhibits in their galleries!

De young Fine Arts Museum is one of the oldest museums in San Francisco along with the Legion of Honour. Located in the Golden Gate Park, the museum showcases American art ranging from the 17thcentury to the present. The collection includes more than 27,000 art pieces from America, Africa and Oceania. The Museum is an exquisite place to be on...


More  



While there is a fee to get into the museum, it was well worth it to enjoy the one of a kind artwork. We also found the building itself well done with interesting nooks and crannies becoming part of the art as well. In addition to the museum, there is also an outdoor sculpture garden with some fun pieces and...


More  



This amazing museum complete with observation tower will turn even a non art lover into an art enthusiast. The setting and exhibit areas are stunningly beautiful!

I adore the De Young. I've been many times over the years. They always have great exhibits, and the permanent collection is filled with important art including lots from now famous California artists. I remember visiting when it was in an old building on Van Ness Avenue. Now it has a glorious new home in Golden Gate Park. You can...


More  



Herzog and DeMeuron copper-clad modernist building is aging beautifully. There are parts of the cladding that are turning verde-gris, which was the intention.
Flower lovers will enjoy the magnolia festival, which starts in early spring, there is a magnolia grove near the tower that is stunning when in bloom. Look for the dates of "Bouquets to Art", the yearly floral...


More  



The American art collection on the top floor is very good -- we have spent an hour or so there on several visits and always find new things. The Northern American native art collection on the first floor is also very good. The restaurant is one of our favorites for lunch, with outdoor seating.

title: Presidio of San Francisco, San Francisco
review_list:
The Presidio is a great place to spend an afternoon. The Walt Disney Museum and Lucas films are both inside the presidio. There is a shuttle bus that runs thru the area. The views of the bay are beautiful from this area.

Unfortunately it was a rainy day, so we just did the bridge and left, but there is a fort under the Golden Gate Bridge, the Disney Family Museum and lots of green trails that looked like they would be fun to explore further. Our glimpse via a bus gave us a taste for exploring it should we return to this...


More  



It was a rainy day when we went through there but thought it was v interesting and would like to return and see it again sometime.

The only really interesting thing about it was learning that the Disney museum is located here. I'm glad it was part of the bus tour and I didn't have to pay separately for it.

I missed this place on my last trip here, but this time I particularly wanted to visit a museum here, so I made it a point to come here this trip. This is a very quiet and unique place. I imagine that this is where all of the top brass stayed back in the WWII era.

This is a beautiful and peaceful area. It is huge overall. Get a map in advance if you are not familiar with the area and find the walking trails. Lots of various areas to explore on your adventure.

We were fortunate to be driven up to and around the Presidio by friends, who explained the precinct and its past and current history, which we found very interesting. Lovely parks up there too if you like a stroll.

Old military post. Beautiful scenery. Got to see George Lucas offices and Star Wars figures. Loved the yogi fountain. Need time to explore the whole area. Lots of walking paths.

I like going to this place. Very nice place a old mlitary post. When in San Francisco stop by and enjoy the scenery. Overy looks the bay.

I entered the Presidio from the Richmond district, walked along the Park trail then joined the Presidio Trail to walk on the bridge. Caught a bus back to the Richmond district. An amazing walk, I loved the serenity... lots to see along the way including the amazing and humbling Cemetery... I do feel as though I need to go back...


More

title: Fort Point National Historic Site, San Francisco
address: Long Ave & Marine Dr, Building 999, San Francisco, CA 94129
review_list:
Visited here as a teen, and was reminded of it in a bit of dialogue in The West Wing as a target due to its location under the bridge. It was just as interesting now. We missed the annual reenactment, but there were still folks in period uniform. The view from the top floor of the bay is amazing. Good...


More  



The NPS does wht they can to keep this historically accurate site available to the public and the views are spectular. Kids will love the history and the waterfront. To be there when a container or cruise chip enter the Bay, is a unique experience.

I am only giving this site a 3 rating because I didn't tour it properly. We rented bikes & got caught in a heavy downpour near Fort Point NHS so we ran inside to wait it out. As we waited, I wandered around & then we talked to a ranger. The ranger was very informative (& clearly passionate about the...


More  



A great place to learn some history of the Bay Area during civil war times. Also offers amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge from below!

We have visited Fort Point National Historic Site. It is an important fort (with cannons) that was used to protect the San Francisco Bay It was in use from Civil War Days to World War II.
It is right by the Golden Gate Bridge. On a clear day, this area is a good place to get a fabulous view and...


More  



The history and museum aspect of the fort point is pretty great and very interesting, but I admit we mostly visited to take pictures of the bridge. Its right underneath the bridge so we got some really great shots. Its not the classic high angle you see most often, but still a great place to shoot from. The history exhibits...


More  



We stumbled onto this place by seeing from above while walking on Golden Gate Bridge. A short walk down from the visitor's centre at the bridge to the Fort. It was quiet with few tourists, although quite windy on the upper levels. Interesting history of when the Fort was an active military hold. Lots of old cannons and guns to...


More  



I cant believe I haven't heard more about this place. You have a unique view of the bay under the Golden Gate Bridge. The masonry is incredible. The history is well told with the displays in the barracks. Worth a visit.

Besides the history aspect of the civil war era fort, it was awesome to make the trek to the fort. One of the best locations to get that Golden Gate Bridge photo.

Aside from its historical value. Ft Point is a photographer's paradise.I've spent hours here with and without a model climbing all over this fascinating structure. A great backdrop for portrait ans family photos and stunning views.

I am only giving this site a 3 rating because I didn't tour it properly. We rented bikes & got caught in a heavy downpour near Fort Point NHS so we ran inside to wait it out. As we waited, I wandered around & then we talked to a ranger. The ranger was very informative (& clearly passionate about the...


More  



A great place to learn some history of the Bay Area during civil war times. Also offers amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge from below!

We have visited Fort Point National Historic Site. It is an important fort (with cannons) that was used to protect the San Francisco Bay It was in use from Civil War Days to World War II.
It is right by the Golden Gate Bridge. On a clear day, this area is a good place to get a fabulous view and...


More  



The history and museum aspect of the fort point is pretty great and very interesting, but I admit we mostly visited to take pictures of the bridge. Its right underneath the bridge so we got some really great shots. Its not the classic high angle you see most often, but still a great place to shoot from. The history exhibits...


More  



We stumbled onto this place by seeing from above while walking on Golden Gate Bridge. A short walk down from the visitor's centre at the bridge to the Fort. It was quiet with few tourists, although quite windy on the upper levels. Interesting history of when the Fort was an active military hold. Lots of old cannons and guns to...


More  



I cant believe I haven't heard more about this place. You have a unique view of the bay under the Golden Gate Bridge. The masonry is incredible. The history is well told with the displays in the barracks. Worth a visit.

Besides the history aspect of the civil war era fort, it was awesome to make the trek to the fort. One of the best locations to get that Golden Gate Bridge photo.

Aside from its historical value. Ft Point is a photographer's paradise.I've spent hours here with and without a model climbing all over this fascinating structure. A great backdrop for portrait ans family photos and stunning views.

title: Baker Beach, San Francisco
address: 1504 Pershing Dr, Golden Gate National Recreation Area, San Francisco, CA 94129
review_list:
We stopped by this beach after visiting the Golden Gate Bridge and Muir Woods to have a bite to eat that we had packed. Not a place you would want to venture into the water (to cold anyway for me) as the wave pattern seemed a bit treacherous. But the waves were beautiful to watch. You can see the Golden...


More  



What a view !!! Beach with golden gate view. Loved it... I would completely revisit this place if ever i would go to Sfo.

Great spot for a view of the Golden Gate Bridge, however we didn't realise it was a nudist beach before going...and we quickly realised it was when we saw a few people having a stroll in their birthday suit! So if you plan on taking your kids, or just don't want naked people in your photos, its something you should...


More  



Want to relax looking at a gorgeous sunset with the magnificent view of the Golden Gate ? this is the place... just seat in the sand and enjoy...

All I knew about this beach was that I'd heard it was a nude beach. We did not encounter any nudists though, as you have to walk all the way to the far northern end of the beach for that, away from the main entrance and out of sight from most of the beach. So if that's something you want...


More  



If you want to enjoy a view with no city skyline, this is the perfect beach. You have the Golden Gate Bridge on the right side and the vast Pacific Ocean in front of you. Parking is not a problem as there are many spots available. Sunset views are perfect here.

After going to SF for decades, it was great visiting a "hidden beach" with a totally different view of the GG bridge. We had heard of it and have a large picture of it so it was exciting to finally go there.

This is a GREAT spot to see the bridge from the west looking east, and there's free parking, porta potties, and it seems dogs are allowed. A nice big beach, and a long walk is nice. But dress warmly - the wind can get intense and it's chilly!

Small beach in the Northwest of San Francisco. From here, you can enjoy an awesome view of the Golden Gate Bridge, and it is usually not as crowded as some other vista points.
There is an accessible and free parking lot right in front of the beach

Free Parking, easy to find, and amazing view, although from a different angle, of the Golden Gate Bridge

title: Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco
address: Jefferson Street, Between Hyde and Powell Streets, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
Fisherman's Wharf was a great place where people gather for food, shopping, and entertainment. I enjoyed the restaurants and the shopping.

Surely this once was a fine area to hang around as you can still feel in the amusement hall. But nowadays it is a dirty place and just not worth visiting. There are many more nicer places to visit in San Francisco. The parking fees are ridiculous.

Fisherman's Wharf is a nice walk around. Spend there some time, look around the shops, grab a bite. It will be a nice way to spend a sunny afternoon in San Francisco.

Some great things to see, such as the Sea Lions and Musee Mechanique.
Some tacky things too, such as the many T shirt shops
Some disappointing things, particularly the rubbish strewn everywhere. Please SF authority, get the rubbish collected and clean the streets.

There's a little bit of everything here. I particularly loved the aquarium and the Musee Mechanique which had hundreds of old old games and amusements that still run on quarters. To cater to your sweet tooth, head to Ghiradelli for an ice cream cone or chocolate bar.

This is the kind of place you only need to visit once. Disappointed, I was expecting more. I found it to be just a dirty typical touristy spot, nothing special. The highlight for me was seeing all the Seals, loud, smelly and fun to watch and listen to them. You can also see Alcatraz on the island. Another cool spot...


More  



Another San Francisco "must do" good way to spend an afternoon and grab a corn chowder! Walking distance from the Alcatraz ferry pier.

There are a lot of Good restaurants & shopping. We didn't find it to have a lot of entertainment but we were there on a Tuesday night. I'm sure it's packed with fun over the weekend & holidays.

This is a very ecletic area from the street performers to the restaurants to all the diverse shops and vendersit is another must see in San Francisco

If you love seafood this is the place to be, although you can find it everywhere in San Francisco...

title: Grace Cathedral, San Francisco
review_list:
One of the sites to see while in San Francisco. Beautiful architecture and try to attend their Choral Evensong. My wife's favorite stop while visiting.

This is more of our problem than Grace Cathedral's problem, we had been wanting to visit for some time, as we have visited the Vatican, St. Paul's and Westminster Abbey in London Notre Dame in Paris. Where the problem arises (for us) is there is no history whatsoever for Grace cathedral, so after a few minutes of looking at the...


More  



It was a beautiful place to visit! The stained glass was gorgeous! I wish we could have stayed for a service!

We were very lucky: when we visited the cathedral someone was playing the organ. It made our visit really special. I loved walking the labyrinth.

The Grace Cathedral sits in the Nob Hill neighborhood & provides a place to rest when you trudge up & down the steep hill between Union Square & Fisherman's Wharf. You can rest on the steps or pay a suggested donation of $10 to check out the sanctuary. The stained glass is beautiful & the services at this church must...


More  



I had the chance to visit the Cathedral during a Mass, they were playing music with strings, and even a grand piano. The place is incredibly beautiful, I honestly felt as if I was in a Mass in Paris.

This is a beautiful and peaceful church. It has a ton of locals and visitors stopping by to see it and sit for a bit in peace. Located in Nob Hill area of the city. One of the prettiest churches in San Francisco.

Amazing cathedral a but asking $10 as an entry fee is pushing the friendship. The fee is optional as is the amount so be your own judge.

My Friend and I enjoyed a wonderful tour of Grace Cathedral which was conducted by a very knowledgeable tour guide. We enjoyed learning about the background of the church as well as the people involved in created the beautiful stained glassed windows and art work. The tour group was small and friendly and we learnt a lot during the tour....


More  



Interesting features and beautiful stained glass windows. Welcomed respite from busy day of touring.

title: Angel Island State Park, San Francisco
review_list:
Excellent Tour Guide, a little crazy, but it helps... tour around the island was a kick, serious knowledge by the guide. Wish there was more. Boat come and go on a very broad schedule leaving you wanting more to do than wait to be picked up

We visited in January 2016 and got off the only ferry of the day with maybe 6 other people. Needless to say, we had the trails pretty much to ourselves. We went all the way to the top of Mt. Livermore (788 ft). The hike itself is pretty gradual, but there are some pretty steep dropoffs so if you are...


More  



The "Ellis Island" of the San Francisco Bay, Angel Island has an important history (and one not always pleasant) for those whose families immigrated to CA from the Far East. Now it is a public park, and a great place for family picnics, etc.

Taking off on the ferry from the charming Tiburon to Angel Island is a breeze. There are several hikes you can do with old and young alike. Pack a light lunch and enjoy it on the top with pano views.

I lived in the Bay Area for 15 years before venturing to Angel Island. I wish I had found it sooner because it was such a fun getaway! It feels like you've been marooned on a lush, abandoned island. There are ruins to explore and plenty of room to hike or bike. There are educational programs. There is even overnight...


More  



Pack a picnic lunch, and wear comfortable shoes. Gorgeous views, and a terrific hike. Great for the whole family. Lots to see see.

You can only get here by ferry (unless you have your own private boat), mostly from Tiburon. But it's easy to spend a whole day on Angel Island. You can climb to the peak, Mt. Livermore, with its spectacular 360 degree view of the Bay from 1,000 feet up, or you can circumnavigate the island and see an ever-changing panorama...


More  



Went on an office outing to this state park. Very good place to go out for hiking, biking and get a grand view of the SF downtown.
Note that you have to take a ferry to go to this park, which itself is fun :)

This was a beautiful place to drive through in a limo definitely a beautiful place to get out and take pictures .

The tour was filled with history, tour guides were engaging and a wealth of stories, free time to explore cafe to enjoy a coffee to soak in the stunning views

title: Dylan's Tours, San Francisco
review_list:
The best tour experience we could have ever hoped for.
Brits first time in SF!
Andreas was the perfect guide.
Informative and engaging.
Thanks for a beautiful experience!

lots of information, the highlights and lowlights of a fascinating city, a great way to orientate if you have a few days to explore more afterwards.

We had such a great time with Alejandro today, as we toured the city for 6 hours. He was full of knowledge, good humor as we biked around San Francisco. Up hills were a breeze thanks to the electric motors..highly recommend.

So glad I chose Dylan's tour. It was well worth the money. We had PEAR as ou guide and he was very informative and personable. We could have never done all the sites on our own. The van was very comfortable and we had a great group of people to share our tour. Would highly recommend Dylan's for your tour...


More  



Leila was our guide and we had a great time and she was fantastic!! I highly recommend this tour. She was great at giving local info and history of SF.

Dylan's Famous Tour (6 hours) is surely one of the most interesting, small group guided tours available in SFO. It takes you to several of the top sites in the city, crosses the Golden Gate Bridge to charming Sausalito and ends with a ramble through the magnificent Muir Woods redwood forest. Our guide/driver Leila was outstanding - her courtesy and...


More  



My 19 year old daughter and I did this tour in Jan 2016. I'm convinced it is the absolute best way to see the SF plus Sausalito & Muer woods!
Warning. This tour is all day so well worth its price tag!
Convenient Pickup & drop off. As the tour guide takes you to ALL of the hotspots in SF,...


More  



Layla was totally filled with facts about the city and was willing to make sure we see the best of what the city has to offer. There was something to see or hear the entire tour.
A+ ----- Just a great tour!

My partner and I hired two electric bikes and spent an awesome day touring the city on our own. Went over the bridge and followed the map that were given. Much easier than expected! Staff were very helpful getting us kitted up too.

My wife and I traveled to San Francisco to celebrate our 30th wedding anniversary and spent three days there. We wanted to see lots of sights without it being overwhelming and read the rave reviews about Dylan Tours. We were not to be disappointed! Our tour guide, Bob, a city native, did a fabulous job of guiding us around in...

title: Streets of San Francisco Bike Tours, San Francisco
review_list:
had great time in meeting new people and exploring the city in a active and fun way. Our guide Earl was very friendly, cheerful and made this a fantastic experience. If you have few days to spend in SF and want to visit and learn about how locals live, I highly recommend to take the Classic tour.

Very nice people, our guide Josh mixed views and stories with a perfect cycling experience. Really good experience, plenty of tipps for food and nightlife. I definitely go back there next time I'm in SF.

Josh was our guide for the day - Heart of the City Tour. The trip was the right mix of history, culture with local knowledge thrown in. Even though the city is known for its hills Josh managed to detour most of them. It is a great way to spend a day in San Francisco.

We had the best time on our Streets of San Francisco bike tour. Was a great introduction to a city with so much history, culture and art. Our tour guide took us to all the local hang outs and gave us great recommendations for other activities and places to go. Highly recommend this tour to anyone visiting San Fran.
We...


More  



We really enjoyed this bike tour. It was great way to see some of the non-tourist spots of the city and gave us a new appreciation for the uniqueness of San Fran. We'd recommend this to anyone. You don't have to be a good biker to keep up. Josh was a great guide with a lot of info to share...


More

review_list:
Anton is passionate and wants to share a city he loves. It shows. I had an enjoyable day being introduced to various interesting spots which I would not have found on my own. It's always nice to have a local guiding you. And the food recommendations alone would have been worth the price tag 👍😉

Anton offers a unique opportunity to experience the culture and vibe of this city. I did trek 4 on Saturday morning of SuperBowl 50, and experienced a very personalized walking tour as part of a small group. It is a set of different pâtes to walk and explore. Some Hills are demanding in terms of efforts. Have really good shoes We were there and it was chilly with winds.
The Trek is Interesting and allow to identify places to go back and visit.

The tour was amazing, Anton's knowledge of the city is second to none. It was insightful and full of gems u probably don't here from the bigger tour providers. title: Wild SF Walking Tours, San Francisco
review_list:
I am in awe of all the information imparted by energetic and enthusiastic and delightful guides.
I thought I knew the Mission District. They took it to another level.
Fully recommend making a San Francisco visit complete by partaking in at least one of the waking tours offered by this company.
Thanks and Aloha!
Jill

I did two Wild SF walking tours when during my visit to San Francisco last month. Both were very interesting and I learned a lot! I did the Night Tour and the Chinatown tour. We had Wild Wes as a tour guide. Wild Wes was very knowledgeable about the city, its history and was happy to share information on highlights...


More  



My wife and I travel several times a year to different places it's been our best experience to have a guided tour then go exploring on our own.

Fun walking tour around Union Square and Chinatown with knowledgeable and quirky tour guide Fischer. We particularly liked the erhu shows and the alleys of Chinatown.

Absolutely awesome night walking tour of some of San Fransisco's darker past. In just over an hour and a few city blocks you'll learn and visit where some famous and not so famous names in history met their untimely end. Wes has an fantastic storytelling technique to make it all throughly entertaining and make the time fly by!

We took the Haight-Ashbury tour since we were interested in the musical background of the city. We wanted to learn a lot about the hippie times and what was going on in that time in that specific place. Our Tourguide Ozy was a great help in order to get to know this part of town with a delightful mixture of...


More  



This tour is very reasonably priced and that is just the beginning. Wes and Ben are fantastic story tellers and clearly have a great knowledge of the city and it's history. They engaged each person in the group and got to know them as well as talking with the whole group. It felt very personal and fun. We look forward...


More  



I really enjoyed the tour I took of the Castro, and learning about the history of the area. My guide, DW, was excellent; she brought a lot of energy and knowledge, and was able to answer all sorts of random questions the group had. I would highly recommend this activity for both residents (as I am) and tourists who want...


More  



If you love culture, people, stories, and history, and are looking for an amazing experience WITHOUT the need to buy or consume more stuff....you will love the Wild SF tour. Wes is a brilliant story teller and historian. We were totally taken in by the tales of San Francisco that he wove.

More  



Informative, fun way to spend two hours. Wonderful stories and songs about a special time in San Francisco history. Would love to do a another tour with this company on my next visit to San Francisco.

review_list:

My wife and I went on this tour and had a great time. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and entertaining. Got to go to smaller wineries so we were able to get better attention than at a larger winery. Would definitely recommend to anyone looking to get a taste of Sonoma and Napa Valleys.

Fun Day trip to Sonoma. We went to 3 wineries, Cline, Larson Family & Nichelson. All three were very special in their own way and the wine was fabulous!

More  



A great Sonoma/ Napa day tour. Adam was a great guide with a very well delivered run through of the Bay area history and Sonoma and Napa wine region. Adam was our tour guide. He was informative, professional, funny, and charming. Our group was small, 7 couples. The sights, smells, and tastes of the Napa and Sonoma valleys did not disappoint.

title: Ferry Building Marketplace, San Francisco
address: One Ferry Building, The Embarcadero at Market Street, San Francisco, CA 94111
review_list:
During busy super bowl the stores handled more than usual traffic with patience and good humor. Better prices than inside the makeshift city.

Great restaurants groceries, wines and spirits, and even a good bookstore at the historic Ferry Building. I ate at the Slanted Door but it contains Oyster, Veggie, Pork and other themed dining places its inside and outside seating. The Book Passage is an exc lent bookstore like bookstores used to be.
Don't miss the well planned History Walk along this...


More  



This is one of my favorite places in San Francisco, love the market inside the building and all the fresh food they have there. You can have a great wine, cheese, meet, vegetables or simple enjoy some fresh oysters. I visit this place every time I'm in SF. Don't miss it!!

Perfect #superbowl50 backdrop for all the festivities! We had lots of great pictures all around this block. The concert at the city stage culminating with Alicia Keys performing on 2/6. San Francisco knew how to host a Super Bowl party bash! Congratulations!

This is a place of two parts - one is the place where you take a ferry and the other is quite an upmarket spot full of eateries, coffee shops and trendy produce stores. The old ferry building has been well maintained and looks good. However if you are there to actually catch a ferry for the first time then...


More  



Called in here for a look around and I was amazed at the quality of the shops selling local produce. Great array of restaurants. A lot of the shops offer tasters and it is a great place to wander around and soak up the atmosphere

Ferry Market is a place to buy gifts for all members of your family, even the ones hard to please. A little something for everyone. History of this place is interesting also.

This building has been refurbished with a broad variety of specialty stores and eateries. Browsing and grabbing a bite to eat should takes around 1 to 2 hours. The Wild West Fungi store was fascinating and worth visiting. The Boccalone store has tasty salumi to sample. Sandwiches were delicious. You can take the vintage electric trolleys from Fishermans Wharf to...


More  



Excellent selection of good quality food stalls and eateries. Decent bread available (which is saying something in the US). Good selection of food shops.

Had never made it in here, glad I did! Cowgirl creamery! I was loving it. Great little independent shops- a foodie paradise. Great little wine bar- a lot to see so walk slowly and take it all in.
