title: Asian Art Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
The former main library was magically transformed into the premiere Asian Art Museum in the USA. Beautiful architecture of a by-gone era. Beautiful galleries house the best in asian art

All you can eyeball. So. Many. Asian. Arts. If you are fond of a particular kind of Asian art, you will find it here. That is a problem if you can call it such. Just a deluge of catalog.

I have been here once, my friend is a member so I got to see some of the displays during lunch. They also have a great restaurant inside. the restaurant is a little $$$ but the museum is wonderful. The building itself is a work of art. Sometimes they have Thursday after hours special for $5.00 entry.

If you like Asian Art this is the place for you. Three floors of high quality exhibits from all over Asia and different epochs. Well displayed. Allow several hours, maybe breaking it up with a cup of tea in the cafeteria (really good blank tea)

Went to see the special exhibition surrounding the influence of Japanese art and the impressionists (Monet, Van Gogh etc.). It was a well presented exhibition and to see the multiple masterpieces was inspiring. Unfortunately I did not have any time to visit the permanent exhibitions, but would love to on my next visit.

Alcatraz was an awesome island to see, and the audio tour was informative. The hop on hop off idea is great and very convenient, however if you hop off for anything more than just photo opportunities (such as the asian art museum), you'll find yourself with many only a little time to catch one more bus and see one more...


More  



If you are already in Chinatown, you can get here very easily on foot. You only need about 30 minutes to tour this site. There is a limited amount of Chinese artwork, with some of it for sale. There are prints at very reasonable prices.
The decor inside is more modern than most of Chinatown. The staff were very friendly...


More  



In addition to its 'permanent' collection, this museum puts together exhibitions that go well beyond art to encompass history and culture. An example of this is the not to miss exhibition on how the opening of Japan resulted in influencing the Art Nouveau and Impressionist movements and how women contributed

The building itself is just beautiful. Marble stairs and amazing ceilings. The entire place is laid out well with interesting points around every corner.

I've been to the Asian Art Museum many times for events. This was my first time for a special exhibit. "Looking East" examines the influence that Japanese art had on European and American artists in the 19th century. I was first intrigued by this idea when visiting Monet's home in France and saw his collection of wood block prints. "Looking...


More

title: Asian Art Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
The former main library was magically transformed into the premiere Asian Art Museum in the USA. Beautiful architecture of a by-gone era. Beautiful galleries house the best in asian art

All you can eyeball. So. Many. Asian. Arts. If you are fond of a particular kind of Asian art, you will find it here. That is a problem if you can call it such. Just a deluge of catalog.

I have been here once, my friend is a member so I got to see some of the displays during lunch. They also have a great restaurant inside. the restaurant is a little $$$ but the museum is wonderful. The building itself is a work of art. Sometimes they have Thursday after hours special for $5.00 entry.

If you like Asian Art this is the place for you. Three floors of high quality exhibits from all over Asia and different epochs. Well displayed. Allow several hours, maybe breaking it up with a cup of tea in the cafeteria (really good blank tea)

Went to see the special exhibition surrounding the influence of Japanese art and the impressionists (Monet, Van Gogh etc.). It was a well presented exhibition and to see the multiple masterpieces was inspiring. Unfortunately I did not have any time to visit the permanent exhibitions, but would love to on my next visit.

Alcatraz was an awesome island to see, and the audio tour was informative. The hop on hop off idea is great and very convenient, however if you hop off for anything more than just photo opportunities (such as the asian art museum), you'll find yourself with many only a little time to catch one more bus and see one more...


More  



If you are already in Chinatown, you can get here very easily on foot. You only need about 30 minutes to tour this site. There is a limited amount of Chinese artwork, with some of it for sale. There are prints at very reasonable prices.
The decor inside is more modern than most of Chinatown. The staff were very friendly...


More  



In addition to its 'permanent' collection, this museum puts together exhibitions that go well beyond art to encompass history and culture. An example of this is the not to miss exhibition on how the opening of Japan resulted in influencing the Art Nouveau and Impressionist movements and how women contributed

The building itself is just beautiful. Marble stairs and amazing ceilings. The entire place is laid out well with interesting points around every corner.

title: City Lights Booksellers, San Francisco
address: 261 Columbus Avenue, North Beach, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
This was a great find: a quiet, cozy place to linger, read, peruse the shelves. Personable employees ready to help but non-intrusive.

Anytime I'm in the area, I have to stop and browse. I typically walk out with a book that I wasn't thinking about buying. If you like books, you'll love this place.

In a time when prolific best selling authors may hire a writer to turn their story outlines into full length novels, or when poorly written novels that are designed to entice solely with sex become a global phenomenon, City Lights Booksellers stands as a beacon to any avid reader with an appetite for knowledge.
This is not a chain store...


More  



3 floors of books, my wife was in heaven but it was not for me. There are loads of cafés nearby if you want to wait there.

City Lights is worth visiting just for its history -- a big player in alternative culture and arts in the 60s; involved in an obscenity trial for publishing Allen Ginsberg's "Howl and Other Poems"; the first all-paperback store in the United States; and the list goes on. Its architecture (clerestory windows and small mezzanine balcony) shows off distinctive details of...


More  



It was fun to pop in since we were walking down that street anyway. Read up on the historic significance to make it a little more special.

Great selection of books. Not a discount place by any means but a good independent store for serious book lovers.

You feel surrounded by history in this bookstore. It has a great selection of books but they are presented in older wooden bookshelves so it has a library feel. Lots of small quirky spaces and even a reading room filled with Poetry - how often do you see that?

This place is a must visit if you're a fan of Jack Kerouac! It has old school charm and the staff are quite helpful.

If you are lucky enough you can bump into Noam Chomsky in one of the aisles reading a book on Hellenistic Antiquity; yep I did and we chatted for ten minutes. I always visit City Lights when in San Fran and walk away with far tooooooo many books. Its not cheap but it is important to keep these wonderful independent...


More

title: 16th Avenue Tiled Steps, San Francisco
address: Moraga St. between 15th & 16th Ave., San Francisco, CA 94122
review_list:
I love this beautiful, tiled staircase! I have introduced it to locals as well as visitors. The fact that individuals in the neighborhood funded and continue to care for this stairway to the stars makes it even more special. There is a theme of traveling from the ocean to the sun & moon as one climbs the rather steep staircase.

A little tricky to find but once we did we adored these steps. Gorgeous and in my opinion, a must see.

These steps make your journey up very pleasant and enjoyable. The reward is at the top, a beautiful view of the bay. There are 3 sets of mosaic steps in San Francisco, this I believe is the newest one.

Take your camera. The steps are beautifully designed. The walk up is tiring unless you're in good shape, but can be done slowly by just about anyone. It's worth the walk to go up the steps.

My mother and I visited the 16th Avenue Tiled Steps, also known as the Mosaic Steps, on the morning/afternoon of July 30th, after visiting the Golden Gate Bridge.
The Mosaic Steps were located at the corner of Moraga and 16th Avenue, just south of Golden Gate Park.
We took the MUNI bus from the Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center parking...


More  



These stairs are the 1st of two sets of stairs in this area by the same group of artists. The other one is a few blocks away, called the Noriega Stairs. These were created by a group of artists & volunteers in conjunction with the Parks Dept, & the Irving Merchants Assc. to beautify the aging stairways in the Sunset...


More  



I came here during a holiday and there were so many people around. So if you want to take a picture with the steps, it's probably best to go right at sunrise early in the morning on a weekday! There's about 200+ steps, but when you get to the top, it's all worth it because there, you'll find an amazing...


More  



This is a great hidden gem and will delight tourists who prefer to immerse themselves in the local scene as natives rather than gallivanting the overcrowded, big$ spots.
We approached from the E side of Grandview Park and climbed the hill before descending the other side to appreciate the mosaic-tiled steps.
The views from the top of the hill at...


More  



As a local San Fran native, I did not know this even existed until I stumbled across it by accident. It is gorgeous and was built by the local residents. But you will need a car to access and park on the public streets and then walk up/down... It is unique and quite lovely.

A nice stop with breathtaking views. It only takes a few minutes of your time. Not very crowded. Take pictures, pictures, pictures on the way up the stairs. Enjoy the view and take more pictures at the top. Not a hard walk up because there are plenty of opportunities to stop and rest while taking more pictures. Once at the...


More

title: Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market, San Francisco
address: Embarcadero & Green Street, Ferry Building, San Francisco, CA 94102
review_list:
If you love food then this is the place for you , but please make sure you walk around all the stalls before deciding on what to buy for lunch. Oh and don't fill up on too many tasters!

My mother and I visited the Ferry Plaza Farmer’s Market on August 1st, a Saturday morning.
We took the BART train from the Mission District to the Embarcadero and walked down Market Street a short way to the market. The market is easily accessible by MUNI bus, BART train and MUNI historic street cars. We arrived shortly after they opened...


More  



We go to the Farmers Market by the Ferry Building in San Francisco. They have a variety of hot food as well as fruits, vegetables and other food for purchase. Today was the week before the Superbowl. We went on a Thursday. Its a fun market place for both locals and visitors.

Lots of good choices to eat where you don't have mass produced food restaurants like Fisherman's Wharf. Recommend a a visit and its an easy walk to Financial District.

The Farmer's Market on Saturday at the Ferry Plaza is beyond amazing! Oh, to only be able to take a huge box of things on the airplane! Even if you buy very little, the experience is well worth the trip. It would be a chef's dream shopping excursion!

We went to the farmers market before Alcatraz. Just don't eat breakfast before! The queues for coffee are pretty long but the produce is pretty amazing. The salt caramel dark chocolate almond brittle is amazing. New also bought organic dried peaches and candy cured salmon.

The location of this market makes it a bit inconvenient for grocery shopping, but you won't find a better selection of products anywhere else. Tourists will love the variety of sampling and tasting, and might even enjoy a bag of fresh fruit. As an East Bay resident, I can't imagine traveling across the Bay Bridge or by Bart to come...


More  



The farmer's market is one of the best place I visited in San Francisco because I am a food lover, cooking and baking enthusiast. The market only operates twice a week, one of them a Saturday. Go there early to give you time to look around and enjoy the food tasting as they will begin to close in the afternoon....


More  



Shop side-by-side famous chefs and their truck size carts at the City’s bountiful Ferry Plaza Farmers Market. In addition to the plethora of fresh organic produce to choose from, other offerings include pastries, coffee, cheeses, nuts, flowers and juices. And, numerous booths prepare hot tasty food to eat on site or takeaway. From the Embarcadero setting to the incomparable gourmet...


More  



Happen to be in SF over the weekend and staying close to the Ferry Terminal. The Farmer market is nice and worth a visit with so many thing being sold, and some really nice food as well.

title: Golden Gate Promenade, San Francisco
address: Marina Blvd. at Baker St., Marina District, San Francisco, CA 94129
review_list:
A lot of locals go there to have a walk, to fish, to relax. The gardens are full of people organizing theyr own BBQ with friends and families. Amazing.

Nice way to see the city front, bay and bridge that's free too! It's a popular exercise track for the locals and for good reason.

A good place to run or cycle on a sunny winter afternoon in San Francisco. No far way from Fisherman's Wharf and the Gheradeli Factory...Must visit in SFO.

Brilliant if you have a few hours, want some exercise and some sea air. Closer to the city is some amazing Architecture with many of the Marina View homes built right on the road frontage.
Great views of the harbor plus a panoramic shot of the city.

Perfect place to get best photos of the GG bridge and other views of San Francisco. Incredible views from all sides.

This is one of my favorite places in San Francisco to take a walk and enjoy the beautiful view and I'm a local!! A must see and see again!

if you want to relax, enjoy the view, smell the sea, come to this place. Easy to park your car, and a nice walk path if you don't want to walk in the beach sand...

we lived in this area for ten fantastic years. after life back east this is a revelation. you wake up as close to paradise as a human gets.
the homes, the sights, the parks and historic sights lead to an unforgettable coastline. food nearby, theatre not far, and real non stop beauty all around you. take someone you love.. kiss...


More  



Nothing much to say about this. The only good thing other than the nice walk to reach it is that you can grab a good view of the bridge for photos.

We just had a great time walking, seeing dogs (lots of them) taking pictures and enjoying the moment. It was even cold, 45-50 degrees ish. So no toes in the water, maybe next time.

title: San Francisco Bay Bridge, San Francisco
review_list:
This bridge is a great second act to the Golden Gate. At night it is very photogenic from the pier area of San Francisco.

The updated 25,000 LED lights make this landmark another San Francisco treasure. Magical lights twinkle in various patterns in the night sky

Had to use it several times while we were there, expect to pay tolls, for all of the big bridges....

The San Francisco Bay Bridge was a majestic way to enter San Fransisco. It was also expensive. We were pretty shocked at the $6 toll we had to pay. But, it is what it is.

We actually got engaged with the bay bridge behind us so it had to get a 5 rating! In honesty though it really is beautiful particularly at night and you get some lovely views from the wharf and piers. Going over it on the way to treasure island is a great experience just so you can appreciate the size!

You can have an amazing view of the city when you´re going towards SF. Big bridge, very comfortable to drive in.

Perhaps the step-child of bridges here, but nonetheless captivating and offering great views of the city, including Alcatraz and Oakland.

You cant come to San Fransisco and not see the Golden Gate Bridge. We travelled over it a couple of times on a bus tour. The stop at Sauciitto end was well worth it. An ideal place to take photos. Definitely worth the visit.

We loved this bridge more than Golden Gate Bridge. They were built within 6 months of each other and so different!

Watching NY fireworks from the SFO Bay Bridge promenade is a once in a lifetime experience. Luxury Yachts in the harbour and take a cruise to Alcatraz in the afternoon to enjoy the view of the bridge from the water.

title: Japanese Tea Garden, San Francisco
address: Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, CA 94117
review_list:
My friend and I just stumbled upon this place and I believe it was def worth the price. It's beautiful pagodas and stupas just added to the tranquil and authentic atmosphere. The flowers, trees and koi ponds were well maintained and impressive. It is def accessible to everyone and is an easy walk.

Well worth a visit as the gardens were truly tranquil with some very attractive ponds and structures.

Well designed. A beautiful use of space. Part of the greater golden gate park. Just wish it was larger. Especially with the entrance fee.

We heard so much about Japanese Tea Garden. We made sure it was in our agenda for the afternoon. The garden is well kept and lively. It is a nice place to walk around and relax. The Japanese pagoda and other items look authentic. There is a koi pond to watch the fishes swim, and a bridge for you to...


More  



When we lived in San Francisco, this was a nice place to just chill. We would just walk around the tea garden and then sit down and have some tea. This is a great place for visitors and residents alike.

Spent half a day at the Japanese Tea Garden. Amazing location, cheap to enter but did wait for nearly an hour to get in due to its popularity. Wander at your own pace and take in all the sights. Definitely doesn't feel like you're in one of the busiest cities in the US when you're there.

I'm so glad we took a few minutes to step inside and order some tea and Kuzumochi (see picture). I had hojicha tea which was smooth and not too strong. My husband had jasmine tea which was sweet and delicious. We sat at a long, center table with a shelf of smooth pebbles running down the middle. There is a...


More  



The Japanese Tea Garden was so beautiful. The ponds, gardens, and koi were gorgeous. Everyone especially loved the bridges and foliage. Definitely a must-see in San Fransisco!

We arrived to the Tea Garden shortly after 9am and found admission was free between 9-10am on certain weekdays - lucky us! An hour was sufficient to explore the garden. There were helpful signs explaining what certain structures were and looking at a Zen Garden, in the rain, was one of the most peaceful moments of our visit.

The gardens are pretty, but nothing wow. If you've seen Japanese Gardens, then this isn't really worth the trip unless you're looking for a nice stroll or have little kids that want to roam around a bit.

title: Coit Tower, San Francisco
address: 1 Telegraph Hill Boulevard, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
The view of San Francisco from the top of Coit Tower is hard to better. From Bay Bridge, right around the city, to the Golden Gate Bridge and back to Bay Bridge it its well worth the trip.

Coit Tower on Telegraph Hill offers the most amazing view of the city, Golden Gate Bridge (in the distance), Alcatraz, and everything else - 180 degrees. It cost us 8$ per adult to go up to the top. That's a bit much - hence only 4 points. Otherwise highly recommended.

It's worth it to walk up to the top for the views. Also, make sure to explore some of the architecture in the neighborhood at the base of the tower... you can find some Art Deco gems.

Coit Tower is a fun way to start of a walking day in San Francisco. The historic tower with it's Art Deco mosaics is impressive. The paintings are a glimpse into San Francisco history. The elevator ride up to look our over the city, bay, bridges, is fantastic. There is so much that can be seen, the benefactor really did...


More  



It's a quick, easy stroll (and a few steps!) from Fisherman's Wharf or North Beach. The view from the car park is great, but invest in the $8 ticket (purchase from the gift store inside) and take the elevator and 2 flights of stairs to the very top where you'll have awesome views over the city and the entire bay....


More  



First and foremost you must go early. There is limited like 20 parking places. You wait in a line until someone leaves to park. Once your there, the view is so amazing. You can see the whole bay even Alcatraz island. Take a tour to learn the history. I hope your not afraid of heights. An elevator takes you to...


More  



Great look at the entire city by the bay. Around the tower was visitor parking and sightseeing pay binoculars but the shrubs over grew them and to get that great view, you have to pay to go up the tower for that clear view. You could still see the Golden Gate Bridge and the Bay Bridge but it's much better...


More  



Been in SF several times and this was the first time in Coit tower. The view was amazing!! 360 degrees of beautiful! Not for the weak of heart if you are walking the steps, it is a long, long climb. But worth every step!

...and on your way down, stop and get some gelato.
Don't cheat yourself, either--walk up! Take your time and enjoy the view and imagine how cool it would be to live here.

We went at night so we only saw it from the outside, so we weren´t impressed. I heard you can go up and have a great view of the city, we´ll do that next time.

title: Coit Tower, San Francisco
address: 1 Telegraph Hill Boulevard, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
The view of San Francisco from the top of Coit Tower is hard to better. From Bay Bridge, right around the city, to the Golden Gate Bridge and back to Bay Bridge it its well worth the trip.

Coit Tower on Telegraph Hill offers the most amazing view of the city, Golden Gate Bridge (in the distance), Alcatraz, and everything else - 180 degrees. It cost us 8$ per adult to go up to the top. That's a bit much - hence only 4 points. Otherwise highly recommended.

It's worth it to walk up to the top for the views. Also, make sure to explore some of the architecture in the neighborhood at the base of the tower... you can find some Art Deco gems.

Coit Tower is a fun way to start of a walking day in San Francisco. The historic tower with it's Art Deco mosaics is impressive. The paintings are a glimpse into San Francisco history. The elevator ride up to look our over the city, bay, bridges, is fantastic. There is so much that can be seen, the benefactor really did...


More  



It's a quick, easy stroll (and a few steps!) from Fisherman's Wharf or North Beach. The view from the car park is great, but invest in the $8 ticket (purchase from the gift store inside) and take the elevator and 2 flights of stairs to the very top where you'll have awesome views over the city and the entire bay....


More  



First and foremost you must go early. There is limited like 20 parking places. You wait in a line until someone leaves to park. Once your there, the view is so amazing. You can see the whole bay even Alcatraz island. Take a tour to learn the history. I hope your not afraid of heights. An elevator takes you to...


More  



Great look at the entire city by the bay. Around the tower was visitor parking and sightseeing pay binoculars but the shrubs over grew them and to get that great view, you have to pay to go up the tower for that clear view. You could still see the Golden Gate Bridge and the Bay Bridge but it's much better...


More

...and on your way down, stop and get some gelato.

title: San Francisco City Hall, San Francisco
address: 1 Dr Carlton B Goodlett Place, San Francisco, CA 94102
review_list:
What a great day in San Francisco. We spent a few hours doing a guided tour of San Francisco City Hall. It's an iconic building on the San Francisco skyline and incredibly historic. It's where Harvey Milk and Mayor Moscone were assassinated. It has recently undergone a seismic strengthening and restoration, and it looks great. I highly recommend this amazing...


More  



Seriously, it's a great place to get married. It's gorgeous inside.
Just think how surprised your family will be when you get home!

City Hall San Francisco has a great architecture. It was beautifully constructed. At dawn, you can experience the changing color of the building from green, blue to red. Amazing to set foot on this architecture. Nearby is the San Francisco Public Library.

What a grand piece of architecture. The marble and huge staircase up to the rotunda remind you of a different era. My spouse and I got married here 2 years ago and it was awe inspiring to have the ceremony in the Rotunda looking down at the massive hall. It's free and there are many attraction near here. There are...


More  



SFGuides offers tours several days a week and gives you a good look at City Hall from several floors. It is rich in architectural details and history , so it helps to have someone knowledgable with you.

If you are interested in architecture this really is a wonderful building to visit. The building is quite awe inspiring.

San Francisco has been the scenery for many films, the city hall has been part of many films also, visiting the city hall was a great experience, the architecture and the history involved is just a must visit.

If you have a few minutes and are in the area, then stop by City Hall. The architecture is amazing and you just might see our mayor. If it is Wednesday, then stop by the Farmer's Market a few blocks away and enjoy some fresh produce and tasty meals from some great food trucks.

Didn't go inside, just got some Christmas color photos of the outside. Nice looking city hall. Maybe one of these years I'll go inside for a look-see.

Have you ever been to San Francisco? Well, if you haven't been to San Francisco, I think you should go there for 3 reasons. First, you can see a typical American city. Second, you can see many grand sights. Finally, you can also see European-inspired architecture.
When I think about America, I imagine a complicated and busy image, for example,...


More

title: San Francisco Botanical Garden, San Francisco
address: 1199 9th Ave, Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, CA 94122
review_list:
I love, love, love this arboretum/botanical garden - trees and flowers from around the world including redwoods, birds including blue and green herons, California quail, and hummingbirds, ponds, paths, benches, yes, yes, yes, and so much more! It is so beautiful, so inviting, so diverse, so interesting, so relaxing, so San Francisco!

We visited in January and walked all over the gardens. There were very few people in the gardens, but the plants and trees were amazing. Wish we lived nearby to visit in the spring and summer when things are in bloom. We had a wonderful 3 hours here.

This place has beautiful combinations of flowers and is a huge space.(I have never looked through all of it) I especially love the Japanese garden with the ponds and the tropical parts. I don't think that I can explain how wonderful it is to stroll through the garden at your leisure taking in all the nature surrounding you. You have...


More  



i am a local & cut through this garden on my way home often. This garden has sections devoted to the plant life of areas from all over the world. It is landscaped in a lovely & beautiful fashion. Take the tour. It is well-worth your time. As many times as I have been through there, there is just so...


More  



This is a very beautiful and spacious botanical garden. Even in January, there were plenty of beautiful things to see. Parking is always unpredictable. Five stars.

I come here 2-3 times a week too relax and enjoy Mother Nature. It's glorious feeling walking all around the park. I love the Moon viewing Garden.

Very diverse plants and environments. My wife and I always visit Botanical Gardens when we can; this one is comparable too the Melbourne Botanical Gardens in Australia for its diversity and beauty. We went in February so I can only imagine how beautiful it is in Spring and Summer. Tip: Take Lunch, a drink and a hat/umbrella and plan to...


More  



Not overly busy, gorgeous and relaxing. It was the perfect place to walk around while having a nice conversation with my friend.

Nice place to visit with different plants and flowers. There were several pianos scattered throughout the grounds available for people to play.

We were here during the wrong weather and it was already 4pm. We had but enough time to walk from one entrance to the other. I think this would be a great place for a walk during a warm day. The grounds appeared well kept and trails were well marked.

title: The Embarcadero, San Francisco
review_list:
What a transformation! City of San Francisco we salute you for hosting a great Super Bowl party! We as football fans had a really great time! Lots of fun things to do even for adults! Not all just for big spenders... Lots of activities with the help of the superbowl50 app. I planned it all with the help of that...


More  



Not too far from Fisherman's wharf. Where all the boats are docked. All the tourists go here. It can be chilly so wear a jacket.

Good views, fresh air...if you need to take a break from whatever, take some time on the Embarcadero to unwind. I particularly love to take active out-of-towners here: we rent bikes (or bring our skates) and go up and down the Embarcadero, from the ballpark to the Ferry Building (coffee! Ice cream! Great eats! Expensive.), to Fisherman's Wharf, and on.

Getting ready for an important business meeting requires a nice place to get focus, San Francisco is a good place to keep calm

San Francisco has done a great job of creating a harbor area that is friendly to walkers and bikers. We enjoyed going to the Ferry Building on a Saturday morning for great coffee and a quick breakfast. We then wandered up through the various Embarcadero buildings up towards our hotel in the financial district....so many shops and restaurants to choose...


More  



With Super Bowl 50 being held in the San Francisco Bay Area, we went to the Embarcadero are to see the workers set up Super Bowl City. We went a couple of days before it opened and plan to return to see the activities such as Chris Izaak perform on City Stage. Fireworks also are planned. There are other fan...


More  



Very fun area ( Pier 39 is part of this). If you like seafood, try the lobster or other seafood sandwiches at the crabstands. Watch out for scammmers however. We got "bamboozeld " by a lady who gave us what we tought were menus or coupons for estaurants, turns out she was giving out "chinese prayer cards" and asking for...


More  



A must visit if you are visiting San Francisco. Would recommend going in the evening, great views of the bay bridge.

Great walking path along the Embarcadero. I like to walk down towards Pier 39, without actually going as far as that touristic hell, then turn around and walk down past Red's Java house just past the Bay Bridge. Great views of the bridge, bay, and downtown San Francisco. While I do stop into the Ferry building market on Saturdays, the...


More  



We spent some time walking at The Embarcadero to see the sunset. It's amazing! You should do it in your time in SFO.

title: Scenic 49 Mile Drive, San Francisco
address: Throughout San Francisco, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
At the end of all our sightseeing, we were trying to find our way back to our hotel and accidently stumbled on this trail and we are so glad we did. After all the hustle and bustle of the big city it was lovely just to drive through countryside and the outskirts of the city with amazing views of the...


More  



the memories you take away are breath taking. the scenery changes, fast! watch for the little signs throughout. you cannot get lost. use a gps and slow down for incredible views along the pacific. if you see a venue you want to stop and explore, do it. no regrets. the song about leaving your heart makes more sense the more...


More  



At least once, those who like driving tours should try my favorite, Santa Barbara to Monterey in either direction. Santa Barbara itself is a great place to visit. Lompoc is nice, and Vandenberg Air Force Base is the site of missile launches. Spring is a beautiful growing season around Guadalupe for those who appreciate flora. Beautiful coastline scenery along a...


More  



This is just what it says. You drive your car along 49 miles of beauty and interest from the heart of the city down to the coast and see beautiful views along the way. It's free, but takes a while. 49 miles through San Francisco takes a while. Do it but plan for it.

The drive is great. Take the time to stop and explore each spot. The view from the peaks is beautiful. Starting early in the day and end near sunset at one of the beaches or the golden gate bridge. It's ok to start at a different point other than the first or the last one. As long as you follow...


More  



Great way to see all the major sights in SF in one day. Also recommend a slight detour: driving up the golden gate bridge and up the Highlands to get great views of SF

If you want to take a scenic road trip, this is it. It is not that long, but it is exciting every single mile !!

You will see, so much of the city, pay attention to the signs. Stop every once in a while for a local treat.

I have done this by tour bus starting at San Francisco City Hall... a bride and groom were just coming down the massive steps indoors... We became their "wedding party" of well-wishers. We went on to several stops including lunch at Beach Chalet and A visit to "Land's End" at the Golden Gate...

Super fun with a limo tour there is a lot of sites that you must stop and takes pictures very beautiful.

title: Filbert Steps, San Francisco
address: Sansome St. & Filbert St., San Francisco, CA
review_list:
My mother and I walked down from the top of Telegraph Hill towards The Embarcadero via the Filbert Steps, on the morning of August 1st.
After admiring the views from the top of Telegraph Hill and the parking lot of Coit Tower, we walked down towards The Embarcadero via the Filbert Steps. The wooden steps were surrounded by beautiful gardens,...


More  



We took the steps "down" only and that was sufficient for a rainy day. (Beware, they can be a bit slippery when wet). It was hard to believe you were right in the City walking through all the greenery and enjoying some of the residential sections before landing in North Beach area just in time for lunch!

This is great way to shortcut from the Embarcadero to North Beach (Italian heritage neighborhood in San Francisco), but beware; you will burn a days worth of calories on the climb! which is just right because when you get to North Beach there is sooo much great food!

It used to be a dump but over the years it developed to a pricey area.
The houses are squeezed in where they fit. Along the steps they a nice garden maintained by volunteers.

We worked out way up these steps and enjoyed every moment away from the hustle and bustle. Lots of greenery and every now and again there is a break and you can see the bay. Historically significant... Do the research before walking it so you can appreciate it a bit more. Wear your touristy gym shoes and get ready to...


More  



This will make your calves ache but so worthwhile as the gardens are real hidden gems. We even saw the local parakeets. Views spectacular.

We really enjoyed our walk up the Filbert Street steps. It's a really picturesque area and the views are well worth it but most of all we enjoyed the quaint side 'streets' which run off Filbert Street and all the lovely houses and gardens along the way.

This is a tucked away place where not a lot of tourists go to. It's a nice place to get away from the noise of the city.

We planned to walk up Filbert Steps from the Embarcadero side but couldn't find them. After wandering around a few streets we ended up walking around to the other side of Coit Tower via Chestnut St, Grant Ave & then Greenwich St which was a steep hill but only a few steps. On exiting from the tower we were able...


More  



I am sure others already wrote about the view, the steep hill, the homes you pass by, and maybe encountering some parrots, and some cats. All I am going to add is that if you walk all the way from bottom to top. You deserve to eat some amazing food after your workout! :)

title: USS Pampanito, San Francisco
address: Pier 45 @ Fisherman Wharf, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
When I was in boy scouts we had the option to stay abord the pompanito for the night. I remember it being very cramped and uncomfortable but it's all worth it when go on the tour.

If you like WWII stuff stop by this jewel, we didn't take the tour but it was very interesting to read about.

Probably not a top 10 thing to do in SF, but if you're in town for several days, or on a repeat visit the Pampanito is a great way to spend a few hours.

The USS Pampanito is a World War II submarine with a museum and memorial that is open for visitors at San Francisco's Fisherman's Wharf at Pier 45. I was curious to explore the sub, but balked at the $15 entry fee. That's too much money. It's unfortunate because I think if the price was more reasonable they'd raise a lot...


More  



If you have an interest in WW2 history then this attraction is for you. Amazing to see how the sub was run in such confined spaces. The men who served in these subs were so brave and had such a lot of discomfort to put up with. The volunteers who keep it going as is are awesome.

Totally restored sub...awesome visit..and information headsets cool with real sounds...incl. the war freighter behind it...a must for sub buffs..worth every penny I spent all afternoon there...u-535 next

When you are down by Fisherman's Quay, ignore all the tat and tourist garbage. This is a gem of a museum and they offer military discount too.Wander through the sub and get a feel what life was really like under the waves.

It was a quick visit but a great pleasure to talk to a veteran. Something to do in a life and I share it with my wife and my 5 years old boy.

Have to agree with all the positives expressed in previous reviews . Amazing to come into such close proximity of such a unique piece of history . The submarine , battleship and arcade museum all very close to each other . Well worth spending some time here .

We enjoyed this self tour, well done, not expensive and interesting view. No time pressure (such as the u-boat in Germany)

title: Alamo Square, San Francisco
address: Fulton St. at Steiner St., Western Addition, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
My mother and I visited Alamo Square on the afternoon of August 1st.
We arrived at Alamo Square via the MUNI bus, and walked a few blocks to reach our destination. The famous row of colourful Victorian houses called The Painted Ladies were situated on one side of Alamo Square.

title: Ghirardelli Square, San Francisco
address: 900 North Point Street, At Polk Street, San Francisco, CA 94109
review_list:
Ghirardelli Square is a beautiful gathering place for food and chocolate. I highly recommend it. It is a fun place to be at any time.

Second visit to Ghirardelli Square but the first time to enjoy a Sundae. Shared a butter pecan sundae in a chocolate coated waffle bowl with all the toppings. Then went shopping at the other stores in the Square.

We enjoyed walking around Ghirardelli Square. I hadn't known that the company began in San Francisco. My husband and I shared a sundae with hot fudge and sea salt caramel. It was expensive at over $10, but it tasted amazing!

Outside of getting a hot fudge sundae - there isn't much to do here. The exhibit that shows how they make chocolate is pretty lame.

Excellent hot fudge sundae. Life is short, eat dessert first and eat it here. Chocolates are pricey but high quality.

If you are a chocolate lover, then this is the place to be.
From hot chocolate to ice cream, it's just the best. Don't forget to their traditional sundae served with the best Chocolate hot fudge you'll ever try.
They sell all their chocolate products and baking products too.

This is a tiny square - very peaceful in the middle, with shops and a couple of restaurants. Many were enjoying making sundaes, but our chocolate experience began and ended at the original Ghirardelli Chocolate store. We were greeted inside with a free sumptuous square of chocolate with caramel. It converted into a bagful of squares we ended up purchasing....


More  



there was a huge line up to get on the cable car so we walked over and up the hill to here. we did not eat, just visit the gift shop.
I cant say I would make it a destination, but to fill time it was ok.

The chocolate shop was awesome. Other than that the cable car starts from here so if you don't want to spend $7.5 on the cable car , one can click pictures on cable car when they are at Ghirardelli square. Wharf, fort mason, pier 39 is all in walking distance..

A small square that has a few different shops and cafes but you only go here for one reason and one reason only... To visit the Ghirardelli shop.

title: The Castro, San Francisco
address: Castro and Market Sts. is the heart of the Castro, San Francisco, CA 94114
review_list:
The area is full of pubs, bars and stores. It´s usually full of people around, looks like a nice area.

We walked the entire area and stopped in used book stores, record shops as well as other shops and stores that were unique. Marvelous buildings and pleasant viewing for people watching.

My mother and I went for a walk in San Francisco’s Castro neighbourhood on the afternoon of July 31st. We were staying at an Airbnb in the Mission District and walked to the Castro from there (the two neighbourhoods border one another). The neighbourhood is also easily accessible by MUNI buses and trains.
The Castro is a neighbourhood near the...


More  



Great food, went back on each trip. Street Tacos, etc Exotic neighborhood in the heart of old San Francisco

The Castro area has its own unique culture and residents, and we really enjoyed an afternoon and evening there. The quirky bar we ended up in was very 'out there' but we partied on late into the night, actually early into the morning, before getting a bus back to the wharf. Felt safe throughout, and enjoyed this different San Fran...


More  



Loved this place was so colorful and fun! when the zebra crossing is rainbow colored you know you have arrived at very fun place. Do go to the fun bars and shops. lots to do!

The Castro is a functioning tourist attraction and a full time vibrant and eclectic neighbourhood. Everyone in the Castro seems like a tourist, even the locals - - and that's a good thing. It's hard to imagine that such a vibrant neighborhood is not an amusement park and I don't mean that in a dirty way.

The Castro is fantastic, over the top, characters on every corner and some really great restaurants, deli', coffee houses and architecture. If you are a bit of a prude STAY AWAY; we loved it but I think my elderly parents would probably pass out. Its a true cultural experience and worth walking. Set a day aside and spend sometime really...


More  



I went on a Wild San Francisco Tour to this neighbourhood and fell in love! The whole place is filled with funny business names, monuments of gay militarism and good bars and places to eat. I loved especially the school and the house with the Barbies. Just lovely!

After brunch in the Castro, we spent some time walking the main strip, checking out all of the unique shops along the way. Many of the stores were playfully themed around Castro's "gay village" heritage. Lots of opportunity to pop into boutique shops and find some interesting keepsakes. If we weren't so stuffed from the brunch we had, I would...


More

title: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park, San Francisco
review_list:
The park really shows the history of the shipping industry of San Francisco. With real ships you can explore it is a great place to check out!

We truly enjoyed the setting. Alcatraz off in the distance, the mighty Golden Gate Bridge spanning the bay and of course the really cool ships!

It's 10 dollars for adults & there were only 3 boats to go on & you couldn't go on one of those even when we first walked in. But it is interesting if you like old ships or history.

We spent a few hours here exploring the ships. Fascinating and a worthy visit. Great views of Ghirardelli Square and Gokden Gate Bridge.
It cost us $10 ppn to board the ships and the ticket was valid for 7days. Great value.

Loved that the nps maintenance shop was open for visitors to look in and see how a steambox works to bend wood for boat repair and restoration. Nice work!! The ships are a lot to keep up with... rot doesn't rest, so we appreciate the hard and skilled labor that goes into these vessels.

The Wharf can be so chaotic and packed wall-to-wall with tourists that it was a very nice break to hit the museum with exhibits, looks at some of the spectacular trees, watch swimmers in late December, walk the shoreline, and explore the ships on the old pier that was used to ferry cars before the Golden Gate Bridge was built....


More  



We came across this place as we were walking along Fisherman's Wharf. We had a national park pass and we could get in using that so thought it would be worth a look. There a a few different boats that you can get onto and explore, with lots of informative displays. We really enjoyed an unexpected bit of history.

Walking distance to fisherman's warf and ghirardelli square as well as the old sailing ship in the harbor worth a tour to see how it was back in the day onboard an old sailing ship.

This is a hidden gem. It is the National Park Visitors Center for the bay. Wonderful exhibits, beautiful building & friendly people. I didn't plan on visiting & just stumbled across it. Wonderful history of the Ocean & Bay front.

Tucked away in a building next to Ghirardelli Square is a beautiful museum worth visiting! Don't miss it while your visiting the Fisherman's Wharf area of San Fran.

title: Westfield San Francisco Centre, San Francisco
review_list:
We were going to NFL Experience at the Moscone Center. Beforehand we had lunch at the food court at Westfield Centre. We also did some shopping.
The Westfield Centre was getting ready for the Super Bowl, Valentine's Day and also for Chinese New Years. There were various decorations for these events..

The shops are great and there are so many to pick and choose from but honestly just pop in for the very unique spiral escalators

I'm not a fan of shopping malls, but anyone staying in the nearby Union Square area should consider at least going briefly into this one to see its 102-foot-wide glass dome or ride the spiraling escalators. The myriad shops range from Aveda to Zara with Nordstrom and Bloomingdale's serving as anchors. I rarely buy here but find it fun to...


More  



Great space with all the latest goodies. Cool to see the Amazon cube......see ya later USA! Check out Soda Pop Jones on the bus tour (guide), the next Late Night show host I feel.....

A great place to shop and spend your time. good eating options and many large departmental stores are available here. High end shops are also present. The overall ambiance is great

The mall has an excellent mix of standard and high end stores, and My China, an Asian fusion restaurant is one of the best mall restaurants I've ever eaten in. Great for families and people watching!

There are a lot of shops. It's a good place to kill time. There is one drawback, however. On Sundays it doesn't open until 11am. They open the doors and allow people in the mall before that but they don't have the restrooms open. Even after 11am, the restrooms still hadn't been opened.

If you wanna kill a whole day in a shopping centre... this is just the place for you. Basically any well-known brand has a shop here, there's good places to eat, nordstrom... basically anything.
It's worth a visit.

Excellent collection of shops and restaurants in heart of San Francisco on market street . Has great food court on the C level

Elegant and sophisticated shopping center, you can find exclusive brands as well as local stores, national and international brands

title: San Francisco Opera, San Francisco
address: 301 Van Ness Ave, San Francisco, CA (415) 861-4008
review_list:
We attended The Barber of Sevilla. Great performances by the artists and very creative set-up. The building as beautiful as impressive. Most importantly, the staff (mostly volunteers I was told) was smiling and helpful. Although a formal attire is recommended, patrons dressed casually are receiving the same warm welcome. This opera house maked our experience smooth, nice and easy, from...


More  



This is definitely top-tier and unsurpassed in the artistic quality. We travel from out-of-state to attend every year, and it is well worth it. They have been doing a great job with innovative productions and finding great voices, many of whom are relatively young but have reached the top level of singing.

This is the second round of this production. First was a few years ago. It is fabulous. Such good music and great new scenery and on-stage modern elements. Sung in English with English super titles. Purists will cringe that it is not sung in German, but they need to get over it! The opera was, after all, designed for local...


More  



My husband and I got married in Sonoma in September of 2014 and we eloped, so we thought it would be fun to do something unique on our wedding night. So, we went to the Symphony. The San Francisco Symphony is incredible. We bought the cheap seats that are typically reserved for the choir if there is one, but there...


More  



I have attended a performance of the San Francisco Opera House yearly for the last few years, on a Saturday evening. This opera company attracts world-class singers. I saw Renee Fleming sing Lucrezia Borgia with them a couple of years ago.
We usually make a special evening of it: dress semi-formally, have dinner at one of the excellent restaurants in...


More  



First, the Opera House is absolutely gorgeous! We saw The Marriage of Figaro. It was excellent! The singing, acting, scenery, and costumes were all wonderful!

Enjoyed the grandeur of the opera via comp tix from my friend. Recommend reading up on the story before going so you can understand what is going on. If you have never experienced opera, take advantage of the SF Opera. There aren't too many California cities which can boast an Opera company of their own.

As an opera lover from Maryland, I am more familiar with the Kennedy Center, which is an elegant but fairly modern-style opera house. So, I absolutely loved the classical aesthetic of the San Francisco Opera House, which has a beauty evoking old world style. I attended with an experienced opera-goer, and we both loved the production of "The Marriage of...


More  



The San Francisco Opera is one of America's oldest and finest opera companies. While they have performances for much of the year, it is particularly attractive in June when they do a festival of three operas in repertory featuring some of the world's greatest singers.

Very beautiful opera house with good acoustics and very helpful staff. A cafe in the opera house serves a very good buffet before the performances (check for details as not all performances may have the buffet). Only recommendation for them would be to better advertise available parking and advance purchase parking.

title: Chinatown, San Francisco
review_list:
Not much extras or something el se but Chinatown. I mean, we all know what are we gonna get...
Basicly u get everything, u have chinese food, every Made in china products, lots of antiques stores, cheap souvenirs, etc, etc.
All surroundings, mood, and ambient is Chinese 100%.
I think it might be interesting in some sort of festival, celebration...


More  



There is so much to do in china town. Do not be afraid to get of your behind and walk around. Even at night it is a pleasant experience with bars clubs and food. We stopped and walked into a sechuan restaurant that was out of this world. Nothing fancy in its decor BUT the food was right on the...


More  



I found it interesting, but the wife was not so impressed. She came along anyway, it was interesting to watch the transactions taking place in the open markets. Just normal life for those folks.

Chinatown is a very popular place to go. Chinatown is a historical place to visit. You can find anything here. Prices vary on things you may find. A unique one of a kind experience. A must see.

This is a living neighborhood in a city that has an Asian population of nearly 1/3. Walking these streets brings one deep into an old and rich culture. Get off Grant Avenue and wander the side streets, visit Portsmouth Sq, and by all means eat. And shop, and have lots of fun. Bring the kids!
Enjoy!

I had a morning to wander without a car from Union Square. So, I hoofed it to Chinatown. It's fascinating. Bring cash and an empty bladder. Just know when you see some trinkets, they will be at the next store and the next. Prices vary all over. Funny thing, with no restaurants open, I could not find an restroom. So,...


More  



Chinatown is definitely an experience you need to see when visiting San Francisco. There's two parts of Chinatown one part is Grant Street. The other part is Stockton Street where all the local Chinese people go to get their fruit food and vegetables. The place looks kind of dirty. Be prepared to deal with a big crowd kind of pushy...


More  



have to be good shape to walk the hills but worth it to see this part of san francisco nice shops and many resturants

This really is a unique place, there is everything you would have in a city all in one district and all Chinese. The food is great and there are a lot of bargains to be found. When we were here in august we needed some extra luggage and so headed straight to Chinatown.

Worth a visit but you fell a little underwhelmed as its tired, dirty and quite shabby. There are shop after shop filled with cheap junk. Reasonable place to buy a San Fran souvenir. Some excellent eateries though!

There is so much to do in china town. Do not be afraid to get of your behind and walk around. Even at night it is a pleasant experience with bars clubs and food. We stopped and walked into a sechuan restaurant that was out of this world. Nothing fancy in its decor BUT the food was right on the...


More  



I found it interesting, but the wife was not so impressed. She came along anyway, it was interesting to watch the transactions taking place in the open markets. Just normal life for those folks.

Chinatown is a very popular place to go. Chinatown is a historical place to visit. You can find anything here. Prices vary on things you may find. A unique one of a kind experience. A must see.

This is a living neighborhood in a city that has an Asian population of nearly 1/3. Walking these streets brings one deep into an old and rich culture. Get off Grant Avenue and wander the side streets, visit Portsmouth Sq, and by all means eat. And shop, and have lots of fun. Bring the kids!
Enjoy!

I had a morning to wander without a car from Union Square. So, I hoofed it to Chinatown. It's fascinating. Bring cash and an empty bladder. Just know when you see some trinkets, they will be at the next store and the next. Prices vary all over. Funny thing, with no restaurants open, I could not find an restroom. So,...


More  



Chinatown is definitely an experience you need to see when visiting San Francisco. There's two parts of Chinatown one part is Grant Street. The other part is Stockton Street where all the local Chinese people go to get their fruit food and vegetables. The place looks kind of dirty. Be prepared to deal with a big crowd kind of pushy...


More  



have to be good shape to walk the hills but worth it to see this part of san francisco nice shops and many resturants

This really is a unique place, there is everything you would have in a city all in one district and all Chinese. The food is great and there are a lot of bargains to be found. When we were here in august we needed some extra luggage and so headed straight to Chinatown.

Worth a visit but you fell a little underwhelmed as its tired, dirty and quite shabby. There are shop after shop filled with cheap junk. Reasonable place to buy a San Fran souvenir. Some excellent eateries though!

title: SS Jeremiah O'Brien, San Francisco
address: Pier 45, Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
Steady as she goes, I've been on cruises to watch the blue angels, bay tours of the moth ball fleet and just toured this WW2 Liberty ship, which is an old merchant marine ship at dock, and she has a lot of history. Lots of walking and climbing stairs. Go on a cruise if you can. Seeing the Blue Angels...


More  



This is an awesome ship at Pier 45 in Fisherman's Wharf. The SS Jeremiah O'Brien is one of two remaining fully functional Liberty ships of the more than 2000 they built during World War II. We would have loved to see it, but they want $20/person to go onboard! The nearby USS Pampanito wants another $15. Too much! They should...


More  



This would improved by an audio tour or some docents. I was glad that my veteran husband was with us to explain things. It was also awkward to have parts of the ship being used by volunteers -- felt kind of like you were peeking into people's personal living quarters at times. It was also confusing to have the modern...


More  



This ship has seen plenty of service in her years and it's good to see her in sailing condition to this day. There's plenty of cabins and holds to explore so I can imagine young kids having a blast running about on the decks. Some of the deck guns and machine guns are able to be traversed and touched which...


More  



A Coast Guard Liberty ship that played a big part in the war. She still sails a few times a year and has an assigned captain and crew which were present the day we went. These ships are few so I was glad to learn of her. She even has a Hollywood credit for the boiler room being in the...


More  



I love it when tours are not canned and protective. This is really your chance to look around this wonderful piece of history, with great freedom. We wandered around above and below deck, explored the engine room, Note that it is a little tricky for those with mobility issues--ships ladders, real ladders, etc. Since we were pretty sure-footed, we could...


More  



Fascinating. Learned alot about Liberty ships and it is great that you have the freedom to roam around the ship and decks and holds using a self guided tour. Press the buttons on the wall outside different cabins to hear recorded information. The 'diorama' of D-day in the museum area really brought home to me the ingenuity and scale of...


More  



The self guided tour is good. You can operate the gun mounts. The diorama inside is fantastic. Lots of historical information.

Beware no toilets use the public toilets before you go on. Its a climb up the stairs to get on a another ladder climb down into the hold but I made it. There is a very interesting video with seats playing in the hold & a gift shop. Video about 40 mins long. You can walk the deck & see...


More  



We spent quiet a few hours here this afternoon. The video is excellent & all of the information they have in the museum is great the way its put together. It's fantastic that you get to wander freely aboard this beauty. Defiantly worth a visit for any age. A wonderful piece of history

title: San Francisco Zoo, San Francisco
address: Sloat Boulevard at 45th Avenue, Parkside, San Francisco, CA 94132
review_list:
The San Francisco Zoo is a great old school zoo. It seems like Zoos of this type are out of style for various reasons, but they continue to freshen the SF Zoo and I think it's very relevant.
The SF Zoo is great for kids which is why we go at least once every 4-6 weeks. It has one of...


More  



I understand that not all the animals will be available all the time, but too many animals were "off". The elephant house was closed without an explanation. I got to see kangaroos and anteaters for the first time. They had the peacocks running free around the zoo which was also delightful. One male peacock was putting a show for the...


More  



We spent a sunny day walking round, Seeing all the animals , loving the atmosphere, listening to the keepers explaining all about their charges and answering questions.
The penguins were a favourite as was the hippo, and the big cats.

We made a return visit to the San Francisco Zoo at the end of January. The weather was nice and the animals were enjoying a warm sunshine day.
The gorillas were playful. The flamingos got frightened by a bird that flew over head. Its the first time I've seen flamingos line up behind each other in s straight line and...


More  



I had occasion to take my ten year old daughter and her friend to the SF zoo on a Monday afternoon,sometimes I worry the girls are out growing the zoo, it is warm afternoon and we were amough the few taking advantage of the zoo that day, everyone we meet was soo nice and friendly, much of the staff went...


More  



Great array of animals, unobtrusive enclosures and great playgrounds should you have children.
Really enjoyed strolling around at our own pace.

Good visit - nice updates in many areas. Food was also good - nice to see some salad options. The kids loved the tigers and elephants in particular.

Austin the Koala was certainly the highlight. There was a hippopotamus, rhino, polar bear, kangaroos, bobcat, leopard, red pandas, ant eater, among other excellently healthy and vibrant animals.
Very little crowd during the time we went and there were no shows. Seeing the animals seemingly happy and having a grand time being taken care of by such a competent zoo...


More  



Clean,Great selection of animals. The best Zoo to date!
Fun filled day trip! Staff was very knowledgeable.

My kids loved it but we kind of found it small. You get to see lot of animals. Nice landscape. Decent food stalls for kids.

title: Haight-Ashbury, San Francisco
address: Haight Street between Masonic and Stanyan, San Francisco, CA 94117
review_list:
This is a nice place to walk around. It is different from other parts of the city. It is nice to walk around and see hot sport of the 1960's

This is the best walk in the west since Boulder's Pearl Street sold it's soul. People watching, great shops and a vibe that welcomes everyone with little pretense. Delight in the wafting aromas of food, people and the California state crop. Walk down from Nob Hill and make it an afternoon. Burn up and take the bus back.I do love...


More  



Came across this gorgeous stretch whilst we were on the hop on hop off sightseeing bus in San Fransisco. I just had to stop! Loads of quaint shops; from victorian clothing to steampunk attire, tattoos, books, shoes...you name it! Found some amazing pieces which I will truly cherish for the rest of my days. Would have loved to spend some...


More  



Great area, full of stores, pubs, cafes and restaurants. There are some really good record stores, books stores and music stores, as well as clothing shops (vintage, modern, etc). I really liked it.

With all the things to do in San Francisco, make this one of your last stops. Yes, I know flower power...blah blah blah. and yes they have some interesting stores. Put that aside and there is homelessness all over. They even have an armed guard in the Whole Foods in that area. Again, they stores are interesting, but once you...


More  



If you like to see the "alternative", quirky side of town, visit this neighborhood. There are some funny stores around.

My mother and I visited the neighbourhood of Haight-Ashbury during the afternoon of July 30th and again on the afternoon of August 1st. Haight Street is easily accessible via public transport (MUNI bus).
Haight-Ashbury is an eclectic, vibrant and interesting neighbourhood in SF with a unique, laid-back and hippie vibe. The neighbourhood has a lot of character and the main...


More  



Being a child of the sixties, I dearly wanted to have a look round Haight Ashbury, but was told by some friends that they felt a bit unsafe there. We went anyway and were delighted to be transported back forty or fifty years. OK so there are a few odd characters and some hippies who probably haven't left the place...


More  



Took my 15 year old daughter here and spent most of the day walking up and down Haight Street. Lots of vintage clothing stores with some seriously good vintage offerings. Recommend looking in Relic Vintage 1605 Haight Street, Decades of Fashion 1653 Haight Street and Love Street Vintage at 1506 Haight Street. Other fun places wee Loved to Death at...


More  



Very retro feel with graffiti walls, pubs, cafes and restaurants. Very fascinating. Shops with weird clothes and old music.

title: Mission Dolores Park, San Francisco
review_list:
Great city park with all the people watching entertainment an urban green space can offer. Undergoing restoration, but getting there. A good place to stop and take a break.

Sat here for a while listening to the musicians while taking in the splendour of nature. Beautiful surroundings in the middle of the city

This is a huge park! To enjoy a break from the hustle and bustle of the city, grab a sandwich and blanket and head over to this park to relax! There are tennis courts and basketball courts. Also, this park has, without a doubt, the cleanest and most well kept public bathrooms! People come to hangout, they bring their bikes...


More  



Literally nobody cares what you do at Dolores Park, as long as it isn't lewd or illegal. Everyone comes here to hang out, from babies running from their mothers around the waves of people, or old men getting crunk to rap music from a boombox.
My friends and I came here after stuffing our faces at brunch to just sit...


More  



Great spot for a afternoon sit down.Walking Vendors provide a unique SF experience and the views of the city on a clear day highlight this green island

I first visited Mission Dolores Park on my first afternoon in San Francisco, on July 28th with my mother. I loved it so much that we returned for subsequent visits a few times during our 7-day stay in the Mission District.
Mission Dolores Park is a beautiful grassy park/green space situated on top of a steep green grass-covered hill in...


More  



It was cold and there were homeless people only, and the park was closed. Nice views. Would recommend on a good, sunny warm day

Escape the city for an hour and relax in Dolores. The park offers a great view of SFand you're able to watch people and just take it easy. Would recommend a visit!
When we were visiting around lunch a lot of teens were hanging out in the park: there is a school close to the park. When we walked the...


More  



Things like the San Francisco Mime Troop bring me there often in summer. It's a calm place to rest your weary bones. Speaking of bones, dogs galore. Want to fly a kite or play Frisbee? Plenty of space.

Super fun park beautiful scenes love walking around here friendly and welcoming it's a must go. Perfect for families.

title: Bay Voyager, San Francisco
address: Beach Street & The Embarcadero, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
We had an amazing tour on the Bay Voyager today led by the incredible Charles who is not only an expert on San Francisco but is also funny and entertaining whilst sharing information about the city he obviously loves.The tour shows San Francisco's stunning scenery and Charles gives extra historical information about the natural and manmade landmarks you see. Our...


More  



Booked the tour in advance as a package with visiting Alcatraz.
The fact it was a freezing overcast day didn't matter, the greeting when we arrived was warm and friendly. The service was excellent.
After putting in our wet weather gear we headed out for an exhilarating trip around the bay, including out the heads after whizzing under the Golden...


More  



My wife arranged this for our family in advance of our visit. I was somewhat skeptical given that I am a licensed Captain and tend to be more critical than the average lubber. This did not disappoint. We caught a spectacular weather day and the tour was informative and engaging. Charles is an affable fellow and provides a fine narrative....


More  



I absolutely loved this trip. Though we were a bit late (NOTE: Show up 30 minutes early to gear up) the tour guide quickly geared us up in waterproof and warm weather gear! We then embarked on an amazing journey of the San Francisco bay on the speedy (and stable) ribbed boat.
We saw all the major sites in San...


More  



It was such an amazing experience riding the Bay Voyager. Best views and best tour guide, Captain Charles! He was knowledgable, nice, humble and funny. He made sure to capture our experience by taking pictures of the group enjoying the wonderful views.

This was a fantastic way to experience San Francisco Bay! Captain Charles is a knowledgeable and experienced guide and he has thought of everything when it comes to making this trip fun and comfortable. Even though our trip was in the middle of a cold snap in December, we were perfectly comfortable in the all weather gear he provided. We...


More  



What a great experience !! Just continue reading the other reviews for more information - it's all true. Great trip, Charles was a very knowledgeable Captain, and afterwards you will find loads of photos on the web (taken by Charles) of your own special day !

If there is only one thing you do while you are in SF- make it this! We were in town for a quick trip and wanted to do something unique- we had researched and researched fun things to do and had our trusty list in hand, we'd even bought tickets in advance. Unfortunately (but then fortunately), we landed and found...


More  



The Bay Voyager trip is excellent. Considering that so much of the city's sights are either on or over the water, I booked this for my wife's birthday (we have just moved to San Francisco). From the start, this was a professional and fund trip with the captain, Charles, a really great chap who is clearly passionate and knowledgeable combining...


More  



Thank you Captain Charles! Amazing local knowledge, his Navy ship story was unexpected yet fascinating. Such a thorough trip, the most spectacular views of the Golden Gate I ever imagined seeing. ...you go right past the other side as well as Oakland too. One of the highlights of our 3 week USA road trip holiday :-)

title: Alcatraz Cruises, LLC, San Francisco
address: Pier 33, Alcatraz Landing, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
The short crossing on the ferry gave a great view of the island which grew bigger and more imposing as you neared it. The audio guided tour was well planned and the stories told interesting and gave a real feeling of what it was like. Great views back to San Francisco and of the Golden Gate Bridge too. Well woth...


More  



We booked in advance to make sure that we were able to get onto the tour although on the day it seemed like there was plenty of space for people to show up and come on the tour. The tours leave every half hour and the boat across to the island is quite large and can take a number of...


More  



We were able to get tickets very easily. The line was short; but that is probably due to being there in the down (winter) season. The ride to Alcatraz was quick & comfortable. We had to ride on the upper deck because people filled in the indoors section. There was a light rain so the seats were wet. But I...


More  



Visited San Francisco in June 2015 and the Alcatraz cruise was definitely worth it. My husband, 22 year old daughter and I went together and we were all completely fascinated by the audio tour. I highly recommend this experience.

My wife and I and another couple were in San Francisco for one day at the end of a cruise in November so we decided beforehand to take a cruise over to Alcatraz. We booked through Alcatraz Cruises because they are the only official ticket vendor for Alcatraz. Buying from somebody else means you are paying more to ride on...


More  



Amazing service, easy to find, ferry was fast, stable and clean. The boats ran on time and we really enjoyed the ride and alcatraz at the other end

Don't bother buying tickets from any other tour operator as basically you'll be paying more to go with these guys, who are the only people allowed to land people. There's a fab exhibition up in the new industries building showing pics/bio of convicted criminals

This is the only official ticket vendor for Alcatraz; so save yourself a headache and just buy from them. Was impressed with the efficiency they used to get people on and off the boat. There is also an abundance of return times to SF so you don't feel stuck.

Very interesting and educational. The audio tour is very well structured and keeps you hooked. The view on the bay is breathtaking.

We had a full day to spend in the city, and after making our own city tour (had a rental car), we decided to book this Alcatraz tour. In traversing the bay area, you cannot help but see the small island from various vantage points. The tours were booked-up, but we were placed on the waiting list for the evening...


More
