title: Japantown, San Francisco
address: Post and Buchanan Streets, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
I was there to eat some Japanese food and it was so good to have the nice restaurant there during the cold weather

While Japantown is by no means, Japan, it certainly has the feel of a small, Japanese train station strip mall with its restaurants, Daiso, and Purikura. We walked through the inside mall as most stores were closing, but we had a good sense of what this place has to offer.
The Kaiten Sushiya had beautiful cuts of fish on every...


More  



I wasn't expecting to visit Japantown while I was in town, but am really glad that I did. There's a quiet pedestrian street that you can walk along that's got a bunch of restaurants. If you like Ramen (Japanese noodles), you're in luck because it seemed like every restaurant has it on the menu.The Peace Pagoda was nice to see,...


More  



Yes, it was interesting to stroll around the mall. However, the area was disappointing as it is definitely lacking atmosphere and authenticity. Even our japanese friends call it "old".

While it may be aging, the indoor mall is a super fun place to walk around and purchase trinkets and other little goodies or just window shop. Definitely check out Daiso - everything is so cheap, you can't walk out without buying something!

Japantown is unfortunately not at all like San Francisco's Chinatown, and that's too bad. It's a small area with more of a mall type feeling and not that of a vibrant Japanese district. Yes, there are a few stand out shops and restaurants, but that doesn't overcome the general vibe of things, IMO. Hopefully things will improve with time. ....

This place kind of sucks. my sister made me go here because she is obsessed with Japanese culture. I figured it could be fun and i would find some cool restaurants and shops. I was so wrong. There is virtually nothing here. Its a bunch of empty streets with a few shops and a beni hani as the big restaurant...


More  



I've been to Japan many times and Japantown in SF is a terrible reflection of the real Japan. It's old, run-down and the food wasn't spectacular. In Japan, the toilets are super clean. In Japantown, you wouldn't want to go to the toilet if you have a choice. We had ramen at a restaurant where there was a long queue...


More  



It's clean, has some japanese shops, and a few pagodas or what they are called. Not a bad area to stay, but nothing special, actually.

Japan town offers an ugly run down shopping mall which i cannot recommend..... It reminds me of the 1970s no atmosphere
The outside Area with restaurants is nicer

title: Transamerica Pyramid, San Francisco
address: 600 Montgomery Street at Washington Street, Financial District, San Francisco, CA 94111
review_list:
It is a design icon and attraction for SF. You can't miss it on the skyline or from the street level.

The Transamerica Pyramid is the tallest skyscraper in San Francisco and the eighth tallest building in the world with a height of 260 metres(85 feet). Situated on 600, Montgomery Street, this commercial building with a unique pyramid structure is a beauty in itself. According to its architect, William L. Pereira, a pyramid is the ideal structure for a skyscraper as...


More  



The Transamerica Pyramid building in San Francisco will cue the viewer to recognize both the building and "The City" from almost any cityscape where it appears. A powerful architectural statement that is iconic cosmopolitan San Francisco
..

Transamerica building is a photo opportunity. You can't visit inside the building and there's no observation deck. But it is a unusual looking structure and it's great to photograph from all angles. I recommend walking right up to one of the corners and taking a picture straight up the side. If you're visiting San Francisco read up on the history...


More  



Since its construction the Transamerica spire has become another landmark of San Francisco. It really is a beauty from all angles and even standing right in front of it. You can go in and ride up for grand views. Has restaurants and shops adjacent. Nice! ...

A beautiful landmark in the big city of San Francisco. We didn't get the opportunity to go inside for which we were disappointed.

its one of things you can zip by when in the bay area. Noting special like the empire state in NY.
Can be avoided for other SFO super attractions.

Clearly the Transamerica Pyramid is the unique feature that identifies the San Francisco skyline. It's best viewed walking down Columbus Avenue. You can go into the lobby but not enter the building otherwise. There is a gift shop and a small park adjacent to the building that's worth a look.

Anyone who has ever visited San Francisco must have seen this pyramid shaped building in the eastern part of the city. Until now I never actually visited the pyramid, but this time I walked past it. Aside from its unusual shape it has a special park next door. A small park hosting Redwood trees. Which are rare in itself, normally...


More  



Know by most of us as the pointed building, it is a good landmark in the financial district of the city.

title: Treasure Island, San Francisco
review_list:
Located between San Francisco and Oakland and accessible from Bay Bridge, Treasure Island provides great vantage points to view the Bay from various angles.

TI is not what it once was when operated by the Navy. Parts of it are now owned by SF, mostly low income housing toward the rear and some other old buildings. The rest is gated off, the dilapidating barracks area. If you want view of the City for a backdrop then this place is a 5. Not much else...


More  



Great views of the city at night and the bay bridge lit up from treasure island. It also gives you and excuse to cross the very impressive bay bridge if coming from San Francisco.

title: Transamerica Pyramid, San Francisco
address: 600 Montgomery Street at Washington Street, Financial District, San Francisco, CA 94111
review_list:
It is a design icon and attraction for SF. You can't miss it on the skyline or from the street level.

The Transamerica Pyramid is the tallest skyscraper in San Francisco and the eighth tallest building in the world with a height of 260 metres(85 feet). Situated on 600, Montgomery Street, this commercial building with a unique pyramid structure is a beauty in itself. According to its architect, William L. Pereira, a pyramid is the ideal structure for a skyscraper as...


More  



The Transamerica Pyramid building in San Francisco will cue the viewer to recognize both the building and "The City" from almost any cityscape where it appears. A powerful architectural statement that is iconic cosmopolitan San Francisco
..

Transamerica building is a photo opportunity. You can't visit inside the building and there's no observation deck. But it is a unusual looking structure and it's great to photograph from all angles. I recommend walking right up to one of the corners and taking a picture straight up the side. If you're visiting San Francisco read up on the history...


More  



Since its construction the Transamerica spire has become another landmark of San Francisco. It really is a beauty from all angles and even standing right in front of it. You can go in and ride up for grand views. Has restaurants and shops adjacent. Nice! ...

A beautiful landmark in the big city of San Francisco. We didn't get the opportunity to go inside for which we were disappointed.

its one of things you can zip by when in the bay area. Noting special like the empire state in NY.
Can be avoided for other SFO super attractions.

Clearly the Transamerica Pyramid is the unique feature that identifies the San Francisco skyline. It's best viewed walking down Columbus Avenue. You can go into the lobby but not enter the building otherwise. There is a gift shop and a small park adjacent to the building that's worth a look.

Anyone who has ever visited San Francisco must have seen this pyramid shaped building in the eastern part of the city. Until now I never actually visited the pyramid, but this time I walked past it. Aside from its unusual shape it has a special park next door. A small park hosting Redwood trees. Which are rare in itself, normally...

Know by most of us as the pointed building, it is a good landmark in the financial district of the city.

title: Moscone Center, San Francisco
review_list:
Best Time of our #superbowl50 weekend. Got a chance to see #antoniobrown of #steelers and lots of fun activities even for adults like us. #sanfrancisco was great host city!

We had a fun day at NFL Experience at the Moscone Convention Center. It was a special exhibit that was held for Super Bowl 50. It was a very large event that had outdoor areas, and also filled the North and South Hall of the Moscone Center.
There were many things to do at the event. There were many activities...


More  



Moscone Center is a top notch, world-class Event Center. It is modern, clean, well laid out and centrally located. Unlike many enormous Convention Center, Moscow Center feels very much like it is tailored to the event it is hosting.
Bathrooms immaculate.
Snack bar good food and good service.
Event staff relatively helpful.
Moscone Center is absolutely enormous. The underground convention...


More  



This past January 2016, I again, had the pleasure of attending the Winter International Fancy Food Show at the Moscone Convention Center, in beautiful San Francisco. The Moscone Center is one of the nicer/modern convention centers in the United States. This show was Very well planned,with a Terrific Staff as well as Signage thru out the show/center. The Moscone Center...


More  



It's functional. Also it's close to shopping. But it doesn't have a lot of charm nor restaurants.
the rooms are big, but not overwhelming. The small break out session rooms are fine.

I have attended AGU here last week.
I can only say that Moscone Center(s) is a great place to host big international conferences.

Site of the annual Fall meeting of the American Geophysical Union hosting approx. 25,000 geoscientists each year. Meeting rooms are generally very accessible, audio-visual is always on point. Would be nice if there were more food options in the center, but there are plenty of nearby locations. Would be nice if there was an indoor connection between each of the...


More  



This has been a really good convention centre for some time now. Facilities remain contemporary. Easily accessible to lots of hotels close to centre as well as Union Square.

Moscone Center is a fascinating place to attend a convention or Apple world as I did many times. Fun to go back and see its progressive growth and hyper utilization of all aspects. The area has gentrified nicely from the old slummy days not so long ago. ...

As a venue for a conference the place is like most others, but unlike most centers it is situated very close to the center of the City. There is a foodcourt just across the Street with many options. I do not Think it is something to go see as an attraction.

title: Wells Fargo History Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
A place where you can experience the cradle like movement of a stagecoach, while hearing the words of Mark Twain and others referring their own experiences more than one hundred years ago. Nicely displayed, the history of those journeys, the bandits and all that

Ok, if I had to pay for this museum I wouldn't have rated it so highly. However, in an expensive city, this is a gem for a family. Small, but if you are in the financial district, pop in. The kids can jump in a stage coach and see how small it was especially when you are told 9 people...


More  



Interesting to learn about the beginnings of this banking behemoth, and so much of the story of the Old Wild West. Bring the kids!

The bank that won the West had tales, movies and TV shows which captivated a generation (and may be in reruns, who knows?) and spun off one of the largest financial institutions of today. The great museum takes you from pony express & stagecoaches to the Net world of today's finances. Price is right, it's free and it's worthwhile! Enjoy...


More  



A little museum showing the history of the Wells Fargo company and, by extension, that of the West and America. A mixture of historic artefacts and interactive games make it a fun, little, free museum. You can have you photo taken with a real Wells Fargo wagon, print your own shipping manifest, and read about Wells Fargo's more recent innovations....


More  



We stumbled upon this on a walk into the shopping area and had to go in. As a kid I always loved playing with my timpo cowboy and indian figures and Wells Fargo stagecoach toys. This brought it all to life . There's lots of little interesting activities to do here. My wife who worked in the banking industry found...


More  



This is right in the Financial District of the city - - its a very interesting look at the history of the Bank as well as of San Francisco - - never a line to get in and well worth a visit.

We found this free museum informative and enjoyable. It was interesting reading about the history of the Coaches and the Pony Express. I hadn't realised The Pony Express only was in operation for 18 months before being taken over by the railroad.

Slightly difficult to fine (maybe we just had a bad map) but this is a great stop. My four year old daughter loved riding in the carriage and seeing the various exhibits.

Being a western fanatic this had to be high on my list of musts. Randolph Scott was missing along with Doris Day but my imagination made up for their loss. A very interesting museum but not a lot to see reall and if you take the wrong turning inside you end up in Wells Fargo Bank.

title: Nob Hill, San Francisco
review_list:
It is a tough walk uphill to get here (at least from the Financial District), but well worth the walk to see some amazing architecture (Fairmont, gentlemens club, etc) and, of course, Grace Cathedral with its melodic bells. Adjacent to the cathedral is Huntington Park where you can relax in a green space with fountains and there were artists displaying...


More  



Put your Fit Bit on, head out early and walk this beautiful part of the City; if you get tired you can jump on a cable car as Nob Hill is one of the few remaining areas of the City that have them. The architecture is amazing as are the views. We felt very safe and the locals were doing...


More  



We found it had lots and lots of houses there very big and looks very grand so I can see why all the rich lived there!
You will find you can see excellent views of San Francico from this location

For visitors and residents of the city this is a lovely thing to do during the holiday season. We parked at the Sutter Stockton Garage and made our way up to Nob Hill and the Fairmont Hotel where the lobby is brimming with holiday cheer. It features a magnificent tree in the center of the lobby and a two story...


More  



We stayed in Nob Hill on our SF trip in April, and we loved it! excellent location, very close to Chinatown and close to Union Square. Hop on a cable car and you're just a few minutes away from everything that SF has to offer.

Come and hob-nob with the snobs. Well we didn't see any snobs but we saw a lot of great architecture and interesting places. Been to SF many times but first time here. Glad we did. It is interesting as is the whole city, just another pocket of different interesting. We came to see church which was great.

You'll likely pass by Nob hill in your taxi or from the cable car as it isn't a top destination with lots of attractions, except the graceful cathedral. It's flanked with top notch hotels, bars and restaurants and that alone is reason enough to visit. ...

There is really nothing special about this attraction (except at Christmas.) The rest of the year you can just take the tour bus and wave as you pass by.

This part of the CITY is wonderful. Take the cable car ride to NOB hill.. Get out and walk around. Some of the world finest hotels and restaurants are here.

One of the hills in the city of San Francisco that deserves a visit. Though not the highest there is a lot to see.
Walking up and down that neigbourhood and enjoying the views and typical local housestyles is already worth it.
And there are other things like the Cable Car museum for example

title: Marina District, San Francisco
address: Chestnut St (btwn Divisadero and Fillmore), San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Waterfront of Marina area is really beautiful and relaxing to walk. Sea view with Golden gate and seagulls around have very serene look. One can pass hours together just watching people and activities in the area. Lovely area to visit..

A visit to this area was part of our Extranomical Day Tour that covered all the diverse areas of the city including the Marina District. A lovely part of the city.

This is one of the best places to stay in San Francisco. The neighborhood has many great places to stay (inns, motels, hotels) and is also well-known for its restaurants. This is fairly affordable too. Close to the Fisherman's Wharf as well.

Enjoyed walking around, but didn't really visit too many of the shops. I wouldn't necessarily go back. Would rather spend my time wandering around Pier 39 and the surrounding streets.

Pretty views and lovely water front with grassy park areas for enjoying the views. Beautiful architecture and beautiful homes along the water front and great village shopping on union street.

Loved being here great sites to see friendly locals don't forget to take pictures this area is great for tourists .

The Marina is all about food, fun and enjoying an easy day less touristy than other famous parts of the city. Chestnut street is the gateway to the Palace of Fine Arts and the Presidio with a spectacular view of the Golden Gate bridge from the waterfront. Spending time and seeing SF on foot is the only way to experience...


More  



This was one of those places I loved walking around. All the promenade around the marine offer the most amazing breathtaking views like at "the wave organ". It is also the district where the Palace of fine arts is located; a lovely surprise for your eyes!

Love the architecture and ambiance of the Marina district, but it's so flat that you can easily get lost after navigating the hills of San Francisco. Lots of little shops, boutiques, stores and restaurants to frequent. Close by the bay. Enjoy. ...

Lots of shopping and cool eateries in the Marina District. The scenery was one to take in for sure; relaxing yet hip. Everything's so colorful, cool, nostalgic.An old motel from the 1960's now an apartment complex was a real highlight for me. I could vividly see the beauty left from the old structure as well as the contemporary spin added...


More

title: Union Street, San Francisco
address: Union Street Association: 1686 Union St., Cow Hollow, San Francisco, CA 94123
review_list:
Union Street runs east/west through a large portion of San Francisco, from Montgomery Street to the Presidio. I like the section in the Cow Hollow Neighborhood best because of its look, atmosphere and myriad offerings.
Lovely Edwardian and Victorian structures contribute heavily to the makeup of the shopping district here. The area is clean with well-maintained buildings. Young adults, reflecting...


More  



Best spot: Union Street and Polk street. These area is filled with sympathetic shops, small restaurants and cafés. After visiting Lombard strret is a good walk to get to know the area, and being able on the way to enjoy the bay view to Golden Gate.

After seeing this street in a number of movies and programs it was on our list of must sees. We walked up from Fisherman's Wharf. While a bit of a hike, it was not too bad and worth the effort.
Next time I will get a taxi to take me down the street as well.

Union Street seems out of the way only until you get ther and discover the vibrancy of it. Besides, if a street has its own Assiciation then there must be a lot going on, and it is as you'll experience. It's quite a long street to explore but coming back next time to where you left off is part of...


More  



very cool street. saks fifth ave down the street. great area lots to see and do. reminds me of the new york of the west coast.

We stayed close to Union Street, so it was my main shopping destination. There are lots of different shops here and some good food places too including the excellent Roam Burger and La Boulange for coffee. It really reminded me a lot of Bridge Street (in its better days) in Richmond, Melbourne. I found it much more relaxing to shop...


More  



Looking for shopping place? You will not find anything better than Union Square. Also you can eat here or have a drink. Everything in one place.

There are more shops on Union than anywhere in the City. There are also a large number of homeless people in the area. Be careful.

We were walking down the street as our hotel was very close by and every corner there were homeless people asking for money. I love this city and it has a great vibe but there are just too many homeless asking for money. I don't care about it too much but if you're with young children or elderly or people...


More  



We did a little shopping and a little wine drinking at the Union street shops in cow hallow.
Very pleasant. Nothing in terms of shopping, eating and drinking that you will not see in other great cities, but pleasant on a warm afternoon.

title: St. Mary's Cathedral, San Francisco
address: 1111 Gough Street at Geary Street, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Typical 1970 architecture, nice touches and some nice depictions of Christ, Mary, nativity scene, and other things Christmas. Impressive place, but will take some of the gothic style over this one.

Its not a popular place among the turists, but definetly worth the visit, beautiful inside and outside.
Take some time inside and feel some peace.

Don't be put off by the outside of the cathedral. It may seem odd to some, but it's worth going inside. The play of colours is stunning and can only be really experienced in person.
Even if you don't have a lot of time, spend 5 minutes inside to bathe in the colours and atmosphere they create.

Went to Saturday evening mass, quite poorly attended though peaceful and prayerful. Nobody welcomed me though!

Modern cathedral which somehow manages to incorporate the traditional aspects at the same time. As someone has already said, it is a work of art. There are windows at each corner of the cathedral and provide light, and views of San Francisco. Over the sanctuary, there is a kind of loose sculptural structure hanging down - I thought it was...


More  



I've been to a lot of Catholic churches and have never seen one like this. The design inside is unique. Worth a few minutes to check-out, then go to Japantown to see the Peace Plaza.

If you go when it's open, you can walk the labyrinth. A special experience! A slice of Europe in the middle of SF, definitely worth a visit.

We went to pray few church in USA among them we found this one is quite Modern with all the up date facilities and very peaceful environment. The main important to prayers are peaceful place where they can have plenty of time to communicate with supreme. Travelers must visit this this place.

WOW!!! What an experience! I have a background in engineering and this Cathedral is spectacular!! What appears to be very modern and simplistic at first glance, is quite complex and impressive as you explore. The architecture is magnificent and speaks for itself but when you stand back and take a moment to appreciate the symbolism throughout the cathedral you can't...


More  



Nothing I imagined could have prepared me for this modernistic cathedral clad in white travertine marble. The absence of a symbolic cross (other than on the roof) on the exterior belies the magnificent architectural masterpiece housing the altar. The interior is a 19-story squarish dome supported by four immense concrete pilings. Given frequent earthquakes, I imagined the true definition of...

Going there you had another hall that eventually led to a parking garage. The hall had an elevator that indicated the Bart station was on another floor. After a lot of wasted...

I was very impressed by the BART system. From SFO Airport it was simple and convenient to acquire a Clipper card and find the station. The BART was a pretty decently priced service especially compared to other options.The train was clean and easy to board/disembark with suitcases. If you are staying in an area that is not directly on the...


More  



Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) provides regional rail service, both above and under the ground, throughout the San Francisco Bay area, with an extension to San Jose currently under construction. Trains offer five routes, vary in length from 4 to 10 cars and generally do not exceed 70 mph.The myriad times I've used this convenient public transport, I've found the...

Bay Area Rapid Transit fondly knowm as BART, operates 5 routes with 44 stations in 4 counties. It is not cheap but the conveniences outbeat the price! BART is a...

Awful and terribly smelly
It is the worst place ever. If you can avoid it, do it. Homeless people use it as their bathroom and bed. They are everywhere. Scary and gross. Use uber.

I used the Bay Area Rapid Transit many times during my 7-day trip to San Francisco from July 29th to August 3rd.

It was great to take one form of clean, fast, efficient and reasonably priced transport to an from our hotel near Union Square in the city.

When it was first suggested that I catch the BART to travel from San Francisco Airport to Orinda (my final destination) I was sceptical. title: Sea Lion Center, San Francisco
address: The Embarcadero at Beach Street, c/o Aquarium of the Bay, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
Stopped here while at Navy Pier just to see what all the noise was- ended up staying and watching their antics for over an hour! There are about a dozen huge rafts set up where the sea lions sleep and sun themselves, and it is highly entertaining to watch their social interactions. The museum was closed (after hours), but on...


More  



Sea lions are just interesting animals. They're fat and loud and obnoxious and graceful and friendly. The Sea Lion Center explains them very well, and provides an area on Pier 39 where you can see hundreds of them just lounging around all day and night. What an incredible sight, and absolutely free. Can't beat it.

Look this was one f those places that just surprise you. You take a walk and go to the embarcadero and enter the pier 39.
Move through all those shops stuffed with turist and go up to the second floor on the left side! There youll find a viewing platform from which you can see all those sea lions taking...


More  



The Sea Lions are fun to watch and it's great that so much has been made of them as they are protected and here to stay courtesy of the Marine Mammals Act. You won't see any fisherman visitors because those pesky blubber balls got far eating the fish out of their proverbial nets. Fun to ponder and great for kids....


More  



On another area (WILL NO BE NAMED FOR THIS REVIEW), I one of only two to write positive of this place/attraction! One person he/she gave only ONE STAR, saying free but only took him/her ten minutes see!
Please ah please ah please people stop with the complaining! Yes is free, but child friendly! I not visit any place no child...


More  



If you're like me and love animals you will love this. I could watch the sea lions for hours! If you're a bit sensitive to smells maybe not for you

This is a small place but it is educational and friendly. It seemed to be more geared towards young children but we liked looking at the sea lion skeleton as it was interesting. The main attraction, however, is the hundreds of sea lions sunbathing and swimming just below the pier. They were so noisy and kept us entertained with their...


More  



I loved every moment. They were noisy and fat and they posed for pictures. I could have spent all day there

Very noisy, very crowded, but a great place to see the sea lions. We visited in mid-June, and there were about twenty sea lions on the docks. They are so cute! One of them swam right below the viewing area and stared us down. This is definitely the best thing to do at Fisherman's Wharf.

Wow what a day!! There were at least a 100 of the sea lions laying on the piers barking at each other as they played, fought, and swam around. A sight to behold! Marvelous creatures!

When it was first suggested that I catch the BART to travel from San Francisco Airport to Orinda (my final destination) I was sceptical. During our trip to SFO, we relied entirely on public transport instead of renting a car. We realized how convenient it is to use bart, muni and other transport options in SFO. title: Civic Center, San Francisco
address: Off Of Van Ness, San Francisco, CA 94118
review_list:
The Civic Center is comprised of San Francisco's City Hall, Davies Symphony Hall, the War Memorial Opera House and the War Memorial Veteran's Building. All but the Davies Symphony Hall are built in the Beaux Artes style beautifully. Each building is worth visiting. We have attended many concerts in each one of them. The Herbst Theatre in the War Memorial...


More  



If you are visiting San Francisco stop by the Civic Center. If the outside is impressive, the inside is breathtaking. The main floor has the big stairs under the dome and in the third floor you have the balconies where you'll have a great view of the windows and the first floor.

Stop by during the morning, where there are fewer homeless characters running around. The architecture of City Hall is beautiful, and the Asian American Art Museum. There's a bustling farmers market about 3 blocks east of City Hall.

Many of the reviewer pix posted on TripAdvisor are not of the Civic Center that somewhat resembles the White House; they’re of City Hall on Van Ness that looks like a black-domed US Capitol Building. The Civic Center does not have a domed roof and is behind City Hall, and is adjacent to Asian Art Museum. As a civic center,...


More  



I always passed through Civic Center on my way to home from BART metro during sunset time, and the view is always adorable. Try to walk toward Van-Ness Avenue since there are a lot of fancy cafes to hangout

San Francisco civic precinct would be at home in ant old world city. Great buildings that make up the government and cultural heart of the city. Well worth visiting.
There were great farmers markets nearby also on the Sunday morning that we visited.
Yes there were some homeless and yes I saw one pee in the street. But this is...

A beautiful historical place, now used for many day to day activities.It was nice visiting this great place. Well worth a visit.

title: Sea Lion Center, San Francisco
address: The Embarcadero at Beach Street, c/o Aquarium of the Bay, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
Stopped here while at Navy Pier just to see what all the noise was- ended up staying and watching their antics for over an hour! There are about a dozen huge rafts set up where the sea lions sleep and sun themselves, and it is highly entertaining to watch their social interactions. The museum was closed (after hours), but on...


More  



Sea lions are just interesting animals. They're fat and loud and obnoxious and graceful and friendly. The Sea Lion Center explains them very well, and provides an area on Pier 39 where you can see hundreds of them just lounging around all day and night. What an incredible sight, and absolutely free. Can't beat it.

Look this was one f those places that just surprise you. You take a walk and go to the embarcadero and enter the pier 39.
Move through all those shops stuffed with turist and go up to the second floor on the left side! There youll find a viewing platform from which you can see all those sea lions taking...


More  



The Sea Lions are fun to watch and it's great that so much has been made of them as they are protected and here to stay courtesy of the Marine Mammals Act. You won't see any fisherman visitors because those pesky blubber balls got far eating the fish out of their proverbial nets. Fun to ponder and great for kids....


More  



On another area (WILL NO BE NAMED FOR THIS REVIEW), I one of only two to write positive of this place/attraction! One person he/she gave only ONE STAR, saying free but only took him/her ten minutes see!
Please ah please ah please people stop with the complaining! Yes is free, but child friendly! I not visit any place no child...


More  



If you're like me and love animals you will love this. I could watch the sea lions for hours! If you're a bit sensitive to smells maybe not for you

This is a small place but it is educational and friendly. It seemed to be more geared towards young children but we liked looking at the sea lion skeleton as it was interesting. The main attraction, however, is the hundreds of sea lions sunbathing and swimming just below the pier. They were so noisy and kept us entertained with their...


More  



I loved every moment. They were noisy and fat and they posed for pictures. I could have spent all day there

Very noisy, very crowded, but a great place to see the sea lions. We visited in mid-June, and there were about twenty sea lions on the docks. They are so cute! One of them swam right below the viewing area and stared us down. This is definitely the best thing to do at Fisherman's Wharf.

Wow what a day!! There were at least a 100 of the sea lions laying on the piers barking at each other as they played, fought, and swam around. A sight to behold! Marvelous creatures!

title: Fort Mason Center, San Francisco
address: Buchanan Street and Marina Boulevard, San Francisco, CA 94123
review_list:
There are lots of things to do and lots of beauty to see at Fort Mason!
We've enjoyed the little museums, checking out the Friends of the Library bookstore, eating at Greens, looking out over the bay, wandering around and serendipitously finding magic, as so often happens in San Francisco!

I live in San Francisco, hadn't visited what is now called the Fort Mason Art and Cultural Center in a few years. Actually part of the Golden Gate National Parks system, it's a beautiful location with oodles of history. I visited twice recently, once to attend the grand opening of Flax Art Materials, (when I stumbled into the Urban Epicurean...


More  



Leisure walk from Town to Fort Mason to the Sunday event there. Food trucks selling various food and Sunday markets where you see all kinds of stuffs from local designer. Refreshing...

Today we were fortunate enough to enjoy this sound installation/sculpture at Fort Mason in Building A. It was absolutely magnificent and I would urge anyone who is in the vicinity to book your ticket and go to this event. It goes on until January 18th. Doesn't take long to experience it and is never to be forgotten.

Fort Mason is a spacious area that is perfect for conferences and large events. It is located close to the water and has amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge (especially at sunset!) and the Bay in general.

From Army base to wonderful green space the Ft. Mason area offers super vistas of the Bay plus nice walkways. I like to park here and walk over to the Fisherman's Wharf area, as it's quite scenic and fun. You'll enjoy. ...

I stumbled upon this attraction after walking down from my hotel to the bay, and was lucky enough to pick up a free 'Fort Mason History Tour' booklet and map from the Fort Mason Center (Landmark Building A). It filled in 45 minutes nicely in mid-afternoon when I had nothing planned. Most things close at 4pm but the series of...


More  



Free, easy parking. Walk to the nearby neighborhood for the bus. Cross over the hill for quick access to Ghiradelli square and fisher mans wharf. The views of Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge are lovely.
Every spring and fall the SF library offers an awesome book sale. Visit on the final Sunday of the sale for dollar book sales.

The Sunday Farmers' Market, craft fairs and annual SF Library Book Fair are fantastic. Also, small art galleries and Greens restaurant make this a terrific destination when visiting San Francisco.

My boyfriend had traveled all of Europe in hostels and I had never experienced it before. He found this quaint little place on the internet and we were able to upgrade to have our own closed-door private hostel room. It was the perfect way to ease into the hostel-travel-lifestyle for me and we had absolutely immaculate views the entire time...

title: SS. Peter and Paul Church, San Francisco
review_list:
We sometimes stop in to rest and relax, to sit and admire, while taking a break from wandering and eating, even though we have no connection to or interest in the religion.

A nice church as well from the inside. It's worth to step inside it.
Special for a church the street number is 666:)

Beautiful Gothic cathedral, stopped by for a prayer before making the steep walk up Filbert Street to Coit Tower.

We attended Mass at the church where Joe DiMaggio served as an altar boy. It is near his childhood home. It is within walking distance of Fisherman's Wharf.

I was in town for a few days on business and had to go to the post office a block away. I have been by here several times but never actually walked up to the church. It is very impressive and really stands out. The church bells are music to your ears and at night the lighting makes it regal....


More  



If you find yourself in the North Beach area, don't miss a stop into this church. The exterior is gorgeous - and the interior is equally impressive. Plus the church has a fascinating history - anarchists tried to blow it up several times in the years after it was built and one was killed as he tried to light the...


More  



Intricate and lovely. Impressive architectural design. Great appreciation, even from a non-Catholic. Definitely worth the stop if in the area.

This church is beautiful inside and out. Parts of several movies have been filed at this church including Clint Eastwood's Dirty Harry and Dead Pool and parts of Sister Act 2 were also filmed here. Joe DiMaggio and Marilyn Monroe had their wedding photos taken here after a civil ceremony.

A very marvelous and beautiful Roman Catholic Church with dual steeples. The church faces a neat park that allows for respite from walking.

Walking through San Francisco’s “Little Italy” area, I saw twin steeples on the other side of Washington Square, a triangular pocket park at Union and Columbus streets. When I approached the magnificent structure, I learned the name—presumably the purpose of the twin spires. There was a small service when I arrived, so I was able to experience the interior beauty...

title: Glide Memorial United Methodist Church, San Francisco
address: 330 Ellis Street, West of Union Square, San Francisco, CA 94102
review_list:
Glide is a must visit for a visitor, or those who live in San Francisco - students or professionals. The church is love based, and all different paths are welcome (religion, origins, colors...) The music is moving, and performed by the famous Glide Ensemble and the Change Band. Soloist Emma-Jean Foster is always outstanding. The stories that are being shared...


More  



Wanted to visit the Glide Church because of its history in the Peace, Love and Hippie generation, but found that that was back then, not now. The church is sited in a pretty run down derelict area with a large homeless entourage around it. Good luck. ...

People in San Francisco knows Glide and the amazing work that they do helping everyone in need: food, work, housing, professional skills, drug recovery, etc.
One of the jewels of the Church is their ensemble, you can not miss it.
On Sundays the church has two services: 9am and 11am.
If you are in San Francisco on a Sunday, you...


More  



I have marked this as average, which I feel I should not have done. I was unable to visit the church, as it was closed, but what made me extremely nervous was the area around it walking to it. It is Scary, it is the home off homless People, but guess this is one of the Great Missions that this...


More  



This church is in one of the worst slums in San Francisco. It is not a safe area at all. Parking is very difficult and your car may be broken into. Avoid it.

I have never experienced 'Church' like this. Rock music to sing Hymns to, real rock and roll. Get there early because this place gets packed. You could see a movie star you would know. The regulars are warm and welcoming. The sermon is straight out of the movies. Go and experience something that is a real San Francisco event. This...


More  



I had the opportunity to attend Easter Service at Glide. What a wonderful experience! Service was filled with powerful music and powerful preaching. While the Sanctuary was filled to overflowing, the congregation was welcoming. You have to be open to gospel music and congregation participation but this was the highlight of my trip to SF.

There's no cross in the sanctuary and their brochure explains it was removed by the pastor in the 60's because it was a sign of death and they're more interested in life. Apparently their pastor did not read about the Resurrection in Seminary. Particularly depressing was his "Jesus Christ can't do it by himself" comment. This place ought to have...


More  



I had a great experience in this Church. I went to the Sunday service and it was energetic, spiritual and empowering in my opinion. I have been living in the states for 20 years but never have the chance to visit a church of this kind…meaning singing, cheering etc. If you have the time visit and give some good donations....


More  



I've lived in numerous cities in the USA and have attended many types of religious institutions searching for one that practices what they preach. Glide is the ONLY one I've found where the community truly practices unconditional love for all people and the environment, as well as working for social justice. This is why I'm happy to support their programs...

title: Balmy Alley Murals, San Francisco
address: Off 24th Street, Parallel to Treat Ave and Harrison Street between 24th & 25th Streets., San Francisco, CA 94110
review_list:
My mother and I visited the Balmy Alley Murals on the morning of August 2nd. We had left our Airbnb apartment early in the morning to go for a long walk through the residential side streets in the Mission District.
We discovered many small alleyways with beautiful, colourful and unique murals on the way to the more well-known Balmy Alley...


More  



Another of San Francisco's very interesting side streets. I think it's worth going out of your way to see Balmy Alley. Some interesting colorful murals and some very interesting subject matter. Get a selfie with the San Francisco arrest scene.

Combined with Clarion Alley, the Women's Building, and other stray murals scattered throughout the Mission District, you'll get some really terrific and vivid photos. I took BART to 24th Street in the morning and headed over to Dynamo Donuts to grab a couple of their daily flavors and a latte (Philz is closer to BART if you don't want to...


More  



Impressive murals, each conveying its own message. Some were very intricate and elaborate, but all vividly colourful.
It's quite a short alley. Not many people here when I walked over on my own from the BART station in the late afternoon. Very glad to have had the time to cover this place!
Tip: Head over to the nearby Philz Coffee...


More  



Don't go here after the sun goes down. It's safe in the day but keep your head up. Don't drive your car down this alley, just walk.

So many different styles and stories filled this alley. It was worth taking the time to visit the different murals in the Mission District. Balmy Alley was my favorite of all the areas. It seemed to have more beautiful art and hopeful themes.

Lots of different styles of art abound on this long strip of art that is at the back of peoples' homes and garages. Very peaceful to walk along and admire the way the art has blended in with buildings and flowers/plants. Political messages, cartoon fun, collaging, stencils - all sorts to be found here. Lots of talent!

This alley in the Mission district is a definite must see if you are in the area—or even if you are not. The ¼ mile alley is paved and provides garage access to the homes on either side. All the garage doors and fences have been painted with colorful, unique murals. The alley just off 24th Street is well worth...


More  



I was recommended this spot after talking to the hotel manager about loving all the street art in San Francisco. After breakfast I took a stroll down here checking out all of the murals on 24th and then happily happened upon Balmy Alley. It's great to see the arts popping up in neighborhoods that have experienced financial difficulty. And to...


More  



Excellent colorful murals. Many by women and portraying women. Perceptive Political commentary and evocative religious imagery abound. A must see in the Mission Disrict.

title: Haight Street, San Francisco
review_list:
There are lots of restaurants, cafes, stores, and houses along Haight, as well as some park, and all sorts of people, including locals, streets kids, homeless, tourists, shoppers, workers, walkers, and the ghosts from the 1960s which still happily haunt Haight Street.

So diverse...interesting people, shops, cafés... I recommend the shop Wasteland, where you can find amazing bargains of clothing, really unique, as they offer old season's designers pieces. There is also a beautiful shop very well organized. Also a good street for leather shoes. Amoeba stre: a huge music store, close to Golden gate park that you can get lost and...


More  



Overpriced, underwhelmed, obviously an area for upmarket alternate professionals! It's a wanna be hippieville, no true hippie could afford this area, though there's heaps of vintage options. It's colourful but with a 18 and 16 yo in tow even they didn't appreciate the constant smell of weed!

One of the neighborhoods that most impressed me for its colors, houses full of unexpected details, unusual shops and is all hippies! It is fantastic!

Neat place to go for a taste of nostalgia. Try the Mexican Street food -- it's tasty, fast and cheap.

A unique part of the city that takes you back in time. There is a great amount of history here so worth doing as part of a tour.

I loved this place!!! It's a must every time I visit San Fran. I love the old hippish feel, although it's got modern day stores, something about just walking through here seems to transport you to the 60's. I ❤️ it here!!!!

We really enjoyed the stroll down this one of a kind street in San Fran. There are plenty of stores to stop and satisfy your trip back in time. Incense, clothing, books food, vintage stores, music...it's got it all. Yes, there are some unsavory looking characters around but non threatening in my opinion. Worth a stop if your touring the...


More  



Elayne Angel was doing a 3 day stint at this shop. She is amazing, knowledgeable, and really the best for the piercings she specializes in. Her reputation preceded her. What was a wonderful surprise was how nice and knowledgeable all the other staff in the shop were. My husband and I are probably not their typical customers (we're middle aged,...


More  



<3 <3 <3 This is a place you must visit in San Francisco! Friendly, amazing openminded, simply awesome By the way there is a wonderful grocery for organic food lovers <3 <3 <3

This alley in the Mission district is a definite must see if you are in the area—or even if you are not. The ¼ mile alley is paved and provides garage access to the homes on either side. All the garage doors and fences have been painted with colorful, unique murals. The alley just off 24th Street is well worth...


More  



I was recommended this spot after talking to the hotel manager about loving all the street art in San Francisco. After breakfast I took a stroll down here checking out all of the murals on 24th and then happily happened upon Balmy Alley. It's great to see the arts popping up in neighborhoods that have experienced financial difficulty. And to...


More  



Excellent colorful murals. Many by women and portraying women. Perceptive Political commentary and evocative religious imagery abound. A must see in the Mission Disrict.

title: Japan Center, San Francisco
address: Bordered by Geary Boulevard and Fillmore, Post, and Laguna Streets, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
In addition to its many Japanese shops and restaurants, which are fun to explore, I also like to sit and people watch and eavesdrop in its central Peace Park.

If you are into the Japanese culture this is a place that is a MUST. Lots of little shops, authentic food and great atmosphere.

This place is awesome featuring a bunch of traditional and modern restaurants, cafes, shops, grocery stores, and discount marts. Hidden on the other side of west mall is a great bookstore.

If you want to feel like in Japan, the best place is the Japan Center in the heart of Japanese Town, in San Francisco - California. Quiet atmosphere. A lot of Japanese restaurants there, my favorite ultimate dessert place " Sophie Crepe " is there. I like also the store: Daiso.

This was fun to see. Lots of shopping, food, and culture, but don't plan to spend a ton of time here.

title: Haight Street, San Francisco
review_list:
There are lots of restaurants, cafes, stores, and houses along Haight, as well as some park, and all sorts of people, including locals, streets kids, homeless, tourists, shoppers, workers, walkers, and the ghosts from the 1960s which still happily haunt Haight Street.

So diverse...interesting people, shops, cafés... I recommend the shop Wasteland, where you can find amazing bargains of clothing, really unique, as they offer old season's designers pieces. There is also a beautiful shop very well organized. Also a good street for leather shoes. Amoeba stre: a huge music store, close to Golden gate park that you can get lost and...


More  



Overpriced, underwhelmed, obviously an area for upmarket alternate professionals! It's a wanna be hippieville, no true hippie could afford this area, though there's heaps of vintage options. It's colourful but with a 18 and 16 yo in tow even they didn't appreciate the constant smell of weed!

One of the neighborhoods that most impressed me for its colors, houses full of unexpected details, unusual shops and is all hippies! It is fantastic!

Neat place to go for a taste of nostalgia. Try the Mexican Street food -- it's tasty, fast and cheap.

A unique part of the city that takes you back in time. There is a great amount of history here so worth doing as part of a tour.

I loved this place!!! It's a must every time I visit San Fran. I love the old hippish feel, although it's got modern day stores, something about just walking through here seems to transport you to the 60's. I ❤️ it here!!!!

We really enjoyed the stroll down this one of a kind street in San Fran. There are plenty of stores to stop and satisfy your trip back in time. Incense, clothing, books food, vintage stores, music...it's got it all. Yes, there are some unsavory looking characters around but non threatening in my opinion. Worth a stop if your touring the...


More  



Elayne Angel was doing a 3 day stint at this shop. She is amazing, knowledgeable, and really the best for the piercings she specializes in. Her reputation preceded her. What was a wonderful surprise was how nice and knowledgeable all the other staff in the shop were. My husband and I are probably not their typical customers (we're middle aged,...


More  



<3 <3 <3 This is a place you must visit in San Francisco! Friendly, amazing openminded, simply awesome By the way there is a wonderful grocery for organic food lovers <3 <3 <3

title: The Beat Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
Just got back. Museum is located between girly shows in North Beach. Easy to fine. Kerouak was before my time but got a kick out of the memorabilia. Owner was friendly and you can't beat the price of admission. Add it to your list of fun things to do while touring San Francisco.

A must-see attraction for all lovers of Jack Kerouak and his generation of friends. This museum, which boasts a small period movie theatre screening a documentary on the Beat Generation characters, is also a bookstore and souvenir outlet.
Located literally around the corner from the famous City Lights Bookstore, the $8 entry fee is money well spent.

Well worth the price of admission. The owner is friendly. The memorabilia is mainly books and some other things which are interesting.

We stumbled onto the Beat Museum after checking out Kerouac's hang-out across the street, Vesuvio. Both venues honoring the Beat legacy are on the same block as a concentration of neon-blasting strip-clubs, some pretty legendary.
The Beat Museum store is in the front (sort of overlit...but then Beats usually wore shades, right?). Kerouac's car is well-preserved and actually made me...


More  



If you're a fan of the beat poets, this is a fun museum to see. It's mostly books and artifacts, but also photos and some context (they could provide more context). The museum itself is quite disorganized, but I guess that makes sense given the subject matter. The museum store is also an experience, and they have lots of 1st...


More  



Worth the price of admission. Owner is very knowledgeable and friendly. Vinyl and books and memorabilia for sale in the shop. Recommended!

What a great little museum. Hidden gem that is great to explore, especially if you're into the beat generation. I thought they would have a lot more considering the City Lights is around the corner, but they do have quite a bit. Also, it does cost to get in, not so beatnik, but then again, this isn't the world of...


More  



This tiny museum is the best way to feel the beat generation and have a look at original books, pictures and keepsakes! The staff is nice, and in the bookstore you can find some gems and rare books!

This museum was everything that Jack Kerouac would want it to be, it is not too gentrified to commercialize the work of the beats, instead the museum communicates the attitudes, philosophies and works of the beat generations heroes in an engaging series of rooms and theatres that really capture the essence of the movement.

I'll be honest. I wasn't even aware there was a beat museum. My girlfriend and I had explored the neighborhood and were waiting for an Uber when we came across this place. We cancelled our ride and took a walk around and the place is awesome. Part museum, part book/music thrift store, this place has tons to check out. Even...

title: Washington Square, San Francisco
address: Union Street and Columbus Avenue, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
My wife and I recently visited San Francisco. While exploring the North Beach area we came upon Washington Square. There is a nice park here, with many small shops and businesses. It is a breath of fresh air for San Francisco

We always walk by here when we come to North Beach. This time we actually partook of a bench and watched the sky and the church after a big dinner at Original Joe's. People are friendly here and they bring their dogs on their nightly stroll. there is a small play area for kids down by Columbus Avenue. Nothing fancy...


More  



Staying near Union Square and going to Fishermans Wharf a lot we walked through Washington Square a number of times and called in for the odd drink. Really nice square a number of bars and a couple of hotels. Would be a great place to base yourself when visiting San Francisco.

Park wasn't anything great, but Saints Peter and Paul Parrish made the trip worth it. Beautiful and intricate. There is no Parrish store as the cathedrals in NYC. Would have loved to purchase a history book. Was nice to have a quiet place to reflect. Moving to say the least.

I find this park fascinating because there is always something going on here. On Sundays there are people lounging about the park having picnics, playing with dogs, and enjoying gelato and when it's nice in the morning there are different groups of people practicing Tai Chi, some practicing sets with fans, and other people just watching. Many buses have stops...


More  



This is a nice little green space in the hub of the North Beach area. Some great restaurants line the streets around this quiet little park.

We walked past many times but today we picked up dim sum, walked over here and ate in the park.
It's small but nice. Some of the benches are in the shade.

Returning from Fisherman’s Wharf district, I left the bus to visit Saints Peter & Paul Cathedral. I spied the twin steeples on the other side of a triangular pocket park at Union and Columbus streets. There’s not much to see, other than a majestic willow tree and a statue of, surprisingly, Ben Franklin. You’d think there’d be a statue of...


More  



We ran into Washington Square on our way to the awesome church located close by. This is a nice little section of town and was enchanting for about 30 minutes, long enough to catch our breath before heading back. It’s worth a brief respite.

Washington Square is in Little Italy and one of the city's first parks. Its a popular place to stop in North Beach as it has plenty of cafes and restaurants and there is also the imposing St Peter & Paul's Church.

title: Pacific Heights, San Francisco
address: 2356 Pine Street (at Fillmore), San Francisco, CA 94115
review_list:
Hilly Pacific Heights has the general boundaries of Bush Street, Presidio Avenue, Union Street and Van Ness Avenue. For those who enjoy shopping, many mostly upscale shops exist on Fillmore Street. As an architecture buff, however, I find it fun to amble through the quiet, residential parts of the neighborhood, looking at the myriad mansions and the lovely Painted Ladies...


More  



Aptly name Pacific Heights sports the San Francisco version of Beverly Hills or any top tiered area. The homes, many large upgraded Victorians, are fabulous to see and to imagine the views. Nice to walk through but better to drive through and admire. ...

A nice place to take a walk. Be prepared for the hills. Nice views of the city and the bay. Very nice and very expensive homes in the neighbourhood.

This area is just stunning. I spent 4 hours walking the street and marvelling at the wonderful architecture. A beautiful area worth exploring.

What a beautiful part of San Francisco as these gorgeous mansions grace the neighborhood. Uniquely adorned they show the richness of the area.

Located at 2356 Pine Street, near Fillmore, a collection of expensive Victorian homes delights visitors. Constructed in the 1890s these survived the 1906 earthquake and subsequent horrific fire. I found that by walking through the side streets many surprising delights. There’s a rather suggestive “Tin Man” at one home. That insightful people chose to restore and preserve these magnificent homes...


More  



I took the MUNI bus from the Mission District to the Pacific Heights neighbourhood. It was really enjoyable to walk around the neighbourhood and looking at the gorgeous, well-maintained mansions. The view from Broadway and Fillmore is stunning! This is a very hilly neighbourhood and the climbing is steep, but there are incredible views everywhere. The house that was featured...


More  



The section at the top of the hill at Broadway and Lyons and nearby s magnificent, both in terms of the houses and also the views.
Expect a very steep walk, no matter which direction you come from. But worth it.

The structures in this section are quite stunning. Very well maintained buildings give this area a defined looked. One can tell that a lot of money has been spent to maintain these homes. Nice to either walk or drive through and enjoy.

cool neighborhood, neat to see Mrs Doubtfire house. love architecture in Pacific Heights! Love San Francisco in general!

title: Pier 7, San Francisco
address: Embarcadero at Broadway, Financial District, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Definitely worth a stroll out to look over the bay. I proposed to my wife here so have very fond memories of the place :)

There are some lovely views from Pier 7 and the entire walk along these Piers is a great gentle walk..

The other piers are fun and exciting but if you’d like some time to just sit and talk without people taking photos and laughing (nothing wrong with that but…) and you just want to enjoy your partner’s company, pier 7 is a fabulous place.

Pier 7 is probably the most attractive pier in San Francisco. The rebuilt pier is solid with pretty black iron railings. We went in the morning, and I wasn't sure if it was worth walking all the way to the end because the morning sun does not give the best view of the Bay Bridge (afternoon sun might be better...


More  



Pier 7 is a public pier located along the Embarcadero. My wife and I spent quite a bit of time at Pier 7 during our recent eight-day stay in San Francisco, as it was a fairly close walk from the Hyatt Regency Hotel where we were staying. Pier 7 is less than a 10-minute walk from the Ferry Building. It's...


More  



Nice place to stroll out to. Beautiful views of the city and the Bay Bridge. Great spot for taking photos (and for fishing, if the number of poles is any indication).

During our visit to San Fransisco we stopped by Pier 7 after our walk along the shore. It was a pleasant and peaceful walk with a surprise seal show at the end of the pier. Nice, romantic setting that offers spectacular views; nothing likethe hustle and crowd of Pier 39! A must stop if you have some time to spare!

Pier 7 is a very nice place to walk for views of the San Francisco Bay, Treasure Island and of the East Bay. There are nice views of the Bay Bridge as well.

Very good place to visit in evening, to look on great views of SF Downtown and Bay Bridge. Sf in night is different. Cool spot.

This is a very nice pier to walk down. Great views with many picture opportunities! It wasn't very crowded and there is no one trying to sell you anything. It's nice and relaxing and a great alternative view of the city!

title: San Francisco Public Library, San Francisco
address: 100 Larkin Street at Fulton, San Francisco, CA 94102
review_list:
You'll smell old books, and homeless. Homeless like being sheltered here and occasionally reading. Great selection of books, videos, music, atlases, and whatever you are into. Pro-Tip, if short of time, ask a librarian. Otherwise, wander the stacks.

Good book sales, The area is kind of dirty. I have only purchased books from here and not spent too much time inside. But it looks like there is a lot of books and references. The book sales are fantastic I usually end up picking up a bag full to read.

For those that still want the texture of holding a book to read, I highly recommend the San Francisco Public Library. The computer system has united all branches with the Main Library so users can request an item, whether that be book, CD or DVD, to the their local branch for pick up. One can renew online too. Once satisfied,...


More  



The building was inaugurated by former Mayor Willie Brown. It clearly had a big budget and few expenses were spared maybe except for the plain, unimaginative exterior (as opposed to beaux arts.
The problem is that the building has been completely taken over by homeless drifters and junkies. In politically correct San Francisco, no progressive thinking liberal could ever impose...


More  



A great piece of contemporary architecture in the midst of the Beaux Arts civic center. Asian Art Museum next door and regular farmers markets in UN Plaza.

Many many boooks are housed in this beautiful Library. In this library you willl have internet access as well as printer access. It is a nice place to get in and away from the noises of the city.

Love the emense diversity of SFPL for having such a diverse community entering on a daily basis. Six floors of peace and calm in the Civic Center.

A totally professional approach,friendly,polite and accurate staff that help you find solutions easily.

There is no reason to visit the library. It's not like Boston or NY. The only thing to really see here is the overwhelming amount of homeless people in and around this building.
Do not use the bathroom in the basement.

You can't go wrong with SF's library - it's everything you want in a library in an updated building.

title: War Memorial Opera House, San Francisco
address: 301 Van Ness Avenue at Grove Street, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
We came to this venue to see the Nutcracker. It was our first time to this venue and we were pleasantly surprised by the history and architecture. We would definitely come back here to see another show!

My first time here. Came for the Nutcracker in December and was very impressed of the venue. The hall area was beautifully decorated in christmas and nutcracker themed decor. The tree was absolutely stunning and instantly put us in the christmas spirit. Arrive as early as possible in order to enjoy the ambiance, a beverage and to snap some photos...


More  



The Opera House was beautiful and was the perfect place to see The Nutcracker. The staff was polite and the house was grand. We had a great time. Even the inexpensive seats were fine for viewing the performance. Highly recommend a visit.

Our family of five came here to watch the Nutcracker.
Parking at the Performing Arts Garage was easy. Make sure to give yourself plenty of time to get there. It is a short 5 minute walk to the Opera House.
We arrived a little over an hour before show time. They locked the doors and we had to wait outside...


More  



I was so fortunate to recently attend opening night of the NUTCRACKER SUITE at the Opera House. It is so elegant, and they had "Snow" falling down from the Cupola's making it even better. From the old fashioned coat checks to the opulent interior, it will not disappoint. The acoustics are fantastic, and the view is good even from the...


More  



San Francisco opera house is one of the best opera company in norrh america. The building that houses the company is grandiose.

Beautiful venue! A Saturday evening performance of the San Francisco Opera at the War Memorial Opera House is quite a social event. La Boheme was the programme. We had some champagne before the performance and during the intermission. One can also choose to have dinner at the War Memorial before the performance. Parking is very organized.

I have had the opportunity to visit this opera house many times over the years. It has a comfortable amount of space, not too large and not too small. It is often full for weekend performances. The operas performed here vary from fabulous to an occasional mediocre performance. I highly recommend anyone to try an opera that they think they...

This magnificent structure was built in the early 1930's, and was the final contribution to the Civic Center of San Francisco of buildings designed in the Beaux Arts style. title: San Francisco Public Library, San Francisco
address: 100 Larkin Street at Fulton, San Francisco, CA 94102
review_list:
You'll smell old books, and homeless. Homeless like being sheltered here and occasionally reading. Great selection of books, videos, music, atlases, and whatever you are into. Pro-Tip, if short of time, ask a librarian. Otherwise, wander the stacks.

Good book sales, The area is kind of dirty. I have only purchased books from here and not spent too much time inside. But it looks like there is a lot of books and references. The book sales are fantastic I usually end up picking up a bag full to read.

For those that still want the texture of holding a book to read, I highly recommend the San Francisco Public Library. The computer system has united all branches with the Main Library so users can request an item, whether that be book, CD or DVD, to the their local branch for pick up. One can renew online too. Once satisfied,...


More  



The building was inaugurated by former Mayor Willie Brown. It clearly had a big budget and few expenses were spared maybe except for the plain, unimaginative exterior (as opposed to beaux arts.
The problem is that the building has been completely taken over by homeless drifters and junkies. In politically correct San Francisco, no progressive thinking liberal could ever impose...


More  



A great piece of contemporary architecture in the midst of the Beaux Arts civic center. Asian Art Museum next door and regular farmers markets in UN Plaza.

Many many boooks are housed in this beautiful Library. In this library you willl have internet access as well as printer access. It is a nice place to get in and away from the noises of the city.

Love the emense diversity of SFPL for having such a diverse community entering on a daily basis. Six floors of peace and calm in the Civic Center.

A totally professional approach,friendly,polite and accurate staff that help you find solutions easily.

There is no reason to visit the library. It's not like Boston or NY. The only thing to really see here is the overwhelming amount of homeless people in and around this building.
Do not use the bathroom in the basement.

You can't go wrong with SF's library - it's everything you want in a library in an updated building.

title: Fillmore Street, San Francisco
address: Between Jackson and Eddy Street, Pacific Heights, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
You have to check this out in San Fran just walking up and down the street getting a taste of the city. You will enjoy Fillmore street.

Fillmore Streey has EVERYTHING: incredible shops (Ruti's for clothes); Shoes; Cafe's (Peets) Restaurants (The Grove); book stores and much much more.

This is a historic street with all your shopping and browsing needs. Some great coffee houses and places for breakfast/lunch. I love to walk this city and Fillmore Street is a happening

We kept hearing how great Fillmore Street was to visit and decided to walk back to Union Street one afternoon after visiting the Painted Ladies/Alamo Square. We walked along Steiner up to Fillmore and the part where Fillmore crosses Turk near the Western Addition felt uncomfortable for me to say the least. I did not feel safe and wanted to...


More

I thought since we were there right after 4th of July it would be dead and the place was happening. Cool scene and vibes. Great little shops and trendy places to eat and listen to some real...


More  



We stumbled upon 4th of July street fair on Fillmore. The street was closed to traffic and many city blocks were taken by food vendors, arts and crafts and performing music bands. All the shops and restaurants along the street were open as well. It was so much fun!
I loved the variety of sounds, foods and of course the...


More  



Great cool area with a nice vibe. Great place to shop and eat or just walk around and people watch. Worth a visit while in San Fran

This is an over commercialized area of town which has lost most of what truly made it unique at one point in time. Use the hop on hop off bus and see it

This street has evolved over the years, and has become a very trendy place for restaurants and shops. You can also see many Victorian style houses.

The Omni concierge (he lives in the neighborhood) suggested Fillmore Street area as a great place to walk and visit boutique shops and restaurants, he was right. On a Sunday we walked the few blocks which was filled with people and dogs. Big variety of shops from Rag n Bones to local stores (Nest--stop in here). There are many restaurants...


More

title: War Memorial Opera House, San Francisco
address: 301 Van Ness Avenue at Grove Street, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
We came to this venue to see the Nutcracker. It was our first time to this venue and we were pleasantly surprised by the history and architecture. We would definitely come back here to see another show!

My first time here. Came for the Nutcracker in December and was very impressed of the venue. The hall area was beautifully decorated in christmas and nutcracker themed decor. The tree was absolutely stunning and instantly put us in the christmas spirit. Arrive as early as possible in order to enjoy the ambiance, a beverage and to snap some photos...


More  



The Opera House was beautiful and was the perfect place to see The Nutcracker. The staff was polite and the house was grand. We had a great time. Even the inexpensive seats were fine for viewing the performance. Highly recommend a visit.

Our family of five came here to watch the Nutcracker.
Parking at the Performing Arts Garage was easy. Make sure to give yourself plenty of time to get there. It is a short 5 minute walk to the Opera House.
We arrived a little over an hour before show time. They locked the doors and we had to wait outside...


More  



I was so fortunate to recently attend opening night of the NUTCRACKER SUITE at the Opera House. It is so elegant, and they had "Snow" falling down from the Cupola's making it even better. From the old fashioned coat checks to the opulent interior, it will not disappoint. The acoustics are fantastic, and the view is good even from the...


More  



San Francisco opera house is one of the best opera company in norrh america. The building that houses the company is grandiose.

Beautiful venue! A Saturday evening performance of the San Francisco Opera at the War Memorial Opera House is quite a social event. La Boheme was the programme. We had some champagne before the performance and during the intermission. One can also choose to have dinner at the War Memorial before the performance. Parking is very organized.

I have had the opportunity to visit this opera house many times over the years. It has a comfortable amount of space, not too large and not too small. It is often full for weekend performances. The operas performed here vary from fabulous to an occasional mediocre performance. I highly recommend anyone to try an opera that they think they...


More

It was dedicated to those who gave their lives in World War l, and was the first opera house in the country that was built with municipal funding. The City went...

title: Off the Grid, San Francisco
review_list:
So many options, but we chose Vietnamese take out from Little Green Cyclo which was delicious. There a few pop up areas that will feature some of the trucks as well.

Wow! So glad we stumbled upon this after our big walk. So many food trucks all in one location. There is a bar and live music. I just wished we had brought a blank along.
Families having birthday parties and kids kicking a ball. Great atmosphere

Great food truck event offering a variety of eats from pizza to sushi, ice cream vegetarian to bacon options for the carnivore foodies. Excellent for the entire family, day time shindig, groups, girls day out, couples quality time...whatever your vice.
It's free, open to the public and has the best view in town right off the marina. Seated in the...


More  



What to do on a beautiful sunny day in The City? Head to the Presidio for Off the Grid food trucks and tents before the end of November.
With a blanket in hand, and a big appetite after a long hike up to Twin Peaks, we found a great spot on the lawn, smack dab in the center of the...


More  



What a great concept! We stumbled upon this while waiting to watch the Blue Angels at the Presidio at Fleet Week. The only downfall was that I ran out of money and stomach space!!! This is the ULTIMATE Foodie heaven... The food trucks had unique and tasty combinations, and the stands had some unique flavors and traditional staples. It was...


More  



Staying near the Presideo we wanted to check this food truck area out. Lots of food trucks and more. Beautiful view, grassy setting. There was a VW car show, family's gathered on grass eating, listening to music, enjoying the beautiful day. Go out and take the family. Dog friendly as well.

I wish there was more of this in England. Great day for friends and families. Weather was great and a really nice friendly atmosphere, food choice excellent and local beers and stronger local produce available.

By far the coolest thing we did while in SF. Awesome food, drinks, and music. It's a great place to people watch, or relax for a nice evening. Truly a great community event and I was so glad we got to experience it.

We went to the one near golden gate park and Haight-Ashbury. The selection was great. We really enjoyed the Chilean beef and rice dish as well as the Myanmar truck.

i love(d)going to this place. Seems like it was such a success that everyone just started adding fillers as rice and frenchfries and a LOT of pasta with a tablespoon of a flavor of the country. plus they raised the prices.
so we quit going until yesterday (8/21/2015) and found it was pretty much the same. if you get a...
