title: Contemporary Jewish Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
The CJM is a cool museum with a hip edge, displaying both permanent and rotating exhibits that are always unique and interesting. The nice architecture, little restaurant, gift shop, and kids area are pluses. Right near SF MOMA and across from Yerba Buena, also highly recommended, the CJM is a worthy destination for your enjoyment and edification.

The exhibits here are always interesting. Do not miss Robbin Henderson's drawings of her grandmother's fascinating life, in the "Chasing Justice" exhibit; the drawings are amazing, and her grandmother's life story is truly compelling. I loved the bluegrass festival exhibit, complete with videos and lawn chairs set up to experience it "live." Always a great place, worth an hour whenever...


More  



The new Experience in Art and Technology was an amazing exhibit that unfortunately just closed, but I am so glad to have caught it. This museum has no standing collection but puts in several special exhibit a year. Also they have a branch of a California style Jewish Deli that is about as good as you can get on the...


More  



This was my first time there, the docent was knowledgeable and gave an overall tour of the museum. Even though one of the exhibits had just closed, there was more than enough to see. Enjoyed the waterfall that spelled out letters. Go!

First time visit, staff was very helpful, exhibitions were all good, nice gift shop. Will not be my last visit!

It was a rainy day and perfect for a visit to a museum. The CJM was perfect for a mid-afternoon visit leaving enough time for the things we wanted to see. We stopped at 3 exhibits. The Warren Hellman exhibit highlighting and honoring the man who founded the "Hardly Strictly Bluegrass Festival founded in 2001 now drawing 700,000 people to...


More  



I love this place and have now been here on 3 separate visits. Always educational and uplifting, makes me want to write and create.

The Contemporary Jewish Museum is home to an amazing art installation with several different attractions which change from time to time. There is an interesting bookshop and a cafe with traditional Jewish food as well as a splendid place for children to play.

Amy Winehouse exhibit from London Jewish Museum interesting and sad and gives a good sense of her; havruta exhibit, too weird and not particularly interesting; another exhibit was closed as they prepare for a new show; and the sculpture exhibit I saw featured on their website, alas, was a single sculpture, albeit interesting. Phenomenal architecture, thx Mr. Liebskind, so really...


More  



We went to the CJM since the Museum of Modern Art was closed for refurbishment. It had an entry fee, so we expected something quite extensive. There was an interesting exhibition about Amy Winehouse, which as Brits, we quite enjoyed, though it was fairly small. There was also an interesting exhibition on Space, Time and Beauty. Then we wandered round...

title: Dylan's Tours, San Francisco
review_list:
The best tour experience we could have ever hoped for.
Brits first time in SF!
Andreas was the perfect guide.
Informative and engaging.
Thanks for a beautiful experience!

lots of information, the highlights and lowlights of a fascinating city, a great way to orientate if you have a few days to explore more afterwards.

We had such a great time with Alejandro today, as we toured the city for 6 hours. He was full of knowledge, good humor as we biked around San Francisco. Up hills were a breeze thanks to the electric motors..highly recommend.

So glad I chose Dylan's tour. It was well worth the money. We had PEAR as ou guide and he was very informative and personable. We could have never done all the sites on our own. The van was very comfortable and we had a great group of people to share our tour. Would highly recommend Dylan's for your tour...


More  



Leila was our guide and we had a great time and she was fantastic!! I highly recommend this tour. She was great at giving local info and history of SF.

Dylan's Famous Tour (6 hours) is surely one of the most interesting, small group guided tours available in SFO. It takes you to several of the top sites in the city, crosses the Golden Gate Bridge to charming Sausalito and ends with a ramble through the magnificent Muir Woods redwood forest. Our guide/driver Leila was outstanding - her courtesy and...


More  



My 19 year old daughter and I did this tour in Jan 2016. I'm convinced it is the absolute best way to see the SF plus Sausalito & Muer woods!
Warning. This tour is all day so well worth its price tag!
Convenient Pickup & drop off. As the tour guide takes you to ALL of the hotspots in SF,...


More  



Layla was totally filled with facts about the city and was willing to make sure we see the best of what the city has to offer. There was something to see or hear the entire tour.
A+ ----- Just a great tour!

My partner and I hired two electric bikes and spent an awesome day touring the city on our own. Went over the bridge and followed the map that were given. Much easier than expected! Staff were very helpful getting us kitted up too.

My wife and I traveled to San Francisco to celebrate our 30th wedding anniversary and spent three days there. We wanted to see lots of sights without it being overwhelming and read the rave reviews about Dylan Tours. We were not to be disappointed! Our tour guide, Bob, a city native, did a fabulous job of guiding us around in...

title: Streets of San Francisco Bike Tours, San Francisco
review_list:
had great time in meeting new people and exploring the city in a active and fun way. Our guide Earl was very friendly, cheerful and made this a fantastic experience. If you have few days to spend in SF and want to visit and learn about how locals live, I highly recommend to take the Classic tour.

Very nice people, our guide Josh mixed views and stories with a perfect cycling experience. Really good experience, plenty of tipps for food and nightlife. I definitely go back there next time I'm in SF.

Josh was our guide for the day - Heart of the City Tour. The trip was the right mix of history, culture with local knowledge thrown in. Even though the city is known for its hills Josh managed to detour most of them. It is a great way to spend a day in San Francisco.

We had the best time on our Streets of San Francisco bike tour. Was a great introduction to a city with so much history, culture and art. Our tour guide took us to all the local hang outs and gave us great recommendations for other activities and places to go. Highly recommend this tour to anyone visiting San Fran.
We...


More  



We really enjoyed this bike tour. It was great way to see some of the non-tourist spots of the city and gave us a new appreciation for the uniqueness of San Fran. We'd recommend this to anyone. You don't have to be a good biker to keep up. Josh was a great guide with a lot of info to share...


More  



My husband, 16 year old son and I joined the tour with Elliott from San Something with Earle as our tour guide. We were given regular updates as the weather was inclement and unpredictable prior to take off.
The bikes were hybrids as expected but were fine for the conditions. Our guide Earle ( sorry if spelling is incorrect) was...


More  



One too tick off the bucket list! I hadn't been on a bike for nearly 15 years and I'm so glad I picked one up again had the most amazing day biking across the bridge then carried on and had a couple of drinks and lunch then biked back, we then caught a boat on the bay to watch the...


More  



I took Classic San Francisco Bike Tour, and found this very good. First, my tour guide, Earl, was friendly and kind. Also, compared to a bus tour I took, the bike tour made me feel like I was in the city much more. Lastly, I would like to recommend this tour to those who want to go on a bike...


More  



Small groups, highly informative, surprisingly flat. Learned loads about the hoods visited and cities rich history in just a few fun hours.

Could not think of a more perfect way to see SF! We did 'The Classic' tour on 23 November and despite the cold, we absolutely loved it. We saw many areas that we otherwise wouldn't have seen as tourists, and the local knowledge and history imparted by our guide Josh was invaluable. We especially loved seeing all of the different...


More

title: Wild SF Walking Tours, San Francisco
review_list:
I am in awe of all the information imparted by energetic and enthusiastic and delightful guides.
I thought I knew the Mission District. They took it to another level.
Fully recommend making a San Francisco visit complete by partaking in at least one of the waking tours offered by this company.
Thanks and Aloha!
Jill

I did two Wild SF walking tours when during my visit to San Francisco last month. Both were very interesting and I learned a lot! I did the Night Tour and the Chinatown tour. We had Wild Wes as a tour guide. Wild Wes was very knowledgeable about the city, its history and was happy to share information on highlights...


More  



My wife and I travel several times a year to different places it's been our best experience to have a guided tour then go exploring on our own.

Fun walking tour around Union Square and Chinatown with knowledgeable and quirky tour guide Fischer. We particularly liked the erhu shows and the alleys of Chinatown.

Absolutely awesome night walking tour of some of San Fransisco's darker past. In just over an hour and a few city blocks you'll learn and visit where some famous and not so famous names in history met their untimely end. Wes has an fantastic storytelling technique to make it all throughly entertaining and make the time fly by!

We took the Haight-Ashbury tour since we were interested in the musical background of the city. We wanted to learn a lot about the hippie times and what was going on in that time in that specific place. Our Tourguide Ozy was a great help in order to get to know this part of town with a delightful mixture of...


More  



This tour is very reasonably priced and that is just the beginning. Wes and Ben are fantastic story tellers and clearly have a great knowledge of the city and it's history. They engaged each person in the group and got to know them as well as talking with the whole group. It felt very personal and fun. We look forward...


More  



I really enjoyed the tour I took of the Castro, and learning about the history of the area. My guide, DW, was excellent; she brought a lot of energy and knowledge, and was able to answer all sorts of random questions the group had. I would highly recommend this activity for both residents (as I am) and tourists who want...

If you love culture, people, stories, and history, and are looking for an amazing experience WITHOUT the need to buy or consume more stuff....you will love the Wild SF tour. Wes is a brilliant story teller and historian. We were totally taken in by the tales of San Francisco that he wove.
He's also super-fun, creative, and genuinely nice and...


More  



Informative, fun way to spend two hours. Wonderful stories and songs about a special time in San Francisco history. Would love to do a another tour with this company on my next visit to San Francisco.

Very nice people, our guide Josh mixed views and stories with a perfect cycling experience. Really good experience, plenty of tipps for food and nightlife. I definitely go back there next time I'm in SF.

title: Buena Vista, San Francisco
address: 2765 Hyde Street at Beach Street, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
We were staying in the city prior to taking a cruise and went to the Buena Vista for a breakfast of crab omelets. We've been here a number of times over the years and always enjoy stopping at this bar/restaurant famous for it's Irish coffee (which we had with our breakfast). More  



The tour guide knew the Buena Vista was famous for their Irish Coffee and it was a treat. Frank, the bartender was an unusually friendly sole and a master of prestidigitation. He keep our crew mesmerized with his tricks. A must see if in the area.

The atmosphere is pleasant, the Irish Coffee is really good, but Tina the bartender made it fun. We will go back to Buena Vista next time we are in the city.

After riding the cable car from the Union Square we found the Buena Vista Pub and decided to stop in and relax before walking the Fisherman's Wharf. My wife and I had our first (and second) Irish Coffees. Really great! The service and ambiance were the best, we will be back.

Had a few Irish Coffees here one night, they sure have them down to a fine art and can churn them out fast. Still decent though.

I absolutely love the Buena Vista. It is a very jovial atmosphere with the very best Irish you can find. The waitresses are very pleasant despite the high crowds that they have to deal with. A must to visit!

Eat here. Cinnamon french toast or omelet. Period.
This place is well known, but it does have a great view, very good food, and reasonably priced. Showed up at 8:45 for 9 am opening. Plenty of rom even thought 30 people were in line by 9.

Stop at the Buena Vista for the best Irish coffee in SF and to watch the show. This is a sure way to shake off the chill and warm you up.

Yes, The Buena Vista Cafe is technically a restaurant but it is also an attraction not to be missed. If you love Irish Coffee this is where it all started. We were staying at tHe Argonaut across teh road, and visited on our forst night for a night cap. The coffees were so good we ended up visiting every night of our stay. Great service, good location but worth the trip for the Irish Coffee alone.

title: The View Lounge, San Francisco
address: 780 Mission St, Downtown, San Francisco, CA 94103
review_list:
This was a nice place to grab sunset drinks with a friend. Service was decent. Prices average for a nice bar in San Francisco.

We stayed at the Marriott Marquis SFO on Dec 31 last year and went to the View Lounge on the Top Floor of the Hotel for cocktails on NY eve. What a view and the best place to see the midnight fireworks. Try the homemade champagne cocktail and get a table next to the window.

Not much seating so get here early to secure a seat with a view, dress is casual to fancy. Take the high rise elevator to the 39th floor in the Marriott Marque on Mission St. Great little appetizers; we ordered the Pork Belly & Chicken Asian Lettuce wraps YUM! And the Ahi Poke style with Sesame crackers. A bit pricey...


More  



nice view , but Dinner no need > Lounge with just coctail is the better option . Restaurant is nice , but overpriced and you will find in walking distance much better options to eat

If you want to have drinks with an amazing view, The View is the right place. The prices are reasonable. I am definitely having a drink there again. They have good cocktails too.

My favourite place at San Francisco.. Great view.. Nice music. No need for reservations.. Affordable prices.. You see the whole Bay Area.. What else you need..

My wife and I stopped here for a couple of drinks and of course the view! A friend recommended this place to us. Great bartenders and really good cocktails. It's a great place to rest after walking around SF all day.

Beautiful lounge for a romantic evening. Go early because it gets crowded especially during sunset. Nice, relaxing lounge with gorgeous city view. Great appetizers. Highly recommended.

It's a perfect spot for a romantic date or a friendly get together. The view is of course amazing and the drinks are strong. The staff is fun and friendly. Come in early so you can get a table by a window.

This place exceeded my expectations. When you step off the elevator on the 39th floor, you utter wow. Floor to ceiling Windows with great views of the city. There's a variety of seating: the bar, couches, tall tables, booths, and comfy chairs.
Great place to bring out of town guests.

title: Grand View Park, San Francisco
address: 14th and 15th Avenues, Sunset District, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Beautiful views up there for a short effort of one hundred or so stairs. But wow ... it's gotten super popular and crowded. I got there near sunset and it was crowded with visitors. Despite the crowds, very well worth going. The views, while not as great as some other hills in San Francisco, are fantastic. Especially sunset over the...


More  



When in San Francisco (Inner Sunset) please drop by grand view park for a really grand view of the setting sun into the Pacific Ocean.
While it is a very steep set of steps to get there, take it slow for those not so fit, it is still doable and thoroughly rewarding experience.
This is really one of the great...


More  



This place is the best in the city for a sunset. It has great (almost) panoramic views. The city lights at night are simply stunning, and since there have been many clear days it has made the sky beautiful at sunset, plus you can see very far away. This would be a very romantic place to bring your lovers. Folks...


More  



This little park on a hill top in SF has amazing 360 degree views. Don't miss walking down from the park and enjoying the tiled stairway on 16th Avenue!

Best view of the city! It's hidden away but you can get great sunsets from here. Also the stairs heading up here are adorned with mosiac. Lovely spot.

This park has one of the best views of San Francisco. From the top of the hill you can see Downtown, Berkeley, Marin County and all the way to Ocean Beach. On clear days you can see the Farallon Islands and Point Reyes.
Get a coat because it can be windy, but you'll not regret the hike to the top....


More  



After climbing the 16th Avenue tiled steps, my friend and I took the extra time to go to the top of Grand View Park. It's free and has amazing 360-degree views of the entire city. We went around dusk hoping to see a great sunset but unfortunately those ever-present San Francisco clouds didn't agree with us. Plan to wear good...


More  



Easily one of the best views of San Francisco.
Like most good things, they don't come easy and to get to the views that Grand View Park offers it will take some walking up steep hills and steps but in the end it is all worth it.
The day after Christmas, I really did not want to do anything but...


More  



Everyone has heard of Twin Peaks, but how about Grand View Park? Unless you do a little digging, this little hidden gem may go missed.
Grand View Park is about a 20-30 minute walk (UPHILL) from parts of Golden Gate Park, while the return trip (DOWNHILL) is about a 5-10 minute walk. There is plenty of street parking around the...


More  



A few steep steps take you up to some fab 350 degree views of the city. The park itself is not really worthy of the name -what you get are the views! Would be lovely to see a sunrise from up the top!

title: Louise M. Davies Symphony Hall, San Francisco
address: 201 Van Ness Avenue at Grove Street, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
One of the world's finest orchestra's plays here. Great Hall and acoustics. If you love music, you will already have this on your list. If you have not heard the SF Symphony, visit the hall and expect a change in your well-being.

The sound in this setting is Very spotty. Some areas are very muffled. The design is very poor. I was sitting in the balcony and a mouse ran up my back. I will never go back, why bother when there such great music halls that were built properly.

We caught Anthony Bourdain's tour at Davies and so cannot speak to its features as a symphony hall. Parking at local garages is sufficient (several within a few blocks of the venue), and there are lots of very good restaurants in the immediate area for a pre- or post-show meal.
The seats and interior decor seemed a bit tired, and...


More  



Got to see Anthony Bourdain with orchestra seats this weekend. The venue is beautiful with great acoustics and probably not a bad seat in the place. Looked up to Loge and Tier seats and they appeared to have a good view too. Bourdain did a Q&A and was able to speak to and answer questions from the higher seats. I...


More  



This concert hall is near the Civic Centre and is a brilliant venue with superb acoustics. The programme/playbill is free and the quality of the music was outstanding. We had the great privilege of listening to Carmina Burana plus Stravinsky and Poulenc for only $20 per ticket. Concert hall facilities were excellent.

We recently went to a concert at the Davies Symphony Hall. I had not been there before and was impressed with the acoustics as well as the beauty of the hall. It seemed that there were no bad seats in the hall. The highlight of the evening was the Rachmoninoff 2nd Piano Concerto. It was beautifully performed by the Sa...


More  



A world class hall which has excellent acoustics from wherever you sit. Front of house facilities somewhat lacking. No china cups! It's a concert hall, not a stadium.!

Excellent concert hall with good viewing & acoustics. We sat in the premium stalls but, honestly, many of the cheaper seats were just as good for a concert. Easily reached by tram along Market St. Not many taxis around at the conclusion of the concert though. There's a shop well worth a visit. Some unusual souvenirs including miniature instruments. We...


More  



We were in town for the weekend and were able to reserve two great seats. It was a Valentine's Day concert. The hall is easy to get to. The design is great with wide common areas. We had a pre concert adult beverage... It's IMO expensive.

2nd tier seats make our 6 symphony package affordable. We love this section off to the side but a cat birds view of all below! We love the whole experience of the symphony MTT always a treat!

title: Greenwich Steps, San Francisco
address: Telegraph Hill, Greenwich & Sansome (Not to Be Confused With the Greenwich Steps on Russian Hill), San Francisco, CA
review_list:
It's great to get good exercise, breathe fresh air, see magnificent houses, possibly see parrots, get amazing views, move to another part of the city, have fun, take great photos, and do it all for free.

My mother and I walked up the Greenwich Steps from The Embarcadero to the top of Telegraph Hill on the morning of August 1st, after we had visited the Ferry Plaza Farmer’s Market.
The Greenwich Steps are a set of stairs that have been built along an almost completely vertical hillside, connecting The Embarcadero to Telegraph Hill, as they wind...


More  



This is a fun way to get to Coit Tower from the Embarcaderro. There are nice views and usually not many people. It is a bit of a workout.

We walked up these steps from The Embarcadero up to Coit Tower, on our way to North Beach. If you need to take a break (heading either up or down) there are plenty of resting places along the way. The gardens en route also provide great scenery while traversing this path. We were unable to see or hear any of...


More  



Wear athletic should and be super comfortable... You're in for a climb! Tons of stairs... But you'll be hungry afterwards and San Fran is foodie heaven :)
These stairs and this area make foe a beautiful walk. Not touristy at all, and not crowded. This was one of my favorite parts of San fran bc we were often walking alone...


More  



A great workout if you have been on a cruise-ship for a few days. Find Sansome Street, and head towards the hill. I counted 366 steps. What a view!

The Greenwich Steps lead to Coit Tower, a phenomenal structure that affords spectacular view and sits atop Telegraph Hill, a ritzy SF district much like Nob or Russian Hill. The steps meander amongst what can only be called a park. There’s lush foliage, and the steps do cross several times the road that winds to Coit Tower. A spinal injury...


More  



Close by to the Filbert Steps that I had originally wanted to take, GPS suggested I use these Greenwich Steps instead for my route from the Coit Tower to Pier 33. Most of these steps are steep but offer wonderful views of the city, neighborhood houses, and beautiful gardens and flowers. I'm not sure how the residents do it. I...


More  



From the Embarcadero near Lombard street you can take a steep climb up the Greenwich Steps as an approach to Coit Tower.
Its a good way to keep fit, scenic views and nice little gardens to look at.

If you want to get a good idea of what the Bay looks like, and see the San Francisco natives in their natural habitat, this
is one good place to go. The climb of the steps is steep but well worth the exercise. You can stop at the main landing and take in the view, really nice anytime of the...

title: GLBT History Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
This is a teeny tiny museum dedicated to gay and lesbian and transgender history. It's worth a look if you're visiting the Castro neighborhood. It can be done in less than an hour. There is a small entry free, but it's free on the first Wednesday of each month. We saw an exhibit on the assassination of Harvey Milk. There's...


More  



Smaller museum dedicated to San Francisco GLBT history. Still very interesting and significant, especially exhibit on Harvey Milk

If you're visiting the Castro district, be sure to stop in at the GLBT History Museum. First, they do a great job providing education and context about the neighborhood and the region through an LGBT sense, but also, they have some wonderful art and history (including Harvey Milk's bullhorn) on display to see. I'm really glad this museum exists.

Don't miss this small, intense museum just a few steps away from the rainbow colored crosswalks. Shards of an important part of recent history.

I really wanted to like this museum. The Harvey Milk piece was the most engaging. Small space without much content.

As LGBT tourists we of course wanted to visit the Castro and take in the neighbourhoods history, and part of that was visiting the GLBT museum. The museum might be small, but it's informative and has some historic Harvey Milk campaign items, which are worth going for alone. All proceeds go back to the museum and the community, so we...


More  



This should be a mandatory stop for all.... you will have a new respect and understanding of the struggle for the LGBTQ community and the courage of Mr. Milk. 'You've got to give them hope!" Thank you to all who have fought and continue to fight so that all have the right to love who they love!

I spent about an hour and a half here enjoying this small museum in the Castro. There are many artifacts from the early struggles for civil rights from the 50's and early 60's. My favorite was watching the video interviews with folks who were directly involved with the movement and their insights from that period.
Harvey Milk's suit and a...


More  



The museum is based mostly on newspaper clippings, but it's still very interesting and informative. It tells in great detail the development of the LGBT community in SF.

This museum started with efforts to preserve mementos and records of AIDS victims. It's a small museum, but it's packed with information and artifacts. The curators are clearly dedicated to preserving forgotten moments in GLBT history in San Francisco, so there's interviews with queer Asian and Pacific Islanders, info on now-defunct "gayborhoods," and an effort to include bisexual and transgender...

title: Buena Vista Park, San Francisco
review_list:
My mother and I visited Buena Vista Park during the afternoon of August 1st.
We had been exploring the Haight-Ashbury neighbourhood and ended up wandering further down Haight Street, when we discovered Buena Vista Park.
The park is basically a large hill with walking trails winding through the densely wooded landscape to the top of the hill.
We entered the...


More  



This park has some nice view and good walking trails. It's a nice place to visit if you want to get away from tourists.

I've lived across the street from this park for nearly 20 years. On the good side, it is one of the oldest parks in the City (established in 1867) and historic. It is about half way between the Presidio and the Mission. When men rode from the fort to the mission they would stop here to take in the amazing...


More  



There was a mock funeral here in 1967 for 'The Hippy', it was hilarious. This park, a big bit of rock that proved too much to remove, is now a wonderful, somewhat manicured part of SF. Not safe at night.

Nice trails and great views. A little oasis off of the Haight. Can walk off the trails to beautiful neighborhoods too. A must see.

The climb from the very bottom to the very top of the park while jet lagged nearly killed me, but the view was awesome, and we saw so much lovely wildlife - hummingbirds, woodpeckers, blue jays - so pretty! Worth a stroll if you can handle the climb.

I stumbled upon Buena Vista Park by accident when wandering through the Haight-Ashbury neighbourhood. It was a great off the beaten path discovery! There was hardly anybody there when I visited in the afternoon, which was beautiful. It was peaceful and quiet walking amongst the trees and hiking up the hill. Once you make it to the top, you are...


More  



We were out pounding the pavement and found ourselves near Buena Vista Park, I knew of the park and had thought maybe we might visit but then remembered that our host did not recommend it. As I was so excited to seeing my first glimpse of the Golden Gate Bridge we decided to climb to the top of the park...


More  



A great place to enjoy some of the landscape and versatile architecture! The park is actually man-made, but was created early in the city's history as people realized the need to maintain green spaces. Lots of history--especially in that people crowded into the park to live following the post earthquake and fire destruction in the early 1900s.

Found a homeless guy to give us a tour of the area and he took us up the hill of Buena Vista park. He took us to a clearing on the hill that over looked the entire city, past the bridge. He gave us a real history of what was going on in the city and things tour guides dont...

My 6 year old created clay figures and his own claymation video while my younger grandson created structures with huge blocks. 3 hours wasn't enough time! great rainy...

Setting: Right beside Moscone center. Great for children younger than 10 years I would say. Parking is in public garages. Lots of interaction with materials and really looking to inspire creativity in children. Lots of possibilities to document and record your creations. The good: you pay one price and you get everything. For food there is nothing really available and...


More  



We took our grandsons to this wonderful museum and they were immediately captivated by the brain-teaser section, the tech lab and the music studio (especially the first two). Our young daughter really enjoyed herself here - lots of activities and the staff were over the top good - friendly - engaged and eager for each visitor to get the most out of their experience - highly recommend going with kids - check out the carousel for a few more dollars and the adjacent park is a great way...

We were in town for a business trip and brought our 5 year old son here. He had an amazing time learning to program robots and making a music video. The staff were very attentive and nice. We had a wonderful experience!

The Children's Creativity Museum was spectacular. It is great for kids of all ages, from 2 year-olds to early teens. It had imaginative and creative exhibits with hands-on activities for everyone to enjoy. We really liked it and hope to go back soon!

Our son is 3 1/2 year old. The museum had some creative exibits, but most of the things at the museum were either for children younger than him or older than him. He really took no interest in anything there. I am a little disappointed. When he gets older we might try it again.

This is a fun place in Yerba Buena Gardens area for kids to come and use their imagination. There is also a theater there. There is a spiral gallery where they plan to show artwork made by children at the center. There is also a store here.
Close to the museum,, there is a merry-go-round as well as giant slides....

It’s a museum that encourages a lot of creative play and imaginative construction for kids ranging from toddlers to elementary school children. title: Candlestick Park, San Francisco
review_list:
Their is an RV park by the same name. We stopped in to ask about the park it's been demolished and they are putting in low rent housings.

i like the history of the park-I was there for Paul McCartneys concert it being the last one to ever play Candlestick a moment in history is candlestick is the site of the Beatles last concert. getting out of the parking lot was terrible. Its all gone now

title: Children's Creativity Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
My grandsons (3 & 6 years) loved this place. We spent several hours creating, building, playing with sand, blocks, magnets, etc. and didn't even have time to get to the 2nd floor. My 6 year old created clay figures and his own claymation video while my younger grandson created structures with huge blocks. 3 hours wasn't enough time! great rainy...


More  



Setting: Right beside Moscone center. Great for children younger than 10 years I would say. Parking is in public garages. Lots of interaction with materials and really looking to inspire creativity in children. Lots of possibilities to document and record your creations. The good: you pay one price and you get everything. For food there is nothing really available and...


More  



We took our grandsons to this wonderful museum and they were immediately captivated by the brain-teaser section, the tech lab and the music studio (especially the first two). It is not inexpensive ($12 per person regardless of age) but certainly worth it. It is attractive, very clean and even on this summer day did not seem inordinately crowded. The carousel...


More  



Our young daughter really enjoyed herself here - lots of activities and the staff were over the top good - friendly - engaged and eager for each visitor to get the most out of their experience - highly recommend going with kids - check out the carousel for a few more dollars and the adjacent park is a great way...


More  



We were in town for a business trip and brought our 5 year old son here. He had an amazing time learning to program robots and making a music video. The staff were very attentive and nice. We had a wonderful experience!

The Children's Creativity Museum was spectacular. It is great for kids of all ages, from 2 year-olds to early teens. It had imaginative and creative exhibits with hands-on activities for everyone to enjoy. We really liked it and hope to go back soon!

Our son is 3 1/2 year old. The museum had some creative exibits, but most of the things at the museum were either for children younger than him or older than him. He really took no interest in anything there. I am a little disappointed. When he gets older we might try it again.

This is a fun place in Yerba Buena Gardens area for kids to come and use their imagination. There is also a theater there. There is a spiral gallery where they plan to show artwork made by children at the center. There is also a store here.
Close to the museum,, there is a merry-go-round as well as giant slides....

title: San Francisco Maritime Museum/Aquatic Park Bathhouse Building, San Francisco
address: 900 Beach Street, San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
Cool museum where you can get to see ship models and it is located right by the see where you can have a nice view of Golden gate bridge. I would also suggest taking a walk along the coastline and hang out at the fishermans wharfs

Stopped by on our way to the pier. Free for the month of November. Part of it was closed for a meeting. Wonder what we didn't get the chance to see. Not often to see a free museum so that was nice. Learned a lot, had part of the ship right inside the museum. Easy walk to the pier, if...


More  



Very quaint little museum. It is free. The volunteer at the information desk was extremely helpful giving us advice about what to visit on the Wharf and where to get groceries.

Maybe I was there during some repairs, but basicly the museum had one room and the other was open but on the walls there were notes like "remove this wall" or "here add pictures".

This is a review for the museum in the Aquatic Park Bathhouse Building near Fishermans Wharf and Ghirardelli Square.
Visitors planning a trip to this attraction should be aware most areas of the facility are not supervised. Visitors should also be aware of crime in the area, and the lack of presence by SF law enforcement is a concern.
This...


More  



From the other comments under this heading it sounds as though patrons were as confused about where they were as I. As far as I can figure, there are at least three components under the overall heading of San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park: The Maritime Museum (which is being reviewed here); the Hyde Street Pier where the historical ships...


More  



This is a surprisingly small museum given the history of the region but it's big on quality ship models and an amazing collection of the best quality art of scrimshaw. Thee is good written commentary on the models and objects. it is well worth a visit for the items noted.

Stop in if you are visiting Fisherman's Wharf. Walk west from the congestion of tourist until you reach the cove with the historic ships. Across the street is a small store front State Park museum. It is full of well done exhibits and will expand your knowledge of the city's history.

Fascinating building in the shape of an ocean liner decorated inside and out by WPA artists. Great outside area for catching the afternoon sun and watching aquatic activities.

We visited on a cold and windy May Day and there are a bunch of boats to see and tour. We didn't have much time but really enjoyed it. Bundle up because it's cold. We wished we had more time because there's a lot to see.

title: Embarcadero Center, San Francisco
address: Embarcadero at Battery, Financial District, San Francisco, CA 94111
review_list:
We decided to partake in the 50th Super Bowl Experience, Lots of people enjoying the festivities. San Fransisco you can be proud of a job well done. The security was visible and reassuring. Plenty of bars and food venues. big stages with music pumping .

Firework show was awesome! Free concert, fun for all the family . Dad's, mom's and children . Felt very safe a lot of security, and bathrooms. Another firework show this Friday Febuary 5 th. Over 50,000 fireworks.

A nice way to walk along the waterfront and see everything from both land and water...the grand towering skyscrapers, the piers, the people, the shops...nice to do.

Embarcadero Center is very much a work week / business day shopping centre, but there are some good entertainment and dining options after hours. In the title I say dead after hours, but I sort of mean that as a good thing. If you are local and you want a place to have a nice walk on a brisk winter...


More  



Go visit the center and enjoy the tall buildings. If you plan to shop and eat, plan to eat early as the Restuarants do not stay open very late.

The Embarcadero Center is a complex of five tower blocks in the financial district of San Francisco. Its also encompasses boutique shopping, dining and entertainment. Maybe it aims to be cool but I preferred Union Square.

I was staying in the area and decided to walk to the Embarcadero Center. I was shocked to see that most of the restaurants did not stay open past early evening. There also didn't appear to be a great selection. The concept is cool, but the execution not so cool. It doesn't hurt to stop by if you're in the...


More  



My wife and I recently stayed at the Hyatt Regency Hotel right in the heart of the Embarcadero Center. The Embarcadero Center is San Francisco’s premier destination for boutique shopping, outstanding restaurants and popular local events. The Embarcadero Center consists of four 30 to 45-story buildings and the Hyatt Regency San Francisco, located between the Ferry Building and the foot...

good selection of restaurants located here. Shopping is plentiful and diverse. okay place. I stumbled upon it with some friends. Wouldn't go out of my way to look for it.

looking for a great restaurant - head down there emarcadero center is near the piers so plenty to choose from. We opted for seafood and had a great meal at a reasonable price

title: San Franciscso Visitor Information Center, San Francisco
review_list:
It was an experience wading through dirty, grimy, urine-smelling streets and homeless before we arrived at the Visitor Information Center on lower level of Hallidie Plaza on Market St. The center is an entirely different world, clean, bright and cheery! The staff on duty was extremely helful and friendly. There were tons of literatures ready to take and advice to...


More  



We used the services of the Visitor Information Centre a few times while visiting San Francisco (we were staying at a hotel nearby).
We found the staff to be very friendly and helpful. We were provided with maps, directions, information on the location of attractions, and how to use the muni transport (including the location of certain stops).
We also...


More  



This is the place to come to get an overview of all that is in the City of San Francisco. So much info, and all of it free!

great place for first time visitors. Plenty of pamphlets about the city attractions. Can get passes and maps here as well. The staff was helpful and friendly.

I first called the info center to find information on where I could buy a 3 day MUNI pass and park my car. I called and left a message because all the info people were busy. I didn't expect a call back the same day, but I did. They told me that they didn't have any parking at their location,...


More  



This is the very best first stop for any visitor to SF. Not only can you pick up your Muni Day Pass or to browse brochures for inspiration. Just get off at the Powell St. BART stop, walk up the steps instead of going into the mall and there you are.

Whenever you have a problem to travel around SF, this is the center to get the answer. To receive maps, travel tips, passes or dining places. The clerk give advice which area or time of day should not be there.

This center had a lot of good information for San Francisco and surrounding areas. Tons of brochures and magazines, plus a few souvenirs, but not a huge selection. It's a little hard to find, but it's down near the metro area, down the steps.

Great place for tourist info and gifts, whether you are visiting the city or a resident about to host guests. Buy MUNI 1-, 3- and 7-day passes here to ride MUNI bus, streetcar, subway and cable car. They also sell the official MUNI map showing all MUNI transit lines in the city. And they offer a small but fun selection...


More  



I had a number of questions to help visitors to this beautiful city. The staff who helped me gave me information that I didn't even know to ask for. They gave me a number of hand-outs that were truly helpful and that I could give to my friends.

title: Treasure Island Flea Market, San Francisco
address: 1 Avenue of the Palms, Treasure Island, San Francisco, CA 94130
review_list:
I really enjoyed this flea market. There was a mix of antiques, upcycled goods, crafts, and unique items. I was able to bring my dog which was great and the food trucks where abundant. It was hard to choose which one to eat from. Also there is a wine and beer bar there which was nice to have a drink...


More  



Our visit last Sunday was a great way to spend a couple of hours before we headed into the city. The variety of vendors was good to very good. We bought a bowl from a vendor representing Haitian artisans who was very passionate about working with the artists and importing their work. This flea market is enjoyable and offers something...


More  



Got an invite to check out the flea market. Had never heard of it. Made the drive. What a great surprise! Absolutely breathtaking views of The Bay. A dozen food trucks. More junk/stuff/collectibles stands than you could want. Surrounded by the historic architecture of the island. Really had a great time.

Wonderful place to shop, sip a cocktail, get some great grub and enjoy stellar views of the city. Pluses: Delicious choice of food; great vendors; unique stuff you can't find anywhere. Minuses: no where to sit to eat; lines for food trucks are insane - like they never thought any one was coming / going to show up? Really frustrating...


More  



Got the discount from Living Social. Even without the discount, it's very reasonable. The weather was almost perfect..it was a little windy, but the temperature was perfect. The market was more than I expected. There were a variety of vendors...odd things, vintage, new & used clothing, furniture. The band sound great! There were also a variety of
food trucks. My...

As an avid Flea Marketeer and Antiques and Collectibles seeker I decided to check out the TI Flea for the first time. I have been collecting and selling Antiques and Collectibles for many years. LOVED this flea market, it is a bit different than most. Local artists mixed in with junkers. Most dealers are more than willing to take reasonable offers. This is a fun and unique flea market experience, enhanced by beautiful views on a clear day. Lots of up-cycled choices and fun food trucks as part of the browsing here....This is not your run-of the-mill flea market!

This is not your usual Bay Area flea market. This one reminds me of the ones you see on the TV Flea Market Flip. Trendy and homemade things. You can find your junk but many one of a kind items. There is a $3 fee to get in and parking can get crowded. Food trucks are there as well along...

This center had a lot of good information for San Francisco and surrounding areas. Tons of brochures and magazines, plus a few souvenirs, but not a huge selection. It's a little hard to find, but it's down near the metro area, down the steps.

Great place for tourist info and gifts, whether you are visiting the city or a resident about to host guests. Buy MUNI 1-, 3- and 7-day passes here to ride MUNI bus, streetcar, subway and cable car. They also sell the official MUNI map showing all MUNI transit lines in the city. And they offer a small but fun selection...


More  



I had a number of questions to help visitors to this beautiful city. The staff who helped me gave me information that I didn't even know to ask for. They gave me a number of hand-outs that were truly helpful and that I could give to my friends.

title: Clarion Alley Murals, San Francisco
review_list:
I love walking down Clarion Alley - I've done it alone, with friends and strangers, and with family - checking out the cool and creative murals, always artistic and often political, passing locals and tourists and workers and sometimes drunks and hidden houses with some open secrets.

My mother and I visited the Clarion Alley Murals during the afternoon of July 28th, our first day in San Francisco.
Clarion Alley is located between Valencia and Mission Streets on the east and the west and 17th and 18th Streets to the north and south.
I was staying at an Airbnb in the Mission District, which was an easy...


More  



Excellent place to take pictures and enjoey the urban art in San Francisco. But stay alert. To one side there's a very hipster neighbourhood (Mission District), to the other is a not so friendly place.

An alleyway filled with dope street art. Nope, not simply your typical can of spray paint graffiti...this is artwork in its rawest expression.
During my visit to San Francisco, Clarion Alley was a must see. It it did not disappoint. I opted for an evening stroll in hopes of catching some work in progress. There wasn't a session taking place...


More  



Take Bart to 16th and mission, then walk up to Clarion. You won't regret it. Clarion Marion Street murals are fantastic. I'm by no means an activist, but this street exemplifies art and free speech.

Lots of street art to see in the Mission District. If you are interested at all in street art, you should do a little research on the internet and see what is going on in the Mission District of San Francisco. Clarion Alley is one of the major murals and has a variety of things to see. Definitely worth a...


More  



Clarion Alley is well worth a visit if your are in the Mission District of San Francisco. Down this small mostly pedestrian alley is a beautiful variety of artwork expressing the key ideas and emotions of many causes. It all began in 1992 with two artists who lived there but has evolved to an every changing array of styles and...


More  



This place is really cool and the Murals are pretty awesome! Such nice works of arts! It might be sketchy to find it but totally worth seeing!

In a neighborhood feeling the crush of the tech boom, these murals are a breath of relief and expression. Well done paintings with biting messages and memorials to those former neighborhood residents who are victims of gentrification. Millennial computer industrials should have a look.

The most colorful alley I've ever seen. I was lucky to see some artists working on their next project! Dont miss it, you ll feel the spirit of this amazing artistic city!

title: Treasure Island Flea Market, San Francisco
address: 1 Avenue of the Palms, Treasure Island, San Francisco, CA 94130
review_list:
I really enjoyed this flea market. There was a mix of antiques, upcycled goods, crafts, and unique items. I was able to bring my dog which was great and the food trucks where abundant. It was hard to choose which one to eat from. Also there is a wine and beer bar there which was nice to have a drink...


More  



Our visit last Sunday was a great way to spend a couple of hours before we headed into the city. The variety of vendors was good to very good. We bought a bowl from a vendor representing Haitian artisans who was very passionate about working with the artists and importing their work. This flea market is enjoyable and offers something...


More  



Got an invite to check out the flea market. Had never heard of it. Made the drive. What a great surprise! Absolutely breathtaking views of The Bay. A dozen food trucks. More junk/stuff/collectibles stands than you could want. Surrounded by the historic architecture of the island. Really had a great time.

Wonderful place to shop, sip a cocktail, get some great grub and enjoy stellar views of the city. Pluses: Delicious choice of food; great vendors; unique stuff you can't find anywhere. Minuses: no where to sit to eat; lines for food trucks are insane - like they never thought any one was coming / going to show up? Really frustrating...


More  



Got the discount from Living Social. Even without the discount, it's very reasonable. The weather was almost perfect..it was a little windy, but the temperature was perfect. The market was more than I expected. There were a variety of vendors...odd things, vintage, new & used clothing, furniture. The band sound great! There were also a variety of
food trucks. My...


More  



As an avid Flea Marketeer and Antiques and Collectibles seeker I decided to check out the TI Flea for the first time. I have been collecting and selling Antiques and Collectibles for many years. Was very pleased to attend this market. It is located in the middle of SF Bay on Treasure Island which is connected to Yerba Buena Island...


More  



LOVED this flea market, it is a bit different than most. Local artists mixed in with junkers. Most dealers are more than willing to take reasonable offers. If you are looking for that unique piece of jewelry or furniture it's worth your stop here. Doesn't hurt that there's a traveling wagon that sells mimosa's, bloody mary's and beer. :) Groupon...


More  



This is a fun and unique flea market experience, enhanced by beautiful views on a clear day. Lots of up-cycled choices and fun food trucks as part of the browsing here....This is not your run-of the-mill flea market!

This is not your usual Bay Area flea market. This one reminds me of the ones you see on the TV Flea Market Flip. Trendy and homemade things. You can find your junk but many one of a kind items. There is a $3 fee to get in and parking can get crowded. Food trucks are there as well along...


More  



There is such a wide variety of stalls here offering massive range of goods you'll find it hard not buy something. We took the 108 bus and at only $3 to go in you'll be in for a treat. I've never seen so many food trucks in ome place go such a wide variety of food. The only downside is...


More

title: Cartoon Art Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
After having walked for half an hour in rain☹️☹️🌧🌧🌧 and finally found out that the museum does NOT excist any longer Tripadvisor got in bad standing😉
Please remove the museum from your list.

My husband's one request for his birthday was to visit this museum during our San Francisco trip. It turned out to be a great visit. I really enjoyed the historical perspective as well as the Darth Vader and friends exhibit. Plus - some cool props from the Avengers movies. Sadly - they closed in September while they find a new...


More  



A small museum showcasing a few artists. Jeff Brown's Darth Vader and Friends exhibit was very cute. Savage Dragon by Erik Larson was also a nice spread with great splash pages. It is a great way to get up close to some fantastic comic pieces. There are some historical items in there as well. They are putting things in storage...


More  



The museum was quite interesting but very small - not sure it was worth $8 each but was a good experience and was something to do whilst visiting San Francisco. As an art teacher - I found it quite useful to see how artists develop their ideas from paper to digital animation as this is something that may help me...


More  



Perhaps it depends on what is being exhibited. On my visit there was a fun display of the artwork used for a few funny kids books about Darth Vader and his kids. There was also a good overview of the history of the cartoon. Both kids and adults will enjoy a visit.

This is my only negative review of many reviews from a SF visit. This museum is small. We wanted to see one of the two special exhibits. Even with the special exhibit and regular exhibits, we didn't spend an entire hour here. There are examples of many cartoons, but only one example and then with no additional detail about it...


More  



It is located downtown San Francisco. Amazing collection and fun! It's medium sized and they have an AVENGERS collection at the back... super awesome surprise! Their store is superb. You can drop $50 easy... great selections!

I took my team to visit the museum as a fun little distraction from work as we work next door. I wouldn't describe any of us as cartoon enthusiasts, but we all enjoyed our visit. It was interesting to see how cartoons evolved across the decades, and it opened up ours eyes to the artistry involved in this genre. It...


More  



If you're in to comics or cartoons stop by. It's a small collection but admission is cheap. You can view the collection fairly quickly if you want or take your time.

I love the cartoon drawings and videos there. Their exhibition covers a large number of different cartoons and it's very enjoyable to look through these.

title: SFO Museum, San Francisco
address: San Francisco International Airport, 806 S Airport Blvd, San Francisco, CA 94128
review_list:
Museum is a great distraction from the pain of hanging in the airport. Always something cool to see.

San Francisco was a pioneer in putting art & an Art Museum in their busy SFO airport, and many cities have copied this wonderful concept. You enjoy the exhibitions upon entering and via the concourses. I love the permanent aviation items as well as the rotating exhibitions. It's not your usual airport experience for sure! Enjoy. ...

I love seeing the museum every time I come to the airport. They have a bunch of beast old vintage Halloween stuff out now. The items brought back a bunch of good memories from when I was younger.

World class collections and displays in many areas - each concourse completely different and very well done. It is worth getting to SFO a bit eary (or even delaying going home) to see the permanent displays and new temporary ones that change over time. Too bad you have to fly somewhere to see the parts behind security.

Best if you have a connecting flight or a long stay at the airport. The best exhibit I suggest is the one that has the airplanes and airplane parts and guides, located in the main hall of the International Terminal. However, they are very simple and cannot be compared to other aircraft museums. Free admission.

The SFO Museum, established in 1980, offers passengers the opportunity to view art in all its terminals, pre- and post-Security. Installations range from more than 80 pieces of public art to temporary exhibitions that focus on a variety of subjects.
On a recent layover here -- in Terminal 3 -- I looked at "The Last Glacier," photographs by Ivan van...


More  



I was pleasantly surprised by the quality and quantity of art in these free exhibits at the SFO airport. I only had time to visit 3 of the current exhibits located throughout the International Terminal Main Hall areas. I was really only expecting a few art displays here and there. But both the Minge Japanese and I Love You California...


More  



No doubt if you are at the airport then you will have some time kill so it's worth taking a look at what's on display. It basically spread from one end of the terminal to other. If you head down to where the library is there is a fantastic display of model aircraft in the window.

If one has time before a flight or are waiting for someone who is arriving, i enjoy going to the free SFO Museum and seeing the various displays. Its a well done museum for being at an airport.

I always feel lucky if I have a bit of a layover in San Francisco Airport Terminal 3 where they have beautiful art exhibits along the concourse.
I traveled twice over the Christmas break with layovers at SFO and took the time to view the beautiful ceramics created by Korean potters.

title: Project Zen Massage and Bodywork, San Francisco
review_list:
Project Zen did create a zenful environment from the gentle music to the lighting and candles in the bathroom. My massage by Em felt very methodic and careful--he covered all the spots in my neck and shoulders that needed attention. I felt safe and in good hands.

I had a "Day of Zen" (one hour of foot massage and two hours of Thai massage) with Jason and it was absolutely outstanding. Very relaxing ambiance and I had Jason's full attention for three hours. So incredibly decadent. So incredibly relaxing! He is incredibly strong, but used no more pressure than I asked for and was quite responsive to...


More  



Had my first ever Thai massage tonight and it was incredible. I worked with Julie and she was great. Good vibes inside as well. I was worried about being right on Bay, but you couldn't hear the street sounds at all.

Never had a Thai massage before - but wow - I will be back. Easy check-in with friendly receptionist; lovely zen-like room; and amazing massage. Love the downtown Burlingame location. I used a living Social coupon - but was surprised that the full price is very affordable given the quality of the experience.

Clean and courteous! Julian was off the hook and I've been getting massages regularly for over 25 years! Highly recommended!

Julie was wonderful. She listened and made sure to work on the areas I needed. Because I recently had back surgery, I was concerned about the massage but she truly made sure she was gentle yet effective.

I love going to Project Zen for Deep Tissue, Orthobiotomy, acupuncture & Reflexology. The practitioners are amazing and the prices are reasonable.

Som did a great job with a Swedish massage today! Reception is always very nice and the cucumber water is fabulous!!!
Highly recommend them here in Burlingame or the city!

Great service ! I love that their hours and location go well with my schedule. Clean rooms and easy check in and out.

when you go for a massage, you want a peaceful atmosphere, clean supplies, attentive service, and to leave feeling better than when you went in.
Usually that's what Project Zen delivers. Today I felt like I got even more.
I don't know how they were able to step it up, but they did. And it was really a wonderful experience....


More

title: Kabuki Springs and Spa, San Francisco
address: 1750 Geary Boulevard, Japantown, San Francisco, CA 94115
review_list:
I have been going to the Kabuki for decades. I went weekly when I lived in the city for about seven years. I had a good friend who was a spa-junkie and our Thursday night soak was perfect for relaxing in a quiet environment and catching up. We fully appreciated that it was a place for soft conversations and kept...


More  



This is a great place to unwind and relax. Massage is quite good, ambiance is chill all the way. Clean and well maintained facility. Respectful clientele. Everything is indoors, so be ready for a more closed-in experience. But, once you relax, you probably won't mind. A great after work respite too.

True Japanese baths. I Love Brian for Shiatsu and the packages are worthwhile and decadent! Put this on your SPA bucket list for sure, or you will be missing out! The lodging and Japantown next door are GREAT TOO!!

I had higher expectations for this place after looking at reviews and pictures of this place. I got disappointed. I came from Seattle and place I go to is away much cleaner, better and bigger. My friend and I didn't receive robs and shoes because we didn't order a service. Toilet has been cleaned for hours. Very few places to...


More  



Kabuki Springs is a very relaxing experience. They offer a sauna,steam room, a warm soaking pool and a cold plunging pool. There are several days during the week that only men are allowed. It's a very quiet and peaceful atmosphere.

Visited here while staying in San Francisco on a Monday which is men's day. I booked a massage and access to the communal baths and spent a good few hours here relaxing.
My Swedish massage was excellent and very thorough and was conducted in a private room. I booked 80 minutes and received a full 80 minute massage.
Being a...

I enjoy the Kabuki Springs communal baths on men's day almost every time I visit San Francisco. The atmosphere is soothing and the facilities are clean and well maintained. More  



I've been going to Kabuki Springs for well over a decade now. It's a gem of a spa offering most any spa service you could want.
It's rare to find a place these days where the "no cell phone" rule is strictly enforced. Kabuki Springs is one of these places (though I will admit - there are times the staff...

I LOVE Hotel Kabuki in San Francisco's Japantown. It is a quirky upscale type hotel in Japantown that treats its guests like special beings that deserve pampering. Upon check-in I received a free guest pass (worth $25) to Kabuki Spas just blocks away. The serene and meditative communal bath was a wonderful way to de-stress after a long, hard day...

This was my 1st time visiting this type of spa and boy was I glad I came in with an open mind. This place was great. There is a dry sauna, steam room, cold tub and hot tub. You can even get a massage. Some days are women only and others are men only and some are co-ed.

title: Royal Thai Spa, San Francisco
address: 685 North Point St, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
After many hour along street in san francisco bay. It's a good time to grab to aroma massage. This is a massage shop under mariott hotel just 2 min walk from pier. Staff so nice,place look great. Why dont try if you tired after get fresh air and seagull:))))

We accidentally found this spa before running a race. I quickly called the other gals I was traveling with and made reservations for them. We all had the Thai stretch massage. This spa is clean, low key, friendly, quiet and your treatment is peaceful. I found a coupon on Groupon but would pay full price as it is reasonable.

The best massage I have had in a couple years. Had a Thai deep tissue 90 minute massage. In the very beginning I was thinking just pressure is not going to do it. And then she really got started. Wow. I believe the lady who worked on me was named Mickey. Really strong hands.

I read about this place on Trip Advisor and was very happy that I did!!
I had spent the morning walking around San Fransisco and was lucky enough to be able to get a walk in appointment for a 90 minute Thai massage.
The massage was great. My therapist was very good and just the perfect pressure was applied. The...


More  



We enjoyed a great couple's aromotherapy massage on Valentine's Day. While the spa was completely booked we got lucky with a last minute cancellation. We liked the atmosphere, courteous staff and great massage. Reasonably priced. Went back the next night after hiking for nearly 12 miles and enjoyed 30 minute foot massages. Once again, another great experience. Conveniently located near...


More  



My partner & I both had a 90 minute massage here. Mine was the Island Style & my partner's aromatherapy. Island Style combined traditional Thai massage with deep tissue massage & aromatherapy. After the massage I felt 6 weeks of travel had been massaged away. My therapist was able to work around my lower back issues (post major back surgery)...


More  



I flew in from NYC for work and desperately needed a massage. I did a quick review search and found this place with awesome reviews. I was bale to book an appointment within the same hour I called!
The staff was amazingly friendly. I had tried to book through the online app in order to get the discount but the...


More  



Highly recommend the 30 minute foot massage! Had a mani and pedi and the staff was friendly and very good at their business. This place offers a nice respite after a long morning of shopping. Value for service was fair. I will definitely go again if I come back to the union square area.

Only negative thing to say is that if you get the foot massage you need to wear clothing that allows you to roll up your pants to your knees. They don't provide any alternative clothing even though we followed the foot massage with a relaxation massage. That's it, just be sure to wear comfy clothes!

I have a package with this spa and i go there all of the time. It is in the touristy area, but don't let that dissuade you from checking it out. They give a killer aromatherapy massage and the space is clean and peaceful.

title: Royal Thai Spa, San Francisco
address: 685 North Point St, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
After many hour along street in san francisco bay. It's a good time to grab to aroma massage. This is a massage shop under mariott hotel just 2 min walk from pier. Staff so nice,place look great. Why dont try if you tired after get fresh air and seagull:))))

We accidentally found this spa before running a race. I quickly called the other gals I was traveling with and made reservations for them. We all had the Thai stretch massage. This spa is clean, low key, friendly, quiet and your treatment is peaceful. I found a coupon on Groupon but would pay full price as it is reasonable.

The best massage I have had in a couple years. Had a Thai deep tissue 90 minute massage. In the very beginning I was thinking just pressure is not going to do it. And then she really got started. Wow. I believe the lady who worked on me was named Mickey. Really strong hands.

I read about this place on Trip Advisor and was very happy that I did!!

More

Once again, another great experience. Conveniently located near...


More  



My partner & I both had a 90 minute massage here. Mine was the Island Style & my partner's aromatherapy. Island Style combined traditional Thai massage with deep tissue massage & aromatherapy. Highly recommend the 30 minute foot massage! Had a mani and pedi and the staff was friendly and very good at their business. This place offers a nice respite after a long morning of shopping. Value for service was fair. I will definitely go again if I come back to the union square area.

Only negative thing to say is that if you get the foot massage you need to wear clothing that allows you to roll up your pants to your knees. They don't provide any alternative clothing even though we followed the foot massage with a relaxation massage. That's it, just be sure to wear comfy clothes!

I have a package with this spa and i go there all of the time. It is in the touristy area, but don't let that dissuade you from checking it out. They give a killer aromatherapy massage and the space is clean and peaceful.

review_list:
Kate made my family and I engaged, interested and wanting more and more!
We learned things we would never otherwise read on a small placard next to the piece of art or research on our own and it was Awesome!
Can't wait to go to the upcoming museums on the West Coast and check out how they got Hacked!
Thanks...


More  



Normally when I think of going on a docent-lead tour, I immediately thinking "interesting snooze-fest". This was not that.
First, the personality and tone of the docent really shrines; they're not trying to hide themselves away into blandness and invisibility — their interests and passions really drive the content and which pieces are selected to be shown.
Second, I'm usually...


More  



Had a great time will honestly never do another museum without doing it the museum hack way cause they are just so boring and dry. Had a great time made me appreciate history again and still have a good time. You know you're having a good time when the guide tells you "the tour will end in 20 minutes" and...


More  



This tour was truly special - Informative in a unique way, fun, engaging, and entertaining! Our tour guide, Kate, made us feel welcomed and right at home. We weren't just going through a museum, we were going on an adventure!
Loved it and will look for Museum Hack in NYC and DC!

Kate, our Museum Hack guide, greeted us at our meeting spot full of energy. She is smart, bubbly and super knowledgable. We had been to the De Young Museum a couple of times in the past but this was one of the most insightful visits we've experience thus far.
Traditionally, we'd just wonder the museum, occasionally stop to stare at...


More  



We had a great time on our Museum Hack tour of the deYoung Museum on December 20th. Casey, Kate, and Adrian were knowledgeable, enthusiastic, and just fun to hang out with! Having dragged our teenager to many art museums in the past with eye-roll results, we were so happy that she cited this tour as one of the highlights of...


More  



We took our staff team of 8 to the DeYoung Museum for bonding and team-building. Museum Hack did not disappoint! We laughed the whole time and had a great time with a scavenger hunt through the museum. Our tour guide Adrian was awesome and made the tour relevant for our team. It was funky and fun-filled, and made us feel...


More  



Our Museum Hack was great and we liked the fact that a museum experience can be fun and engaging. Our tour guide, Casey, was great and knowledgable.

Casey from the Museum Hack team led our group of merry pranksters on a fun and filled curated tour of the De Young dropping knowledge and laughs on us left and right.
It was so much fun and definitely something I'd recommend to anyone who appreciates art and has a sense of humor and is looking for an adventure in...


More  



To be honest, museums normally stress me out -- kids running around, you have to be quiet, and you have to remember all the information you read or else the trip would be for naught.
Kate gave a wonderful tour of the De Young, immediately putting me to ease with her warm and casual personality. The pieces she selected were...


More

title: SF Adventure Tours, San Francisco
review_list:
We organized a beer tour with Eric and SF Adventure Tours for our buddy's bachelor party. It was one of the highlights of the trip. From Eric's superb knowledge of the city to the absolutely perfect stops for beer (Magnolia, Speakeasy), we couldn't have asked for a better adventure for our beer-loving bachelor.

My family and I (3 boys aged 10-16) had this tour organised for us before we left Australia. We were hoping to see the sights of San Francisco whilst finishing off the day with a tour of Alcatraz. Our time in SF was limited and we wanted to see as much of the city as we could. This tour did...


More  



Eric was the best guide!! He also asked if there was anything is San Fran we wanted to see and took us to the sites that interested us the most. He knew so much about the city and made it such a fun day!!

Eric is 100 percent knowledgable about SF. The tour was FABULOUS! We were a little cold on a 50 degree day but no worries - Eric provided us with blankets to keep warm and a stop for hot chocolate kept us very cozy. His photo opportunities are perfect and we loved his one liners for a laugh here and there....


More  



If you only take one tour of San Francisco, make sure it is with Eric in the back of his open-sided adventure truck. This man knows SF and his love for it is obvious as he took us on an always informative trip and often very humourous (he is the master of the pun) around the neighbourhoods that make up...


More  



We had only 36 hours in San Francisco and went on the SF Adventure Tour on the recommendation of a friend. The tour has a maximum of 12 guests which is terrific.we covered a lit of ground on the tour and saw more of the coty than had we done a self drive tour.
Eric the guide is fantastic! He...


More  



Eric runs a great business and offer an array of tours to suit everyone's needs, take the time to talk to him and he will tailor a trip you will remember for ever. Eric is extremely knowledgeable about the San Francisco area and delivers information in an interesting way - easy to understand and not droll!!

Great way to see San Francisco! Eric was a great tour guide, from us confirming the tour the day before, to the end of the tour, he was so friendly and helpful. He picked us up in his done up van with surf boards on the side right on time, and then we proceeded to pick up the rest of...


More  



If you want to see the highlights of San Francisco in one day, learn a little about the history and have great fun while your doing it - Eric is the best tour guide you can have. He picked us up close by our accommodation and soon helped us fit in with the rest of the group. His slightly warped...


More  



Our tour started with Eric picking us up from our own hotel. From there we received a very informative and personalised tour from Eric. We seen so much of San Fran in one day that we would of not been able on a bus or any big tour group. Definitely recommend if you are in San Fran, as you won't...


More

title: Vantigo Tours, San Francisco
review_list:
My husband and I brought our 17 yr old daughter to San Francisco and wanted to show her around the city. We chose Vantigo as the reviews were great and the sites they covered in a half day were perfect for us. We had a great tour with Justin and he covered all the right topics and sites for our...


More  



We had about 24 hours in San Francisco, and knowing we wanted to see the city but we didn't want a big tour bus or to drive ourselves around, we reserved the night tour of the city. It was great! We felt like we got to see everything, and Eddie did a great job of telling us about the area...


More  



We did the Highway 1 brewery tour. It's a long tour (6 hours approx) but time flies with the combination of quality craft beer, micro breweries and beautiful coastal scenery. This is a small hands on tour operator (the owner of the company was our tour guide) who effortlessly puts a personal touch on your tour regardless of the group...


More  



If you are visiting the Bay Area and are looking to explore Wine Country in a small and intimate manner, don't look any further than Vantigo. A wonderful small operator that creates a personalized experience, you will visit four wineries and learn about the wine industry on this day long trip. Convenient to downtown tourist hotels in SF, the tour...


More  



We've just moved to the city and had friends visiting so decided to book a tour to get to know San Francisco. So glad that we used Vantigo! Eddy was a great tour guide, really knowledgeable and fun. The VW van is a nice touch and it felt more intimate than a big 'hop on hop off' bus. Also due...


More  



Family of four (2 adults and 2 children - aged 11 and 10). WE LOVED THE TOUR. Eric was fantastic and so passionate and full of information. He included the kids in the activities, and had little surprises on board. We had an awesome time.

Our tour guide Eric was simply brilliant from the moment we arrived. The tour was meant to be for a minimum of four people but no one had booked except the two of us and he still went ahead with the tour as planned as he didn't want to let us down and what followed was a tour to be...


More  



If you're looking for an absolutely fabulous look at San Francisco get on board!! Eddie was our driver...what an informative and excellent tour guide!! The minute you hop into the VW bus its like a family trip (only without the squabbling...) To say this company takes you around the city is an understatement. If you were to try and drive...


More  



Our tour guide was excellent - for our small party (there's only so many you can fit in a bus) the insight was tailored, took into account our interests and where we from and our comforts.
So many great stories that I had to pass on a few to my friends too.
The recommendation for lunch "Scomas" was spot on....


More  



Booked a tour of San Francisco with Vantigo tours early on the day of the tour. Was able to use the easy booking system on my mobile - a bit of a plus for a start and the rice was good. The VW tour bus was called Gerry(after Gerry Garcia- well it is SF after all!). The bus picked me...
