title: Castro Theatre, San Francisco
address: 429 Castro Street, Market Street, San Francisco, CA 94114
review_list:
I've lived close to here for 25 years and can't imagine how many times I've graced the doors.
There are few single-screen theaters left in the City but this is the best. They've recently upgraded sound & projection, and the seats are comfortable enough.
Grand design by Timothy Pfleuger, the "starchitect" of his era in SF. Be sure to look...


More  



Perfect destination on public transportation (Bart to one of three Muni trains) just cross the street and you are there. A fun place, folks laughed, cheered and clapped. Watch a classic vintage movie like "Vertigo" or Noir films coming up the last week of January.

It's a great old theater! And if you happen to be able to catch one of the sing along shows... you'll thank me.

Always on the lookout for their monthly schedule release! They frequently do double features where you get to enjoy 2 movies and discover one that you might not have enjoyed in a theater otherwise. Good popcorn, great service, all kinds of community events and film festivals. A neighborhood highlight!

I've seen a few films here, and always enjoy the atmosphere. Try and catch the organ playing! Another great way to appreciate a great city!

If you are a theatre lover, you can not miss Castro Theatre, they have a great programme list and the interiors are really unique.
This building is an icon in Castro. beside it there is loads of coffee shops and honestly deserves a visit

The Castro Theater is a fully functioning movie theater, and it's a historical landmark in San Francisco. Almost every movie or TV show that set in San Francisco has at least one shot of the Castro Theater- - well if there's a gay nexus to the movie. This theater has so much more than just a regular movies. you'll find...


More  



The Castro is a very cool historic theatre and shows one of the best programs of art, vintage, and revival films around. It's an amazing place and a true cultural hub for the avant-alt film community and draws crowds from all over the bay area. It's also located in the (fun) Castro which is filled with a terrific selection of...


More  



Another landmark location on the Extranomical Day Tour, with Don, our guide. Another part of the cultural heritage of the city.

For the last night of our three day visit to San Francisco, we took in "Breakfast At Tiffany's" at The Castro Theater. In hindsight, this was one of the greatest highlights of our trip. This historic theater is THE CROWN JEWEL of the neighborhood, and venturing inside is like walking back in time! The staff is incredibly friendly and helpful!...


More

title: Best Tours San Francisco, San Francisco
address: San Francisco, CA 94105 (Formerly San Francisco Private Food Tours from Great Food Tours)
review_list:
Over an hour to get to SF for Cupcake Tour. Eight people waiting, but tour guide never showed up! We all checked our emails, but they did not let us know it was cancelled. No apology, and no mention of getting our money back. A scam.

I bought a voucher through Groupon for a Chocolate tour during our trip to SF. We had a hard time trying to figure out how to even use the voucher on the Best Tours website. After we finally figured out how to book it, we set a date for Thursday at 4:00 PM. We got to the meeting place, Fog...


More  



I bought a voucher on living social for a tour in SF. First, it was very difficult to figure out how to use the voucher on the Best Tours site. After repeatedly contacting Best Tours via email and getting no response (I sent at least 5 emails and there is no other contact info listed except a chat line that...


More  



I signed up for a chocolate tour with Best Tours on October 17th. The tour was unexpectedly canceled the night before due to "staffing issues". The tour was $100 and they charged that to my credit card upon purchasing the tour. I understand that tours can be canceled due to various issues, but a full refund is an obvious expectation....


More  



We greatly enjoyed the tour given by Michaelangelo. The tour was actually cancelled but we missed the email notification. Michaelangelo offered to take us on the tour anyway and we had a great time. We highly recommend the tour especially if you get Michaelangelo.

Tour guide never showed, never called, we wasted cab far to get there for NOTHING! We called the phone number and there was no option to talk to a human being and no option that applied to us. Even the Expedia support desk couldn't get ahold of anyone.
FOR THE LOVE OF GOD/BUDDHA/ALLAH/WHOEVER DO NOT DO THIS OR GO ON...


More  



Fabulous chocolate tour. Loved the additional history of the city that was provided on the tour, very witty. Wish there had been a little more hard core chocolate, and a little less 'candy'. Loved the organic tea place.

When planning this tour, I carefully read all the chocolate tour possibilities on line and chose this tour because of all the rave reviews. I booked this tour online a few weeks ahead of time. I read the website stating that we would be notified 48 hours ahead of time if our tour was cancelled. We showed up at the...


More  



We did this tour for my mother-in-law's birthday and everyone loved it!! Our tour guide, Derek, was great. There was so much chocolate to taste I couldn't taste it all. I would definitely recommend this tour.

I found a Groupon for the Chocolate tour of SF (~$20/person).
We went to 7 different chocolate shops, and the chocolate was INCLUDED (you don't have to pay extra). Most of the shops were on Market St. There was about 1.5 miles of walking. It ended at Westfield Mall after about 2.5 hours.
Our guide, Derek, was really entertaining and...

title: Metreon, San Francisco
address: 135 Fourth Street, San Francisco, CA 94103 (Formerly Metreon Sony Entertainment Center)
review_list:
I stopped at Metreon for some lunch. The food court is decent enough but far smaller than the nearby one in the Westfield centre. I had korean noodle soup which was good and the seating area was nice and airy/bright looking onto Yerba Buena gardens.
There's not a huge amount in this building - just food, imax cinema and a...


More  



Actually not a bad place for the range of food stalls/cafe/drinks in the food court area and reasonable too as that part of town does not have many affordable places to hang out. Free Wifi too.

Getting a bite to eat can be expensive in downtown San Francisco.
The food court at Metreon offers several stalls that serve food at comparably reasonable prices. Some 5min walk from Market St / Powel St.

Nice mall, lots of eats, well laid out. Next to a nice park, full of lunch-time workers. Has a City Target.

The Metreon has changed a lot since its original opening. Now it's basically a movie theater a small food court a Target store and a really nice place to view Yerba Buena Gardens. For a local it's a nice place to do some quick shopping, have a bite to eat, and go to a movie. For a tourist it might...


More  



Over the years, it seems this building has struggled to find its identity. But now it has a pretty good collection of walk-up casual fast food restaurants, plus a movie complex. The new Target store is a gigantic plus for the building and the area. The grassy areas outside are also nice in a downtown setting. During the last weekend...


More  



Went to see Mission Impossible Rogue Nation there and tried the ETX room. It's amazing. Great sound and a giant, crystal clear screen. Good entertainment option.

Metreon has improved over the past two years. First-floor eateries are nice. There's descent variety and it's a clean place to dine. AMC movie theater is an okay multi-cinema theater. It's nothing special. The view from the upper-floor windows is the best thing about Metreon. Looking out over Yerba Buena Gardens never gets old. And, the new Target was a...


More  



The building stands out, it was not too far from our hotel. it contains a cinema, some small shops and places to eat. We had a wander around but there are more interesting places to explore just outside.

This is a shopping center with a movie theater. It is not an attraction; with two exceptions - the view from the lobby of the move theater across from the snack bar and the clean bathrooms.
From the lobby of the movie theater you have a view of the park and behind it beautiful buildings which surround it. Whenever I...

title: Sundance Kabuki Cinema, San Francisco
review_list:
It was kind of cold damp December evening in San Francisco...we decided a movie was a good option...the Kabuki Cinema was a great choice because we could buy our tickets and reserve our seats on line...(I must have an aisle seat for comfort). It was also nice to be able to purchase your favorite alcoholic beverage, if you're so inclined...(be...


More  



Like reserving seats on line. Nice feature.
Easy to purchase tickets on line.
Was on the main floor.
Seats comfortable.
Had ice cream-bit overpriced, to be expected.
Food/drink options are probably better on balcony which is for 21+ years old.
Clean area.

Were excited for this adult cinema, serving drinks and food. Very pleased with both the wine list and food menu, all home made (non-fast food) local food menu. We had the club sandwich which was great, served with chips and wine. Loved it! Popcorn were also home made so very authentic. Theater and chairs were a nice size. Great date...


More  



I heard good things about this chain but in reality it's no better than any other.
Drinks and snacks are not competitive and screen and audio quality no better than any other

This is a lovely, intimate cinema experience that is much nicer than the big corporate multiplex cinemas. It is good for couples as the seats are largely in twos. The auditoria are small and the seats comfortable. The sound quality was on the loud side. The real thing for me was that although they have showings that kids can go...


More  



I'll be back. It was such a great experience. My bf and I hit the bar before heading into our movie. I love that there are little tables between a pair of chairs and the chairs themselves are pretty big. You need to purchase your designated seat before the show but I love that. You walk in with your drinks...


More  



I like that you can get assigned seats without worrying about coming to theater earlier to get a good seat. Theater provided food and beverage, we planned to eat while watching movies, but the line was so long that we could not wait without missing some of the movies, so we ended up watching the movie without ordering food. It's...


More  



After many days walking and exploring SF I wanted to give my feet a breather for an hour or two. They offer a better quality of snack (a beer isn't bad either). The best are the 21 and up shows.

Comfortable seating. Seat can be preselected on line. Bar service so you can have a nice drink with your movie. Good sound system. Escalators...

We absolutely loved seeing a movie here. We purchased the balcony seats for 21 and over crowd. Loved the bar and food selections. We both had craft beers we don't usually find too many places. We ordered the steak quesadilla and chicken tenders. Chicken was good, but the quesadillas were outstanding. It was nice to sit in reclining, theater seats...

title: 7D-Experience, San Francisco
address: Pier 39, Building M-1, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
Went in with my adult son for a laugh and was quite impressed with set up . We played the road warrior game ( not sure if thats the right name ) and enjoyed it . Decided to go again for the $7 deal and played the Zombie game . The Zombie game was awesome and a lot of fun...


More  



We had some tickets for this from a school promotion, so we decided to do it. There are several different "games". We did the Zombie Game. You sit in a theatre, wearing 3D glasses and get to shoot the zombies with light guns. First of all, it was not scary at all. It is basically a large-sized video game. It...


More  



This is a group video-game style experience. You are escorted into an amphitheater-style room with moving chairs. Over the course of about 5 minutes you play a game with the group in which you try to kill all the zombies. Meanwhile, the game is in 3D and your chair is moving around. Pretty fun, but definitely overpriced for the quality...


More  



We never would have done this if it wasn't included, but my husband and I had a ball shooting the zombies! Great fun and be sure to do it!

We took our boys 6 & 10 for the experience (Gigatron I think it was called) and I don't know who had more fun then or me. It blew my mind it was like being on a roller coaster, gun range and syfy movie all at the same time. It was maybe 10 min which seemed a bit much for...


More  



Stumbled across this place and decided "why not...lets give it a try".
As an adult I remember thing like this from my childhood from Disneyland.....but this was way more high-tech (and hilarious!!)!!

The zombie experience was amazing. Really funy! We had ones of the 10 funiest minutes in my life.
We strongly recommed it. The images and movements were so coordinated that you feel inside the film

I have no knowledge of the rest of the experience, but as for the laser maze, it was a huge disappointment. Or perhaps I should say a small disappointment since that more accurately depicts the problem. My two boys were so excited to tackle a movie-style laser maze. After I plopped down $10 for the tickets, I was expecting them...


More  



This really was a super fun experience, and not just because I took 1st place. The price is only $12 per person for a 10 min. experience. Totally worth it! You get 3D glasses and a laser gun. The chairs move as simulated. My husband said he literally lost his guts at one point, saying he felt like he really...


More  



We went for the shooting game (via Groupon) and then did the lazer maze while waiting. The Zombie shooting game was really fun, only complaint is when the house is full, its really hard to figure out which one is your airpoint/dot.
Laser maze is really fun. makes you feel like you are in the movie Entrapment or Ocean's 12

Stumbled across this place and decided "why not...lets give it a try".

You must purchase at least a three day pass that allows unlimited riding for three consecutive days. Cables cars, railway, and buses.

title: Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial and Waterfall, San Francisco
review_list:
Right in the downtown area, near MOMA and the Yerba Buena, is this lovely little park. So many people on a sunny day, lounging and enjoying. The waterfall is so touching, such a legacy he left us.

View it from afar, view it from the sides, view it from behind, where you can read multi-lingual quotes from the great American civil rights leader and hero Martin Luther King. Find a favorite and read it out loud. Take photos from different angles. Also enjoy the rest of Yerba Buena and the surrounding area with so much to see...


More  



This is a beautiful waterfall designed memorial dedicated to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Located in San Francisco's eclectic Mission District.
It's super easy to find and definitely worth capturing. I enjoy seeing how different cities across the States honor Dr. King, I must say SF did me proud with this memorial.

Of all the MLK locations I've seen this by far is the best. It's such a peaceful place to visit with the waterfalls present. It's in a nice arts area and has a lot of space for people to read, relax and take in the atmosphere. Definitely a must see while in the area.

The Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial and Waterfall is located in the Yerba Buena Gardens. It is a nice waterfall, but not remarkable in any fashion. If you're in the area, as I was, it's worth stopping by to see the gardens and waterfall; however, I would not recommend going out of your way to visit this SF attraction.

We were not expecting much, but since we were in the Convention Center, we wandered over at lunch time. It's a lovely and tranquil little park and a very nice tribute to Dr. King. I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to make a trip here, but, if you're in the area, it's nice.

In the heart of the city, amongst the noise and chaos, is a roaring waterfall to comemorate the life of Dr. King. Children love to run their fingers across the glass plaques etched with moving quotes by the great peacemaker written in several languages.

SF stands for many, if not most of the principles that the Rev. Dr. MLK stood for; so, an appropriate and inspiring memorial seems to be needed, as well as a very peaceful waterfall... And, it's just steps from the Museum of the African Diaspora, another must-see...

We walked by here during lunch time and there were a ton of locals enjoying the park and having lunch! The memorial itself was well done and we enjoyed all of the quotes from Martin Luther King, Jr.
Definitely worth a quick stop if you're in the area or are looking for a nice spot for a picnic!

Nice spot to walk around in the city. Big grass area for a picnic or to just relax. Lots of things to do on all sides of this memorial.

title: St. Patrick Catholic Church, San Francisco
review_list:
I popped into St Patrick's during a busy Sunday afternoon and was instantly calmed by the tranquil atmosphere.
The church itself was nice enough but for anyone from Europe it wasn't particularly outstanding.
I sat at the back of the church for some time quietly watching a blessing. Sitting in the calm and welcoming atmosphere was the pleasure for me...


More  



Great church in the heart of downtown. Chimes out all the calls to prayers and if you are in the Marriott it works as a great alarm clock!

St Patrick is a beautiful Gothic style church that looks out of place on Mission Street among newer buildings. The 1851 church is well worth a brief stop if you are near MOMA or the convention center - well maintained with very nice stained glass.

Was blessed to attend a Sunday Mass and a weekday Mass here right next to our Marriott. What an inspiring priest and such a well-maintained historic Church in the heart of the city. Thank you for making it so easy to Keep The Faith!

Attended the Sunday 9:00 am mass because this church was close to Park Central hotel. Basic mass; beautiful church.

Loved the stained glass at this house of worship. The structure is classic to view. If you're a fan of old churches like myself, you'll enjoy the experience here.

I happened to joint the mass in this church. The stained glasses were beautiful and overall the church was not over decorated at all, which fits to my taste.

We attended Mass at 10:30am on a Sunday and the Mass was impressed with the beauty of the building.
The Mass was said in Latin and English (although it was not a Latin Mass which uses pre-Vatican II format).
It looked like a great community of faith that we were able to join them for a short while.

This church in a way reminds me of St Patricks New York. It is church built in the Gothic style circa 1851 by the Irish who settled in San Francisco at that time. To day, just like New York it is dwarfed by skyscrapers. A little oasis of a church that survived earthquake and fire. The Irish are no longer...


More  



In an area of more modern buildings, St. Patrick's Catholic Church with its Gothic Architecture is pleasing to my eyes. I like the way it looks and am happy that it is an active church within San Francisco. It is close to the Yerba Buena Gardens/Metreon area of San Francisco.

This is a beautiful waterfall designed memorial dedicated to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Located in San Francisco's eclectic Mission District.
It's super easy to find and definitely worth capturing. I enjoy seeing how different cities across the States honor Dr. King, I must say SF did me proud with this memorial.

Of all the MLK locations I've seen this by far is the best. It's such a peaceful place to visit with the waterfalls present. It's in a nice arts area and has a lot of space for people to read, relax and take in the atmosphere. Definitely a must see while in the area.

The Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial and Waterfall is located in the Yerba Buena Gardens. It is a nice waterfall, but not remarkable in any fashion. If you're in the area, as I was, it's worth stopping by to see the gardens and waterfall; however, I would not recommend going out of your way to visit this SF attraction.

We were not expecting much, but since we were in the Convention Center, we wandered over at lunch time. It's a lovely and tranquil little park and a very nice tribute to Dr. King. I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to make a trip here, but, if you're in the area, it's nice.

In the heart of the city, amongst the noise and chaos, is a roaring waterfall to comemorate the life of Dr. King. Children love to run their fingers across the glass plaques etched with moving quotes by the great peacemaker written in several languages.

SF stands for many, if not most of the principles that the Rev. Dr. MLK stood for; so, an appropriate and inspiring memorial seems to be needed, as well as a very peaceful waterfall... And, it's just steps from the Museum of the African Diaspora, another must-see...

We walked by here during lunch time and there were a ton of locals enjoying the park and having lunch! The memorial itself was well done and we enjoyed all of the quotes from Martin Luther King, Jr.
Definitely worth a quick stop if you're in the area or are looking for a nice spot for a picnic!

Nice spot to walk around in the city. Big grass area for a picnic or to just relax. Lots of things to do on all sides of this memorial.

title: St. Patrick Catholic Church, San Francisco
review_list:
I popped into St Patrick's during a busy Sunday afternoon and was instantly calmed by the tranquil atmosphere.
The church itself was nice enough but for anyone from Europe it wasn't particularly outstanding.

More  



Great church in the heart of downtown. Chimes out all the calls to prayers and if you are in the Marriott it works as a great alarm clock!

St Patrick is a beautiful Gothic style church that looks out of place on Mission Street among newer buildings. The 1851 church is well worth a brief stop if you are near MOMA or the convention center - well maintained with very nice stained glass.

Was blessed to attend a Sunday Mass and a weekday Mass here right next to our Marriott. What an inspiring priest and such a well-maintained historic Church in the heart of the city. Thank you for making it so easy to Keep The Faith!

Attended the Sunday 9:00 am mass because this church was close to Park Central hotel. Basic mass; beautiful church.

Loved the stained glass at this house of worship. The structure is classic to view. If you're a fan of old churches like myself, you'll enjoy the experience here.

I happened to joint the mass in this church. The stained glasses were beautiful and overall the church was not over decorated at all, which fits to my taste.

We attended Mass at 10:30am on a Sunday and the Mass was impressed with the beauty of the building.
The Mass was said in Latin and English (although it was not a Latin Mass which uses pre-Vatican II format).
It looked like a great community of faith that we were able to join them for a short while.

This church in a way reminds me of St Patricks New York. It is church built in the Gothic style circa 1851 by the Irish who settled in San Francisco at that time. To day, just like New York it is dwarfed by skyscrapers. A little oasis of a church that survived earthquake and fire. The Irish are no longer...


More  



In an area of more modern buildings, St. Patrick's Catholic Church with its Gothic Architecture is pleasing to my eyes. I like the way it looks and am happy that it is an active church within San Francisco. It is close to the Yerba Buena Gardens/Metreon area of San Francisco.

This was one of the top things that I enjoyed on my San Francisco visit. Informative, inspirational, woke up the brain cells and fun! Good for any age. Had a great time with all the hands on displays. A really neat place.

I've been to a lot of exhibits and galleries in my life but none like this. The inventions span games to architecture to humanitarian to software. Some things you can interact with.

If you like science at all, you really need to go to this little gallery. It has limited hours but is worth the trip.

The Austodesk Gallery is hidden away on the 2nd floor of an office building near the Ferry Terminal. title: Golden Gate Park Windmills & Tulips, San Francisco

review_list:

Today they are historic windmills to see. When first built, they were used to pump water. They pumped over 1 1/2 million gallons on a daily basis.
During tulip season, we especially like to visit this area.

title: Lyon Street Steps, San Francisco

review_list:
A must experience for those visiting the Pacific Heights area of San Francisco. There is a beautiful garden halfway down the steps. The views of Alcatraz, Palace of Fine Arts and Angel Island are wonderful.

These steps should not be missed!! The bottom of these steps are at Lyon &Green in the Pacific Heights area of San Francisco. A nice area with an AWESOME view to the Bay, easy parking. My boyfriend and I parked the car on Broadway and Lyon Streets at the top of the steps. More  



Pacific Heights is just a stunning part of San Francisco and this is an absolutely must see spot. Since there are only 12 TA reviews, I guess it hasn't made it to that many people's radar screens.

Lots of locals were out and about jogging up and down these steps. My brother and I took the bus to the top and walked down on our way to the Palace. Glad we came down instead of up! More  



Maybe it was the time of day I was here, but unlike Fillmore or 16th Avenue, there were quite a few people running these stairs with reps, and timing themselves. We walked down Lyon Street from our hotel on California Street. We walked to the to the Palace of Fine Arts and then back up. There are stopping points along the way to catch your breath. More  



Returned to San Francisco and delighted to find the Lyon Street Steps available for trekking up and down. This is OFF the beaten path and known to locals. Arrived as the fog still hide the Golden Gate bridge from view. Up and down several times. Quite a workout. Enjoy!

Between Pacific Heights and Cow Hollow, just on the edge of Presidio and not far from the Palace of Fine Arts (with its stunning dome) are the Lyon Street steps.The views from the top are spectacular! title: Noe Valley, San Francisco
review_list:
You probably need Silicon Valley wages to live in Noe Valley, with its many streets of lovely, well-kept Victorian Houses.
It is off the beaten track for most visitors to SF, but is definitely worth the visit, not just for the architecture, but also for the shopping and restaurants and general laid back, and lovely vibe - all centred around...


More  



This is a wonderful place to stay in San Francisco for a number of reasons. It's a beautiful, peaceful, safe and generally friendly neighborhood with lots of shops, restaurants and a Whole Foods (a smaller one than some others, but still good). Great shoe stores, by the way. The sun shines here more often than in most places on the...


More  



24th Street is a great place for tourists and locals to walk around, there are plenty of one-of-a-kind locally owned shops and restaurants easily accessible from the 48 or 24 Muni lines.

A wonderfully funky part of San Francisco to visit with many small gift shops, cafes , restaurants and other retail therapy. Just take the Bart to 24 th and mission ( 3 stops, 2 dollars) and walk up into the Valley area. Eat at Fresca or Savor or any of the bars and cafes.

Lots of unusual one of a kind shops. A lot of interesting architecture. Limited parking areas. And hills.

Stayed in Noe valley at the beginning of our visit for 10 days, really lovely area-the village is particulary nice. Easy transport to the city from Church St on the bus. Also a really beautiful church, gothic architecture and wonderful stained glass windows Well done to all the parishioners who decorated the altar for Christmas -really beautiful!

An upscale area with beautiful homes and a quaint shopping area with fun shops and dining spots.. Found a great apartment in Noe valley for my son to live in while going to Grad school .. lots of families, children and dog walkers :)

Noe/Mission (24th) has 2.5 really great beer places where the (mostly) locals go.
#1 Rosamunde (@BART, 24th @ Mission)
#2 CaskHouse (3853 24th St/ btw Sanchez and Vicksburg)
#3 Valley Tavern. 24th @ Castro st. (lots of taps - however it only gets a 1/2 star)
Why go? The locals are fun and love beer plus it is a safe...


More  



S.F. has so many great neighborhoods to explore, and Noe Valley is no exception. Filled with lots of great restaurants, shops and of course, just fun to stroll and people watch. Stayed on Duncan Street in Noe Valley for 5 days. Very nice area, lots of lovely little restaurants to eat at. title: Golden Gate Park Windmills & Tulips, San Francisco
address: 1691 John F Kennedy Dr, San Francisco, CA 94121
review_list:
In the spring the tulips are so beautiful, even though it is not a large area. Throughout the year the landscaping changes, the parade of colors and shapes a delight to the eye.

We visited the windmill area of Golden Gate Park. One can also see the windmill from the beach area.
Today they are historic windmills to see. When first built, they were used to pump water. They pumped over 1 1/2 million gallons on a daily basis.
During tulip season, we especially like to visit this area.

Windmills and tulips, and also the name of a queen from our past... It was a weird experience to see these old high-build mills at the border of the Great Ocean. Tulips were not avaliable in the fall, so the buildings looked even more odd.

Had a great time, the host was a sweetheart! loved every place we went, overall great experience I will totally do it again.

More  



I have taken this crawl 2 times. In May and November 2015. I had an awesome time and found some new friends. I thank the wonderful Mayya for great guiding and for making me feel welcome ini SF. I also thank her for having patience with a crazy swedish guy.
If you´re ever going to SF, don´t miss this crawl.

It was a good show. The place, not so good. But the worst this are the waiters that start cleaning the tables and bringing the bills 20 mimutes before the show ends boring the musicians and the audience as they decide when the show ends.

title: Pier 23 Cafe, San Francisco
address: On the Embarcadero, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
The cafe is ideally located in the tourist zone of San Francisco on Emarcadero. It takes just a few minutes to walk to the cafe from the famous Pier 39 with its hundreds of sea lions sunbathing in front of spectators or from the ferry station.
There are indoor dining halls in this cafe, as well as an open terrace...


More  



Visited here several times and found the food was great, drinks reasonable and the view was exceptional . Looking out across the bay added to the enjoyment of this bar.

I went here because I know the place. I have been here before and enjoyed the atmosphere, drinks, and food. The service has never been incredible but I chose it again for the familiarity and because I wanted a place close to where I was staying where I could watch the game.
After standing at the, "please wait to be...


More  



Very cozy bar/restaurant which packs up very quickly. Tasty food/(oysters!!!) and a good selection of draft makes this a great venue. Out back you are right on the water with outdoor seating. Later, live entertainers come in and (on my last visit) played music from the roaring 20's. Great spot. (needs more seating)

At the end of our first day in SF my girlfriend and I had some craft beer in this little cafe. It was a nice and short visit. It is definitly worth it to stop by.

Pier 23 is one of the smaller Pier along the walk of the Pier's with a great little cafe/bar that has fabulous views across the bay. A nice place to stop off for a drink and a snack. (forget the coffee....nobody seems to make great coffee in America!... that is my mission to find one that does!)

This is a great bar with live music, great beer and lovely food. We was walking past and decided to have a drink in here. There was a band on when we first walked in which was great to watch but after they had finished we went and sat outside and the views of the bay are amazing. The staff...


More  



We eat here every time we come to San Francisco and always enjoy the experience. My husband started with drinks after a long morning of travel...Bloody Marys and draft beer...a great way to start vacation! We shared the fish tacos and absolutely delicious clam chowder. The view was delightful, but breezy, as to be expected.

We asked our concierge for a place to have a family celebration that was casual, reasonably priced, and had a variety of food. He made us reservations at Pier 23. Our family of 14, aged from 5 to 67, were given a table outside, on the water. They have a large menu that accommodated those that love seafood, and those...


More  



The food is fresh and the view is great. The service made it even nicer. The price is reasonable. Parking is off street and can be easy to find if coming in the early evening. There's a live music on the weekend as well. It's a nice little spot.

The food is fresh and the view is great. The service made it even nicer. The price is reasonable. Parking is off street and can be easy to find if coming in the early evening. There's a live music on the weekend as well. It's a nice little spot.

title: Lou's Fish Shack, San Francisco
address: 300 Jefferson St. at Jones St., Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
This is no posh restaurant but very well located along Fisherman's Wharf and offers fast dine-in service. We tried 2 varieties of grilled fish and a lovely plate of fish tacos (unusual!). The Margaritas are served in an ordinary tumbler glass but have generous tequila serving size and lots of flavour. Prices are mid-range and overall we had a fine...


More  



Very tasty. Perfectly spicy and with corn tortillas. Even though it's in the midst of a very touristy area the service and food where good.

We ate fish and chips outside and it was busy. The fish and chips were good but they weren't extra special. Service started out ok but then had to wait pretty long for waitress to bring the bill. Overall it was a good experience.

We sat here for a drink and a bite, the staff was friendly and the food was okay. Not special, just okay. What doen really do it here, was the gear few.

Hey, we guys had Lunch at this Restaurant on 02 October, we ordered grilled salmon, Oysters and some Beer, the Beer was good but the oysters n Salmon Ruled us, I asked the bartender that where do you guys get the Salmon so she is like that's the secret, better than a gourmet Salmon, my mouth still gets watered remembering...


More  



Went to Lou's for a quick bite. Tried the dungeness crab sandwich; it was juicy and tasty. My husband had the salad with grilled prawns; average at most... I can make a better salad at home. Outdoor seating with big umbrellas for shade was nice. Good service.

We had a couple of beers ( The Golden Gate IPA was good), the Crab Bisque, a crab sandwich and the shrimp pasta. All were good, the service was good as well, but there are too many above average places nearby to rate it any higher.
We went here our last night of a week long holiday. We should have...


More  



What a pleasant relief from the extravagant prices around the pier. Stopped in on a week day after noon and it happened to be happy hour. $5 wings, calamari, margaritas, and specialty beers. Food was good service was good and the restaurant was actually clean.

Along Fisherman's Wharf there are many restaurants offering similar menus including the typical clam chowder, shrimps and prawns in many ways (salad, fried, with pasta, etc.), sandwiches and fish. Lou's Fish Shack is one of the busiest. The place looks more a practical than a fancy place, but that's ok, you are in SF. Waiter was correct, probably too informal,...


More  



While there are quite a few eateries on the Wharf, few are worth the money. However, we happened to go by Lou's during happy hour where they had $5 wings, fried calamari, margaritas & drafts so we stopped. Both the calamari & wings were good and a good value during happy hour. Nothing else on the menu appealed to us...


More

title: Beach Chalet, San Francisco
address: 1000 Great Highway, at Ocean Beach, Between Lincoln and Fulton, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
I recently had dinner here with a family member who was visiting from out of town. We wanted to have dinner and take in the sunset. The Beach Chalet itself is an old beautiful building which is quite impressive.
When we arrived we were quickly seated by the seating host. There were plenty of available tables and lots of staff...


More  



We had dinner here with friends of ours who live in SF and they say it's one of their favourite places to eat out.
The food and service was great, our waiter was especially attentive and friendly.
What's really stunning though is of course the magnificent view. You can oversee a large part of the beach and the sea, so...


More  



My first Ciopinno dish aam francisco and the fish was truly delicious. The view of the ocean was also stunning on a very warm day in July. Service was excellent and our food came out piping hot. Will definitely eat there again. Great venue opposite the beach.

We arrived without a reservation and were seated quickly - the window tables were all RSVPed so we sat across from the view. And it a wonderful view even from across the way. Sarah was a friendly and efficient waitress. Our food was brought quickly to the table and was very tasty.

Arrived at 7:00 PM for my scheduled reservation, confirmed by phone with the restaurant at 7:30 PM. was told to wait to be seated by 8:00 PM. Come back and check with hostess. Came back at 7:55 and table was still not available. Was told then that they had overbook resulting in the waiting time.

Ocean Beach is beautiful. This place was recommended to us by a local person on the bus and we thank him! Three of us had different meals-seafood linguine, veggie bocatelli, and fish and chips. All fresh and delicious. Beautiful views. Quick service. I am a beer snob and the beer was pretty darn good as well. Thanks!

Lunch with hubby - went on recommendation from a friend. Lucked out on both a prime parking space and window table.
Beer was cold and tasty - food hit the spot - arancini app was good - as was my crab cake - thought hubby's fish and chips was so-so.

I rank the food average but the view is excellent if you can get a window table. The building is an important landmark and you can read its history in the room below the restaurant. A nice place to lunch on a sunny day at the beach.

Sept. 7 2014, For my birthday. Our waitress was great, but when you have bad help from kitchen to table it reflects on her! My crab eggs benedict was brought with not crab as well as my other quest. It was brought back to the kitchen, and we were still waiting for the rest of our party (12) to get...


More  



Only had to wait 5 minutes for a window seat for 4 at noon on Saturday. When we left if was a much longer wait. Great view of the beach and the ships coming into SF Harbor. I had an oyster stout beer which I think is brewed on premises. Pretty good for $5. Friend had a house Bloody Mary....$11.50!...


More

title: The National Shrine of Saint Francis of Assisi, San Francisco
review_list:
Loving the story of Saint Francis of Assisi and what he stood for, made this visit even more memorable. One of the greatest experiences is to visit the replica of the chapel which is next door. I spoke to one of the Franciscan Monks for over half an hour. Truly an experience I will not forget. The gift shop is...


More  



A beautiful building, which provides sanctuary from the city outside. Worth visiting if you are in this area.

You really need to take the time to walk through the church . It is so beautiful. I love the paintings on the ceilings. You will be awe struck when you look down the pews to the front. Words can not describe the beauty and peace.

Stop in - to see this grand church. No longer a parish and supported only through donations. Feels spiritual and will touch your heart.

I had the great joy of visiting the National Shrine of St. Francis of Assisi and discovering the beautiful replica of St. Francis' Chapel in Assisi. This treasure is a place of prayer and recollection, but also a visual splendor of Frescoes, tile work, stonework and atmosphere so like Italy, you would think you were transported. The attendants to the...


More  



It was on a food walking tour that we were shown the National Shrine of Saint Francis of Assisi. We were privileged to be welcomed by a church greeter and invited to tour the shrine and enjoy.
La Nuova Porziuncola is a scaled replica of Saint Francis's Porziuncola in Assisi, Italy, and we were delighted to say that it brought...


More  



While the church itself is closed for renovations, the 75% scale model of St Francis' church in Assisi is holy and wonderful. A nice place to light a candle and offer a prayer before the blessed sacrament. Daily mass at 12:30, Sunday at 11. Free, but seek donations for upkeep of the national shrine. Cool gift shop right around the...


More  



The Cathedral is temporarily closed for renovation; rumor is that it will open in September 2014. The adjacent chapel is open.
The adjacent chapel, La Porziuncola Nuova, is a scaled replica of Saint Francis's Porziuncola in Assisi, Italy. It was dedicated in San Francisco on September 27, 2008 by Cardinal William J. Levada, Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine...


More  



This is definitely a visit for pilgrims. There was a special service when we visited, so we were given the opportunity to see the Shrine and Church in the early evening.

We stopped by this church while strolling along in North beach. We also visited the gift shop. This church is just exquisite. Take time to stop by this gorgeous church and it's history. As you enter the church you are on a marble floor from Assisi. There is an exact replica of the original Porziuncola Nuova in Assisi Italy. All...

title: Xanadu Gallery (V. C. Morris Gift Shop), San Francisco
review_list:
Unfortunately it looks as though Xanadu is no longer in this building. When I visited today the place was closed up with a big 'to lease' notice across the window. Peering through the window the place looked empty.
What a shame! I hope I'm wrong, or at least that the building opens to the public again soon. The architecture inside...


More  



A beautiful gallery with drool-worthy jewelry and objects d'art
from Asia and Africa. The building that houses this stunning collection was designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.

Although this isn't strictly an attraction - it is an art gallery just off Union Square which has many beautiful pieces for sale - it is the only Frank Lloyd Wright building in San Francisco. The prototype for the Guggenheim in NYC, it is incredibly beautiful inside, and you are welcome to go in and look around, even if you...


More  



for over 20 years have known marsha vargus . she know so much about Asian art and goes to Asian week nyc every year past years has had art works in galley there. we know no matter what day we can go we will find art we would love to have for our home the gallery has lots of south...


More  



This store is tucked on a little street just off Union Square that has a European feel (dining tables set in the middle of the street just up from the gallery). While the merchandise is mostly very pricey antiquities, and the staff is very friendly and willing to take them out and show you the items, the main reason to...


More  



I entered the Xanadau Gallery on Maiden Lane and was impressed by the superb art collection. I also noticed that they had similar Japanese art prints to some that I had at home. The staff there is very good and willing to answer all the questions I had and gave very good answers. Its impressive place to go for this...


More  



Just off Union Square we found the Xanadu. It has had several names over the years but is special in that it was designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. It is free entry and when inside it had the spiral walkway just like Wright's other design - the Guggenheim in New York. The displays were mainly Chinese dynasties showing carvings and...


More  



This is Frank Lloyd Wright's only building in San Francisco, and it's an unknown treasure! Originally designed as the V.C Morris Gift Shop, The building now houses the Xanadu Gallery. They have lovingly restored the building and are proud as punch to let you roam around it at your leisure.. The building was designed in 1948, and incorporated the now...


More  



We stopped in because we are architecture buffs. The staff was very friendly. The details are very interesting, and the merchandise accents the feel of the building. The gift ware is good quality, with some items being socially responsible. Stop in, they don't mind if you are just there to see the neat building, which feels round but is actually...


More  



This is a nice place to rest from the craziness of Union Square. The visit takes 10-15 minutes and you will see nice African art mostly. I wouldn't make a detour for this Galery but you will certainly go to Union Square, so it`s worth a stop.I wouldn't bring my young kids (0-10).

title: Camera Obscura, San Francisco
address: 1096 Point Lobos Ave, San Francisco, CA 94121
review_list:
Well worth the paltry $3 admission. We were alone the whole time we were inside. This obscura actually has rotating lenses, so the incredibly detailed image (reflection) we see on the screen is not only in motion as it moves from ocean to street to sidewalk to cliffs, but you can see vividly even the waves crashing. Although I've only...


More  



For only 3 dollars each its definitely worth a look. The 360 degree view of outside display in front of you on a "plate" in a dark room.

Not a very attractive building from the outside but prepare to be surprised. This is science at its most basic but the result is beautiful. This is a daytime activity.

This tiny little building really packs a punch! you see the surrounding beaches live in this amazing contraption! it was about 2 bucks per person, and worth every penny, probably could get 5 bucks per person, but they stay lower priced and that is cool!

A neat little stop while in the area. For $3 enjoy the magic of mirrors and sunlight reflecting a live picture onto a wooden concave table. Knowing the technology stems from 11th century theories and plans makes it pretty awe inspiring.

If you are visiting the Cliff House, do pay the $3 admission fee and enter the world of the 1930's. They use mirrors to reflect the outside world onto a table in the center of the small dark room. They also have some old-style 3D photos on the wall. It is like being in Playland in the 1950's.
The camera,...


More  



My husband and I really enjoyed it. Very relaxing, and something you don't see every day. A fun thing to do. Pay the small fee - and just do it!

You can spend 5 minutes in this exhibit or you can spend an hour in the exhibit. Cheap entrance fee and a nice place to explore the visualizations of the environment around you while enjoying the sound of the waves. A very relaxing exhibit.

This is a very simple attraction, with a small entrance fee. You basically walk into a room that is a projection of the outside view of the ocean and seal rock using very basic camera technology. It's fascinating and worth the hike up the small overlook to see it. It may only take minutes to view, but it is something...


More  



Was here in the summer of 1990; glad to see it's still around. The images that are projected onto the viewing surface appear almost surreal-hard to explain! Make sure that you visit on a sunny day.

title: National AIDS Memorial Grove, San Francisco
address: 856 Stanyan Street, Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, CA 94117
review_list:
We decided to take the path less taken in golden gate park and walk down the stairs once we spotted the grove's sign. It's beautiful and serene! Came early in the am and without the crowds you hear the quietness and birds chirping ! It's well taken cared of by volunteers, the foliage is so beautiful and along the pathways...


More  



I've been to the Deyoung, etc. many times, but I didn't even know this memorial was here. Beautiful and peaceful. Highly recommended.

The National AIDS Memorial Grove is a landmark with a lot of history attached to it. It's beautiful to visit in the day, but even more amazing to visit during the annual Memorial Gala. Would definitely recommend visiting if in Golden Gate Park.

These gardens are simply beautiful. Such a serene and peaceful spot to leisurely wander through. A true credit to those who established it and to those volunteers that maintain it.

I have been fortunate enough to attend the Light in the Grove fundraiser two years in a row. This magical night is a Celebration of a year of hard work and upkeep of The Grove and raises funds for its continuation. The Gove is a serene place where the engraved names in the Circle of Friends, either your own, that...


More  



At home, we provide care to patients living with HIV/AIDS on a daily basis, so this memorial held some significance for us specifically. We got to Golden Gate Park by taking the 5R bus from downtown, which was a quick and easy trip. From there, it was a pleasant walk into the park itself. The grove is kept immaculately by...


More  



The memorial is awesome, a great place to visit while in Golden Gate park, we have nothing like it in Brazil. I loved the peace and quiet.

At the northern part of this huge Golden Gate Park is hidden this memorial grove, one dedicated to those suffering from AIDS and those who're fighting against it.
Walking down a few steps, I saw a shrine-like open ground in the middle in a size of four basketball courts. On its two longer edges are religiously grown bushes, which I...


More  



This is a sobering meander along the hillside. Relax and enjoy the quiet places for reflection. Very near the lawn bowling.

This space is freaking awesome. I wish we had anything like this in Houston. The park is very large, with amazing spaces created to honor the loved ones we have lost to AIDS.

title: Macondray Lane, San Francisco
address: Jones Street between Union and Green Streets, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Even if you're not a Tales of the City fan this charming little byway is really beautiful and worth a visit. Pure San Francisco! For Maupin followers it has assumed almost shrine status. But sad to see on our latest visit this week after a few years that the iconic wooden staircase is looking so forlorn.

So pleased to have found this little gem. Loved the series of books and have read them several times. Pretty little walkway made you feel like you were in the real heart of San Fran. A must see for Tales of the City fans

It's pretty amazing when an author creates characters that become "friends". I loved the Tales of the City and the characters. Couldn't wait to see their "home". This quaint little lane is fun to visit if you are a fan. The views of the bay are amazing! Read the books and visit the lane that inspired Barbary Lane.

This was a quiet little walkway, hidden away off the main busy streets. I like it as it felt like a secret and was really pretty with lovely flowers and a wooden entrance

The 45 bus goes up and down Russian Hill on Union. That's fun by itself because of the steepness of the hill. You just get off at Jones and walk UP the hill toward Green. Hell of a hill but it's only half a block. Turn left into Macondray Lane. It is a public right of way, the private part...


More  



Again I'm a Tales Of The City fan so had to see it. Would love to live here in this peaceful spot. Beautiful views through the trees and shrubs.
I especially enjoyed seeing all the different plants and flowers growing beneath the trees.
It's a breath of fresh air in a bustling city.

Having read the Tales of the City books many, many times, this was my pilgrimage to where it all began, Barbary Lane (or Macondray Lane as it's actually called).
The lane is peaceful and has amazing views of the Bay.
The high light for me was of course the famous steps, a must for all Tales fans.

I didn't know about the tv serie, but I just ended up there upon suggestion and I really enjoyed my time there, a small "forest" in the middle of the city. very nice!

As a huge fan of the books (I've read most of the books two or three times), I went on a sort of secular pilgrimage to Macondry Lane.
For fans, the place is magical. I was so excited to see the stairs leading up to it - exactly as I imagined it in the books. Spectacular views of the Bay...


More  



This is where Armistead Maupin got his inspiration to write Tales of the city and where the tv series was filmed for the iconic steps. Fans of the books will love it here!!! Great views over the city, but not much else.

title: National AIDS Memorial Grove, San Francisco
address: 856 Stanyan Street, Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, CA 94117
review_list:
We decided to take the path less taken in golden gate park and walk down the stairs once we spotted the grove's sign. It's beautiful and serene! Came early in the am and without the crowds you hear the quietness and birds chirping ! It's well taken cared of by volunteers, the foliage is so beautiful and along the pathways...


More  



I've been to the Deyoung, etc. many times, but I didn't even know this memorial was here. Beautiful and peaceful. Highly recommended.

The National AIDS Memorial Grove is a landmark with a lot of history attached to it. It's beautiful to visit in the day, but even more amazing to visit during the annual Memorial Gala. Would definitely recommend visiting if in Golden Gate Park.

These gardens are simply beautiful. Such a serene and peaceful spot to leisurely wander through. A true credit to those who established it and to those volunteers that maintain it.

I have been fortunate enough to attend the Light in the Grove fundraiser two years in a row. This magical night is a Celebration of a year of hard work and upkeep of The Grove and raises funds for its continuation. The Gove is a serene place where the engraved names in the Circle of Friends, either your own, that...


More  



At home, we provide care to patients living with HIV/AIDS on a daily basis, so this memorial held some significance for us specifically. We got to Golden Gate Park by taking the 5R bus from downtown, which was a quick and easy trip. From there, it was a pleasant walk into the park itself. The grove is kept immaculately by...


More  



The memorial is awesome, a great place to visit while in Golden Gate park, we have nothing like it in Brazil. I loved the peace and quiet.

At the northern part of this huge Golden Gate Park is hidden this memorial grove, one dedicated to those suffering from AIDS and those who're fighting against it.
Walking down a few steps, I saw a shrine-like open ground in the middle in a size of four basketball courts. On its two longer edges are religiously grown bushes, which I...


More  



This is a sobering meander along the hillside. Relax and enjoy the quiet places for reflection. Very near the lawn bowling.

This space is freaking awesome. I wish we had anything like this in Houston. The park is very large, with amazing spaces created to honor the loved ones we have lost to AIDS.

title: SoMa (South of Market Street), San Francisco
address: Bounded by Market, First and Townsend Sts., San Francisco, CA 94103
review_list:
Filled with restaurants, food trucks, cafes, bars, businesses/companies, this area is interesting and near enough to city center, that it's an easy diversion.

I tried to understand why this are is even on the "to visit" map. It is just a neighbourhood which had it's epic when nerdies were working there but now it has nothing special to offer other than a quiet area for locals

South of Market is a place to go when you want to sample cuisine from around the world and all in trucks! Not the fanciest dining but it is hearty and delicious and more reasonably priced than a sidewalk café. The area does have some need to improve but what district doesn’t and you won’t feel like holding onto your...


More  



This is a great place to visit if you like food. Plenty of food trucks, little cafes and interesting buildings all around. Stay a little aware of shady characters that hang around here though, nothing too dangerous that we witnessed. but helps to be a little careful walking about.

South of Market Street is a weird, but cool place to visit. There are a lot of well known companies that have their offices here. Firefox, Uber, etc

We stayed in this area. Its easy to get to Union Square. Shopping and movie theatre nearby as well as cafes, bars and restaurants. There was even a Burlington Coat Factory in the vicinity. The area is getting slowly gentrified but it can be a little dicey at night.

Great place to enjoy a great game/match on large screens with great Food Trucks from all parts of the world: Chinese, Vietnam, Indian, Burmese, Burgers and Beacon......

If you are looking for great shopping and great food you have it. Area has completely gentrified meaning you have a cityTarget, AMC, *beautiful* Westfield Mall (eat under the dome and you will see what I'm talking about), Marlowe, Fringale, Tin Vietnamese, and several other really great places to eat & drink.

The South of Market Street area in San Francisco, Ca. is a very nice area. My wife and I stayed there for a few nights as my son was in UCSF Medical Center. Not an area that you would want your wife out late at night by herself.

We were duped by a place we were supposed to stay when we booked our "hotel". Turns out we ended up in a place that we had to walk around SoMa and Mission street. Many displaced people and other characters. I wouldn't be walking alone here at night that is for sure!

title: Macondray Lane, San Francisco
address: Jones Street between Union and Green Streets, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Even if you're not a Tales of the City fan this charming little byway is really beautiful and worth a visit. Pure San Francisco! For Maupin followers it has assumed almost shrine status. But sad to see on our latest visit this week after a few years that the iconic wooden staircase is looking so forlorn.

So pleased to have found this little gem. Loved the series of books and have read them several times. Pretty little walkway made you feel like you were in the real heart of San Fran. A must see for Tales of the City fans

It's pretty amazing when an author creates characters that become "friends". I loved the Tales of the City and the characters. Couldn't wait to see their "home". This quaint little lane is fun to visit if you are a fan. The views of the bay are amazing! Read the books and visit the lane that inspired Barbary Lane.

This was a quiet little walkway, hidden away off the main busy streets. I like it as it felt like a secret and was really pretty with lovely flowers and a wooden entrance

The 45 bus goes up and down Russian Hill on Union. That's fun by itself because of the steepness of the hill. You just get off at Jones and walk UP the hill toward Green. Hell of a hill but it's only half a block. Turn left into Macondray Lane. It is a public right of way, the private part...


More

I especially enjoyed seeing all the different plants and flowers growing beneath the trees.
It's a breath of fresh air in a bustling city.

The lane is peaceful and has amazing views of the Bay.
The high light for me was of course the famous steps, a must for all Tales fans.

For fans, the place is magical. I was so excited to see the stairs leading up to it - exactly as I imagined it in the books. Spectacular views of the Bay...

title: Cellarmaker Brewing Company, San Francisco
review_list:
Lots of different beers to choose from, service was quick despite the fat that the place was packed. Clea bathrooms. They need to try and squeeze in ore seating though!

We stopped during Beer Week 2015. Great beer, good atmosphere. Since it was beer week, it was crowded, but the bar staff was attentive and provided great service. Looking forward to stopping again during this year's Beer Week.

Stopped here as I had a few hours to kill on my way to SFO. I called ahead and they weren't busy. Between the time I grabbed a cab and showed up, they were packed. The bartender remembered I had called and a had a barrel wheeled out from the brewery so I'd have a table top - great people...


More  



Great beer, lots of choices although IPA-focused, nice venue just off the major streets. A little small so not good for big groups but otherwise fantastic!

As part of a Northern California beer trip, we visited Cellarmaker in San Francisco on the insistence of a friend. We arrived in a very small but open space with a lively bar. The 2 bartenders were animated and quite friendly.
Beer prices were very fair and they offered small pours for samples. I was told their IPAs were the...


More  



Friendly and quick service and you can get 4oz flights to taste all the beers. A good range though some were out. Country music on the jukebox including Charlie Daniels band so kudos for that.

Cellarmaker had a really good selection of beer. They also have a poster signed by Huey Lewis in one of the bathrooms, so this is pretty much the coolest place ever. (No irony intended, I really like beer and Huey Lewis).

Cellarmaker Brewing Company is a new brewery in SOMA. What they lack in history is made up for in imaginative brewing. The tasting room was lively and friendly - housed in a industrial modern setting. They have lots of hoppy beers if you like IPAs.

My husband and I love to check out local breweries when we're visiting other cities. In San Francisco, I stumbled upon the reviews for Cellarmaker on Yelp and was excited by their hop-focused beers. We walked here (some of the streets in the area didn't look like the best, but it wasn't a terrible neighborhood), and on a Friday evening...


More

title: Rodney Lough Jr. San Francisco Gallery, San Francisco
review_list:
I wrote an earlier review about 3 years ago, but now Rodney Lough gallery is closed in San Francisco. The only gallery he has is in Las Vegas. I just don't want people going there thinking that it's still open in San Francisco. It was a great place, but now you'll have to go to Las Vegas to see his...


More  



This is an amazing gallery for Rodney's photographs. The displays are amazing, the lighting perfect. The photographs are not cheap but you are buying a work of art. Posters are available if you can only wish for the real thing. We have now bought 2 of Rodney's photographs and they are wonderful. We were helped on both occasions by Dana...


More  



Stumbled across this gallery while walking around Fisherman's Wharf. It's probably the best reason to go down there if you're a photographer or are into photography. The gallery is huge, the largest single artist gallery in the world apparently.
The photography is first rate, all shot on large format, so the prints are exquisite. If you've been to a Peter...


More  



The gallery itself is very attractive and well laid out. The photographs of Rodney Lough Jr. were eye catching. It was interesting to read about the gallery itself and the efforts that Mr. Lough made to make his gallery "green". The story of his career as a photographer was also very interesting. We spent a while talking with one of...


More  



I wish I could afford his work!!! absolutely by far the most beautiful images that still resonate in my mind. He captures the warmth and beauty of nature . I've been to some of the places Rodney photographs and the way he presents these are magical. It is mystical the way he brings out feelings in my soul I didn't...


More  



My wife and I visited the wharf in early June, and just happened to pass the gallery. I am a huge fan of all things Yosemite, and noticed an amazing photograph from the street so we went in.
1st, I want to say this is a review of the gallery, and not Rodney Lough Jr's work, which is extraordinary. I...


More  



Loved everything about this gallery! If you love art, you must visit this place. Each peace took my breath away. Very tranquil, fun, emotional, melancholy, peaceful, happiness, sadness, spiritual.... I mean each piece speaks to you in a different way.

There used to be several Lough galleries, but it appears that they have consolidated in San Francisco and this is by far the largest of any they previously operated. While thier intent is to sell you Rodney's outstanding photography, the place is set up to invite browsing without feeling pressured. You can walk through and the salespeople will give you...


More  



This gallery is right in the tourist area of Fisherman's Bay. I am a photography hobbyist and love looking at photographer's work. I sometimes look at landscape photography and think it's ok - I could probably have taken that though. Not so here - every single image was breathtaking, and each so beautifully presented. I could probably have spent a...


More  



Didn't know what to expect but thrilled we found the gallery down on Fisherman's wharf. His photos are fantastic and displayed beautifully. We were treated really well by Dana, who showed us several pieces and how they change in different lights. Definitely worth a visit..

title: Winery Collective, San Francisco
review_list:
Perfect for a wine tasting introduction to Californian local wines! Mark was a brilliant host giving us just enough information and entertainment. We ended up tasting both flights and bought a couple of wines to take home too!

While walking Jefferson Street near Hyde Pier and the cable car end stop we found this gem, Winery Collective. Mark greeted my friend and I as we entered the door. We had stopped for a wine tasting and wonderful flights are offered. Mark spent time with us and seemed to know the wines that each of us would enjoy. He...


More  



Mark is over the top nice and very informative wine is great, wines that you cannot find anywhere else, the petit Syrah is second to none

Had 6 tastes for two for $30 including tax and tip. Conveniently located next to the lovely Argonaut Hotel, we sampled two whites, three reds and a sparkling wine. Damon was our host and did a superb job explaining what we were tasting. Loved it.

After several unsuccessful tries to book a Napa valley tour , I decided to try this winery to taste some of the best Californian wines . You can send there a couple of hours discussing the wonderful art of winery.
The staff is very helpful and they really know their wines. Also since your there try the restaurant next door...


More  



Saw the sign and decided to try a flight. Three of the flight were nice, the others fine. Nice bartender, lovely group of Europeans at the bar with me. Fun time, not overly expensive- I suggest the more expensive flight. The bottles themselves can feel pricey.
Would come back.

First, we are avowed winos, and second, I never look at ads in the hotel magazines, or on printed area maps. However, this was an exception, and I am glad that I made it.
Wife's meetings were canceled, and after a conference call, we found ourselves with an entire afternoon free in San Francisco. I studied my concierge-supplied area map,...


More  



I was in San Fran for one week and I had been wanting to try to place. My wife finally decided to go in on our last night. We both tried a sampler. Wines are good but expensive. Bottles are 30$ and up. As soon as we were done, we were asked to pay and basically leave. I couldnt just...


More  



It was a warm day in Aug and the crowds on the sidewalks were dense. I barely noticed signage at eye level for this place and stepped in. What a pleasant surprise. A nice welcome from the wine server and a lovely lovely, airy space adjacent to The Argonaut Hotel. I sat down and relaxed. They had 2 different flights,...


More  



Although the place has a great ambiance and very good location next to the Argonaut Hotel, if the bartender has a fedora on, walk out and go across the street. Extremely rude and we won't go back.

title: Lafayette Park, San Francisco
address: Washington, Sacramento, Gough and Laguna Streets, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Did a walk around the square and had a look at the recommended walking tour online before I went. Lots of very pretty houses and interesting architecture. Worth the visit.

This is a local hang out mostly occupied by the children and dogs of well to do residents, high above Fisherman's Wharf. Some of the approach streets have gradients that might deter all but the hardiest walkers but are liberally dotted with stylish old houses and manicured gardens. A panoramic approach to the Golden Gate and views of water that...


More  



What a gem of a park! It's clean, there's an amazing playground area for kids of all ages, and a cute little off-leash dog area. Loved it!

I saw this park on the map the hotel gave me and had never heard of it, so I decided to check it out. What a fantastic park! I loved it! It seems that the neighbors primarily use this park, and they were friendly. But the houses surrounding the park, particularly on the north side and heading down Octavia St...


More  



Spectacular views from an under used park frequented primarily by dog owners. In true neurotic, Californian style dogs are forced to be exercised on an area of astro-turf. Come on you guys, get a life.

What a wonderful park. Stunning views towards the bay and the city. Clean, quiet and lovely, and with wonderful, tall trees. If I'd brought food and coffee I would have stayed there all day.

Great on cool days, as there is very little tree cover in the playground. There are water fountains that have been turned off due to the drought. Otherwise, fun slides and the scenery is pretty. Good spot for picnics.

Wouldn't say this merited a visit on its own, but worth taking in on walk of this area. However a very pleasant well tended hill park which is really is a large square in a period residential district east of Pacific Heights. From its highest point amongst the tall pines and manicured shrubbery are views of the Bay & Alcatraz...


More  



This is beautiful place to visit in the middle of San Fran. I can't get over the beauty of the parks all over this busy and packed city. Dog friendly place, clean public washrooms, big hills (that are loads of fun to roll down when you're four :-). The childrens' playground is great for ALL ages, and is safe, gated,...


More  



LaFayette Park is a great hilltop park a full city block square. It has just been renovated, and it looks right in line with the very nice Pacific Heights neighborhood - safe, clean, and classy.
They have just installed a large new playground, the best I've seen complete with a stone water path so kids can get their feet wet....


More

title: Hendric Point, San Francisco
review_list:
If you've ever seen a movie that was set in San Francisco you've seen this view. However, seeing it in person is unreal. I've been here many times in my travels to and from the bay area, and this view is something that I never get tired of. It's crowded all the time, and finding a decent place to park...


More  



The Golden gate bridge, in all its glory, on the way to Muir woods. Hard to find parking during holidays and can get crowded.

On the way to Sausalito, stop and see the Golden Gate Bridge in all its splendor. Great place to view the bridge in its beautiful color.

Another nice stop to get a view of the Golden Gate Bridge away from the more busier Vista Point. This is on the way to Sausalito.

Fantastic place to get views of the bridge and all of the surrounding area. But what are those odd people in suits and ties doing there? They just stood there next to some leaflets on a stand. I didn't make contact with them for fear of being whisked off by some sect or another. Odd.

We took our six year old and this was our first time here. A must see in the bay area! Great views in every direction.

Skip the overcrowded tourist trap at Vista Point on the way across the bridge from SF to Marin county. Go explore Sausalito and the Marin headlands, Muir woods etc, and catch the Alexander Ave exit going southbound on 101 on your way BACK into the city for the best view of the bridge and coast that there is. Just at...


More
