What a wonderful park. Stunning views towards the bay and the city. Clean, quiet and lovely, and with wonderful, tall trees. If I'd brought food and coffee I would have stayed there all day.

Great on cool days, as there is very little tree cover in the playground. There are water fountains that have been turned off due to the drought. Otherwise, fun slides and the scenery is pretty. Good spot for picnics.

Wouldn't say this merited a visit on its own, but worth taking in on walk of this area. However a very pleasant well tended hill park which is really is a large square in a period residential district east of Pacific Heights. From its highest point amongst the tall pines and manicured shrubbery are views of the Bay & Alcatraz...


More  



This is beautiful place to visit in the middle of San Fran. I can't get over the beauty of the parks all over this busy and packed city. Dog friendly place, clean public washrooms, big hills (that are loads of fun to roll down when you're four :-). The childrens' playground is great for ALL ages, and is safe, gated,...


More  



LaFayette Park is a great hilltop park a full city block square. It has just been renovated, and it looks right in line with the very nice Pacific Heights neighborhood - safe, clean, and classy.
They have just installed a large new playground, the best I've seen complete with a stone water path so kids can get their feet wet....


More

title: Hendric Point, San Francisco
review_list:
If you've ever seen a movie that was set in San Francisco you've seen this view. However, seeing it in person is unreal. I've been here many times in my travels to and from the bay area, and this view is something that I never get tired of. It's crowded all the time, and finding a decent place to park...


More  



The Golden gate bridge, in all its glory, on the way to Muir woods. Hard to find parking during holidays and can get crowded.

On the way to Sausalito, stop and see the Golden Gate Bridge in all its splendor. Great place to view the bridge in its beautiful color.

Another nice stop to get a view of the Golden Gate Bridge away from the more busier Vista Point. This is on the way to Sausalito.

Fantastic place to get views of the bridge and all of the surrounding area. But what are those odd people in suits and ties doing there? They just stood there next to some leaflets on a stand. I didn't make contact with them for fear of being whisked off by some sect or another. Odd.

We took our six year old and this was our first time here. A must see in the bay area! Great views in every direction.

Skip the overcrowded tourist trap at Vista Point on the way across the bridge from SF to Marin county. Go explore Sausalito and the Marin headlands, Muir woods etc, and catch the Alexander Ave exit going southbound on 101 on your way BACK into the city for the best view of the bridge and coast that there is. Just at...


More

title: BATS Improv, San Francisco
address: 2 Marina Blvd, Fort Mason Center, Bldg B, San Francisco, CA 94123
review_list:
In my opinion, BATS is the best improvised theater company in the Bay Area. The cast members are amazing storytellers -- I laughed and cried as an audience member on the same night.

Attended a performance where the audience was asked to text suggestions which appeared on the screen on the stage. The topic was the high price of housing in San Francisco. The performance started out well but morphed into an unfunny bit which even ended with one of the characters committing suicide. Improv should be funny, this was not.

After a dinner at Off the Grid Ft. Mason, we attended the third week of improv theatresport competition between The Judges and The Clowns. The performers were amazing and came up with such quick adaptations to their performances based on audience suggested topics. The evening went quickly and we were especially impressed with the expressiveness and creativity of Ben Johnson....


More  



Not your usual comedy or improv but great fun anyway. When we went it was a competition among two teams who did different types of scenes with suggestions from the audience.

A friend and I checked out BATS on the weekend. There is a small bar before you walk in with a few wine and beer options plus soft drinks. Had a fun time, the improv was good but we like Secret Improv Society on Sutter better. Some fun bits and audience interaction, check it out! The theater is in the...


More  



Our family went to their improv show on New Years eve while visiting San francisco. It was a fun family activity but not funny at all. They took a few suggestions from the audience - for example, the weather - and then put on a fairly scripted farce that was cute but not funny. The performers were spirited and the...


More  



I have been going to BATS for over 20 years and have thoroughly enjoyed every performance. I like other theaters as well, but BATS is my favorite because I always feel good when I leave, having laughed so heartily! If you are visiting San Francisco, BATS at Fort Mason will deliver a hilarious show!

We've enjoyed several evenings at BATS, ranging from their take on Downton Abbey, mysteries set in an imaginary English castle and other miscellaneous shows. They have always been a blast; the improvisation is truly impressive and the way they manage to have a show come full circle, bravo.
We enjoy taking our teenage kids there, but we've also been for...


More  



I've been attending shows at BATS for about 10 years and seeing their improv shows has really changed my perception about what is possible in an improv performance. Yes BATS perform Theatersports games in a mock competition and short form scenes and yes their shows are usually very funny, but its more than that. BATS has expanded the world of...


More  



I have laughed until I've cried in the BATS audience more than once. The improvisors at BATS are at the top of their art form. Student shows on Sundays are cheap and fun too.
They also have guest performances by the group 3forAll -- those shows are not to be missed!

title: Neiman-Marcus, San Francisco
address: 150 Stockton St. at Geary Blvd., Union Square, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
A beautiful building with top end brands. This is the ultimate in shopping. If you can't afford the prices of the clothes you can still enjoy the elegant ambiance!

The rotunda is gorgeous, with a wonderful, historic skylight. There is a nice little cafe at the top of the rotunda, fun for a coffee or drink and maybe a snack. A nice stop if you're a fan of historic architecture, otherwise just another Nieman-Marcus.

This is a wonderful restaurant in Neiman Marcus on Union Square and we had lunch there, great meal with popovers and great wine!
The service was wonderful and the view excellent. A must when visiting San Francisco

hmm where to begin ? This Neiman Marcus store is beautiful if you have an opportunity to visit you should. We dined in the Rotunda restaurant very nice atmosphere with a good view of the entire restaurant and the construction site conveniently located by the front door of Neiman Marcus as you walk in and see a armed guard. (With...


More  



My wife and I are a typical couple where I hate to shop and my wife hates not to shop. However, this store near Union Square was very fancy and if shopping was always this elegant, I perhaps wouldn’t mind it. What I loved perhaps most is the fact the prices. The prices are so far out of our league...


More  



You visit this department store for its elegant decor and the first thing to do as you enter the store is to look up rather than look for bargains. We actually did not find any bargain when we went but we did admire the view above us.

The Neiman Marcus is one of my favorite department stores in San Francisco. The decor is elegant and it is conveniently located on Union Square, right next to the Westin where we have stay previously. The service was prompt and courteous as always.

Very nice department store, which focuses on the top brands. It has a beautiful men's department with the finest (and largest) dressing rooms I have ever seen. It is a neat service to reserve a dressing room where they already hang your choices. There is also a separate perfume department with a very good vendor (with a lot of knowledge),...


More  



NeimanMarcus.com is not good shpping service, i received mr order with in 8 days.
Its very poor shipping service the comparison of other fsession web site.

Stopped in to replenish a cosmetic item; the staff were TERRIFIC! all introduced themselves, their speciality; offered expertassistance/advice, generous samples - no hard line sales pressure. I'd gladly return & recommend the lovely cosmetic dept!.

title: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park's Visitor Center, San Francisco
review_list:
After walking by in years past I finally dropped in, and I was pleasantly surprised by the great exhibit hidden in this old cannery.
Learning more about the history of the San Francisco harbor was great, and I'm impressed by the work that must have gone into this wonderfully thorough exhibit.
If tou have a bit of time I would...


More  



A great trip through the history of San Francisco, pretty large and extensive, especially for being entirely free. Not too far from Fisherman's Wharf and the end of the trolley car line, so lots to do in the area and easy to get to. Way to go, National Park Service.

Really enjoyed the visit to the visitors center, can be done in about an hour, close to the maritime historic center and the maritime museum, no affordable parking available.

We were told about this place near the Fisherman's Wharf foreshore by a tour guide, and it is, as he said a little known gem. Great self-guided tour of the history of the San Francisco waterfront.

Staffed by National Park Service, this has no admission charge. Open at the location for ten years, the building used to be the Del Monte cannery. This is a must-see history museum related to how sea transportation evolved San Francisco. Many authentic relics are preserved here. There is a rotating authentic light house set of mirrors, the size enormous. This...


More  



Focused on the historic ships moored at Hyde Street Pier, we almost skipped the Visitor Center across the street. What a tragedy that would have been because it is so much more than a mere information center handing out brochures, which is what it sounds like. It’s a museum of the first order and an interesting, compelling one at that,...


More  



If you're into history, this is a great first place to visit before hitting the rest of SF's NPS sites. It is just far away enough from the rest of the embarcadero to not have the crazy crowds but still within comfortable walking distance from the rest of the piers.
The museum is laid out chronologically from the Ohlone natives...


More  



Good tour by NPS employee orienting visitors to the history of the city and the development of its waterfront. Museum is well done with good wall plaques. Artifacts and pictures interesting. Wharf allows visits to historic vessels.

This small museum is situated within the Argonaut Hotel. Its free entry and less of a visitors centre but a small museum recounting the San Francisco's maritime past, its people and a bit of history of the city. There are some interactive displays and a short video. Its a good respite to have if you are down by Fisherman's Wharf.

The interactive museum and visitor center is located by the Argonaut Hotel and the Fisherman Wharf Cable Car area. The sign in front says "National Park Visitor Center". There is a visitor center inside, plus a very good museum that describes San Francisco History as well as the various neighborhoods.
I also liked seeing the short movie there that described...


More

title: San Francisco National Cemetery, San Francisco
review_list:
I have visited war cemeteries all over the world. This small National Cemetery on the trail between Presidio and Golden Gate has a lot of history from the Indian Wars to current times. It also has a number of graves of "Buffalo Soldiers" - African American soldiers who were given this name by the American Indians for their bravery on...


More  



This is an impressive cemetery of honour, which is beautifully situated between the hills and forests. Like all National Cemeteries this one is also very good maintained.

This is a cemetery and a wonderful memorial for the thousands who gave their life in different wars. The size of the site and the number of tombs are sobering and overwhelming. The place is well maintained and has a beautiful view of the bay.

A quiet place to reflect upon the world & its troubles & to remember those who have fought for our freedom. The National Cemetery is in a beautiful location overlooking San Francisco Bay & the Golden Gate Bridge - a very fitting final resting place for America's heroes.

Just visited the San Francisco National Cemetery - and that’s was a visit that gives the wings of time a meaning.
The cemetery is lying on top of a high hill viewing over the Bay area and gives the US warriors from wars going back to WW1 a proper and honorable last rest.
All tombstones are in scripted with the...


More  



It's a beautiful and sad place.
A short (free) bus ride from Golden Gate Bridge on presidiGo, there are fantastic views of the bridge itself.
Easy to get lost in thought thinking of all the men and women who have given their lives for their country.
Man has been doing it since before there were countries..I wonder if we can...


More  



My Father is buried here - WW 2. It is a sad place - to see all of the vets - row after row. The premises seem to be well maintained. Often people forget how many served our country in the seemingly endless wars we are gotten involved in. It is but a small tribute that we owe to these...


More  



This is a beautiful cemetery. It's very well kept and everyone acts as they should.
Those interested in militay history will find soldiers (and their wives) from WWI and WWII, Korea, Vietmam, and Iraq. You will also see headstones from the Spanish-American War, American Civil War and Buffalo Soldiers. There are some headstones needing attention, but otherwise seems a fitting...


More  



The National Cemetery is a short distance from many of San Francisco's tourist stops but it's worth every step it takes to get there. It's a quiet, respectful tribute to those who served our country for decades - some gravestones pay tribute to those who died in the early 1900s. It's well kept and a computer outside the cemetery office...


More  



My dad is buried there. I enjoy seeing the history that only a stone can tell you. A lot of folks there that gave us our freedom. We should never forget...

title: Don Edwards San Francisco Bay Wildlife Refuge, San Francisco
review_list:
It is a hidden gem in the SF Bay Area we can stay so close to nature-hills, wet lands, trees, birds and ducks.
It is an easy walk. Sometimes it is windy, so get yourself ready for the windy walk.
I have never been there for sunset but people take some great pictures of the beautiful sunset.
It is free:-)

If you are in the Fremont or Newark area this is a nice park to catch some trails and take in some wild life. Not a lot of visitors so you have run of the teails which are well kept. Hike up the hill to get some nice views of yhe SE bay area and the salt ponds that provide...


More  



We spent some time birding here on a recent trip to the area. I highly recommend bringing a scope to see the shorebirds, as they make up so much of the bird life and you won't see mug without a scope. The Don Edwards area is huge and can be confusing--be sure to get a map and figure out the...


More  



So a brief summary:
Pros: very few people, a lot of birds, a lot of history, well maintained trails, a lot of history and good visitor centers, free
Cons: smells bad, the views are not very spectacular by the Bay Area standards.
An extended version with the tips:
I've been living in SF Bay area for many years and I...


More  



We enjoyed walking around this area. There were a few egrets and lots of ground squirrels. It's a nice walk. There are also covered picnic tables and a sandy area where children can play. We hiked to the top of the hill where you can see for miles and were able to catch our breath at a bench in the...


More  



A very memorable learning experience. .There is a museum, interpretive signs everywhere explaining the history of Indians use of the area long ago as well as the current use of the salt ponds, abundant wildlife and plants, and of course the amazing view of the entire south bay. And it's all free!

South bay marsh flats are usually quite desolate, but this 2 mile Tidal Trail loop is partly along the sloughs, partly up a hill with a great view of the bay. Visitor center not open on Mondays. Can even see SF on clear days.

First thing in the morning, during the day or in the evening, this is a wonderful sanctuary for wildlife, including human. The history of Alviso going back to the 1800's is easy to imagine when you visit this preserve. The ghost town of Drawbridge is barely visible but if you look closely you'll see some of it. This is a...


More  



Pros: Nice marshes and a nice view from the top of the hill. The marsh had a few birds in it.
Cons: Not much to see and a helicopter flying in scared away the few birds that were around.
Note: This is probably much better when it's migration season.

I live near Don Edwards San Francisco Bay Wildlife Refuge, so I visit often. The weather is pretty good here in the SF Bay Area, so it's always been sunny, though often windy (it is near the bay). The hiking is good and the view is great. Don't have to walk far. Nice historic additions, too. It's near the Dumbarton...

title: Columbus Avenue, San Francisco

I recommend walking, not driving this one. Start in China Town... Do that towards columbus (make House of Nanking your last stop in China Town, it's near Columbo...) then transition to this North beach neighborhood. Oh... While your in China Town... Share a lunch dish so your not too stuffed for all the Italian yummyness.

More  



Columbus Avenue is a row of about five blocks or so that has a beautiful sidewalks of Italian Cafe. San Francisco is my hometown. It is categorized by districts, and Columbus Avenue is in the heart of "North Beach" known as the Italian town. Here, you will find authentic Italian restaurants, lots of really good pizza spots, but the best...


More  



This is the place for nightly entertainment and bars. Good places to eat and be entertained. Lively and crowded during peak nights.

We came here on the HOHO bus tour an area with an Italian twist and a notable comedy club where the late Robin Williams was known to make impromptu appearances. A long road but not all of it is interesting.

At first, Columbus Avenue looks like any other large street in San Francisco. But then one starts to explore the street. To me, its the delightful North Beach area. title: Huntington Park, San Francisco
address: California St - Cushman St, Nob Hill, San Francisco, CA 94108
review_list:
Located in Nob Hill this park is good place to relax and take some time from busy life. Locals present are also very friendly.

Not the most exciting and entertaining but the locals seem to love it and relax in it. We stopped by on our strenuous week of trying to see all of San Francisco and surely enjoyed the respite it gave my feet. Nice place to read a book, picnic and enjoy the beautiful nearby church.

Nestled in the shadow of the imposing Grace Cathedral, this formal little park on top of Nob Hill is a lovely place to visit, especially on a sunny day. It's a popular dog park, so you can watch the dogs romp and play, and the owners for the most part clean up after them, so you don't have *that* to...


More  



Found this peaceful park across from the impressive Grace cathedral. Lose the tourists- see another side of SF.Fab water fountains of the quality found in Europe. Ladies doing Tai Chi. Dog owners and a play park.really nice. Atop Nob Hill- u must be able to walk up a hill!

This is an adorable park in the heart of San Francisco with a lovely fountain. Nob Hill (aka snob hill) is a classy and expensive old SF neighborhood where the cable cars roam and there are sweeping views of the Bay and of SF. It's a great spot to take a rest from your tours of the City. There's a...


More  



This is a nice little park with a smaller playground and a bigger playground for the kids. Smells a little like dog poo because it's also a dog park area. The fountain is pretty. My kids were happy to play after climbing very steep Stockton street. The church bells are nice too.

This delightful small park is situated opposite the Grace Cathedral, it is very well kept, peaceful and a great find. The centrepiece of the garden is the Roman "Fountain of the Tortoises".
A plaque on a building wall in the park tells the history of the address, that there once stood a stunning white timber mansion with marble steps which...


More  



Debated about the rating ("3" or "4") but the views of Grace Cathedral are fantastic. So what do you have in this park:
(1) a very nice fountain (with water --- which is rare in this drought)
(2) gorgeous views of Grace Cathedral
(3) marginal views of TransAmerica Tower
(4) some views of Nob Hill
(5) children's playground
All in...

title: Grateful Dead House, San Francisco
review_list:
Although this is in deed the house they lived in it is now someone else's home. Who has put up a gate but is still very nice. If you are a true dead head you'll enjoy it, don't go out of your way to see it in afraid it has no historical value. However the neighborhood is cool so get...


More  



So If you're in San Fran, taking a quick uber to walk near the corner of haight and ashbury is worth it... Just a sight to see, nothing special, more of a check off your list :) and while you're there, wave to the grateful dead house. Nothing really to do, it's just a suburban residence now days, but if...


More  



Like a lot of places with historic/cultural resonance, life goes on to obliterate any traces of what made them famous/gave them significance in the first places so that only those in the know are aware of what went on there once. So it is with the house at 710 Ashbury Street that was once home to Jerry Garcia and the...


More  



I'll warn you ahead of time, I'm an old time, tie-dyed in the wool, Deadhead! If you're not, you may find this shrine incredibly boring. But I had to make the pilgrimage (2nd time in my lifetime) to 710 Ashbury. The old place is incredibly well kept (although you can only see the outside... it's a private residence) and the...


More  



I love visiting SF's Haight/Ashbury district and meeting up with other folks at Jerry's house at 710 Ashbury. This visit was especially special as it was the 50th Anniversary of the Grateful Dead and people were in town from all over the world to go to the 2 concerts in Santa Clara.
I'm surprised no one has bought this house...


More  



Quick stop whiling touring this section. I can see if you're a big Grateful Dead fan how this place would have some meaning. Nice quick pic of the exterior.

As a Dead Head, this stop was very surreal. I'd recommend it to any fan, old or young. No tours since it's a private residence. Worth a look nonetheless.

Stayed in this home in 1989 on our honeymoon. Was the Sprecher Mansion. Was a fantastic experience. Today is our 26th wedding anniversary!

Personally, I can't name even one song by the Grateful Dead, so this stop on our tour was a little wasted on me. Still, I can understand why fans would want to visit and get a shot of the place.

I saw the home after looking it up before my visit. I think this is a place for fans of The Grateful Dead and their music. Otherwise it is just a home to look at. I am glad I went and saw it firsthand.

title: Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, San Francisco
review_list:
The location of this venue is very central, next to major hotels et al. The programming is greta, too but gosh, the seats! If you are seated on the side there is no way you can see a whole show without having neck pain. And if you are in the center, you still get this old-fashioned outdated seats.
Needs some...


More  



Some of the most interesting modern art is showcased here. It's evolved over the years and today is somewhat better. The exhibits can be meh or wow, the range is quite large.

Yerba Buena is a lovely venue for dance performance. It feels intimate, but spacious, and we've had good viewing from every seat we've had in a dozen or so visits. It's best accessed by public transit (super easy, on every Muni car line, get off at 4th & Market), and also near a huge variety of restos & cafes. The...


More  



Nice small venue with good sight lines and acoustics. Chairs are not very comfortable and led to a couple of aching backs after about an hour. Easy to order through ticket service on line but print at home did not work and the box office is hard to reach by phone due to limited hours. Stopped by during the day...


More  



The YBCA is a superb gallery space that runs specific contemporary art displays throughout the year. Admission is a little pricey given the somewhat sparse collection. I enjoy contemporary art a great deal and with the MOMA closed, decided to give it a shot. Some of the pieces were interesting but lacked the much-needed background explanation required to understand the...


More  



We love this small theater...a wonderful mosaic of events and artists appear here. Last night we saw Anna Devere Smith's talent intensive, Un-Ted. The staff is stellar. Online tix are a breeze. Great pricing. Easy parking at 5 th and Mission streets. Very attractive on so many levels.

When visiting San Francisco, take in some of the wonderful culture that we get to take for granted. Some of my favorite dance performances take place in this little theater where every seat is a good seat. Any performance by the Smuin ballet is going to be wonderful. The tickets for performances are far less than the ones for the...

title: Harvey Milk Plaza, San Francisco
address: Southwest corner of Castro and Market Streets, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Harvey Milk Plaza is unfortunately the entrance to the Castro Street Muni metro station. Aggressive homeless and open use of heroin and crack can be found here. Metro station personnel refuse to take any action.

in Castro At the end of the metro. Nice to see the great Harvey having a lovely plaza named after him Castro is fab too

After the movie Milk with Sean Penn many people got familiar with the name Harvey Milk and with his legacy. It was cool to see that the people from the neighborhood take care of this plaza proudly.

The Harvey Milk Plaza is a tiny memorial honouring Harvey Milk by means of several signs adjacent to a public transport station. The 'Harvey Milk Plaza' signage rests on a walkway that is lined with trees and greenery. All in all, this is not a site to seek out, but worth checking off your list when in the Castro District.

Simple food executed terribly. Cooks lack knowledge of temperature of proteins. Average
Restaurant with average prices.

Harvey Milk was a civil rights icon of SF. If you have watched the movie about him with Sean Penn then definitely visit the Harvey Milk plaza.

I thought there would be more to see at Harvey Milk Plaza so it was a little disappointing but you have to visit if you're in the Castro area.

title: The Wave Organ, San Francisco
review_list:
Cons: pretty much everything else. Do not go expecting to hear the wave sounds - it's more miss than hit to even hear a "gurgle" from the pipes. Do not go expecting to see different or better sights of the bay (Alcatraz, GG bridge, etc.) than you can see pretty much anywhere else along the Embarcadero as you walk, stroll,...


More  



Could be a disappointment if your expectations are high. We could not hear any music through the tubes, though there were waves. but the area itself is lovely with all the facilities for a picnic. View of golden gate bridge on one side and atcatraz island on the other side is awesome. we could even see some sea lions and...


More  



We went right after high tide. I expected more sounds, but all we could really hear was a gurgle. It might be a cool place for reflection as it's quiet and nice, but as an organ... I just didn't really like it.

We went to the wave organ which is in the other side of the yacht club, it may be that we went when the waves weren't high enough to make any noise but it really didn't make any noise. However you have some great views of Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge.

I had high hopes for the Wave Organ. We even went to catch high tide. But I have to say it was a real bust. If you got right up next to one one of the tubes and listened very carefully you might hear some gurgling that sounded like water going down a bath tub drain. There are so many...

We walked from the Marriott courtyard - which was a very pleasant jaunt but the way the route makes you think you may never get there.... We did go at high tide (as recommended but did not hear any "music". Did meet a nice local and his dog Rufus. View was awesome and the built in seat was unique. My...

title: Stockton Street, San Francisco
review_list:
I often find myself on Stockton Street during visits to San Francisco.This long North/South thoroughfare runs between Market and Beach streets and includes a tunnel that extends for a bit more than two blocks. Buses travel the street regularly and many can be picked up near Union Square -- an upscale shopping district.
As an architecture buff, I always like...


More  



Stockton street is the main market street in the area of Chinatown, where fresh produce is sold from shops and stand all across it. Weird Chinese stores selling exotic foodstuff that doesn't have an English name and an Asian candy shop where only the brave dare - All this and more, on Stockton Street.

I stayed on Stockton Street for business and over the 4th of July weekend this year.
It's a relatively quiet street, but the entire length features a wide range of shops, restaurants and attractions. If you get time to walk it, it's fascinating.

San Fran...the city that never sleeps....not. We couldn't find a parking space until just before 6:00 pm and at 6:00 pm the vast majority of the shops closed. A few restaurants still open but it was a disappointment.

There are several shops on the street with everything you can think of. Pressed duck and prepared food, clothes, vegetables, silk komonos, lottery tickets, all sorts of fun things. It's crowded with elderly Chinese people doing their daily shopping, and the language is a sharp contrast to what the English speaker is used to.

Stockton Street takes you through the less travelled roads in Chinatown. Make a visit to this part of Chinatown as it is less touristy and far removed from the crowds elsewhere.

Stockton Street from Columbus to the tunnel is the commercial center of the real Chinatown. It is an interesting walk that you should consider doing....
Let's start with the negatives:
1) nothing touristy here (except maybe Kong Chow Temple --- one of two temples that claim to be the oldest Chinese temple in the US; this temple relocated in the...


More  



Stockton and Pacific Street is where you will find Chinatown for locals. None of that touristy stuff on Grant Ave. Sidewalks packed with people and produce and ducks hanging in the window. Visit Chinatown gate and then head over here for the real deal.

During a recent trip to San Francisco we used Stockton Street to walk from Union Square through Chinatown and found this a nice path to use for this city street walk.
In the Union Square area, Stockton is typical of Powell, with lots of shops and dining but it seems to quiet down once you pass Union Square a few...

Stockton and Pacific Street is where you will find Chinatown for locals. None of that touristy stuff on Grant Ave. Sidewalks packed with people and produce and ducks hanging in the window. Visit Chinatown gate and then head over here for the real deal.

title: Lincoln Park, San Francisco
address: Clement Street at 34th Avenue, Richmond District, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
While we didn't get to see a lot of this park, we did walk the trail that wound along close to the coast. It was awesome! There was one fantastic view after another. The trail wasn't too hard to walk and there were branch trails that went to various points that offered great photo ops. It was a great hike...


More  



This is a very special park with some nice sculptures and amazing views, while you walk around, though too often missed by tourists and locals.

3* Lincoln Park Golf Course
The bad news is this place is run down. The drought has exacerbated the condition of the fairways to where there are very large barren and dirt areas. The ball does travel a little further though.
The course is hilly and the greens seem small.
The good news is that the views e.g., Golden Gate...


More  



Some truly amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge from this lovely and expansive park. We were too late to get into the Legion of Honor (I think they close at 5pm), but did do some unexpected bird watching (osprey & falcon or hawk). Will definitely return on a future trip to SF.

this park is huge, so big that families got there to take a piece of it and sit and have their family picnics and play baseball or football. the flowers, the trees and the statues are beautiful and every thing is so well maintained. it really is a surprise around every corner. never crowded because its so big.

Take a long bus ride on the #1 California. Get off at Clement and walk through the park to the Palace of the Legion of Honor. See the GG Bridge. Smell the plants. Can't be beat.

Lincoln Park got its name by being the western end of the Lincoln Highway, The Lincoln Highway was the first road across the USA. There are stellar views of the Bay, San Francisco skyline, and Golden Gate Bridge from Lincoln Park.
We have visited this park often, The Legion of Honor Museum, which is a fine art museum, is here....

Just an amazing golf course. It was in great condition, the staff was great to deal with and beautiful weather. I played Mon & Tue around 9:45am

This course is a must for fellow golfers. Hidden in the Presidio amongst the trees, it really is beautiful and perfectly challenging from the elevation and slope changes to the narrow fairways, this is a challenge for the average and not so average golfer! The course is very well maintained and has lovely views of the area. When playing, be...


More  



One of the the best course. Playing this one you got to have a course management. Bunch of blind drive. Fast greens.well knowledge staff.

Course is in great condition. Staff were excellent, one of the Pros even gave me a lift back to Fisherman's Wharf. Good quality hire gear - Taylor Made or Callaway. Some great holes, some nice elevation changes. Big thank you to the Pro shop staff.

This is a very lovely hilly course. The fairways are tight so that an errant shot can land in another fairway. The pace of play was fine the day that we played. This was a course that I knew nothing about before going to San Francisco. The Concierge at The Fairmont hotel told me that it was as nice as Harding Park without the 6-7 hour rounds. I took his advice as was not disappointed. This is a must play.

title: Lincoln Park Golf Course, San Francisco
review_list:
The El Camino del Mar and Lincoln Highway (same street) offers unrivalled, unique views of the Golden Gate Bridge from the south and west. There are plenty of available stops/vistas west of China Beach in the area of Lincoln Park Golf Corse. no cost, pleasant drive, fantastic pics! Enjoy!

We play here each time we visit SFO. I am not a good, my husband is, but we still enjoy the course. Lots of terrain, and fabulous views. The grass is a little on the goat ranch side, but it is a nice spot to spend a few hours.
The down side is that many people us the cart paths...


More  



City of SF owned 18 hole course. Relatively short which is great for high handicappers. Lots of undulating fairways. Best part are views of San Francisco, Marin Headlands, and Golden Gate bridge. Small bar and restarant on site

This is a challenging course most of the time as it is a HILLY course, and there are amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge, the wide open Pacific Ocean, and the hills across the San Francisco Bay to Marin County. Another bonus is that you get to tee off on a few holes right behind the Palace of the...

For a public course and in a City that has very limited space, it's pretty good. It's a muni which puts it below the maintenance standards at other public courses. But the price point reflects that. The 17th hole has one of the most memorable views you will ever see in golf.

I wasn't expecting much of a course based on the reviews I had read but I was up for a try. The city should invest more dollars into the clubhouse and golf course and they would get it back tenfold. Ok, for those looking for a "premium" golf course, this one isn't for you. The greens have lots of stray weeds and the fairways aren't always rewarding (dry grass, bald patches), but if you want to play in one of the California's best cities, and pay less then $50, this one is for you!

title: Fort Baker, San Francisco
review_list:
Free. Great parking. Awesome view of one of the world's most famous bridges. Not much else to do, but if you just want some photos, can't go wrong here.

After visiting Sausalito, we took a drive down the road to Fort Baker, and were pleasantly surprised by the unique view of the bay and Golden Gate. This seems to be an off-the-beaten-path side trip. The children's museum would be a lovely stop for families with young ones.

There are trails in the official maps here, but all of them are fenced off. No way to get near the horseshoe bay.

For some lovely views, with a one minute drive, go just over the Golden Gate Bridge (GGB), past the first right turn to 'Vista Point', take a series of first right turns. Go right onto Alexander Ave, to the first right turn - onto Bunker Rd, to the next first right turn onto Murray Circle and drive down to Horseshoe...


More  



We took the drive today and the views were absolutely amazing. Stop at all of the overlook and take spectacular pictures. Great drive. Don't stop and ask the [park rangers any questions though. Young guy was a real smartass.

We love stopping at Fort Baker and have toured a few times. The area is really beautiful for walking, biking, and photos. There's a nice view of the golden gate from the pier and a children's discovery area (for a fee). We just enjoy walking around and touring the facilities.

So you really want to see the Golden Gate Bridge!! It must be seen from the northern (Marin) side. BUT, and yes WOW--Look at Fort Baker, a former military facility that you can stop at and have a GREAT (not good-Great) lunch/dinner. Also they have hotel accommodations which while somewhat pricey (hey your're in CA) are worth a look see....


More  



This park provides great views of the Golden Gate Bridge and the San Francisco skylinie as well, try to go here to get these views.

Fort Baker isn't a spot you will find on the tour bus route but it's a must see if you have a car. Drive over the Golden Gate Bridge and up the hill and stop at Battery Spencer (1897-1942) - Battery Spencer was a reinforced concrete gun battery located on Fort Baker Battery construction was begun in 1893, completed in...


More  



The “Coast Miwok tribe” inhabited the Fort Baker area, prior to the settlement by Europeans.
In 1700s, Fort Baker got its name because the cove was shaped like a horseshoe.
In 1775, the Spanish vessel San Carlos, under the command of Juan Manuel de Ayala, entered San Francisco Bay.
By 1810, Spanish colonization had completely shattered the integrity of the...

title: Sigmund Stern Grove, San Francisco
address: 19th Ave and Sloat Blvd, San Francisco, CA 94132
review_list:
Fun entrance is at Sloat Blvd. and 19th Ave. This is the redwoods section. It is a valley surrounded by huge eucalyptus trees. Total stroll around Pine Lake and back about an hour. Summer Sunday concerts are great and free. The house can be used for weddings. Two parking lots. Mid parking lot caters to off leash dog walkers. Been...


More  



So this place was not that easy to get to as there are a number of ways to access it. We attended an evening wedding and reception here and was amazed that a grove like this could even exist in the City! While we couldn't research the history, the setting was serene. Many trees, strung lights, and a old housing...


More  



perfect place to walk a dog....jog or hike...beautiful lake in the middle.....tall beautiful trees everywhere............i would pitch a tent there and camp overnight if it was possible....lol

We watched 2 concerts at this amazing ampitheatre this summer and this is a beautiful and unique concert venue. We found a spot in between the trees quite uphill but it was okay. If you happen to be in San Francisco around this time, I suggest you check out the free summer concert schedule.

It is enjoyable to go to a summer concert here. There is a variety of music events such as SF Symphony, Hawaiian, Pops, Sergio Mendes, etc.). The park is part of the city's park department and the concert venue has been going now for over 75 years.
We like the eucalyptus trees and walking among them.
For those interested in...


More  



We were lucky to be in SF when the Stern Grove festival took place (every Sunday starting in June till August) the park is more than lovely! And it was fantastic to hear the SFQuartet and Rufus Wainwright playing their beautiful music!

During the summer (on Sundays) this is the place to be in San Francisco. The afternoon concerts are the best anywhere --- SF Symphony, SF Opera, SF Ballet, Hawaiian, Pop, Blues....every year the variety is outstanding. I always arrive at 7am....leave for a couple of hours....then start preparing lunch on the green around 10am. Often, between 10am and noon there...


More  



We had driven past this park many times but did not actually go there until last week. The beauty and appeal of this place is hidden until you actually enter the park and go for a walk. There is auto access off Vale St with a smallish parking lot. The park is beautiful, lined with tall eucalyptus trees throughout. On...

title: RocketBoat, San Francisco
address: Pier 39, Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
The only reason this didn't get five stars is because, after purchasing our tickets and standing in line, the boat broke down.. We were able to exchange our tickets for the following day and had a lot of fun! Be prepared to stand in line to board as they do not give you particular boarding times, you just line up...


More  



Went Sunday morning, boat pretty full, worth getting there 30mins before to grab one of the best seats in the open side of the boat, though the twists and turns of the boat mean you'll have a good seat where ever, though down the side of the canopy will miss some the view. Captain ensures plenty of trill twists and...


More  



We enjoyed the movements ( tricks) but the ride seemed a little slow. The boat was fully loaded so that probably didn't help but you could see the cars on the bridge were moving faster then the boat was.
Would I do it again - probably not. But I can say I did it once .

We had so much fun on this boat! The sun was out, the boat was fast and the music was load!! Wooooohoooo fun!

The Rocket is a great ride but does not give you a trip around the Golden Gate or Alcatraz ! spend all of the time under the Bay bridge.

According to my 9 year old granddaughter this was the best part of our trip to San Francisco. We sat near the front of the boat so we didn't get soaked but the captain still managed to get us a little wet. It was a short tour of the bay but we did a lot of spinning & turning. The...


More  



We used the Explorer pass to ride on this attraction as a family party of 5 adults and we all had a great time. My wife was apprehensive about going on this trip, as she doesn't really like speed boats, or indeed open water, but she thoroughly enjoyed herself. The crew were great and happy to take photos with our...


More  



We took our family of 7 on the Rocketboat and had a great time! Our kids ages range from 3 to 18 years and every single one of us enjoyed this excursion! I do have to say that they advertise 30 minutes, but as we timed the rides, they were shorter than the 30 minutes promised. However, we had such...


More  



Thirty minutes of sheer enjoyment must do while visiting San Francisco. It is suitable for all ages. It is a well organized tour company.

Ok you wont learn much on this 30 minutes trip but you will get to ride over most of the bay down to AT&T Park and back in under 30 minutes. You will get wet if close to the sides. It is 100% fun.

title: Golden Gate Park Carousel, San Francisco
address: 320 Bowling Green Drive, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Have been to Golden Gate Park several times and did not know about the carousel. It's hidden near the tennis courts, play ground, and the lawn bowling club. What a beautifully restored 1914 treasure. Even adventured a ride on an elegant ostrich for just $2.00.

There Is a carousel in the Koret children's quarter for $1! In San Francisco, this is a bargain! It is cash only, so come prepared. Parents can ride with their children 5 years old and younger. It is right next to the playground for younger children and steps away from the older kids playground. There is also a cement slide...


More  



This classic carousel of many colorful creatures is housed in a very nice round building on the eastern end of the very large Golden Gate Park. This was our first stop on an afternoon visit to the park. I had planned to ride, but my husband did not want to ride -- sorry I missed it -- next time I...


More  



The carousel is Beautiful! You can feel the history on this beautifully manicured carousel. I can't believe it's been around since the 1930's! My little one had a great time! :) The carousel is enclosed indoors so, even on a hot day, the sun isn't torching the seats. The cost for a ride was very reasonable. I can't remember exactly,...


More  



The carousel is old school so lovely. The booth where you buy tickets also sells drinks, ice cream and snacks. Just past the carousel is a wonderful playground, huge! Lots of climbing and other activities for toddlers through to tweens. My personal favorite is the cement slide - take some cardboard with you!

This review is specifically for Koret park which is right next to the carousel but doesn't have its own review site. The carousel was closed today (not sure if that's Mondays or if it's seasonal? ) But the park was fantasic. It had two different fun and clean playgrounds and a super awesome stone slide that the kids slid down...


More  



All the carved animals and the magic of the mirrors and lights and around and around it spins, still delighting crowds with its beauty and old world charm.
Bring the kids, they'll love it. And bring the kid in you, too.
Enjoy!

Beautiful area full of attractions and green fields with woods and flowers.
Absolutelysomething you cannot miss!

She rode the carousel Golden Gate Park and was thrilled with the ride. It was a beautiful carousel and nicely restored. It was the morning and the nannies and their kids were all around the children's park. It is not crowded; tickets at the food stand. The prices are much better than the one in SF and the much more...


More  



On a ten day roadtrip we decided to add this to our itinerary so our little could feel like she had something that was just hers. None of us really enjoyed it but it was a nice break from being in the car.

title: Lucky Strike San Francisco, San Francisco
review_list:
I came here for a private event - the bowling was fun and well organized...but since was also to be our dinner venue I had my concerns. However, I found all the food to be quite good - they had a nice variety including sushi. Lucky Strike is very well staffed so it was always easy to find someone to...


More  



Our group met up at Lucky Strike while on vacation in San Francisco, it was a Wednesday night so likely that explains the lack of a crowd, which worked for us as we got the full attention of the bartenders, waiters, etc. We had a great time and the facility was great, no complaints from us!

We went to this combination of our bowling alley that also serves food after a San Francisco Giants game. It has about 10 lanes very uniquely decorated. Lots of TVs for watching sports. Big widows to check the action at ATT Park. It's a nice place to go after and before games.

I used to live down the street from here and stopped in a few months ago before a giants game. It is one of the newest bars in the area and is a fun place to go drinking, bowling and have some good food. They have a nice selection of beers on tap and very good sushi. The busiest time...


More  



The lanes are a cool place to hang out and you can also pally pool and there are lots of spots to chill out. If your group of friends is large or small you can have a good time here. Right next to baseball field for pre- or post-game entertainment.

We stopped at Lucky Strike for a late afternoon snack after a fun day in The City. This was our first visit and it has a great vibe. We sat down and ordered cocktails, they were well made and refreshing. Three of us ordered sushi and one ordered sliders. The sushi is made to order at a sushi bar located...

lLved the concept of this bowling alley/bar! Great social place for after work events or with friends. We had a private area with our own lanes and the food and service was good.

Twin Peaks is an amazing old bar. It's great. Massive carved wood and glass mirrors behind the bars like in the old days. It truly is the Castro District's gay version of Cheers. I make a point of having a martini (maybe several) here whenever I'm in the City, which is often. Great cocktail bar with experienced professional bar tenders...


More  



It's the first place you see when you jump off the tram. A really nice chilled bar with great bar staff who are really friendly. A great first stop in Castro. They recommended some places to eat. The clientele are friendly especially to visitors.
We will definitely return.
Try the mandran which is mandarin liqueur and cranberry juice.
Lots of...

It almost felt like we walked into the gay version of Cheers. This was a neighborhood bar with a friendly bartender.
Situated on a corner that made this place hard to miss.
We stopped in for a drink after spending the better part of the day sight seeing.
The place had a bit of a musty smell. The bathroom was...


More  



wonderful little castro area bar, full of history and wonderful bartenders, friendly guests, too. we really enjoyed a monday night visit.

This historic bar became our local during a two week stay in the Castro District.
It is comfortable and friendly with a great atmosphere.
On our first visit, we were not aware of the bar's history as the first gay full length glass windowed bar, through which people can see in as well as out. We were told that the...

Right on the corner of Castro and Market, it's pretty much the first place you come to when visiting the Castro. Right as you enter Castro the Twin Peaks is a must stop. This beautiful building survived two major earthquakes and has also survived every decade since the turn of the prior century. Twin Peaks is an amazing old bar. It's great. Massive carved wood and glass mirrors behind the bars like in the old days. It truly is the Castro District's gay version of Cheers. I make a point of having a martini (maybe several) here whenever I'm in the City, which is often. Great cocktail bar with experienced professional bar tenders...


More  



It's the first place you see when you jump off the tram. A really nice chilled bar with great bar staff who are really friendly. A great first stop in Castro. They recommended some places to eat. The clientele are friendly especially to visitors.
We will definitely return.
Try the mandran which is mandarin liqueur and cranberry juice.
Lots of...


More  



It almost felt like we walked into the gay version of Cheers. This was a neighborhood bar with a friendly bartender.
Situated on a corner that made this place hard to miss.
We stopped in for a drink after spending the better part of the day sight seeing.
The place had a bit of a musty smell. The bathroom was...


More  



wonderful little castro area bar, full of history and wonderful bartenders, friendly guests, too. we really enjoyed a monday night visit.

This historic bar became our local during a two week stay in the Castro District.
It is comfortable and friendly with a great atmosphere.
On our first visit, we were not aware of the bar's history as the first gay full length glass windowed bar, through which people can see in as well as out. We were told that the...


More  



Right on the corner of Castro and Market, it's pretty much the first place you come to when visiting the Castro. Feels friendly, slightly older crowd (by which I mean it's not full of 20-somethings), clearly full of regulars. The bar staff weren't terribly great, but I think that was more about just not being very good bar staff than...


More  



Right as you enter Castro the Twin Peaks is a must stop. This beautiful building survived two major earthquakes and has also survived every decade since the turn of the prior century. The bar staff has worked there for decades and the clientele are loyal regulars. Take time to chat with both! I ordered a premium gin martini and it...


More  



Nice old bar with a crowd on average older than 50 nonetheless nice bartender and relaxed atmosphere. Apparently the first bar that to refused to hide LGBT

We stopped in on a sunny afternoon while walking around the Castro. They have a very cozy atmosphere that could easily make it a nice little coffee bar. Though they seem to cater predominantly to older men as two women we did not feel unwelcome in any way. The bartender was a nice man who chatted and laughed with us....


More

title: 440 Castro, San Francisco
review_list:
So yes, the crowd is a lot older than other bars - certainly no twinks in here.
That being said, the staff are friendly and importantly the drinks are cheap so thats a bonus.
Worth stopping in if you're in SF.

its the best place in SF, no doubt, i am going there ones a month or so, people are so friendly and nice, its always a fun place to be , drinks are cheap , my fave bar in san francisco

rather older crowd but friendly and clean. drinks are cheap. in the heart of the castro. Gets very busy at night.

I visited for 440 alone on a Saturday night. The bar was packed it was about 11 PM and the man although very bearish, and Butch, or nice-looking and friendly. If you like this type of trade this is your bar.

This is a fantastic bar on Castro with very friendly staff great drinks and fun entertainment
We loved it here they have many theme nights with deals on drinks
If your one of the boys and feel like some eye candy for the older guy get yourself here
Every nights s fun night
Locals are friendly
Hassle Drama free gay...


More

Friendly bar staff and we were lucky...


More  



It was the first pub we came to in the Castro. It was happy hour 6 until 9 pm . We just made it. It is busy . Nice friendly crowd . Good crowd / atmosphere . . I'd certainly go back

Visiting SF and thought I would check out the area in the afternoon.
Old fashioned bar, but that was fine as there are plenty of modern bars. Drinks not over expensive either but ordered bottles.
Very handy location for both the tram and the other Castro area bars and clubs.
Certainly thought the regulars could have been a little more...


More

More  



Pretty standard gay bar, nice drinks and cheesy music!
Pretty dark and seedy but not in a bad way, bar staff and patrons seem like a bit of a laugh!

title: Badlands, San Francisco
review_list:
We always come to Badlands when we are in SF, love the drinks and dancing. Music is played by a VJ and includes showtunes, pop and anything else one would like to dance to.
The place gets packed, so come early and enjoy.

I went to San Francisco by myself and basically stayed in the castro. I stumbled upon Badlands because I met a few people at The Q. They said that Badlands was the place to dance. The line was long but it went quick. The music is current music, top 20, and there is a large mix of people. It doesn't...


More  



we loved the facts that: music not too loud, we could speak, enough people not too much, cheap drinks, goodlooking gogo dancers

Nice neighborhood dance club. Very well-lit and uplifting dancing area. Bartenders are friendly but drinks are sort of diluted. But this may not be a bad thing, as you can keep sipping without getting drunk. Music is kind of mix of upbeat pops. Don't expect trance and heavy house. Safe and sane are pretty much the words I give, but...


More  



Fun night dancing with some folks I met at a conference I attended. Great mix of music from all eras. Dance floor filled up very quickly.

This place has a pretty good atmosphere, friendly staff but the crowd doesn't really start going until late...
Drinks are made well, and are reasonably priced.

Modern but still welcoming and not pretentious (as many modern gay bars have become).
Not over expensive, nice mixed ages and types of men and, thankfully, not too many hetrosexuals

We visited from the UK in as part of our West Coast tour, Great cocktails. lots of boys/men running around and trying to out bust eachother on the dancefloor! Made for a great night sitting at the bar and watching everyone. No dresscode.

If you want a fun filled dance party, head on over to Badlands. It is a gay club, but you'll have a good time no matter your orientation. Just a heads up, the signs male/female are clearly optional on the restroom door. So, be prepared for that.

Fun nightclub - great music/videos - lots to see and lots to drink! Staff were super friendly, and was a great place to meet up with friends and have a good night out.

title: Mount Davidson, San Francisco
review_list:
It is a nice stroll up to the top. You don't have to work too hard to get there. The views up there are amazing. And at the top there is this Armenian memorial represented in a big cross in remembering the genocide that was perpetrated btw 1915-23. It's a good view of San Francisco, the ocean, and across the...


More  



This is one of those places where you feel like you have just discovered a little hidden secret. Mount Davidson is right in the middle of a residential neighborhood (a very nice residential neighborhood at that) and there are many places to stop and begin your adventure. Take any one of the many trails and walk to the top. You...


More  



There are lots of lesser known, open space areas with good views of the city. Like most, there's a bit of a hike to get to the top. This is one my favorites to go to on good days for photos.

It is quiet and non touristy.. usually locals.. great view.. good place to make love :) Bring a picnic and a great bottle of CA vino... with some Sonoma county cheese and SF sourdoooh.. then get a cab to take you back to the Palomar Hotel for more fun.. or the Sir Francis Drake.. love this city...Woohoo!!!

I would recommend this over Twin Peaks primarily just because you have to walk to the top. Once up there, you see Twin Peaks, but it's not in front of the view of the city. Awesome Awesome views. Park at Myra and Dalewood and walk up. Enjoy the hike. There are plenty of trails in the woods but it's pretty...


More  



On a clear day, you can see far out onto the ocean (Westward), you may even see a whale. The history & peacefulness of the hike is well worth the time it'self! Soak in the view of the city (North Eastward) on a sunny day, but bring water & a snack, or a lunch (& your camera). You will always...


More  



It's a very manageable hike to the top of Mt Davidson. If you're a "Dirty Harry" fan, the cross at the top is in one of the crucial scenes. Panaoramic views of the the city are worth the trip!

Mount Davidson is a good little getaway in the middle of the city it takes about 5 minutes hike to the toponce there you have a good view the city there's a big ship there you can sit down relax have a little lunch but that's about it and beware the mosquitoes they are definitely up there in the summertime...


More

title: Pioneer's Monument, San Francisco
review_list:
This enormous bronze statue atop a stone pedestal rests in the middle of a traffic circle formed by Fulton Street, between Asian Art Museum and SF Library. It’s a landmark nestled between parks, the Civic Center and City Hall. The monument is impressive, but is more of a landmark than an attraction. From this point, there are many TripAdvisor-identified attractions...


More  



I wouldn’t go out of my way by any means to come visit the statue outside of City Hall but if you’re in the area, it won’t hurt to come and see it. It is quite impressive but really you can pass on after 2 minutes.

A nice imposing monument situated just outside City Hall celebrating the early pioneers of San Francisco, hence the name.

Do walk by the grand City Hall building and the impressive Pioneer Monument while doing a walking tour of San Francisco. But avoid the nearby stretch of Market Street. To continue your city walking tour to the east, take a route that will not put you on Market Street until you are closer to the visitor center near the intersection...


More  



I've seen a lot of statues and monuments over the years and must say this one is quite impressive indeed. The detail and size are striking. Worth a stop to observe and take some photos.

This nearly 1000 ton monument used to be located near the corner of Hyde and Grove Sts. It was moved around the year 2000 to its present location on Fulton St. to make room for the then new Main Branch of the San Francisco Public Library. There has been some controversy about the monument because of how it depicts Native...


More  



This sometimes controversial monument is in the Civic Center area of San Francisco.
The pioneer monument was sculpted by Frank Happersberger.
In the monument he depicts many of he pioneers who were important in California history.
Integrated into the monument are the pioneer John Sutter, John Fremont, Sir Francisco Drake, Father Junipero Serra, James Lick, General Valllejo, James Marshall, Juan...


More  



This impressive monument located near City Hall is a celebration of early Californian history. Created in the late 1890's as a gift to the city by James Lick, a pioneer investor, it withstood the great earthquake of 1906.
Take the time to walk around the monument, observe the different characters on the four pedestals, also read the names on the...


More  



This is one of the nicer monuments in the city (situated between the Asian Art Museum and the City Library near City Hall).
For those that are unfamiliar with San Francisco, around the base are the list of the early pioneers in San Francisco lore, each with a large street named after them.

These camera-friendly bronze sculptures on granite bases were located on Fulton Street between the City Library and the Asian Art Museum. They depicted figures in California’s history. A woman atop the center column held a shield and spear; a bear stood beside her. On the column below the woman, four bronze reliefs depicted key episodes of state history. At the...

title: Presidio Officers’ Club, San Francisco
review_list:
The Offices' Club is a great restored building to explore but don't miss the museum. The museum is at the back of the building and has a wonderful time line history of the Presidio. There is a very helpful docent on hand to answer your questions about the museum and the Presidio. This is all free! Just make sure you...


More  



We visited the Log Cabin at the Presidio. This is also where the presidio officer's club was located It was built in 1937.
There is also a nice lawn area with beautiful views of San Francisco. Wedding ceremonies and other events are held here today. One needs to call and schedule the event if one wants to rent the facility....


More  



Be sure to stop by the free "museum" inside the Presidio Officer's Club in The Presidio. Great history lesson about the founding of San Francisco with a tribute to the Ohlone Native Americans. There is also a 20' video worth watching.

What a great way to top off a walking tour of the Presidio! The history and stories of the Presidio were great to learn about, and the restoration of the building was nice to see. Very nice historic structure!!!

On my walk today visited this Beautiful location & surroundings. Many restaurants, walking areas. Today I happened to visit an exhibit at the Officer's Club of the Vietnam Baby Lift and thoroughly enjoyed it. Many different exhibits going on here and a short film about the Presidio which is well worth a visit. Will have to go back & see...


More  



What a great space - and intriguing exhibits - current exhibit on Babylift was awesome and pretty thought provoking.
Beautiful building and great use of space!

Stop by to see the restored Adobe sections, tour the museum and gardens, stay for lunch or dinner. Great lectures and demonstrations on Thursday at 7pm- free but best To reserve a Space. You can bring drinks in from the restaurant. Great music programs on Fridays at 6pm; free but reservations recommended . Presidio@presidiotrust.gov.

title: Pacific Union Club, San Francisco
review_list:
Well this is certainly one of the best clubs I've been to. Located in nob hill all the places to go is nearby. Cable car is also there. And yes, the staffs were very cooperative.

One of the great private clubs of the world. Rooms are very spacious- king beds and sitting area- and very comfortable. Quiet, discrete and elegant, but obviously part of it's charm is that it is very old-fashioned, in the nicest possible way.
Car park in the very centre of Nob Hill is extraordinary and incredibly convenient.
Food is of course...


More  



This is a simply stunning building. Tall marble columns, fine timbers and polished brass. Moulded ceilings that wouldn't look out of place in Chatsworth House.
The friendliest and most helpful staff, with nothing too much trouble.
For all the old-world style, it also has excellent wifi!

This club is really beautiful and the service is perfect. It's calm and you don't heard the sound of the street from your room

As a woman, I admit, I was a little put off that I could go not go everywhere in this gentlemen's club with my husband, but it is a gentlemen's club. The building is absolutely lovely and full of old world charm. It was built in1898 and survived the 1906 earthquake. The staff is beyond belief! One must be a...


More  



Fantastic location on Nob Hill. Cable car outside, anything you could want to do in easy reach.
And privacy. And impeccable service. And silence at breakfast.
Just the way staying away from home should be.
Gymnasium and pool terrific.
You need to be a member, or member's guest.

This is the quintessential gentlemen's club. We stayed there as the guest of a member. The building is the house of one of the "big four" San Francisco barons and it is the only one that survived the 1906 quake more or less intact. It is at the top of Nob Hill between Grace Cathedral and the Fairmont. The interior...


More  



This is, or was, now that ladies are admitted, the finest gentlemen's club this side of London's St James's. The swimming pool, steam room and gym equipment are second to none; the bedrooms spacious and airy and tastefully furnished. The card room quiet and well stocked. The library is well-maintained and well-used by members. The staff are efficient and their...

title: Bill Graham Civic Auditorium, San Francisco
review_list:
This place was awesome. I attended a Tool concert here and found it well run, filled with friendly helpful people, had a cozy area where you could gather with friends for a drink and great conversation. There were minimal wait time for drinks and toilets. The theatre area was small so no seat or vantage point was bad. They had...

A two day music event here and this was perfect venue! Room for everyone who attended, great layout, rooms for chilling, areas to sit, bars & food areas, staff was cordial, coat check was fast and efficient. All in all, a great experience.

review_list:

Darn hard to find in City College a bit down the peninsula from the big sights of SF, it is nevertheless a worthwhile trek to see a masterpiece. Hopefully it will...

The Diego Rivera Mural can be found here.
without the monastic atmosphere of most of the museums.

I lived in SF for 5 years and always wanted to visit but never find the time. I finally did on a recent trip back to the Bay Area and I can't believe I didn't go sooner. This is wonderful. Another reason I miss the Bay is amazing (free! attractions) like this.

title: California Welcome Center, San Francisco
review_list:
Traveling in SF by myself, so I headed in for some advise. Everyone was extremely friendly and very helpful. Not at all pushy which I find can sometimes be the case. They helped me find things to do that were specifically suited to me and how I wanted to spend my visit. Would definitely recommend having a chat to these...


More  



I have seen better, but the workers are helpful and will give you a map and tell you whatever you need to know. If you are already at Fisherman's wharf, stop in.

Some of these centres are awful (e.g. Buffalo NY), but this one is great. Lots of great information, well located on Fisherman's Wharf and, best of all, friendly and knowledgeable staff (thanks Zakhida!).

We checked our bags at this place and NEITHER the clerk NOR claim tickets notified us of the business hour! Turns out the place closes at 7pm and, even when we returned only 10 minutes late, we had to catch a midnight flight without our baggage!

title: Cow Hollow, San Francisco
address: Union St (btwn Steiner and Gough), San Francisco, CA
review_list:
We ambled into Cow Hollow after looking at Victorian houses in Presidio Heights. The Painted Ladies here didn't seem quite as grand, but they were still worth a look. We visited on a national holiday so I noted many residents out and about. They seemed to be 20- and 30-somethings.
The big drawing card for tourists here would be Cow...


More  



Great fun to walk around this funky neighborhood. We LOVED the Twig Gallery at 2162 Union Street and bought a fabulous mermaid clock along with some other fun souvenirs. The owner, Keith Chamberlain, boxed it all up and mailed it to us so we did not have to carry it home. Nearby we also found an amazing consignment store with...


More  



Cow Hollow is a funky elite (aka expensive) neighborhood with lots of botiques, restaurants, and specialty stores. Nice to walk around but make sure if you plan on doing more than looking it will be costly.

This is an area for budget motels where you can find cheaper accommodation and free parking, useful if you have a rental car. Its easy from here to get to the Golden Gate Bridge and to Fisherman's Wharf.
The area was once known for field were cows grazed.

We wanted an economical alternative to staying in downtown SFO for a few nights before my conference (downtown) began. What a GREAT area Cow Hollow is! It is mostly residential, but there are neighborhood bars, shops, restaurants around. It was perfect. Nothing too touristy like Fish Wharf. Everything felt more local and we loved the food and places. Would definitely...


More  



My wife and I spent in evening in this area and we're sadly unimpressed. It was quiet, dark, and only mildly interesting...and this was during a Saturday night amidst the Xmas break.
It's very local-ish. But would have preferred to have been in North Beach or Union Square having now seen it.

Lots of cool shops and restaurants known as Union Street Shops. Recommend spending a bit of time here. Ther are lots of young people giving this area a lot of energy. There is no reason to spend every night on the Wharf, so give this a visit.

Great shopping and eating. It changes through the years, but remains an excellent neighborhood, full of wonderful meditative walking streets--a nice place for a break from your usual haunts ... unless, you are fortunate enough to call this your usual haunt.

Cow Hollow may not be as polished as the Marina District but it still has much to offer. There are many great restaurants (see my review of Gamine) and numerous stores to explore. There are also a number of smaller hotels in the area - I would give serious consideration to having it serve as home base for a trip...


More  



My wife and I stayed in Union Square, so it was refreshing to get out of downtown and come down to this more relaxed area. We didn't eat here, but we went to a lot of shops, and we saw some good-looking restaurants we wished we had checked out.

title: Press Club, San Francisco
address: 20 Yerba Buena Lane, San Francisco, CA 94103
review_list:
Quite the scene with people, terrific spacious spot with nice decor and lighting and lots of good wine to choose from. At our visit, they had a half-price off bottles of wine for $75 or more...a really great buy. Lots of banquettes, stools, and seating to find yourself chilling out.

Have been to a couple of college alumni meet ups at the Press Club since relocating to this distant land called California. Tucked away on Yerba Buena and below decks, this is a classy wine bar with a large and good selection, plus tasty nibbles. Seems best suited to a group. Unlike most other places in my adopted city, it...


More  



I was just there for a private party during a convention. The space is absolutely beautiful and the wine was pretty great too!

We had a gathering of 25 people for my daughter's birthday. It wasa very nice place for a gathering. My daughter had made arrangements with the club for the space and the wine. When we arrived everything was setup with both red and white wine and all the glasses. There was also pitchers of water on the tables. During the...


More  



I have been to this place several times and its a nice place to hang out, catch up with friends, meet people. I like the layout of the place, great ambiance and I absolutely love the music here. It' has an upscale feel so if you want to go a little fancy I'd highly recommend Press Club.
It's a wine...


More  



This place has a very trendy, modern feel, it's an underground wine bar. Right out the back door of the Marriott Hotel and sitting somewhat underneath the Four Seasons. Have been a couple of times, the last time we had them set up a selection of local cheeses and wines for our group of about 25 in the back area...


More  



This place is NOT a tasting room anymore, despite the owner's description. It is simply a wine bar that serves a lot of local wine. They do not have tasting stations for individual wineries anymore.
We arrived at 3 in the afternoon on a Saturday. It was the Chinese New Year parade day and the start of SF beer week....


More  



Great place to hang out in SOMA; big modern space, hidden underground, good range of wines...but wish they had a range of sparkling wines as well...the list was more limited than i anticipated. A little pricey, but expected of SOMA.

We recently went to the Press Club and had a pretty good time. The decor is very nice and we really enjoyed sitting on the couch drinking wine and noshing on some yummy appetizers. title: Glad Tidings Church, San Francisco
review_list:
I moved to San Francisco looked for a Church to get plugged in to the city. Wow! Glad Tidings could be termed a loving United Nations! It is totally diverse, it is designed to welcome EVERYBODY from everywhere. Most important you will hear the truth in a loving and compassionate manner!!

Being new to SF, spent some time looking for a church to be a part of. When I first came here, I noticed that people were very friendly, there was a lot of diversity, and people were serious about being real with Jesus. That was many years ago and still attending. The church is continuing to grow and filled with...


More  



This church is on fire! I never been to a church that worship with authenticity. God brought me in this church where I have seen Him work in me more, experiencing genuine love, belongingness, peace, answered prayers, and comfort through the Holy Spirit.
I love this church, I want to keep coming back!

If you're looking for a great assemblies of God church in SF, or any great church this would be it. This is a multi-cultural environment with both young and old where I was welcomed warmly from day 1. There are many groups to be a part of throughout the week. Great childcare and thriving youth groups. Highly recommend this church...


More  



PASTOR: approachable, sincere
SERMON: on healing addressed real questions, but left feeling hope that God is able
PEOPLE: were friendly and welcoming
CHILDREN'S DEPARTMENT: Safe, well organized
MUSIC: band and praise team was contemporary and full of life
COFFEE BAR: as a guest you get a FREE Latte or Cappuccino or Hot Chocolate
DEMOGRAPHIC; Multi-racial but everyone embraced

I like the fact that this church is open to all. What I don't like is that communion is NOT offered on Sunday. As a believer, I think that this is a huge loss.

Being at this church has definitely shaped me into being a more faithful believer and an active believer. I have been attending since July of 2009, and nearly 3 years later, I am so glad to be here. I am challenged to grow, I am encouraged and I am supported. There are so many ways to gte involved, you cannot...

If you’re visiting SF you have to check out the sites, part of that is checking out what's happening @ Glad Tidings Church. GT is a friendly environment, and Grace Café is said to serve some of the best coffee is the City! Come check it out and get some coffee while you’re @ it! =) www.gtsf.org

I have been to this church my whole and it is great! Its a multicultural church where the diversity of SF is adequately represented! I would not go to any other church before this one... its a fun church, NEVER BORING! There is always something new to do here!

This church is on fire! I never been to a church that worship with authenticity. God brought me in this church where I have seen Him work in me more, experiencing genuine love, belongingness, peace, answered prayers, and comfort through the Holy Spirit.
I love this church, I want to keep coming back!

If you're looking for a great assemblies of God church in SF, or any great church this would be it. This is a multi-cultural environment with both young and old where I was welcomed warmly from day 1. There are many groups to be a part of throughout the week. Great childcare and thriving youth groups. Highly recommend this church...

PASTOR: approachable, sincere

PEOPLE: were friendly and welcoming
CHILDREN'S DEPARTMENT: Safe, well organized
