COFFEE BAR: as a guest you get a FREE Latte or Cappuccino or Hot Chocolate
DEMOGRAPHIC; Multi-racial but everyone embraced

I like the fact that this church is open to all. What I don't like is that communion is NOT offered on Sunday. As a believer, I think that this is a huge loss.

Being at this church has definitely shaped me into being a more faithful believer and an active believer. I have been attending since July of 2009, and nearly 3 years later, I am so glad to be here. I am challenged to grow, I am encouraged and I am supported. There are so many ways to gte involved, you cannot...

If you’re visiting SF you have to check out the sites, part of that is checking out what's happening @ Glad Tidings Church. GT is a friendly environment, and Grace Café is said to serve some of the best coffee is the City! Come check it out and get some coffee while you’re @ it! =) www.gtsf.org

I have been to this church my whole and it is great! Its a multicultural church where the diversity of SF is adequately represented! I would not go to any other church before this one... its a fun church, NEVER BORING! There is always something new to do here!
And this place is for everyone: couples, families, teens, friends, business,...

title: Speakeasy Ales & Lagers, San Francisco
review_list:
This is the place to go for a good beer. Eat ahead so you can imbibe to your hearts delight. Love their Double Daddy IPA. Atmosphere is dark and a feel of privacy. Staff are great. They have happy hour chili on Fridays too !!!

They just started doing beer tours again at Speakeasy Ales & Lagers so while in SF, we went. It's all the way out in Hunter's Point but the tour is less than $8 and you get 2 tasters of beer while you're there. You also have the option of sitting at the bar and ordering beers as well. We rode...


More  



Staff totally knows craft beer. The on tap selection is diverse and high quality. If you love beer this craft micro is worth a visit. Bartenders Sochi and Katie were indulgent with their time and expertise. Wish I could give this brewery 6 stars.

What a great place to come. Can't recommend highly enough. All the beers are delicious and having the option for small tasting glasses allows you to try them all. Great atmosphere and love the old school themes. The staff went out of their way to ensure I enjoyed myself. They were fantastic. Knowledgeable about the beer and really friendly. Wish...

title: The Bay Lights, San Francisco
address: San Francisco Bay, San Francisco, CA 94118
review_list:
The Bay Lights are working again. These lights are on the west side of the western span of the San Francisco Bay Bridge (No, this is not the Golden Gate Bridge--that's a different bridge). The clever part of these lights is that you can't see them at all as you drive over the bridge. They'd probably be too distracting. But...


More  



The Bay Bridge is beautifully lighted at night and it can be seen from many of the Restuarants in the area. Don't miss it as the new bridge shines!

We saw this part of the night bus tour of San Francisco. Obviously they schedule the stop for us to admire the light show and the tour guide gave it a big build up. It was just a shame we were all feeling a little chilly to make the most of it. However it was an awesome sight to see...


More  



The lights are awesome but they turned them off in early March. Heard they needed to make bridge repairs but they'll b turned back on before super bowl 2016.

The Bay Bridge light show is a stunning show of lights. It was done as a celebration of the new Bay Bridge that was being built. There are more than 48,000 LED lights, that do a synchronized light show. The light show was designed by Moffat & Nichol and built by Nebraska-based Valmont Industries. It is lit at night. The...


More  



My wife and stayed at the Harbor Point Hotel last month and had a view of the Bay Bridge from our fourth floor room. What a terrific light show hanging every few seconds. I was trying to do some light reading and found I could not concentrate with this attraction outside my window. I finally gave up and put my...


More  



The Bay Lights, is a spectacular LED sculpture on the western span of The Oakland San Francisco Bay Bridge. You will be dazzled and mesmerized by the 25,000 individual white LEDs along 1.8 miles span of the Bridge. At night, stroll along the Embarcadero, dine at any of the waterfront restaurants or visit a SF 'Sky Room' and gaze out...

title: USS San Francisco Memorial, San Francisco
address: 2400 El Camino Del Mar, San Francisco, CA 94121
review_list:
A fitting memorial to this ship that participated in the Battle of Guadalcanal and suffered many losses. Has great vistas around it as it abuts the Lands End. Interesting incorporation of the actual ship pieces, broken though they are, as part of the perimeter of the memorial.

The story of USS San Francisco is engraved in a plaque nearby and is quite interesting. Enjoy beautiful views from here. There are park benches that look out to waves crashing against rocks that stick out of the beautiful blue Pacific with the golden gate bridge in the distance. Gorgeous!

My favorite spot to sit and enjoy the beauty. Most amazing views of the ocean and Golden Gate Bridge. Nice trails to enjoy and plenty of parking.

very nice memorial. nice setting. didn't feel scared or have problems with theft. decent stop while touring the sites.

I would advise against visiting this area, unless you are partial to vehicle burglary and theft. I parked in the public lot in front of the memorial and decided to hike down the trails for better views of the Golden Gate Bridge. When I returned, I found my rental car windows broken into and some of my personal things stolen....


More  



I took the steps up from the trail to get a better view and decided to walk over and see what the memorial was about seeing I was there. I am glad I did, being Australian, I am grateful for their sacrifice seeing we were next on japans hit list. R.I.P.

Good place to go if you want to avoid the Tourist traps. Plenty of parking trails and a great view. There's a nice little restaurant nearby could get a good lunch.

The memorial is very small but humbling in the same respect. The memorial itself is built from actual pieces of the ship which was decommissioned due to the heavy damage sustained during the battle of Guadalcanal. My grandfather was stationed aboard this ship during the war and during Guadalcanal, so it was very special to be able to see this...


More  



Was just walking when we stumbled upon this memorial. I was in complete shock at the battle damage on display.utterly sobering and a true testament to all the brave men and women who fought in Ww2.

I still wish more people would visit this memorial. Stop by while walking/hiking Land's end trail and learn a little about the ship and the horrors of the Battle of Guadalcanal

title: Queen Wilhelmina Garden, San Francisco
address: 1690 John F Kennedy Drive, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Beautiful place to see flowers and a windmill. Great for a walk around or just sit on one of the benches. It could be a nice to bring a picnic lunch too.

The garden is dedicated to former Netherlands queen Whilamena, and it is beautiful. Parking at mid-morning on Sunday was no problem. Giant tulips were abundant and the windmill was fascinating. The flowers are beautiful and it's an amazing setting. A peaceful and relaxing place to visiit.

San Francisco Golden Gate Park has two windmills; the north windmill is in the Queen Wilhemina Garden. It is a small but delightful "locals" area of Golden Gate Park, although all can definitely visit.
I could easily find free parking right beside the garden mid week. A mom and her toddler were having a good time playing hide and seek....


More  



Stopped late Saturday afternoon to see this large Dutch windmill in the garden. There were many flowers blooming around the garden, which included red tulips. Very impressive windmill, suppose the season we visited is not a time for abundant flower blooms. Nevertheless, as Midwesterners, we appreciated the view along with the charm of the windmill. Nice photo shoot stop!

The garden is beautiful and flowers changed for the season. The windmill is incredible and much larger than I expected. Larger than many of the ones I saw in Holland.

A pretty place to hang out. I'm Dutch, so I couldn't resist to visit this part of the park that is named after one of our former Queens. It's nice to stroll around a bit. Especially with all those tulips and a windmill. If you're into botanical gardens, you should appreciate the tulips. It's not a place you would spend...


More  



We had just finished walking the coastal trail and we could see the two windmills in the Golden Gate Park on our approach, the windmills looked a little run-down, so we weren't expecting to see such a beautiful garden with gorgeous green grass and pretty flowers. It seems out of place, a little piece of the Netherlands with the beach,...


More  



What a lovely find. I really like well maintained, colorful gardens. This is what I consider a nice find on the west end of Golden Gate Park. A beautiful place for pictures with that special background, and when you walk to the center of the garden, the olfactory experience is marvelous. I can sit and watch the flowers grow and...


More  



At the far end of the golden gate park you find this piece of Holland. Too bad the tulip garden didnt have any actual tulips.

We literally only stopped by here because there was a geocache in the area. The flower beds were out of season and empty but the visit inspired us to research the interesting history of the windmill.

title: Potrero Hill, San Francisco
review_list:
As a San Francisco Bay Area local who just visited Buenos Aires and Santiago, I must say I am not that impressed with Potrero Hill. The shopping district is modest and it is likely a nice part of San Francisco to live. But as an attraction, it really isn't that great. A city with as much money and international notoriety...


More  



I lived on Potrero Hill in the 90's and early naughties. It has changed over the past 10 years but still has it's "Goat Hill" charm despite the influx of folks and the regular busy-ness of the local cafes and restaurants.
The ONE thing to watch -- the parking patrol who drive around giving tickets are professional automatons -- they...


More  



Potrero Hill is a lovely, quiet residential neighbourhood south of the city, overlooking the Bay on one side and the Mission on the other. You can walk to both the Bay and the Mission, but beware the hills, which are very steep in places.

I am a regular visitor to SF and the bay area, but this is the first time I have stayed in Potrero Hill. It's like being in a village at the top of a mountain. The views are great, the roads are very steep, and the people friendly. Quite a set group of local 'village' shops as well. Easy taxi...


More  



My wife and I have visited San Francisco for over 40 years. We've always stayed in the busy downtown/marina core. While both areas are great we now prefer to travel as a local and Potrero Hill is a GREAT neighborhood! Grab yourself a VRBO and enjoy the many fine restaurants in close walking distance. Be sure to check out Sally's...

title: Golden Gate Theatre, San Francisco
review_list:
Saw a Gentleman's Guide to Love and Murder. What a Wonderful musical. Top notch Broadway productions. The theatre was packed-defiantly a must see

Come here for those blockbusters that are on tour. Or maybe some other performance, but come and take a gander at the splendor of old. Such memories this building holds, so much history of the City.

Historic building. Always the best in Broadway
shows. Though seats are smaller because of
theatre age, it still is a thrill to watch the shows.

My wife has always been an Angela Lansbury fan so for our 20th anniversary I arranged the trip down to see her at this play as our anniversary present.
I can't say anything negative about the theatre - it was built in the day and was pretty much what I expected. I thought it was a nice piece of history...


More  



Yes this theatre has seen better days , & as previous reviewers have commented not in the best part of S . F , but area go up & down , anyway on to the theatre .
Tess Collins & her team do their best , we saw Angel Lansbury along with 1600 patrons , it was clean - comfortable...


More  



This theater is a Grand Dame of San Francisco theaters. We saw Angela Lansbury in Blithe Spirit. Of course I would have gone anywhere local to see Angela Lansbury in anything. She was amazing ( keep in mind she is 87!)
The theater, despite its age had good acoustics and did a great job!!

The play was great - Angela Lansbury - how can you go wrong? It is a lovely theater, and the staff was very accommodating. Would definitely go back.

The Bathrooms are downstairs and there are only a few stalls for women. It is an old theatre but the accoustics were good and the seating in the theatre is comfortable. The lobbies could be updated and another women's bathroom should be installed with more stalls and then the theatre would receive a very good rating.

Going to the Golden Gate Theater on the corner of Taylor/Golden Gate/Market Street in San Francisco is a quasi dangerous trek to the slums. The smell of urine is ubiquitous as are the throngs of low life. A first thought is to hold on to your purse, wallet, walk quickly, and maintain a low profile. The theater itself has seen...


More  



Beautiful Beautiful Beautiful loved it. I recommend to everyone. A must see!!! Do not wait must go go go....

title: Sentinel Building, San Francisco
address: 916-920 Kearny, Columbus Financial District, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
We accidentally found the Sentinel Building while passing by it on an architectural tour. title: Neptune Society Columbarium, San Francisco
address: 1 Lorraine Ct,. at Anza, Richmond District, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Penny had seen this on a Billy Connolly TV program about death. Visiting a vertical graveyard may not be top of your tourist list but this is a lovely, peaceful place with moving memorials to the people whose ashes are here. Well worth a visit

I’m a tapophile (someone who frequents and appreciates cemeteries), so The Columbarium was an important stop on a recent trip to San Francisco. But you don’t need to like cemeteries to visit this important and unusual place, which holds thousands of people’s cremains in niches, urns, boxes, all in glass-fronted or bronze-enclosed cases. Some of the “residents" are famous, most...


More  



We had seen a Huell Howser California Gold segment on the cemetaries of San Francisco. He said that in the 1920s, the city council in San Francisco wanted to get rid of the cemetaries and move the remains to Colma. So the bodies in the Richmond District, where the Columbarium is located were move, but the main building of the...


More  



i have used Neptune service when my uncle passed away, there are very helpful and needful in time and also the parer work was taken care peacefully and without disturbing others which was really stunning, well we all were disturbed the way they handled makes me to write this review..they are top class and simply superb.

The Columbarium is only 3 miles down Geary Street from Union Square, but it's a totally different experience. Instead of tourists and street performers, you'll discover a jewel-like building dedicated to honoring loved ones with displays of their urns and treasured possessions. The "residents" represent the wonderful diversity that has always been San Francisco. Asians are in niches next to...


More  



The Neptune Society helped us with our loss and did it a corporate manner. However, we were exceptionally pleased with the Boat Captain "Stewart" and his crew who treated us with kindness, carring, and thoughtfulness; because of the crew, we would recommend the Neptune Society to anyone...!!

Off the beaten track in San Francisco is America's cheeriest repository of human ashes. The magnificent Columbarium -- a century-old, copper-domed neoclassical bldg. with stained glass -- displays windowed niches filled with cookie jar, teapot, brandy decanter and piggy bank urns. You'll see photos and memorabilia of thousands of the dearly departed, including politicians, veterans of the Gold Rush, celebrities...

review_list:

This is a, still, undiscovered gem. Go visit before it's overrun with tourists ruining the shots of the stairs and the...

address: Between Stockton and Kearny Streets, Union Square, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
We visited this spot as part of a Hitchcock tour (yes, this area was filmed in one of his movies. It was also known as the "red light district" many years ago with more than 1200 prostitutes walking this tiny area. The only building Frank Lloyd Wright designed in SF is also here (an art gallery now). Worth taking a...


More  



This short street runs for two blocks from Stockton at Union Square to Grant and from Grant to Kearny. It features cafes and upscale shops, such as Chanel, Hermes and Prada. Maiden Lane closes to vehicular traffic between 11 a.m. and 6 p.m. and I find it fun to stroll here during those hours in nice weather when the cafes...


More  



Although Maiden Lane has a relatively interesting history (being the red light district once upon time) today this small pedestrian lane is rather dull. Yes there are some designers stores, Marni and Channel etc, but there aren't that many and the street itself is pretty dull and dark.

Very pricey bit of SF, can be snobby, can be welcoming. Shops here are tres tres and not for everyone. On a nice day, a stroll along, poking in where you choose, maybe a bite or something...
Enjoy!

One of the oldest streets in San Fran with a colorful (red light) history. You will enjoy strolling along Maiden Lane and seeing some of the upscale shops.

Maiden Lane is one of the oldest streets in San Francisco and originally it used to lead to the original port in San Francisco where the dock workers and prostitutes used to ply their trades! It is only a small street with some interesting shops along the street. The Romper Room is near the corner of Maiden Lane and is...


More  



Maiden Lane used to be part of the red light district. Now it is a peaceful pedestrian street during the late morning to evening with a handful of upscale stores, art gallery, and cafes. There are some business offices on the street as well.
Its key to know that Maiden Lane runs between Geary and Post Streets to see the...


More  



THE HISTORY --- Check out their website (maiden-lane.com)
Prior to the 1906 earthquake, the street was called Morton Street and was the center of San Francisco’s red-light district. There was often one murder a week in this area. The earthquake, which leveled much of the city, rendered this two-block stretch rubble.

More  



Please go to this little gem of architecture tucked away on a sweet street, Maiden Lane, not far from Union Square.

This street is so close to the Union square and yet being a bit tiny, does not get that much traffic by the tourists. If you did not know that there is an interesting gallery, Xanadu, you would not even venture here, but give it a try. The Gallery did change my point of view of Maiden Lane

title: NextArts, San Francisco
review_list:
My sister and I used NextArts for our parent's 30th wedding anniversary at the Fort Mason Center last week. Austin was great. We rented uplights, drapery and patio heaters from them. Set up was a breeze and they even helped with designing the event. We strongly recommend them.

I decided to rent the drapery for my sister in laws wedding, the drape was beautiful and really put together the wedding.

Wow! The lights!! We hired NextArts to do sound stage and lights for our wedding reception. Oh my God!! We had bistros lights everywhere.

NextArts audio video and lighting in San Francisco was absolutely amazing to work with. I work for a local magazine company and put on upwards of two events a week, and working with NextArts has been a lifesaver. I recently got married in San Francisco. We chose NextArts to do our lighting and décor for our wedding. Everything looked amazing!!!
GO WITH NEXTARTS PEOPLE!!! NextArts is a great nonprofit organization. Excellent and professional service. They had exactly what I needed. I highly recommend them.

title: Stonestown Galleria, San Francisco
address: 3251 20th Ave. at Buckingham Way, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Easy parking and public transportation available (Metro) this shopping mall provides a lot of well known stores and pretty decent restaurants.
It´s very similar to any other shopping mall but a little bit old. It is near to Park Merced.
They also have a big Apple Store (if you like Apple goods).

A bit old fashion both inside and out. There're food court there and food is good. If you don't like shopping and stay near Park Merced or Lake Merced this is the choice.

The smallest mall I had ever been too. It so limited and it carried mostly women accessories and clothes. I walked around the whole mall three times trying to even buy one thing and plan failed. Nothing worth shopping for at this location.

Much easier than the hassle of paid parking and long walks to everything. Many of the stores will offer to ship you items if they don't have them in stock, free shipping.

We have shopped for thigns at Stonestown Galleria a few times. In general, its an average shopping center in San Francisco.

I visited during the weekday when most were working. It was very quiet, not much going on which is good for me, although the staff in the stores tended to stalk you. The hallways, stores, and restrooms were clean. I enjoyed the Nordstrom's shoe sale of course :-)!

good place to eat at olvier garden shop sight see or go to the apple store or high end shopping good parking and good service thetaxidriversguidetosanfrancisco.com

This is not the best or the biggest mall around, but believe it or not it is one of the oldest ones in San Francisco. It's kind of bifurcated by a road that splits the Nordstrom and Trader Joe's off from the main part of the mall.
Among other attractions is the Trader Joe's where hundreds of students from SF...


More  



This is a typical mall you would find in any city. It's located near SFSU, so its location isn't really a tourist destination.

title: International Art Museum of America, San Francisco
review_list:
The title may be misleading in terms of the art not being international. Maybe universal would be a better word if they're aiming for hinting at how the knowledge and interpretation behind Dorje Chang's is universal. The works were beautiful and thought provoking. But for most people that do not come from a Buddhist background could be confusing hence the...


More  



Just happened to be walking by and it looked very interesting from the outside. Step inside and ground floor was like a tiki bar with water, ferns and plants. Second floor has quite an extensive artwork collection from China and some European influence.

This place is hilarious! A vehicle for the most egregious artwork we have ever seen, mainly from the so-called H. H. Dorje Chang Buddha III. He not only paints hilarious bling dross, but also makes frames and "sculpture" too. It is really fantastically funny, so long as you go with the right attitude.
It's been suggested by others on tripadvisor...


More  



Since its inception IAMA has amassed works from many parts of the world and is a real centre of peace and tranquility on this busy street. Recommended in Jonathan B's guide to San Fran this is home to an absolutely incredible array of the 16 painting styles of H H Donje Chang Buddha 111. He is the only person in...


More  



As you enter off the street you're in an ersatz forest complete with waterfall and pools. It looks a bit like a really superior papier-mâché model. Upstairs there are showcases of more ersatz stuff -pseudo-corals of huge size and lurid color, and many works on paper, somewhat reminiscent of classical wood-block prints, by a Chinese artist who became an incarnation,...


More  



This is a new museum with free admission. Has few nice displays. The best part was that we were the only one in the museum. Loved to have it all to ourself

I'm still going to recommend a visit to this 'museum', and I use the term quite loosely. It's free after all and there's one or two works worth looking at. Generally speaking though it feels like some kind of propaganda machine for HH Dorje Chang Buddha III and his paintings and calligraphy.
A quick google search will turn up all...


More  



Just came across this while walking along the street. I found the H.H. Dorje Chang Buddha III exhibition very interesting and inspirational. I would have liked to purchase a few postcards of the paintings and sculptures I liked, but this wasn't available. If you are interested in art, then its worth a visit.

Yesterday went to a very interesting museum. IAMA = International Art Museum of America, opened a year ago, but they don’t have budget for advertising, so I haven’t heard about it till recently. They have Asian and European paintings, and the whole collection looks strange, like scrambled at the last moment, but still enjoyable. Some paintings are difficult to see...


More  



Worst thing I've ever seen. Must be a front for tax evasion, drug running or some sort of smuggling. Maybe they have those things that steal your credit card info in the walls? Bizarre.

title: Alta Plaza Park, San Francisco
address: 2700 Clay St., Pacific Heights, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
This is a great neighborhood park on a hill offering views of several parts of the city and bay. There's a playground, tennis courts, lawns, and more, making it ideal for kids, adults, dogs, locals, and visitors just to take a break. A beautiful place to relax in the city.

Alta Plaza Park is at the top of Pacific Heights. It has beautiful panoramic views of San Francisco city and bay. On a sunny day, it's nice to bring the dog, grab a picnic lunch and enjoy people watching but especially the views.
The park is spacious and has a lot to offer. There are lots of trees, large grassy...


More  



I can't believe I stumbled upon this place and it's gorgeous! Where else can I go to enjoy a panoramic view of the city while my daughter can play on the playground! Best of all, I get greeted by happy dogs in the park too! I would visit this park again if I return to San Francisco.

I'm still going to recommend a visit to this 'museum', and I use the term quite loosely. It's free after all and there's one or two works worth looking at. Generally speaking though it feels like some kind of propaganda machine for HH Dorje Chang Buddha III and his paintings and calligraphy.
A quick google search will turn up all...


More  



Just came across this while walking along the street. I found the H.H. Dorje Chang Buddha III exhibition very interesting and inspirational. I would have liked to purchase a few postcards of the paintings and sculptures I liked, but this wasn't available. If you are interested in art, then its worth a visit.

Yesterday went to a very interesting museum. IAMA = International Art Museum of America, opened a year ago, but they don’t have budget for advertising, so I haven’t heard about it till recently. They have Asian and European paintings, and the whole collection looks strange, like scrambled at the last moment, but still enjoyable. Some paintings are difficult to see...


More  



Worst thing I've ever seen. Must be a front for tax evasion, drug running or some sort of smuggling. Maybe they have those things that steal your credit card info in the walls? Bizarre.

title: Alta Plaza Park, San Francisco
address: 2700 Clay St., Pacific Heights, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
This is a great neighborhood park on a hill offering views of several parts of the city and bay. There's a playground, tennis courts, lawns, and more, making it ideal for kids, adults, dogs, locals, and visitors just to take a break. A beautiful place to relax in the city.

Alta Plaza Park is at the top of Pacific Heights. It has beautiful panoramic views of San Francisco city and bay. On a sunny day, it's nice to bring the dog, grab a picnic lunch and enjoy people watching but especially the views.
The park is spacious and has a lot to offer. There are lots of trees, large grassy...


More  



I can't believe I stumbled upon this place and it's gorgeous! Where else can I go to enjoy a panoramic view of the city while my daughter can play on the playground! Best of all, I get greeted by happy dogs in the park too! I would visit this park again if I return to San Francisco.

title: Anchor Brewing Company, San Francisco
review_list:
Excellent tour around the actual working brewery (no show rooms here). As an added bonus it starts and finishes with beer to drink.
Worth noting it's a bit out the way of the main city, so plan your route if your not driving.

We were the first Sunday tour and the tour was great. Lots of samples, the equivalent to 3 bottles of beer. Interesting history and worth the price. You need to make reservations online. With looking into if you like beer and history.

Six of us booked a tour at the Anchor Brewing Co. The tour begins with a sample of the basic Anchor brew. Then you are shown through the facility and the brewing process is explained. The visit concludes with a tasting of 5 or 6 current releases. Although I am not a beer enthusiast, I really enjoyed this.

A great brewery tour. The ambiance is unique ... big copper kettles, beautiful bar in the tasting room. Excellent presentation of their products and methods which are unlike those of any other American brewery.
You do have to reserve in advance, and a month before there was no space on the tours we were in town during, however with perseverance...


More  



My husband and I and 6 friends did the brewery tour on our most recent trip to San Francisco. Our tour guide Braden was fantastic! We learned so many interesting things about Anchor Brewing Company and beer making in general. I would highly recommend this tour to any beer lover / history buff. The tour started with a "welcome beer"...


More  



Booked this online before travelling and was very easy to do. You go to the actual brewery and get shown round, our tour guide Dela was great. You see how the beer is made and told every aspect about it. Then you go to the tasting room and we had 6 tastes of different beers and you got a decent...


More  



As a member of the Campaign for Real Ale for nearly 40 years, I've visited more traditional breweries than I care to remember. But our visit Anchor Brewing will sit right up there as one of the best. The company has been in existence for over 100 years and can rightly claim to be the original craft brewer.
The visit...


More  



Any craft brewer will show you the brew and fermentation tanks. What's special about Anchor Brewing Co's tour is you get the full history of the business that dates back more than a 100 years. I value tradition. You see all aspects of the process. The boiling of the wart. The various fermentation stages. The bottling and canning. And the...


More  



Get a reservation for $15 and take the tour. It comes with multiple tastings at the conclusion. Nice tour covering the history and beer making process. Tasting is generous. Tour leader was knowledgeable and entertaining. Great for any beer enthusiast.

A nice tour of a local well known brewery. Fun tour, learn a lot about the brewing process and some history behind the company and industry in the US. You need an advanced reservation so don't just show up expecting to get in. You will get to taste their whole line or part as your heart desires.

title: Oceanic Society Farallon Islands Whale Watching, San Francisco
review_list:
If you're interested in whales or seabirds, and will be in the San Francisco Bay Area during summer or autumn, don't fail to visit the Gulf of the Farallones National Marine Sanctuary.
Whale sightings aren't guaranteed (see their "Whale Watching Terms and Conditions), but over something like 10 trips with the Oceanic Society I've always seen whales. I've only done...


More  



Very well run. I liked the fact they call the day before and talk to you so you are well prepared. This is not a leisure cruise. You are on a fishing boat. Staff were very well informed and very helpful. i would recommend this cruise.

We had a very good experience, even though the sea was absolutely brutal when we were out there. Lots of good wildlife and birds, including 6 humpback whales that came so close to us (we didn't approach them) that we could hear their spouts.
The captain and the deck hands/naturalists all did a great job in helping us get the...


More  



This was a totally fun day. Lots of unusual birds , sea life and the weather was dry, sunny and the water calm by the bay on this day. We had a great crew. Very informative . Our day started about 8:00 am on a Saturday and ended about 4:30 pm. Bring some snacks, water, hat, sun screen and a...


More  



I booked this tour online. My daughter and I are nature lovers. We were so looking forward to this experience. My first disappointment. The boat was way too small for the number of people booked on it. There weren't enough seats for everyone. A number of us had to stand during the 8 hour tour. This is hard to do...


More  



We went on this Whale Watching Tour as a family with four adults and had a fantastic time. We saw at least twenty Humpback Whales and two Blue Whales, much more then we expected. We saw whales diving, whales breaching, swimming by the boat. Absolutely breathtaking. I took a few super pictures. The Naturalists on board wre really nice and...


More  



The highlight was a blue whale suddenly surfacing about 30 feet away for about 5 seconds to check us out. The whale was much bigger than the 50 foot boat , 'The Salty Lady' that we were on. This is an 8 hour trip to an island that is the home of thousands of birds and sea lions. Be prepared to a bumpy ride to the island. The guide was very informative who talked to all of us onboard. There is a small area to sit inside is being outside is uncomfortable. Take drinks and something to eat....

Had a wonderful family trip. Boy does the Oceanic Society know how to put together a great trip. title: Punch Line, San Francisco
address: 444 Battery St. between Clay and Washington, Financial District, San Francisco, CA 94111
review_list:
Great for date night or hanging with friends. $10 and a 2 drink minimum and plenty of up and coming comics. Street parking was plentiful on a Sunday night. We would definitely do it again.

Nice comedy club, good although basic food menu, spacious and has great comedians. Service was very good and ambiance is very nice. Great place to relax and laugh without spending a fortune.

We hadn't been to a comedy show in ages and to celebrate our birthdays, we decided we needed a few laughs. We got a good seat in the second row and both shows were sold out. They have a two drink minimum, I ordered a ginger beer and my date had an orange cream soda. They did not enforce the...


More  



This stand up comedy venue is one of our favorites! You can catch big name artists here at a cheap price! Moreover, the venue offers discounts. The cocktails are top notch, there is ample free street parking around the venue, and it's in a relatively safe neighborhood. The MCs and staff are top notch--always offer a welcoming smile.

First time at the punch line. The comedy and the interior design were nice. The cocktails were undrinkable though. Too sweet and little alcohol. Wine was not good either. Tried a few of them all. There is a two drink minimum.

We were here at 2.30pm. Staff told us to come back at 3 to buy tickets. From 3 to 3.30pm we waited but although staff saw us, they refused to open the door. Didn't feel like working apparently...

Our experience at Punch Line was what we expected from a comedy club--we got good seats, our drinks were ok--not too watered down. The club was well run and we had a good time--much better than our experience later in our vacation when we visited Cobb's Comedy Club.

Saw Rob Schneider along with some other great comics. Absolutely loved him. Every seat is a great seat. Free parking after 6:00 pm on a Friday night in a very nice part of the city. Door staff friendly. Ordered a couple of beers and had the chicken sliders and a small veg pizza since there was a food/bev. Req. of...


More

Very nice place with two floors and bars, you can meet all kind of people here.
The Bootie SF is a huge mashup party with great djs. You can almost dance close to them as the crowd is used to get on the scene when the party is getting hot ;)

Went for the Trannyshack Costume party. Left before the "Live Entertainment". Music was all one droning beat that killed my desire to just dance, building was dingy and run down. Staff was RUDE. Waste of the $15, I wish I had just given it to the all the bums sleeping on the ground outside.

Loved the music and the 2 stages with different music going on. The upstairs one is small and plays techno but was never too packed the night I went. title: Bottom of the Hill, San Francisco
address: 1233 17th St. between Texas and Missouri Sts., Potrero Hill, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
My friends and I were waiting in a long line, shivering in disbelief as we contemplated how the venue had enough capacity for all of its guests. Lo and behold, we made it to the entrance and realized the venue extends back, where concert goers can order food and sit at tables. There was even a side door leading out...


More  



Excellent venue to hear off-beat live music. Cool decor and friendly and attentive staff. The decor and layout is uniquely San Fran.

I have been to bottom of the hill a couple times to watch some shows. The bar is in a quite neighborhood with plenty of free street parking. The venue is very small which can add to the appeal. This is the only venue I have been to where you can actually have conversations with the musicians while they are...


More  



Went here with friends to watch a show. The bar is extremely small (obviously) and the set up is a little strange and clumped together. The stage is the on the far left up against the wall so if you would like a good place to watch and listen, you're either directly in the middle or on the far right...


More  



This is the kind of place you will find the new up and coming top music makers. You will want to check them out. See who is playing and plan ahead as there will be a line if the band is good. We don't use cabs anymore in this area and SF. We use services like lyft, Uber and Sidecar....


More  



This place is hands down my favorite place to catch a concert in the Bay Area. Just plan on calling a cab to get home after (unless you like to walk). Middle of nowhere, great venue. Note, very safe neighborhood, so safe to walk to downtown from there.

title: Cow Palace, San Francisco
address: Geneva Avenue and Santos Street, 2600 Geneva Avenue Daly City, San Francisco, CA 94134-0206
review_list:
If you haven't gone to this yet. I highly recommend it. The people that work there and attend there are amazing. The beauty joy and magic that comes to life when you step inside and beyond words. I felt like I stepped back in time and was apart of it. I have three children 14, 4, and 1. A lil...


More  



This review is specifically for the Great Dickens Christmas Fair held each year at Cow Palace.
We has a lovely time yesterday at the Christmas Fair. There are hundreds of actors dressed in period costume interacting with guests, as well as regular folks dressed up. It was our first time, so we were in street clothes and didn't feel out...


More  



Serves its purpose but not the best venue for just about any event. It's run down and dated. Getting OLD.

This place is an oldy...and it looks it! still, there is something cool about the place. Maybe it's all the history of the events that have taken place there.

What an amazing time we had at this event. It is always a great productions, great food, plenty of things for the family to do. Great service - shuttle took us from event to our cars in upper parking lot when it was raining. Great Experience - highly recommend it.

My husband and I went to the Dickens Faire for the first time. I had so much fun. So many people in 1800 costumes. The food was good and lots of entertainment going on. Shops of all kinds. Can't wait to go next year and we are going to dress up. The building itself seemed fine it was so decked...


More  



Great location for fast in and out. The neighborhood around the Cow Palace is a little different. If you are city wise it is okay. If you are not comfortable in the intercity setting you may want to drive a little before you look for a quick meal. While the Cow Palace is a one of a kind location, the...


More  



The Cow Palace is in Daly City, which is south of San Francisco. Its a fun place to go see evens.
We have seen several events there such as rodeos followed by the Charlie Daniel band. We have gone to the zoo there.
The place is big and as such there is lot to explore when they have a boat...


More  



Cow palace was built in the 1940's and everything about it is old including the smells. Steps are steep and uneven so ladies, please don't wear high high heals. More  



We have visited
The cow palace several times and I'm not sure why it's called cow palace I've never seen any but the venue is nice the parking is easy and I have a great time every time I'm here. Any event here is always an experience.

title: California Historical Society, San Francisco
review_list:
I enjoyed the comprehensive exhibit about the 1915 Pan Pacific Exposition. There were a lot of displays, and it is amazing how much our culture has changed in 100 years. It's well worth the $5 entrance fee. I see that other reviewers were disappointed, obviously expecting more than there is. Perhaps the CHS should make sure that visitors know what...


More  



The only exhibit is the one on show. In my case it was City Rising: San Francisco and the 1915 World's Fair. Most of the artifacts are in the research library.

Current exhibition is the 1915 Pan Pacific Exposition. Lots of memorabilia and a scale model of the Fair. Several video displays give insight to the event. They also have a limited hours historical library that unfortunately was not open when we visited Very pleasant, helpful and knowledgeable staff.

Only the ground floor was open and it was entirely dedicated to the 100th anniversary of the 1815 San Francisco Fair. Whilst mildly interesting, I felt cheated of a more comprehensive overview of the city's history. The tickets are very expensive for what you get - 6 rooms showing souvenirs, postcards, books and photos and a couple of videos. I...


More  



The current exhibit on 1915 Pan American International Fair at the California Historical Society is a superb exhibit. The only remaining building in San Francisco now is the superb Palace of Fine Arts. This historical exhibit honors the 100th birthday of the fair. There are various short video programs one can watch when visiting; these are well done. Its hard...


More  



Wonderful exhibit on Yosemite's history. Great photos, especially Carlton Watkins. It took about an hour to read the information. The building itself is interesting. Great value at $5.00.

A really interesting exhibit on a Mexican lady settler who grew to be prominent in San Francisco's Yerba Buena beginnings, is currently on display in the first floor gallery. One can see documents, even photos of the tiny settlement and learn much about the beginnings and the many hardships of this major city. Juana Briones is in her way a...


More  



The current display is midly interesting at best. No real info on California or SF history. Book shop was terrible-very few actual historical books.

California Historical Society is worth an hour or two if you are interested in how San Francisco evolved over time. Current display on the Bay area is interesting though lacking in depth of information. The best part for me is the library, where I could sit and read at leisure about almost any California topic I chose. Admission is by...


More  



Seemed more of a photo art gallery than anything else. A bit small and not much other than the photography exhibition and that had little to do with the history of California as it featured more of an exhibition of a local photographer who dealt in rural scenes.

title: Battery Boutelle, San Francisco
review_list:
This is the best location to photography the bridge!! At sunset is blows your mind. It is a rather intense hike to get down to the location - lots of steps. If you are not in good physical condition - do not attempt. I have the most amazing photos of this location!!! so beautiful!!

A SF native drove us up to the scenic viewpoint of the Golden Gate bridge where it was almost impossible to find parking, as the viewpoint was popular. We took our share of pictures, and then our driver showed us this "secret" road with an 18% grade (downhill) and all of a sudden, the sun reflection on the Pacific Ocean...


More  



Barring less-than-good weather, our next visit here will include bringing a picnic lunch and hiking around the area. Although, it's an easy walk out to the cliff area to take in the view, I saw there was plenty to explore if we had the time. The vista is gorgeous. We met some nice folks and we took each others photos...


More

title: The Marsh, San Francisco
review_list:
We saw "Each and Every Thing" on Friday night.......Dan Hoyle is amazing, funny, clever, such a great observer and writer as well as performer. He is a master. I was reminded of when we used to see Lily Tomlin at The Boardinghouse in SF (30 years ago??). Both Lily and Dan Hoyle have created and embodied wonderful characters they had...


More  



The Marsh hosts some of the US' top solo performers. These gifted artists can hold your attention on stage - with little or no props - for over an hour with their stories. Some of the artists can portray as many as 10 different characters in the space of a performance. Others are more straight up stories about the life...


More  



I wish I could give this theatre a higher rating because I REALLY enjoyed the performance. (Grumpy old Jew by Charlie Varon) However I felt the theatre itself was lacking in several area. The first was that we couldn't by tickets online. It was Saturday morning when we were researching plays to see for Sunday night. The Marsh lets you...


More  



One of the best entertainment deal in San Francisco The Marsh is the internationally known for solo performance theater. It's almost impossible to see a show at The Marsh that won't give you something to think about and and realize what a great theater experience can be.
With two stages in San Francisco and two in Berkeley, both near BART...


More  



This review is for the Berkeley location of The Marsh, located at 2120 Allston Way, Berkeley.
If you're looking for an inexpensive evening out with a friend(s), go to the Marsh's website and see what shows are lined up. The theater is small and they tend to have one-person shows. Plan an evening of dinner at Gather, (or one of...


More  



I recently saw Brian Copeland's "The Waiting Period" at The Marsh. What a delightful surprise. The Marsh is a tiny little theater that is just what the doctor ordered. A venue for new and unfolding artists, The Marsh seats, maybe 100+ people, so everyone is in the first row! Loved the show and wouldn't hesitate to see another performance there...


More  



Caught a provocative performance of All My Children by improvisor Matt Smith. This 90 minute show was a funny, evocative exploration of paths not taken - a childless man of a certain age looks up all his old girlfriends, arranges to meet their kids and announces he's their father!
Have enjoyed numerous performances over the years at the Marsh, which...


More  



If you want some good theater, I've been going to The Marsh for years. Fun area of the Mission as well. Warning: the normal people crowd thins late at night, especially on week nights. You don't want to be out with the folks who are left.
http://www.themarsh.org/

The Esplanade offers a nice green open area in the Downtown neighbourhood in San Francisco. Great to take a chill out break in, sot down and watch the world go by.

Many people enjoy the esplanade area every day in San Francisco. It is at Mission Street and Yerba Buena Lane. It is by the Metreon Center in San Francisco. It is a short walk from the Moscone Convention Center and many people walk past the area daily.

title: Tin How Temple, San Francisco
review_list:
We went because it was on our walking tour sheet we picked up from the hotel. I guess to say you've been there is okay, but I wouldn't make a special trip.

We had to use GPS on my phone to find. When GPS showed we were there, we still didn't see it. But because we had read all the trip advisor reports, we knew it was hard to find so we stayed put and played I spy lol. We had a good laugh when we looked up and the sign was...

While visiting Chinatown, we wanted our 2 teenage granddaughters to see a Chinese temple. It was difficult to find Tin How Temple since there was just a doorway with the name on top. We started climbing steps in what looked like a residential apartment. Forging ahead, at the top of the third floor you could smell the incense in this...


More  



After climbing a staircase (and reading various things that we can't do in the temple) we entered it and were told: "No children!" and asked to leave. Strange I didn't know that I look like a child (there were only two of us, me and my wife). Very bad experience, if they don't want visitors they should state that at...


More  



After looking for the temple for awhile, we finally found the temple....impress with the temple which was now at 104 years old....its really impressive to be able to pray here.....love the feeling of relieve after praying......

After spending about 40 minutes in Chinatown trying to locate the small temple and asking all the locals, which had never heard of it...ran across an American giving a walking tour who told us that we had walked by it three times! Yes! It is that small and hard to find! I didn't find the stairs a difficult walk at...

I've visited Buddhist temples and shrines in Japan but this was a first for my family, and I had to coax them up the stairs. Even so, everyone wasn't sure what to expect.
Finding the stairs is a little difficult as others have noted, but there was a clear (but small) sign saying Tin How Temple over the stairs.
I'd...

Not to repeat everything everyone else has said.....
1) hard to find entrance (see photo of sign)
2) three flights of stairs

4) no photos allowed inside
5) nice small temple (nothing that would get anyone to excited), though the light fixtures are attractive
6) small "donation" required

Beautiful temple on Waverly Place. Oldest Chinese Temple in US - founded in 1852. Tin How is the goddess of heaven and sea. Three flights of stairs to climb to see inside of temple.

We found this fairly easily, though you wouldn't guess there was a temple by the modest marking on the front door. After looking for the temple for awhile, we finally found the temple....impress with the temple which was now at 104 years old....its really impressive to be able to pray here.....love the feeling of relieve after praying......

After spending about 40 minutes in Chinatown trying to locate the small temple and asking all the locals, which had never heard of it...ran across an American giving a walking tour who told us that we had walked by it three times! Yes! It is that small and hard to find! I didn't find the stairs a difficult walk at...


More  



I've visited Buddhist temples and shrines in Japan but this was a first for my family, and I had to coax them up the stairs. Even so, everyone wasn't sure what to expect.
Finding the stairs is a little difficult as others have noted, but there was a clear (but small) sign saying Tin How Temple over the stairs.
I'd...


More  



Not to repeat everything everyone else has said.....
1) hard to find entrance (see photo of sign)

4) no photos allowed inside
5) nice small temple (nothing that would get anyone to excited), though the light fixtures are attractive
6) small "donation" required

Beautiful temple on Waverly Place. Oldest Chinese Temple in US - founded in 1852. Tin How is the goddess of heaven and sea. Three flights of stairs to climb to see inside of temple.

We found this fairly easily, though you wouldn't guess there was a temple by the modest marking on the front door. After walking up to the fourth floor and reading several reminders to tourists and tour guides we fully expected to be fairly shunned upon arrival. Upon reaching the temple we found a quiet splendor in bold red and tarnished...

title: Embarcadero Center Cinema, San Francisco
address: One Embarcadero Center Promenade Level, San Francisco, CA 94111
review_list:
After the remodel, the movie going experience got super charged. The roomy seats recline like a lazy boy - nothing else like it in SF. Also love that they serve kettle corn. This film geek want to rent it out for a party - yes, it's that good

This cinema depends largely on which theater you're visiting. My favorite is the ultra small theater with electric reclining chairs. But the larger cinemas with more traditional chairs are rather uncomfortable. Staff at the Embarcadero cinema are inconsistent. I've had rude and counters and I've had very polite encounters. As a Landmark Cinema you'll find the best independent films here.

We have gone to see movies several times at the Landmark Theater (also known as the Embarcadero Center Theater.)
There are seven theaters. They play recent releases and also foreign and special event films. For example, we have gone there to watch the Academy Award nominee short films. Four of the seven theaters have luxury style stadium seating.
There is...


More  



My husband has a conference he attends in SF every year. We always build in a day or two at a hotel near the Embarcadero Center Cinema so we can have our own mini film festival. This place shows real movies. Some of their theaters have lazy-boy style seating that makes for sublime comfort (check with the on site concierge)....


More  



Renovated theater, one of the Landmark groups best for foreign and indie films. Now has reserved seating, a wine and beer bar, and snack food options like veggie rolls and empanadas. On the upper level of the first center. You can use the on site kiosk to buy your reserved seats. Get here early to find the best seats or...

title: Lake Merced, San Francisco
review_list:
We enjoyed a nice walk by Lake Merced in San Francisco. The views were very nice. There is areas for picnics as well. There is also a golf course nearby.
On this trip it was the end of January on a nice sunny day.
It is large 614 acre park. The park is also popular for boating, bike riding, and...


More  



I use the lake for jogging. It is peaceful and the scenery keeps me jogging until I finish running around the lake. You'll see high schoolers rowing in the lake, people golfing, and the landmark Dirty Harry shooting range. It's also near the beach which makes its location even more enjoyable.

One of my favorite places to walk in this part of SF. The lake is ringed by high rise buildings and is actually quite urban, but as you gaze toward the towering trees, the scree of birds in your ears, the City melts away. Enjoy!

We love to walk here in the mornings - a great amenity for the locals. The birds are a joy to see and there are always a few people fishing. Not sure if they ever catch anything as the water looks a bit murky but fishing is more about contemplation anyway! On Thanksgiving morning we were excited to see a...


More  



Spectacular vistas, great golf course. Unfortunately it was too foggy to see the course, The clubhouse was fantastic, wish we could stay longer!

title: Eden Fine Art, San Francisco
review_list:
Great works of art and great knowledgable people. It was a pleasure to find this gallery. I will definitely be back every time I visit SF.

We enjoyed going to Eden Galley in San Francisco The colorful art whimsical art is so fun to see. The art gallery specializes in international art. They have art, sculptures and photographs from leading artists for sale at the gallery.

title: Lotta's Fountain, San Francisco
address: Coner of Geary-Market and Kearny Streets, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
There's not a whole lot to this memorial to those killed in the great earthquake and fire of 1906. This is the spot where survivors used to gather every year to mark the anniversary of one of the greatest natural disasters in U.S. history. This part of the city was obliterated. The fountain was commissioned by Lotta Crabtree as a...


More  



We took the hop on / off bus and we heard about the importance of this statue but we didn’t get off. We learned it had withstood fires, earthquakes and still remains today thus it is relished by the people of San Francisco and signifies hope and endurance.
However, upon closer inspection, it’s really not that pleasing to the eye....


More  



We whizzed past this on the Big Bus tour. Lotta's Fountain is regarded as one of the oldest surviving monuments in the city. Donated in 1875 and it survived the earthquake of 1906.

This fountain known as Lotta's Fountain is one of the oldest standing landmarks in San Francisco that has withstood earthquakes and time but was recently refurbished as it had been left unkept for years. If you are walking down Market Street you won't miss it...

A walk down Market Street from the trolley car turn around to the bay will take history lovers past some nice landmarks; one of them is Lotta's Fountain. I was enchanted by this structure. Unfortunately, it sits at a very busy intersection, making it difficult to photograph. Those who appreciate history will want to pause here.

My wife and I was shown Lotta's Fountain during an architectural tour of San Francisco that we took. Lotta's Fountain is the oldest surviving monument in San Francisco & was donated by singer/dancer Charlotte Mignon Lotta Crabtree in 1875. After the earthquake in 1906, the fountain was one of the few remaining structures on Market Street & became a central...


More  



I just accidentally found this by walking around San Francisco at night. There isn't much information around it to really tell you what this or why it's relevant. But you can tell it is old and is not an eye-sore. But definitely don't skip anything just to see this.

It is a simple fountain that is not hard to find, and you walk right past it if you are exploring San Francisco's downtown. It isn't the fountain that is import, in fact, it really isn't all that pretty, but its history is so very very important to San Francisco. You can read all about that here: http://www.artandarchitecture-sf.com/financial-district-san-francisco-december-13-2011.html

This statue has lots of history, but from a strictly aesthetic perspective, it is just ok. If you don't see it when you are in town, you won't be missing anything special.
I have seen the hop on-hop off busses go by the statue and tell the history (which is quaint), but I like other statues (Banker's Heart; Mechanics Monument)...


More  



This cast iron fountain was constructed in San Francisco prior to 1875 and was the meeting point for victims of the April 18, 1906 earthquake that demolished the city from the earth's rage underneath and from atop, also, the resulting fire. It was here that Luisa Tetrazzini, entertained San Francisco's opera lovers on Christmas eve, 1910. Every year on April...


More

title: Portsmouth Square, San Francisco
address: 50 Walter U Lum Pl, b/t Clay St & Washington St in Chinatown, San Francisco, CA 94108
review_list:
If you are looking for a place to rest or relax, this would not be it. Right between a big hotel and Chinatown, this park is always filled with people carrying on animated conversations or playing chess and checkers and sometimes Mahjong, a Chinese favorite table game using ivory tiles. There is a tots' playground so there would lots of...


More  



This was the closest thing we saw in Chinatown that resembled life in China. Having lived in China for four years now we can say it felt like being home for my wife. It reminded me of a typical day as we walk from our apartment complex. There the elderly ladies do a dance with music and each part of...


More  



Portsmouth Square was the only place where we could rest our feet after walking for hours on Chinatown. The place was buzzing with action, and filled with eldery citizens playing mahjong and cards. This isn't a quiet park where you can close your eyes and day-dream, there is a lot of commotion going on.

It has several statues/monuments to look at. An active area with people dancing and singing. Part of Chinatown, so if in the area, worth a quick checkout

While staying in the Hilton Financial District in SF, we frequently walked through this park adjacent to the hotel. It was fascinating to see the Chinese people gathered here all through the day. In the morning there were groups of men and women doing Tai Chi. During the day groups of men were intently playing cards, women talking. At night...


More  



For me - this is the heart of San Francisco Chinatown. It feels like a country within the city. We were here around 6-7 pm in January. The atmosphere in the square was amazing: music playing, people dancing in one part of the square; people playing cards in another part of it. It was the closest to being in China...


More  



For a place with so much history associated with it, I was under the impression that it should be a pleasant place to visit. Yes, it's fairly interesting with several monuments erected here in honour of this event or that person. And yes, there were the ubiquitous groups of elderly folks sharing a game of mahjong or cards. Maybe it...


More  



We enjoy going to Portsmouth Square in the Chinatown Area of San Francisco. It is known as the heart of Chinatown. There is a playground here; people gather; some play mahjong.
The square is rich with history. There is a statue for writer Robert Louis Stevenson, who spent many hours at this park.
Portsmouth Square was also the site of...


More

title: Crocker Galleria, San Francisco
address: 50 Post St, b/t Lick Pl & Kearny St, Financial District, San Francisco, CA 94104
review_list:
I work near here - looking out of my office window upon it right now...
One block long - connects Post to Sutter - and narrow. Mixture of retail at varying price points, couple of service firms, and sort of a food-court feel to the top floor.
Lunchtime is financial district wage-slaves using the food-court. The retailers suffer a high...


More  



This is a wonderful building but i found it just far to busy. The main problem was that the walkways that are around the central opening are fairly narrow plus most of the shops have tables and chairs on these walkways. As we had a wheelchair with us this made it particularly difficult to get round. There is a roof...


More  



At Crocker Galleria there is a weekly Farmer's Market on Thursday; twice a week in the summer.
We have also had lunch here. There are various small places to have lunch; there is also cupcakes, pastries, etc. There are some stores; on our recent visit some were selling San Francisco Giants items as they are in the 2014 World Series....


More  



The Crocker Galleria was right next to our hotel, but we only realised this on the last day of our stay. Each time we left the Galleria Park Hotel we had turned left, the Crocker Galleria was to the right as you leave the hotel. If you are staying at the Galleria Park Hotel you can also enter the Crocker...


More  



Mainly we came here for something to eat. Maybe it was the time of day but it was very busy, even too busy to walk properly. The mall has a number of quaint shops that give it a more local character.

When we stopped by there was a little farmer's market, where you'd never expect to find one. Amazing architecture and nice selection of shops to find gifts for everyone back home.

Sparse offerings of quick-ish food. Not open weekends or evenings. Obviously intended for those working in surrounding buildings.

Crocker Galleria is a small shopping center with few shops and amenities located near Union Square. The selection of stores is scarce. Most of the establishments in the mall close early in the evenings and stay closed during the weekends.

A new 3 sotry mall, built for lunch-time shopping. Once a week, farmer's market occupies the firs floor.
Food is average, shops are simialr to what you can find in an area.

title: Yerba Buena Ice Skating & Bowling Center, San Francisco
review_list:
Fabulous ice rink, with a beautiful glass panel allowing loads of natural light, in a great location.
Their schedule is excellent too.
On the other hand, out of the 4 times I have been there so far, on 3 occasions, Dealing with 3 different cashiers, I thought the customer service was absolutely DREADFUL.
On 1 specific occasion, on a 3...


More  



In an effort to find late night entertainment we headed to the Yerba Buena Bowling Center. It turns out it was disco bowling night which really means let's increase our prices to almost double what normal day time bowling costs. For the money we paid I didn't feel like we got enough. The disco bowling includes lights and music videos....


More  



I love this ice rink! It's beautiful, full of light, and very friendly people. The ice is always amazing and for the first time I attended the coffee club session for 18 and over in the am. They had free donuts, coffee and a free group lesson to whomever wanted to participate. Of course I did. I always look forward...


More  



Close to the Metreon and the Moscone Convention Center, Yerba Buena Ice Skating Center is a fun place to go ice skating indoors when in San Francisco. I have enjoyed the center.

Yerba Buena center is the perfect place to spend a day with kids! There's an ice skating rink, bowling alley, creativity museum, enclosed carousel, outdoor cafe and fabulous play area. It's got more than enough to do in a day, or a weekend, and is clean and well maintained. Lots of fun for kids and grown-ups alike!

I went skating at Yerba Buena with my co-workers last December. The rink is sizeable and the skates are standard. We made sure to go mid-afternoon so the space wasn't crowded and we were free to stumble our way across the ice. The staff seemed bored but helped us when needed.
If you're looking for standard, no-frills ice skating then...


More  



While strolling through the Verba Buena Gardens park, my grandson and I ran across this ice skating arena. He asked to go skating so checked it out. We were there at open skating time. Admission was $10 and skate rental $3. What a bargain. The area was well managed, clean and very reasonable.

title: The Winery SF, San Francisco
address: 200 California Avenue, Building 180 North, San Francisco, CA 94130
review_list:
We visited Treasure Island for the Flea Market and saw the sign for tasting. After enjoying our time visiting with local artists and vendors we stopped in. We tasted all of their wines ($10 for 4 standard wine tastings, $15 for 4 premium wines), most were good. We bought a couple of bottles and left saying we would return and...


More  



It is located on Treasure Island in San Francisco Bay. The island is man-made, constructed 1936-37 for the 1939 Golden Gate International Exposition. The Winery SF tasting room is upstairs overlooking their very impressive "cellar." There is a great deal of memorabilia from the building's past as part of the Pan Am Clipper terminal (1937-41) and is very near Clipper...


More  



Different atmosphere. $10 for 4 wine flight of local wines was a fair price. Didnt have wines that suited my taste but for $10 the experience was still fun and cheap.

So much closer than Napa, and without all the pretense! We tasted all of their wines ($10 for 4 standard wine tastings, $15 for 4 premium wines), most were pretty good. The server did admit that the bottle of bubbly was opened the previous day and had lost its fizz. Not sure why she didn't open another bottle for us...


More  



Hosted a corporate dinner here - staff were all lovely and helpful in getting the set-up exactly as we needed. Note to event managers: they contract outside caterers. Our catered food was very bland (I wish I could tell you which one we went with), but we were told AFTER our event, that there are a few caterers that they...


More  



It was great to have the opportunity to taste wine in a unique venue, but the great tasting room employees. Christian was informative and professional. We left with an unplanned case of wine :-) and we'll be back!

The server did admit that the bottle of bubbly was opened the previous day and had lost its fizz. Not sure why she didn't open another bottle for us...


More  



Hosted a corporate dinner here - staff were all lovely and helpful in getting the set-up exactly as we needed. Note to event managers: they contract outside caterers. Our catered food was very bland (I wish I could tell you which one we went with), but we were told AFTER our event, that there are a few caterers that they...


More  



It was great to have the opportunity to taste wine in a unique venue, but the great tasting room employees. Christian was informative and professional. We left with an unplanned case of wine :-) and we'll be back!

title: Asia Society and Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
I love the art of Asia and found this place really good. the displays were great and the lighting was nice. clean facility with a lot to view!

Felt very calm, spacious, beautifully arranged. In our group are travelers who've been to India a lot and have an interest in Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Islam. We were all happy we got the free portable audio guides. Learned a lot. Lovely lunch in the Asian cafeteria.

title: Sea Cliff, San Francisco
review_list:
See how the rich live in the foggy part of San Francisco. Lovely homes and views are terrific when the sun shines here, which is not very often!

We stumbled upon this neighborhood while trying to get to Land's End. The homes are nice and there is a nice view (if you can catch a glimpse of it in between the houses) of the Golden Gate Bridge. If I remember correctly, the streets are paved with bricks or cobble stones. We went in June and I am writing...


More  



very exclusive neighborhood with multi million dollar homes. golf course, Legion of Honor (museum) (fee except for once a month on first Tuesday). Interesting architecture.

We visited Seacliff because our family are huge Robin Williams admirers. His home is here. We went just so we could say we walked past his home.

I always like to think of Sea Cliff's former Victorian Edifice, framed by lightning, looking foreboding. Today it's a nice place to eat and reminisce about its former proximity to the Musee Mechanique and ice skating - yes - rink.

title: Octagon House, San Francisco
address: 2645 Gough Street, At Union Street, San Francisco, CA 94123-4402
review_list:
This is a really beautiful house from the outside. Situated on Gough Street between Union and Green Streets, near a lovely little park. The only problem is that it has (as an understatement) very limited opening hours. From memory I think it is the second Sunday of every month, except of course, if that Sunday butts up against a public...


More  



friends and I stopped, only to find the place closed. has an interesting look from the outside. check beforehand to see if opened.

There is nothing quite so invigorating as a challenge, and a house museum that is open very
limited hours is just that to those who visit historic houses.
The small octagonal building has been significantly altered inside to suit the purposes of the Colonial Dames.
The volunteers are plesant, enthusiastic and informed. the collection is the result of donations although...


More  



Open rarely, but go if you can. Tip: if the scheduled opening coincides with (or is close to) a holiday, the house may well not open in my experience, so call ahead to make sure. Well worth the visit to see this uniquely shaped house, although there is little inside of the original. But the collection to do with the...


More  



My grandfather's construction company was hired in the early 1950's to renovate the building which was empty at the time. During construction, his crew found a time capsule in the wall. It contained a letter about the times, the effect of the Gold Rush, etc. among other items. That, and the beautiful neighborhood this house is in, near a fine...


More  



Colonial Dames bought the house, restored it with some changes, and give the tours. Their interest and excitement in our country and history is contagious and you find yourself wanting to know more and visiting all their other properties.

title: Vermont Street, San Francisco
address: Between 20th Street and 22nd Street, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Are you kidding? I've lived in the San Francisco Bay Area for more than 25 years and I've never seen Vermont Street until today. This is truly a utilitarian crooked street, and it's just as crooked as Lombard Street. It doesn't have the beautiful flowers and the pretentious homes, but it is definitely worth going well out of your way...


More  



Lombard gets all the attention and with the flowers and brick it is much prettier . However Vermont is great since you don't have to deal with bumper to bumper traffic or pedestrians standing in the middle of the road .
If you are coming into the city along 101 (NB) it's very simple . There is a Vermont Street...


More  



I took some relatives on a first time visit and did the insider city tour by car and had read that Lombard is not actually the steepest or crookedest street in the City - so headed there and it was blast! Let's you see lots of the City and we followed with Lombard which we mocked all the way down!

There is always going to be debate whether Lombard (more turns) or Vermont (steeper turns - more turns per meter) is the most crooked street in San Francisco ... for now, I would say you do not need to make a decision. Vermont Street is a residential street in Potrero Hill...nice, but probably not worth the visit unless you really...


More  



Worthwhile going to just to say that you were there. It was a little confusing getting there, but once there it's a quick (not too quick, it's steep and very windy) trip.
Kinda a long run for a short slide, but still glad I went.
BTW, it is definitely more crooked than Lombard Street. No question.

Despite Lombard Street's claim evidence suggests that this street is genuinely the crookedest street in the world. As most people believe the tourism board's mistaken claim that Lombard Street is the crookedest street in the world, Vermont Street is absolutely free from tourists! Vermont Street is accessible using the number 19 bus from Eighth Street in downtown San Francisco.

A quiet gem hidden in a sunny neighborhood of San Francisco. Nice to walk around, fun to drive, you can ride bicycle downhill. SF Muni bus 19 stops a block away, and also goes to Civic Center Bart train station.

It was Such an Experience to Finally go down San Franciscos Crookedest Street! I know its hard to believe that Vermont Street is more Crooked than Lombard but it really is! Its funny to because man of the locals in San Francisco do not even know that Vermont Street even Exists! But Trust Me It Does. With One Less Turn...


More

title: 111 Minna Gallery, San Francisco
review_list:
Checking it for an upcoming reception we are hosting. Great space and great art Bartenders very friendly and make great drinks. Love they have Tiger Beer! Will be a great place for a party.

I attended a professional event at 111 Minna was was very pleased with the experience. The space is both roomy and intimate. We had a modestly private area for the food for our group. It was good finger food.
The art was a nice diversion.
All in all, a great setting!

A nice place to host parties and wind down with friends. The space is great and in a good location, would recommend for events.

And a top art gallery to make it even better. Try the pastries, they are fresh and exquisite. Went there for a meeting and loved. Plus one of the fastest WiFi connections around.

Lovely venue - excellent staff for a corporate event we had recently. Spot on, food was great, service was great.

small catholic church worth a viewing for fans of old churches. has a nice look from the street view. if in the area,worth checking out.

title: Sacramento Street, San Francisco
address: Between Broderick and Spruce Street, Presidio Heights, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Close to the Market street, a lot of shops and art. Also a lot of dirty and smelly homeless people around.

If you want to shop for home furnishings and antiques, bring lots of money and shop to your heart's content. Definitely a different experience in the city.

This is an area known for unique shops relating to home furnishings, hardware as well as art and antiques. You will also find quaint or avant garde clothing shops all rather expensive.

Little unique shops. Locals shop and stroller these parts. Upscale whatever. If you're looking for something bring lots of $. Consignment stores (bka: thrift shops) abound. Not a mom & pop place but mani-peti...

title: Old United States Mint, San Francisco
address: 88 5th St, Mint Plaza, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Interesting old building in a San Francisco / American landmark. But today the building is a wasted opportunity. Locals and tourists alike would love to go in and see this very important historical building, but it's not open to the public.

The old Mint now stands empty, a sad reminder of how some of this cities historic landmarks can be ignored. This building saved SF after the quake of 1906, being the repository of all the bullion in town, and reports of SF being ruined were quelled by men working here at the time.

This event happens annually the first week of December. It is a wonderful trip into the past with a Holiday flair and elegant food service. You can watch for it next year or go to the SF History Museum website and signup for their notices: http://www.sfhistory.org/events/holiday-tea-at-the-old-mint
On Wednesday, December 3, we had afternoon tea (seatings are at noon and 3:00...
