Behind the scenes tour of a storied building. Steeped in history of the Gold Rush, the 1906 earthquake and fire, etc. The Granite Lady is being - gradually - turned into a top of the line museum and interpretive center. Docent-led tour is chock-full of interesting facts.

This is a must see sight for visitors to California. It is full of California and San Francisco history. A lot of information on American money and California Gold Rush circa 1849. Information on the 1906 Fire which destroyed most of San Francisco. A great place for the family. Well worth the trip.

San Francisco is a major destination for conferences and a huge draw as a great location. Entertaining corporate clients in a unique , interesting yet econmical and practical venue can be a challenge. The Old Mint known as The Granite Lady is an historic facility with modren refurbishments. Spacious, open and ideal for extensive or minimal staging what ever the...


More  



The Old Mint has a history that few buildings in San Francisco can claim. It survived the 1906 earthquake. Tours of the old mint require a reservation and all visits are guided by a volunteer docent. The museum that used to be on the Mint’s main floor has been removed and there is a fund raising effort underway to accumulate...


More  



One of the things that I love about San Francisco is its buildings. This is another example of what makes the city so unique. Its sad to hear that our nation's coins are no longer minted here, but I guess thats progress, or so we hope.

title: Old United States Mint, San Francisco
address: 88 5th St, Mint Plaza, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Interesting old building in a San Francisco / American landmark. But today the building is a wasted opportunity. Locals and tourists alike would love to go in and see this very important historical building, but it's not open to the public.

The old Mint now stands empty, a sad reminder of how some of this cities historic landmarks can be ignored. This building saved SF after the quake of 1906, being the repository of all the bullion in town, and reports of SF being ruined were quelled by men working here at the time.

This event happens annually the first week of December. It is a wonderful trip into the past with a Holiday flair and elegant food service. You can watch for it next year or go to the SF History Museum website and signup for their notices: http://www.sfhistory.org/events/holiday-tea-at-the-old-mint

title: Presidio Theatre, San Francisco
review_list:
I love independent theatres like this, and when I'm on vacation, finding new spots like these are what I love to do. It's quaint, comfortable, and close to many delicious restaurants and nightlife spots to stop in before or after catching a film. Support places like these! We need more of them!

Its not your traditional 300+ seats theatre,, we are talking about 20-30 seats, small room, I attended the movie "Fury" there, the screen and sound are great, pop corn and pop were not that amazing,
for $11 an evening, its ok and walking distance from where i stayed.

title: Redwood Ramblers, San Francisco
review_list:
My husband and I were only in the San Francisco area for 2 days and we're so glad we booked the tour! First off I want to thank Pierre for being so incredibly flexible and generous. When weather threatened the date we booked, we were able to work out a different date, and he even picked us up from the...


More  



Pierre was a terrific host and guide. Picked us up at our AirB&B on time. Was both attentive and informative throughout the trip up and down Mt. Tam. Even lent his walking "sticks" on the long down hill. The walk was invigorating but not overly challenging. Beautiful views and a learning experience rolled into to one trip.
Best of all...


More  



We went to San Francisco for our honeymoon, and we are so glad we decided to book tours with Redwood Ramblers. First, the tours are very well-planned; we took two and it was obvious that our guide, Pierre, knew the trails and thoughtfully chose the best routes/trails. Our first tour-Bridge Bay and Headlands took us over the bridge to a...


More  



Had great fun hiking with Pierre! He was knowledgeable, thoughtful and very easy going. The views were amazing along the way. I definitely will do it again next time I visit San Francisco!

Pierre is exceptionally knowledgable, friendly, and just an overall awesome human being. Our hike around the Rodeo Beach and Point Bonita Lighthouse area was informative, and I was actually kind of sad it wasn't a bit longer. A spectacular way to get the lay of the land for visitors, and an even better way to decompress after a long work...


More  



One of our best San Francisco experiences. Away from the tourist traps and the typical bus tours. Incredible nature hike with vistas of the Pacific ocean, the city in light and fog, majestic Redwood tree groves. A really peaceful and also very easy day since our guide took care of all of the details.

The Coastal Headlands hike was terrific. Great views of the Golden Gate Bridge, the Point Bonita Lighthouse and the Marine Sanctuary. It was nice to get out of the city and see just how beautiful San Francisco is.

We only had one day away from a grueling work week in the Bay Area. I was hoping that a guided hike might be available for all of us. The tour leader took care of all the particulars and it was a truly perfect day. Lunch was arranged it an authentic San Francisco Italian neighborhood deli. We had an incredible...


More  



Some mates and I, in San Francisco, recently, decided that we’d like to see the city from a different perspective. We rang Redwood Ramblers, and they picked us up from our hotel and then took us on an unbelievable urban/country bushwalk. They started us on the northern edge of town in the Marina Green, led us across the Golden Gate...


More  



it was an awesome hiking experience today with RedWood ramblers! Pierre is very knowledgeable and professional. I recommend this for any one who likes hiking. and for those who don't hike, you are missing a lot ;)... Eslam ElNakib, Egypt

title: Rrazz Room, San Francisco
address: Hotel Nikko, 222 Mason, San Francisco, CA 94102
review_list:
I eagerly looked forward to the Rrazz Room's move to 1000 Van Ness (a classic building on old Auto Row in SF) and the opening night performance of Patti Lupone. While the venue itself on the mezzanine level was beautiful the service was atrocious. Let's count the ways. (1) There are two adjoining stairways from the ground to mezzanine level....


More  



Buried deep within the Hotel Nikko is San Francisco's premier jazz and cabaret space. You will find everything you expect - good sightlines, good sound, overpriced drinks, great entertainment

Great jazz/blues in an intimate environment. However, they are moving 5 blocks away to the old Cadilac building on Van Ness.

First time in San Fran and we wanted to listen to some classic Jazz, we got there about 20 min late the music was great and the energy in there is fantastic also the venue is very classy its in a actual hotel. The one thing that was not good was food it was really pricy and the mains where...


More  



An intimate spot to enjoy cabaret singers and more. The drinks are generous and well-prepared (two-drink minimum at the show), and there's a nice seletion of appetizers and small meals, so getting there a bit early before the show gets you good seating and eating. The welcome is always charming and efficient, and the wait staff very pleasant and does...


More  



Smaller venue with all seats really good. Sound was super! Two drink minimum but they bring one at a time so ice doesn't melt. Reasonable prices and snack/dessert menu available. We had a great time.

This is an authentic nightclub that features music--mostly Jazz and The American Songbook tunes--good food, 2-drink minimum, but they are nice about it! The location is great--1 block from the Powell St. Bart Stn. in the Hotel Nikko. I go to Goldstar.com to find out who is featured.
I have never had a bad experience there, and I often bring...


More  



First, the negative - we had to wait in line for a very long time to get in and get seated. When I bought the tickets for the show (in advance), I was instructed to arrive no later than 7:15 pm to be seated for a 7:30 pm show. It's a very small venue and thus I was surprised about...


More  



So glad the SF club tradition is going forward at the Rrazz Room! Many great name acts all the time, including the local "Bud E Luv" band on occasion! Much fun, and the Hotel Nikko is easy to get to.

We listened to the Tommy Igoe band, and they were great! The Rrazz Room is located in the Hotel Nikko. It is a small venue. Great atmosphere, two drink minimum, and we were not blown out of the room by the sound system.

review_list:

More  



Amazing atmosphere, we really loved chilling out listening to great music drinking $2 beer! I wish every city had a bar like this.

small crowded club but everyone was so enthusiastic. Music was great and watching the dancers was a show in itself. Real neighborhood type place

So nice place to have a beer :-) They have great stuff!!! Especially on Wednesday, there us a live music, if you are into swing dance, you should not miss here :-)

One reason and one reason alone... Beatropolis plays there. Or played there.
I hate Soju man. And it is tight a tight squeeze. I think you end up here because you like whatever band is playing. Beatro got me.
However, I just don't fit in, I get it now, and that's cool. I don't like when people actually consider what...

title: Boom Boom Room, San Francisco
address: 1601 Fillmore St. at Geary Blvd., Western Addition, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Apparently they don't let bags in.. Shame I traveled from Miami to see some good local bands, but these guys are too selective for my type of blood.. Mr. Hooker must be turning in his grave..

Just happen to drop in here (via a taxi - definitely) and caught a UK reggae band debut in SF. Black Slate no less - had a great time! The venue is OK and their sound engineers seem to have it set up right - drinks are reasonably priced too.

husband and i went here based on the reviews. $15 cover (not bad for S.F.); just a hole in the wall live music joint: band was good ;singer fair. but the worst part is that the young crowd was standing around blocking view of stage for those who were seated . people weren't there to LISTEN to music...it was more...


More  



I am writing a mixed review because I was so excited to surprise my husband by taking him on our last night in San Fran to a jazz club where I thought I was going to see a blues/jazz band from New Orleans which was advertised on their site. I purchased the tickets for a '9:30' show and it was...


More  



I went there without knowing anything about the place. The live music was great. The venue really has something special. Somenight end crazy some others less i guess but the night i spent there was unforgettable.

There is something going on most nights at the Boom Boom Room and it's nearly always awesome. A chance to get up close and personal with live music in a safe and special environment.
I saw two bands there whilst I was in SF and the ambience and sound was excellent on both occasions. Admission prices vary, but beer is...


More  



My boyfriend & I want to hear a Funk fusion band. We got there at 9 pm, but there was a rap band as the opening band. UGH! We ended up going down the street to a Brazillion restaurant with a Jazz band. Which was a great detour! We went back to Boom Boom Room at midnight and had a...


More  



Once again I visited San Fran's Boom Boom Room not knowing what to expect and was blown away by the great music. Not being a local or even from the USA, many of the performers were unknown to me but I took a gamble and had a fantastic night out out with top quality music and dancing. It's crowded, loud...


More  



This place is open until 2:00 am and serves alcohol until 2:00 am. The staff are wonderful, including the bouncer. Great, friendly people who enjoy the company of others. I visited there on a Sunday night with a friend and colleague and we enjoyed good music for several hours, and many drinks. I would most certainly return again with more...


More  



We had a blast at the Boom Boom Room. Parking is close and cheap. Friendly eager servers, nice environment. Get there before 9 pm for a good comfy seat.

title: Asian Art Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
The former main library was magically transformed into the premiere Asian Art Museum in the USA. Beautiful architecture of a by-gone era. Beautiful galleries house the best in asian art

All you can eyeball. So. Many. Asian. Arts. If you are fond of a particular kind of Asian art, you will find it here. That is a problem if you can call it such. Just a deluge of catalog.

I have been here once, my friend is a member so I got to see some of the displays during lunch. They also have a great restaurant inside. the restaurant is a little $$$ but the museum is wonderful. The building itself is a work of art. Sometimes they have Thursday after hours special for $5.00 entry.

If you like Asian Art this is the place for you. Three floors of high quality exhibits from all over Asia and different epochs. Well displayed. Allow several hours, maybe breaking it up with a cup of tea in the cafeteria (really good blank tea)

Went to see the special exhibition surrounding the influence of Japanese art and the impressionists (Monet, Van Gogh etc.). It was a well presented exhibition and to see the multiple masterpieces was inspiring. Unfortunately I did not have any time to visit the permanent exhibitions, but would love to on my next visit.

Alcatraz was an awesome island to see, and the audio tour was informative. The hop on hop off idea is great and very convenient, however if you hop off for anything more than just photo opportunities (such as the asian art museum), you'll find yourself with many only a little time to catch one more bus and see one more...


More  



If you are already in Chinatown, you can get here very easily on foot. You only need about 30 minutes to tour this site. There is a limited amount of Chinese artwork, with some of it for sale. There are prints at very reasonable prices.
The decor inside is more modern than most of Chinatown. The staff were very friendly...


More  



In addition to its 'permanent' collection, this museum puts together exhibitions that go well beyond art to encompass history and culture. An example of this is the not to miss exhibition on how the opening of Japan resulted in influencing the Art Nouveau and Impressionist movements and how women contributed

The building itself is just beautiful. Marble stairs and amazing ceilings. The entire place is laid out well with interesting points around every corner.

I've been to the Asian Art Museum many times for events. This was my first time for a special exhibit. "Looking East" examines the influence that Japanese art had on European and American artists in the 19th century. I was first intrigued by this idea when visiting Monet's home in France and saw his collection of wood block prints. "Looking...


More

title: Isla Studio Photography Classes, San Francisco
review_list:
The 3 hour intro to photography class was just what I needed to get me started on using a DSLR camera. I will no longer have to shoot in Auto!!! The instructor, Michael, did a wonderful job with teaching and keeping the class informative and fun. I have taken other photography classes before but for some reason this class really...


More  



We went to the beginners photography class not really knowing what to expect, but ended up learning a ton about our cameras! Michael was a great teacher and we would highly recommend the class to anyone looking at getting a bit more into photography!!

I learned a lot by taking this class. now i have started my own business as a event photographer after taking this class. staff was really helpful.

I took the 3 hour beginner photography workshop today and highly recommend it. It covered the basics you would need to know as a beginner or amateur photographer. I always felt intimidated by those mysterious knobs and buttons on my new camera, but now feel much more comfortable with my camera. I still have a lot to learn, but now...


More  



I took the beginning photography class to really learn how to use my DSLR not in Auto mode. It was a very informative class, fun too. I am excited to practice what I learned. Highly recommend class to anyone looking to improve their photography and get more out of their camera!

I had two classes with Isla Studio
Very knowledgeable instructors, a lot of useful information
Thank you

I had to reschedule my class that I already booked, and they were so understanding! I was able to reschedule it with no problem at all, which was awesome.
The class was informative, easy to understand, and fun! Michael was funny and was very approachable with answers to questions. I feel like my camera isn't a mystery anymore and I...


More  



Bought the combo deal (3hr class+photo walk) for $180 ($90 each). Dragged the hubby with me. Hubby is an experienced photographer but he learned three new things, such as a better understanding of aperture & shutter speed.
Great intro class to digital photography using the MANUAL feature! Michael is a great teacher! Explained the basics (aperture, shutter speed, exposure, and...

The beginner class was great. I am SO happy to actually know how to use my camera and I will not be using "AUTO" anymore. Can't wait to do the photo walk!

I have done the photo walk and the beginner classes and they were both very informative and fun. The photo walk was down by the Golden Gate bridge getting low light shots and talking about composition. address: 201 Third Street, Ste. 900, lower level, Powell and Market Sts., Union Sq., San Francisco, CA
review_list:
I have been coming for 20 years to San Francisco for conventions here. Unfortunately, despite the beautiful center, the area around the center for at least a mile is covered with thousands of drugged out panhandlers who are aggressive with passersby all hours of the day and night. I saw some attack children and adults and police are powerless to...


More  



Down the stairs or escalators from street level, you'll find just about everything that's on in The City from these nice folks. Don't hesitate to ask as they'll probably have an answer for you. Lots of promotional material.
and maps, lots of them.
Enjoy! And Welcome to SF!

We have stopped by here, but more often visit the web site. It is a source of information for travelers to San Francisco Bay Area. It also has an events section to see some of the things across town that are going on. While there are other sources for this information; this web site generally does ok for major events...


More  



We were staying in the area and this was very helpful. I had a rough idea of what I wanted to do during my couple of days in the city, but they helped me refine my plans. Thanks for their help in making this a great trip.

title: The Mechanics Monument, San Francisco
address: Corner of Market, Bush and Battery Streets, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
We stopped to take a photo of the Mechanics Monument. It is on Market Street. It is a bronze sculpture done by Douglas Tilden. Be sure to view it from different locations to see the mastery in this sculpture.

Here is a nice little monument depicting the shoreline in the 50’s. I thought it was going to be a dumpy little place but it is actually quite clean and a lovely place to rest your feet after a day’s trek hitting all of the historical sites. This is a great park in a decent place and I didn’t see...


More  



This a bronze sculpture by Douglas Tilden located at Market, Bush and Battery Streets. It seems to have been spruced up recently and originally celebrated the Union Ironworks.

Those who like historical tributes will want to pause at the Mechanics Monument. It's easy to stop during a walk down Market Street from the trolley car turn around to the bay where several landmarks and statues may be viewed.

I'm a local. Last time i walked past this monument there was garbage on it and around it. This negated any desire to stop ams read the inscription.

The Mechanics Monument used to be where homeless hung out, bike messengers rested and pigeons pooped.
No more. Not since the entire monument was re-landscaped and steam cleaned. And not since they posted a round-the-clock DPW employee in a yellow vest to clean tables, pick up trash and attract office works to this little park.
It seems to be working....


More  



This is just an average monument in the city.....what makes it special is the plaque just to the west of the statue (on the ground)....it depicts where the shoreline was back in the 1950's (about 4 blocks from where it is today).

address: 700 block of Steiner Street, San Francisco, CA
review_list:

title: San Francisco Flower Mart, San Francisco
review_list:
Many vendors in one place. Most all sell retail at a little higher price, but still a good value for pots, containers, baskets, ribbon, flowers, tools and all supplies to make floral arrangements.

For anyone that loves crafting or has a child in a floral class this is a wonderful place to shop. The prices are fair and there is so much to see. they have so many options for live and cut plants. If you need it I am sure they have it. I highly recommend stopping in if you are going...

Visiting a friend, we went to the flower market early in the morning. Of course there was the traditional fog and cool air but it started to get nicer as the morning wore on. We had a petit dejeuner at the corner cafe and headed in to look for flowers for a wedding. What a delight of smells and colors!...


More  



Loads of vendors with every flower imaginable. Orchids galore and every shade of cut flower you desire. Wreaths and succulents too. A sight to behold if you love flowers. Prices are reasonable too. Just love strolling through here.

title: Tank Hill, San Francisco
address: Twin Peaks Boulevard, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Good view, stunning really, but honestly this is just a pit stop on the way to twin peaks, so if you're heading up there, stop off here for a view without a crowd.

I have gone up to Tank Hill many times, and always bring out-of-town visitors here. title: Mount Sutro Forest, San Francisco
review_list:
This is a relaxing getaway from the hustle of a big city. If you want to get away from the noise of the city, this is the place to go. There are great trails and not many people. It's a place tourists don't flock to and seems more like a place only locals know about.

As soon as you enter, the sound of cars is replaced by birds and the sight of streets is replaced by tall Eucalyptus. I feel hesitant to post a review on this place because of how much I love it and I want to keep it to myself and the few others that already know about it. This forest is...


More  



While on the trail, one forgets that the park is located in the middle of the city. The trails were first built in the 1800's and rediscovered only a few decades ago. Some of the supporting walls built in 1886 can still be seen. The Mount Sutro Stewards offer guided hikes, although their website tends ot be hard to find....

review_list:
I was hoping to save this trip for my next visit. I had gone a couple of years ago and it was a neat little museum to explore. I had never heard of it until I saw something on it, I can't recall if it was a flyer or something else. So sad to know this place is closed. They...

Don't waste time looking for it, the museum is closed. No idea if there are plans to reopen. While in the neighborhood check out the beautiful Sir Francis Drake Hotel across the street and have an original milkshake at Lori´s Diner on the corner.

Took a beautiful 2 mile stroll on a gorgeous SF sunny day only to be told the museum no longer exists. What a shame! I was so looking forward to a little history lesson

This museum offers a broad range of history for the area. It is a great place to spend a couple of hours. And the $5 entry fee is a great deal. The location is very convenient, which helps make a full day of enjoying the area.

Why does the TripAdvisor rating jump from average to 'very' good I wonder? I'd rate this museum 'good'. We spent a happy hour exploring, and the 5 dollar admission is decent value. I think they could really raise their game by better presentation. Some exhibits had no accompanying explanations. A number of rooms had screens showing relevant information though in...

The Embarcadero Promenade is a waterfront walkway along the northern waterfront on the Bay side of The Embarcadero. We took a leisurely stroll at the weekend and it was more crowded than usual.

title: Treasure Island Wines, San Francisco
address: 995 9th Street, Building 201, Treasure Island, San Francisco, CA 94130
review_list:
Treasure Island has several wineries, this is a co-op of six or so different wineries. More

title: Eurasian Interiors Chinese Antiques Furniture, San Francisco
review_list:
A very nice selection of candles and other home scents. An added bonus of some lovely decorator pieces. Staff helpful.

For antique collection, you may find the true historical and valuable furnitures here. Nice taste, warm atmosphere and not pushy staff...

I just love this beautiful store in San Francisco!!!
The antiques there are the best quality and the service is so great that I can feel their enthusiasm to find every possible answer to my questions about Chinese furniture and fengsui.
Their lacquered cabinets are especially marvelous!
I strongly recommend everybody to go there and experience it!

Very high end Chinese antique furniture store in San Francisco. And the price is very reasonable compared to N.Y. even after adding the shipping price.
I bought a pair of antique chairs and a long sideboard. The owner took care of the shipping. I'm very happy and satisfied with this transaction.
For sure I will visit them again in next...

review_list:

This is a nice park across the Embarcadero from the Ferry Building. One interesting (Korean) statue but otherwise just a quiet park for sitting and enjoying lunch. Pictures tell it all.

title: Julius Kahn Playground, San Francisco
address: West Pacific Avenue & Maple, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Returned to San Francisco after many years. Delighted to find Julius Kahn Playground still a charming place! Great place for a walk! Dress in layers because can be foggy and cool and then turn sunny and warm.

Julius Kahn is a playground operated by the City of San Francisco but located on the outskirts of the Presidio, a unit of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area. The playground has play structures and swings one does not usually find and many of them are suitable for children with disabilities. My niece is blind and she loves it there....


More  



This park is a great place to go if you are in the Presidio and need a change of scenery. Keep in mind that it is geared for younger kids and there are a few really fun structures to play on other than the average playground. There is also a field if you bring a ball and a baseball pitch....

More  



Sutro Tower standing at 977 feet is near Clarendon Heights area in San Francisco. It rises from a hill between Twin Peaks and Mount Sutro. It is a prominent part of the city skyline. It is also a landmark.

title: San Francisco Helicopter Tours, San Francisco
review_list:
If you want to get the best views of the City of San Francisco, this has to be the way to go, I flew on Sunday Morning the 3rd of January 2016, the weather was not Ideal, however I had no more time left as I was Leaving that day. Despite that the flight was worth every cent. Leaving S.F....


More  



This was the first time we had decided to splash out and do a helicopter tour while on holiday and I am glad we did, what a fantastic experience and worth every penny. Very well organised from being picked up at our hotel and being brought back afterwards, however we did not take into account being caught in rush hour...


More  



The ride is quick so enjoy every second. Friendly staff and worth the money but it's not cheap. My only complaint was the back area is small (3 seats) and they put the 3 biggest guys all in the back 3 seats. The two people beside me were very fat and I didn't enjoy that. They should have put one...


More  



What a great trip! We were lucky as the helicopter was at another airport so we got a free ride into the bay for the start of our 30 minute tour. You see the whole city and we even went under and over the golden gate bridge as it was a fine day. What an experience!

A fantastic experience. Flight was 30mins and was fantastic. Great sunny day helps. Pilot knowledgable and informative throughout flight. Was a special treat following our wedding and was worth every penny.
Traffic in San Francisco can be a nightmare so expect pick up and drop off to be a bit off time.

This tour was offered as an extra by our tour guide although he'd not done it himself! As I was in SFO and not knowing if ever I'd come back I thought why not. We were picked up at the Fairmont hotel and driven out to SFO airport which is just the other side of the Golden Gate bridge. Straight...


More  



3 people @ approx $235 each for 30 minutes as a gift. Requested front, got 1 rear middle seat, 1 facing backwards, 1 rear forward facing viewing difficult. Headphones not working, found tangled in seatbelt, but told very little commentary anyway. Left with safety belt not properly secure after staff check. locals know better!

We booked through Viator. Our flight was at 1 pm on Sunday 4th Oct. upon booking I agreed a pick up at the Hilton Hotel in Union Saquare, the email and voucher said the same. But when I confirmed with San Fransisco Helicopter they sant an email confirming they pick us up from Beach Street.
The bus was 15 min...


More  



We decided to try the helicopter tour of San Francisco. The view was absolutely amazing, but the best part was when the pilot announced we were going under the bridge for a different view! Wow! what a feeling! I recommend this tour to everyone!

What a way to see this amazing city. Picked from our hotel and driven out to Base to be boarded in our helicopter for a half hour trip in the safe hands of our excellent pilot and guide. Massive highlight due to the excellent weather was a loop under the golden gate Bridge. Can't recommend enough - might seem expensive...

title: Red and White Fleet, San Francisco
address: Pier 43 1/2, Historic Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
If you are short on time, but want to take in as many attractions as possible, then the 60 minute Golden Gate Bridge cruise is perfect. The boat ride takes you out to the bridge, then around Alcatraz Island while giving you some great back ground stories and information. The $30 price tag is a great bargain. Next time we're...


More  



We were on the last cruise of the day in mid January. For photographers, just know that this means the bridge and area is perfect for photography at that time. We were given individual headsets that you can set to your native language. very helpful and informative. We actually stayed on the front of the boat for most of the...


More  



We did the twilight cruise and WOW the city looks so beautiful at night was well worth it you sail out to the Golden gate bridge then back past Alcatraz which is very very creepy at night then you sail past the city towards and under bay bridge they provide food and entertainment the food was good it was a...


More  



I bought the 1 1/2 boat tour (blue line). Very great price $37.00 per person. We took the last tour of the day. Friendly, clean, and organized. A gentleman on the boat offer to take photos (forgot to get his name). The boat slows down for better view. Headphones and a audio were given for personal tours in English, Thai,...


More  



Less than $40.00 and an hour and a half ferry ride to see the city from a boat in the bay, sign me up again! You literally get to go from GG bridge to the BA bridge, and you'll get to take some remarkable photos. First time CA visitor, my first stop was Fisherman's Wharf, and I had a couple...


More  



We took the Alcatraz tour which did not put us ON the island, but circled around it, with a very interesting narrative. What a great way to spend an hour and a half, learning about the city and the prison and getting some sightseeing done as well. This made our SF GoCard worth it!

We took the Golden Gate Bay Cruise, and we really enjoyed this tour, you get a really close view of Alcatraz (in case you aren't planning to go inside), and they take you under the Golden Gate as well. It's also very informative if you are not familiar with the history of the city. Totally recommend it! (We were able...


More  



The ferry cruise itself was actually good and informative! Too bad the weather was very foggy and rainy at the same time. The crews were very friendly and they helped everyone with taking pictures.
If the weather is good, it is totally recommended to do the bridge-to-bridge cruise!

Took the basic 1-hour cruise from Fisherman's Wharf out under the Bridge and back around Alcatraz. Good audio commentary on headsets (multiple language options included) with interesting background to the history of the area. Recommended for any visit to the city.

Did 1 hour cruise that went under golden gate bridge. View of golden gate from cruise is amazing. I found commentary precise and very informative.

Our guide was Ken. He was very informative, funny,serious, & professional. He was well versed in wines and wine making. Tour groups are small. He gave us a short history lesson of San Francisco and the Napa area. If I could change one thing....I'm not sure what it would be!
Highly recommend this tour and very highly recommend you request...

The tour guide was great and the stops we went on were good.
I was super disappointed that the Muir Woods portion was cancelled 2 days before we got there. It was refunded, but we didn't get to see them and that was the main reason we booked the tour. They DID offer replacement dates, but we weren't able to...


More  



Very friendly staff, driver and our guide Mary were fantastic, everything was as its promised, great tour, lots of interesting historical facts to hear from our kind and nice guide. Small group, excellent atmosphere, I definitely recommend this tour. Only thing that they could improve is a little bit more time for a photo session near Golden Gate bridge. Thanx...


More  



It was a cool winter afternoon, and we had originally booked the Muir Woods tour with downhill hike, but that was cancelled due to bad weather having washed away a bridge! So we took the standard afternoon Muir Woods tour instead, and were really happy with it. Our guide Molly was very pleasant and capable. We did a brief tour...

We did the premium SF tour and were very happy. Long time visitors of SF found neat stuff that we hadn't seen before. The guides were fantastic and the sights were unique. The premium city tour was well done. The tour covered a lot of ground in short time. Short visit times at each stop were good.

Cary was the best guide ever and it was a fabulous day--so much fun!! Weather turned perfect; wine was great!! Everyone should do it and ask for Cary!!

title: Bike & View - Bicycle Rentals and Tours, San Francisco
review_list:
I reserved a bike on the homepage (Bike & View) a few months before I was starting my trip in the USA. My hotel was in the neighborhood (500 meters away). The location is very convenient. The bikes are in good shape. The staff gave me some helpful information and a short introduction before I was starting my roundtrip on...


More  



We spent a day on the bike to discover San Fransisco. Sometimes quite challening, but in general it was very nice. Bike & View personnel was flexible and the bikes were of good quality. Would go again!

I booked Christmas eve, went Christmas day. I didn't have enough cause for the deposit on me, but the team were very helpful. Bike was pretty good quality and gear ratios did the tricks for the hills. Would go again! Definitely need to bike San Fran

My friend and I rented two bikes from Bike & View. The location is very convenient and it is less crowded compared to the Fisherman's Wharf area. The bike path is a few blocks away from the shop and the staffs are very helpful giving us information. The bikes are in good shape with disc brakes and a front pouch...


More  



We thought it might be a nice idea to do the Golden Gate Bridge by bike. Basically it is a good idea, but you should chose the rental agency very carefully.
Bike&View was not what we would choose again! The contract says that you have to pay for every repair, e.g. when there is a problem with the tires. Only...


More  



We took 2 bikes to ride the Golden Gate Bridge. The service from the staff on pick up was great. The staff gave us some great advice and the bikes were great. The shop is in a good location.

Rented 7 bikes for the day. Rode across Golden Gate Bridge to Sausalito, had lunch and a drink or 2, then rode back. Fabulous day out; excellent service from Bike & View. Thanks very much

We have made the reservation one day before over Internet and have get a very good rate. Bicycle are in good condition.

Despite sharing a name you are unable to drop off and pick up at the different locations. When booking in person this is not explained and you end up having to pay an extra $40/bike

Get the best rates and bikes by renting from a place a little off the main stretch (10 min walk from the wharf, 1772 Lombard). Book online and save 30% per bike (final price 23$ for 24h). Includes helmet, lock and small bag. Quality of the bikes was perfect. Hybrid between city bike and mountain bike. Would love to have...

title: 1.5-mile Coastal Trail, San Francisco
review_list:
Raw coastal trail, well maintained and meandering through beautiful old trees, with the coast below and the city in the distance. Really nice and worthwhile outdoor urban experience.

The coastal trail, starting from cliff house a bit north of Golden gate park's western end, is a charming afternoon / sunset trail with beautifull views of the ocean and Golden gate bridge.

title: Alemany Flea Market, San Francisco
review_list:
This place is terrible. Two bubbles is probably being generous. I love flea markets and am fine seeing a mix of junk among some more interesting vintage goods, but this place is all junk, all the time, at every booth. I swear, people are selling stuff that you'd most likely throw out without a second thought. We went here b/c...


More  



This is a farmers market rather than a flea market, at least on Saturday mornings. Dozens of vendors displaying a wide range of fresh and dried fruits, nuts, vegetables (especially for Asian cuisine), flowers, olives, with a few prepared food vendors (pizza, Cali-Mex, cheese, baked goods) in the second row. Worth visiting even if you're not cooking. Parking is tight...


More  



This is the original certified and city-sponsored farmers market. Open only on Saturdays from dawn till about 2:00 pm. It is much larger than the farmers market at United Nations Plaza (which is open Wednesdays and Sunday mornings) and the one at the Ferry Building. All the produce is sold by the actual farmers. There are also a few vendors...


More  



It was a small cute market. Since we weren't planning on cooking a lot we just went for snacks and lunch. There was a lot of fruits and vegetables to pick from. We got Desee el de for lunch, a small food tent. I got the corn quesadillas with chicken and onion and my husband got the flour tortilla with...


More  



If you go to this flea market you will meet a lot of people from SF and very few tourists. I found some nice things, the prices are absolutely fair.
Sundays from 7:00 am to 3.00 pm on a parking - during the week there is a farmers market there.

title: Custom Made Theatre, San Francisco
review_list:
My husband and I have been regular attendees at Custom Made shows. They are always fun, well acted and well produced. Tickets are reasonably priced and the new location, just off Union Square makes it very convenient. There is a bar downstairs and they sell treats and snacks inside the theater.

CustomMade Theatre has moved. Current production"In Love and Warcraft" is well acted, well directed, and very engaging.The Gamer, Evie, lives in the world that someone else built and finds it extremely difficult to leave that world to deal with intimacy.

title: 450 Sutter Building, San Francisco
review_list:
This is one of my favorite San Francisco buildings, because of its history and architecture. Built in 1929, the 26-floor structure was the first West Coast skyscraper designed to withstand an earthquake. Its architect -- Timothy Pflueger -- was inspired by the ancient Mayan culture for the design.
The Art Deco facade displays terra cotta that was restored between 2007...


More  



This tower is used as a medical offices but is famous for its Neo-Mayan Art Deco style.
The building was designed Timothy L Pflueger and has an imposing exterior.

If you are a fan of Art Deco buildings, this would be an interesting stop for you (and you would probably rate it higher than "3"). If you have a general interest in different types of buildings, do drop by if you have the time...the lobby and exterior are worth the quick look.
450 Sutter is a 26-floor, 105 m...

Folks who admire great design and high style will enjoy the lobby of this building. With its gun metal grey and golden hiroglyphs it looks like The Matrix crossed with a Mayan temple. address: The Ferry Building on the Embarcadero, San Francisco, CA 94111
review_list:

title: Chinese Culture Center, San Francisco
address: 750 Kearny Street, Third Floor, San Francisco, CA 94108-1809
review_list:
This little museum takes about an hour to explore and it's very interesting. It's hard to understand San Fran's heritage without learning about the Chinese experience and their influence on San Francisco's development. Probably not great for kids unless there is a tour going on, but otherwise it provides a nice, quiet and informative breather in the midst of site...

Our whole family visited San Francisco for many times, but we only discovered this gem during our recent trip, the Chinese Culture Center's "Heritage Walk", their tour is very flexible with great rate. title: Francis Lefty O'Doul Bridge, San Francisco
review_list:
wow this place is buzzing if you don't fall about laughing I will be surprised they have entertainment around the piano various artists but I must say Frank had us in stiches with his hunour and his song choice he is very good with crowd participation a great night

If one parks in one of the parking lots south of the San Francisco Giants Baseball Stadium (AT & T park), one walks across this bridge that crosses the water to get to the ball park....and then again, one walks over it again to get back to the parking lot.
Its a bridge that crosses the boat canal.
Unless one...


More  



I have crossed this bridge dozens of times and when I saw it listed on trip advisor for San Francisco, I said to myself "what the .... there is no reason for this to be on trip advisor and I should make sure it is appropriately rated."
So I went over there (I love ATT park and I wanted to...


More  



It goes up and down to accommodate sail boat with tall masts. It has no redeeming value esthetically or artistic architechtural distinction what-so-ever. It's a bridge that crosses over a boat canal and why it even appears here as an "attraction" is beyond me.

It's a baseball joint. Lefty O'Doul was with some minor league team and then the Giants, I think. Been awhile since I've been there. There can be a line for the food, but the food is abundant and tastes great. They specialize in sandwiches at a reasonable price. Plus, it is close to all the big name shops.

This small draw bridge is not worth seeing, not worth being listed among San Francisco's attractions. It is next door to AT&T Park, however, so if you're out to see a Giants game, the bridge is right there. If you're obsessed with obscure bridges.

title: Teuscher Chocolates of Switzerland, San Francisco
review_list:
You walk in and your senses come alive with the smell of chocolate. They have great packaging and every day they have a new flavor to try. The lemon, rose, butternut crunch and champagne were wonderful. Great gift ideas.

Stopped in while walking by, so glad we did! The truffles are mouthwatering and delicious. Also tried the dipped orange peel and dipped ginger...... both were fantastic! But my favorite is the honey chocolate; one bite and I died and went to heaven. Had to go back the next day to get more.

review_list:

Previews reviews already mentioned what is is so not much to add but...

title: Cole Valley, San Francisco
address: Cole and Carl Streets, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
If we didn't have a plan to dine at one of the local establishments, I wouldn't say this is a must see place, but nonetheless interesting to walk around in and explore...lots of eateries, young and funky people.

Walked around on a beautiful fall day, had brunch and window shopped and enjoyed the ambiance of Cole Valley. Beautiful architecture and nice shops, bars and restaurants. Muni runs through it so easy access. Wish I lived there!

If 'u ain't one of em' beware. I'm a southerner and am used to a more welcoming attitude and was surprised by the 'airs' put on by the locals in Cole Valley. For a cosmopolitan city they really don't embrace the cultural differences they believe they do.

Cole Valley is a small, discrete neighborhood tucked away between the craziness of the Haight and the staid splendor of Ashbury Heights. title: Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail, San Francisco
review_list:
This was a drive I did by myself as I had a full free day. The trail went through lovely farmlands, many, many winery vineyards, ruins of the Dutton Hotel in an old area called Jolon, Mission Soledad, and Mission San Antonio, ending in Fort Hunter Liggett. Mission San Antonio is the 3rd Mission in California built by Fr. Serra....


More  



Juan Bautista Valentín Alvarado y Vallejo was Governor of Alta California from 1836 to 1837, and 1838 to 1842. He led several exploratory partie. He was a major leader in politics, ranching, and exploration of the area.
To mark his exploration, the trails he explored and traveled are now known as the Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail. It...


More  



There are beautiful views of the city. The trail is clean and well maintained. Very few bugs to bug us, and the terrain in suitable for most abilities.

The "trail" runs along a couple of state highways in my town. One of these highways has sidewalks and the other does not. I wouldn't really call this so much a trail as the site of a historic trail.

South Bay is the area below San Francisco distinguised by, among other places, silicone valley. This box shows a picture of the Golden Gate Bridge take from the Marin Headlands and has nothing at all to do with S.F. What gives?

title: Strawberry Hill, San Francisco

review_list: A relaxing island in the middle of Stow Lake. Relax, picnic, read, meditate, listen to Huntington Falls, visit the small Chinese pavilion, watch the boaters. For a sense of this story through artists' lenses, this gallery is essential....

title: Fillmore Auditorium, San Francisco
review_list:
We go here frequently, lastly to see Patti Smith. The upstairs is full of history, with posters of bands since the 1960s adorning the walls. The sound is much better downstairs and there is no seating, unless you are handicapped or lucky enough to get the few tables upstairs. The beers are limited, though they do offer Prohibition and Lagunitas....


More  



This is a beautiful venue, easily accessible by public transport, and surrounded by restaurants and shopping. It is across the street from Japantown which is also an interesting place to check out before a show.
You are greeted by friendly staff who obviously love their job. The acoustics and overall mood are impressive. The chandeliers, bucket of apples, and free...


More  



We enjoyed a fantastic soul-funk, 3-band concert here. Tickets were well-priced, Sound amazing, the atmosphere and crowd just great. Drinks slightly expensive, but all in all the evening was priceless. 100% recommended for tourists!

I went to see a concert it got cancelled and since I had gotten rid of my ticket after I got in I pretty much lost my money this place had Terrible service I tried to fix the issue I had right when the show got cancelled even an employee who saw my ticket and held it vouched for me...


More  



Came to the Kimbra & Mikky Ekko concert and it's a great place to go to. So much history and great setting. The staff is super friendly, it almost felt like a family establishment.

...played here. And you can visit the Poster Room upstairs to prove it to yourself. Saw the Punch Brothers perform here on a recent Friday; a recent transplant to the Bay Area, this was my first trip to this iconic rock venue. It's great fun, the people are nice and the sound is good.
Nota Bene: The area around Fillmore...


More  



We absolutely love music so got tickets to a show without really knowing the band! If you are into rock music, this is such a legendary venue it has to be seen. There is a poster room upstairs where you can see all the promo from loads of classic gigs - Hendrix, Cream, Tom Petty etc. The band we saw...


More  



The Fillmore Auditorium is not only an intimate, capacity 1000, concert venue; it is a museum reflecting rock shows that began in the mid 1960's. All of the major acts have performed there.
Audio and sight lines are excellent. Beverage and food is available.

Was able to get tickets for a show to this old venue on Oct 23rd. Good venue, much bigger than I expected. Bar service easily accessible down the entire left side. High ceiling with 10 chandeliers. Photos of some of the great acts that have played there in the past. had a great time.

Amazing, historic venue. So many famous bands played here... Great staff, super friendly, nice pours on the cocktails! And Delta Spirit puts on an awesome live show.

Don't waste your time here unless you're on a mission to complete every SF stairway. No views, the houses are okay,...


More  



This is another unique example of San Francisco's wonderful sight seeing magic. Good excercise. Beautiful seanery. The mailman must be in great shape.

Tucked away near the end of Ord St in the Upper Market area, the Vulcan steps have to be among the longest street stairways in the City. It is quite a workout to climb them but well worth it. Good views abound and the houses and gardens along the stairs are quaint and well-maintained. And you feel so good after...

title: Upper Grant Avenue, San Francisco
address: Above Columbus, North Beach, San Francisco, CA 94087
review_list:
As you see the Upper Grant Avenue area, you will see bookstores and a few places to eat. As you proceed south on Grant, you will quickly arrive into the heart of Chinatown. Enjoy!

Plenty of small bars, restaurants, used book stores etc to make your walk interesting. Not too hilly as is the rest of the city.....go south of course. You can walk all the way to China town and on to Market street.

title: Top of Broadway District, San Francisco
address: 250 Columbus Avenue, Suite 207, San Francisco, CA 94133
review_list:
What a difference a couple of years make. So much cleaner, livelier, new restaurants and dance clubs. A great place to get together with friends for the evening. Great places to have a cocktail, have dinner and dance. Will definitely return time and time again.

Lots of cool clubs and restaurants in the area. Fun live music at the Condor club.
Great food at Tomaso's restaurant. Stopped by Larry Flynts Hustler club. Good music, pretty dancers!

Whether you are seeking fine dining, international cuisine, a casual meal or comfort food, drinks with friends, craft exotic cocktails or you want to take a walk on the wild side this district has everything for you.

title: Kong Chow Temple, San Francisco
review_list:
It claims to be one of the oldest temple in US. Temple timing is from 9-4. It's not that big and is on 3rd floor.

We have two temples in San Francisco that claim to be the oldest Chinese temple in the US (the other being the Tin Hau Temple on Waverly). Both seem to cater to the occasional tourist rather than any practicing members of their faith.
For starters --- NO PHOTOS ALLOWED --- in the building or within 100 feet of the building....


More  



You cannot take pictures or video, but this nice little temple is worth a visit if you you can find it.
We visited on Christmas and I am glad we did.

title: Randall Museum, San Francisco
review_list:
We were taken there by relatives, who live in SF, and have a teenage son. Had no clue it was a children's museum. Since I have raised 3 sons and have been to gazillions children's and science museums all over the country, I was disappointed and confused by this choice.
It is cute, somewhat interactive, and free. But even in...


More  



First visit. Large model train lay out, 100 local animals who can't be put out in the wild, Appeared to be lots of classes available for locals.

This is a nice little museum which is free to kids and has some animals, cars and trains. it's not great, but ok - combine it with a walk up the Corona Heights hills and get a spectacular view of the city. I'd normally give this a rating of 3 stars, but with the walk up the hill, it becomes...


More  



If was a way to spend an hour entertaining the kids. Pros - free with a few animals to see! Cons-top of a hill and dirty! Wouldn't bother.

We walked from 20th street & Church. Very steep hills pushing a stroller. Google map was inaccurate resulting in need to back track. Needed hot water for a babies feed. Took at least 30 mins to access some with hungry baby waiting. As its a child's interactive museum such facilities were expected. A coffee/ kitchen bar would help mums.

I found the Randall by way of the now gone SF Free Civic Theatre Companywhich used to perform in the Museum theater.
This small, FREE, natural history museum has lovely grounds, parking and amazing city views. Pack a picnic and come enjoy a meal and some fun for the kids!

address: 1 Ferry Building, Ferry Building Parking Lot, San Francisco, CA 94199
review_list:

title: Dubbelju Motorcycle Rentals, San Francisco
review_list:
We rented 4 BMW GS's in September. Flew in from Western Pennsylvania for 8 days of riding in Northern California.
The Bikes were all in great shape, ready to ride without issues. We shipped our riding gear into Dubbelju and it was waiting for us upon arrival. The staff was great! Helped us with anything we requested. Also helped with...


More  



the best road trip in California is riding a motorcycle from San Francisco. Dubbelju is a small motorcycles rental business with well maintained motorcycles and a friendly staff that will give to you very good tips about small roads to ride in the San francisco region.

Took my first ever road trip down to the Big Sur using a Triumph Bonne hired from these guys in December 2014. Sorry it has taken so long to put up a review here. Great company and terrific trip advice. The bike ran sweetly for the whole trip. Thoroughly recommend them.

Great experience, bikes are well maintained and staff is very helpful. They bend over backwards to make sure you are happy.

Making a trip from Scotland to San Francisco to ride motorcycles with friends who live in the Bay Area is a pretty big deal for me. So it's important that things go well and that the rental company provides a great service.
This has certainly been my experience of renting BMW R1200GS motorcycles on two occasions. Make that two occasions...


More  



I have rented 4 motorcycles from them on 4 different occasions. I have had a great experience in terms of bike selection and advise about roads to take. I have rented anywhere from one day to 4 days and most of the time with some sort of luggage. I can't think of another place in the US with such a...


More  



If you are in the Bay area looking for a motorental, stop looking you've just find it!
I highly recommend this place ! Dubbelju has been a great experience for me! No only for the technical reason, but also an honest and warm welcoming!
I have been renting a Honda Shadow 600 for a week. The motocycle was in perfect...


More  



Had a wonderful talking with Bobby who is the person to help me and he knew all about bikes and was very kind. Rented a motor scooter for in the city and this have more than enough power. You have a great selection of bikes to choose from

Staff is relax, friendly, very professionnal. Motorcycles are great although our flashing lights did not work. If you want to experience San Francisco area in a unique way, motorcycle is the way to go and Dubbelju is where to rent one!

title: Banker's Heart, San Francisco
address: 555 California Street, A.P. Giannini Plaza, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
This used to be the headquarters for Bank of America the plaza has a black granite sculpture. It should not be mistaken for the various hearts dotted in and around the city.

555 California was the headquarters for Bank of America; In the plaza the 200-ton black Swedish granite sculpture "Transcendence" by Masayuki Nagare resembles a liver but is derisively known as the "Banker's Heart".
It was a beautiful sculpture, but cracks are developing; maybe it is sad the Bank of America moved to North Carolina --- who knows.

title: 49 Geary Street Art Galleries, San Francisco
address: 49 Geary St, (between Kearney & Grant Sts), San Francisco, CA 94108
review_list:
This gallery is very warm climate wise, and very hot content wise. I'm not sure of the relation between photographers and penises, but it is quite apparent here. Far too many pictures and sculptures of penises for a family to enjoy. Would not recommend. Other artwork is very overpriced and the staff know nothing of the work.

I bought a photo from 1950s San Francisco from Robert Tat Gallery. There were quite a few very beautiful ones, it was hard to chose. Robert provided excellent commentary.

It's always been our tradition to hit all the photo galleries in SF and with the best ones at 49 Geary Street, we can do that in one trip! Amazing work, amazing artists, amazing galleries! This is a must-see stop in SF!

review_list:

Staff were really friendly though and always happy to help.

review_list:
The Rocketship is gone and has been replaced by another piece of "art" --- what a let down. I asked Parks and Rec where it had gone, but they were unsure (sold; storage....but not moved).

The Raygun Gothic Rocketship is neat, but behind it, you have the Bay Bridge, which now has LED lights (super cool), and the city skyline at another angle. The Rocketship kind of gets drowned out in it's environment. Nevertheless, it's cool to see , but you'll forget it after you go down to the Ferry Building or to the Wharf....

When I first saw this all I could think of was the sci-fi movies of the 1950's that I saw while growing up.
In todays films the kids think the special effects( in new movies) are really something but as a child I thought things like this was amazing!

title: Gold Country, San Francisco
review_list:
We took this drive. It is very scenic.
However, there are no antique stores in LaHood. No trace of gold mines or history as you drive through the area.
I believe to really see the gold country and typical tourist communities you need to go other towns in CA.

Gold Country is an odd entry for San Francisco. People here do like to go to Gold Country - which is where the gold rush occurred in the mid 1800s and thus the name. The most scenic and historic road to drive in the area is known as Highway 49 We have visited Gold Country and driven highway 49 numerous...

review_list:
South Park is a small oval park in an area that contains some small IT and web companies. Its popular place for workers at nearby companies to hang out and eat lunch.
It was easy for us to get there as we stayed nearby.

In San Francisco, EVERYONE owns a dog but no one owns a Pooper-Scooper or plastic bag!!!
When I was little, I excelled at playing HOPSCOTCH ---I now play a newer version of it called DONT-LAND-IN-IT!!! Visit South Park and play this game yourself!!!

More  



The food was stale! The tacos looked like they have been prepared days ahead and my salad looked and tasted way beyond expiration date! The only reason why I'm giving it two stars is because our waitress was pleasant and efficient.

Dined at SFO location late in the day. We ordered quickly as the kitchen was closing soon. My BBQ pork sandwich was okay but hubby's BBQ chicken was tough and stringy. The garlic fries were unedible. The fries appeared old and were refried and tossed on the plate. Very disappointing to be served sub-par food at premium pricing.

Ate at the SFO airport location. My bacon cheeseburger was excellent and served medium rare as requested. His Nibs fish and chips wasnt anything special. However the garlic fries were awesome! The beer, meh. We prefer Canadian micro brews. Service was attentive. Price reasonable for an airport.

This is absolutely the worst beer I have ever had in my life! Stay away! Service is bad as well as the food. Don't waste your time here.

Skip this place. It is one (of only a couple) of options in this area of the airport. My family was hungry and we had less than an hour to boarding time. I appreciated the Gordon biersch at home because the menu complimented my vegetarian diet so I was excited to see there was one at the airport. The downside? No vegetarian options. Enough said. No more airport Gordon Biersch for me!

title: John McLaren Park, San Francisco
address: Mansell Street at Shelley Street, San Francisco, CA
review_list:
Our car window got smashed and luggage and everthing taken so be careful. We were parked near the pond taking our son's dog for a walk.

My husband and I enjoyed walking and birding in the park. We saw many hummingbirds, chestnut-backed chickadees, and pygmy nuthatch there. It's a relaxing and lovely area that's not as crowded as other parts of San Francisco.

McClaren Park was created in 1927. It's named after John McLaren, who among other achievements is known locally as the "grandfather of Golden Gate Park." It's in Visitacion Valley, overlooking Mission St. in the Excelsior, and if you've seen the 80-foot tall blue water tower at its crest, you know which hill is home to the park.

We have been out twice with city kayaks. The equipment and instruction is great. 1st time kayaking but we were in good hands w/Ken & Jemma; they gave excellent instructions on how to, when to and keep a watchful eye on us while on the bay. The place is huge and equipped with all sorts of paths for different levels. I found the paths very interesting and the staff super helpful. We bought there climbing shoes and the guy let us in for free, as a gift. That's nice! Definitely I will go there again.

We took the intro to climbing class and loved it. Our instructor Noah was super patient and a great instructor. We had a blast and would highly recommend.

The place opens daily from early hours. Includes a gym, lots of space. Walls are very well maintained and marked properly. Parking may be an issue at certain times. Bring your own gear, otherwise you can rent.

Great tour, very informative and exciting. Tour guide was an amazing story teller and very captivating. If you have time during your visit this would be one of your favorite...

I brought a group of 13 Girl Scouts from Atlanta GA to San Fran for a week and this was one of the highlights of our trip. This tour takes about two hours and takes you through the Haight district. Taking this tour during the summer, it wasn't really dark, but we had a fabulous time. The guide, the stories, the history, and the architecture make this a very worthwhile adventure. I've always loved this bit of whimsey on the gritty corner of 6th and Harrison. Normally inanimate objets captured in the act of defenestration.
Many may contemplate the act, but only the truly strong clocks, sofas, tvs and chairs attempt it.
